HEADLINE: Small Business Is Overwhelmed By Health Costs

BYLINE: By GLENN KRAMON

 BODY:
Millions of small American businesses that provide health coverage for their employees have been staggered in recent months by insurance rate increases of 20 percent to more than 100 percent.
Many who run these businesses say they can no longer afford insurance. They say they may have to drop their coverage if they cannot find a less expensive policy or transfer more of the cost to employees.
The frustration over rising medical costs is voiced by business owners around the country.
 
Too Expensive
''I've gotten to the point where I either have to give it up or change carriers,'' said Mitchell Black, the owner of a printing business with six employees in East Orange, N.J. ''I am losing a lot of sleep because I just can't afford to pay $5,102 every three months.'' 
The problem is troubling supporters of a growing effort in Congress and in some states to require all businesses with more than a few employees to provide for health coverage. More than 30 million Americans, many of whom hold jobs, have no health insurance.
What is more, representatives of business organizations say the sharp rises in health insurance costs could chill growth in the sector of the economy that has provided many new jobs in recent years. The 3.8 million businesses with fewer than 500 employees account for 53 percent of the American work force, and they have created nearly two of three new jobs in the past six years, according to the Small Business Administration.
 
'It's Real Serious'
''When you realize the economic development implications, it's real serious,'' said Francis M. Miller, president of the Colorado Business Coalition for Health, a Denver-based employers' group. ''And it's creating larger and larger pools of uninsured people as more small businesses give up on health insurance.''
Small businesses are not alone in facing higher medical costs. Increases for businesses of all sizes are averaging 20 to 30 percent this year, up from 15 to 25 percent last year, recent surveys have found. The reasons for the increases include sharp medical inflation, the rising use of expensive treatments, the need to cover the cost of care for the uninsured and those under government medical programs that have limited what they will pay.
But there is wide agreement that the cost increases have been even greater for many small businesses, as well as for the small minority of Americans who buy their insurance on their own.
Among the main reasons is that insurance carriers are moving away from the past practice of assigning the same rate to all policy holders in a community.
''The concept of group insurance is beginning to fall apart, at least for small businesses,'' said Robert Hunter, president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization, a consumer group in Alexandria, Va.
A new survey by the National Federation of Independent Business, a group in San Mateo, Calif., that represents 570,000 businesses averaging 13 employees, found that increases in health insurance premiums for its members ranged from 20 to 200 percent this year. Managers at insurance companies agreed that premiums had been sharply rising this year and said many increases were 20 to 35 percent.
Annual insurance premiums for small businesses now range from less than $1,000 an employee to almost $10,000, depending on age, region, family members and other factors, industry people say.
Carolynn Miller, the group's legislative representative, said 90 percent of the businesses say it is becoming ''prohibitively expensive to provide health insurance.''
Indeed, the survey found that the percentage of members offering health insurance has leveled off at about two-thirds or even declined slightly since 1986, after growing between 1978 and 1986.
 
Increase of 74%
Mr. Black, who started his printing business 20 years ago and began offering health insurance 14 years ago, said his rates under Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey rose 74 percent in July. His rates have almost tripled, from $1,811, in just over three years, and he is now looking for another insurer.
Ray Morgan, who runs a waste-hauling business with seven employees in Algona, Iowa, said he recently switched insurers for the second time in a year to avoid increases of 83 percent in 11 months, to $2,685 a month from $1,471. The first carrier was the Principal Financial Group in Des Moines, and the second was Connecticut General Life.
Mr. Morgan found a policy under Blue Cross and Blue Shield that is only 11 percent more expensive than his previous policy. But he added, ''Through the ordeal I've become somewhat cynical, and I expect to see the cost of this policy go up too.''
 
'Tremendously Big Check'
A popular restaurant in San Francisco, Perry's, was forced to switch carriers a year ago when its previous insurer proposed an increase of almost 50 percent for its 50 full-time employees, said the restaurant's owner, Perry Butler. He said he recognizes ''the positives that medicine has brought us,'' but added, ''It's a tremendously big check that you hate to write.'' As in many businesses, his employees now pay part of the premium.
Business and insurance people cite several reasons that rates have risen faster for many small businesses.
''Government programs like Medicare have set limits on what they will pay for various medical treatments, and the largest companies can negotiate their own deals,'' Mr. Miller said. ''The doctors and hospitals then shift costs to the small consumer - to small companies and individuals.''
Also, many small businesses have not yet begun the cost-containment measures now used by larger businesses, like health maintenance organizations and reviews to eliminate unnecessary tests, operations and days in the hospital, said Dr. Jules H. Lichtenstein of the Small Business Administration.
 
Different Rates
Another factor is that instead of basing their rates on the claims experience of a large number of people and offering everyone one price, many insurers will now establish rates based on factors including the age, sex, geographical location and line of work of the group, said Richard W. Hill, a vice president and actuary at the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Insurers in some places also establish further categories that partly reflect the business's actual claims experience.
As a result, a costly illness by one person in a small business could in some cases affect the company's rates far more dramatically than at a big company, insurance experts said.
 
Excluding Risks
Also, insurers that once routinely accepted new accounts have begun to make the decision more carefully, requiring each applicant in a very small business to fill out a medical history. High-risk candidates can then be excluded, or coverage for certain existing medical conditions can be waived, or premiums can be increased.
''You don't have the type of shared-risk environment you had before,'' said Maureen E. Sullivan, director of business strategy consulting at the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association. She said most Blue Cross/Blue Shield plans have spread the cost across as many people as possible but that smaller insurers were fragmenting the market by signing up only healthy people.
Health costs for many small businesses are also rising faster than those for big ones because of a difference in the way they are insured.
 
Self-Financing
Most larger businesses finance their own insurance and are exempt from state regulations that govern the insurance carriers used by most small businesses. In some states, such regulations require health plans to include specific benefits that unregulated companies might not, like coverage for in-vitro fertilization in a few states and mental health care in many. Such regulations raise the cost of coverage - by 20 percent in some states, according to Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Some companies then decide not to offer even basic coverage.
Also, most insurance carriers last year had underwriting losses equal to about 4 to 5 percent of their revenue, and are now trying to recoup those losses through prices that are even higher than the increase of 15 to 25 percent expected for health care expenditures this year, said Steven G. Auerbach, an associate consultant at Blue Cross/Blue Shield.
Finally, smaller businesses pay higher administrative costs, 15 to 40 percent of the total cost of the premium, compared with about 5 percent for the largest businesses, said Jack Needleman, vice president at Lewin/ICF, a Washington health-policy consulting firm.
In confronting their high costs, small businesses are trying various tacks. Some are forming bigger groups with more power in purchasing medical coverage.
 
Forming an Alliance
In the Denver area, for example, small companies are participating in the Colorado Health-Care Purchasing Alliance. The alliance has contracted with doctors and hospitals for the lower prices that only large companies typically enjoy.
Prudential and Blue Cross/Blue Shield plans around the country have begun to offer networks of doctors and hospitals to small businesses.
Other small businesses are slowing the increase of their costs simply by asking employees to contribute more for their health care.
But the Federation of Independent Business is seeking other changes, including exemption from state regulations so that insurance carriers can offer no-frills plans to small businesses.
The group is also seeking to increase to 100 percent the tax deduction of the cost of health insurance for self-employed business owners. The deduction is now 25 percent, compared with 100 percent for incorporated businesses.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
'Class War' Pitch Now Fails, Democrats Find in Tax Defeat

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The Democratic defeat on the capital gains tax in the House of Representatives this week is raising new questions on Capitol Hill about the party's message, the strength of its leadership and its ability to hold the line against a popular President.
Within the party, it has fueled debate over the wisdom of an appeal to voters that relies on economic classes. The Democratic leadership fought against cutting the top tax rate on capital gains, an important proposal of President Bush's, as ''a tax cut for the super-rich,'' a gift paid for by the middle class.
In the aftermath of the Democrats' 239-to-190 defeat, that approach, a staple of the Democratic Party and reminiscent of the unsuccessful 1988 Presidential campaign of Richard A. Gephardt, now the House majority leader, is drawing criticism on both sides of the aisle. 
 
New Republican Possibilities
''The thing I think our party has missed is that the American people do not buy in, in any fundamental way, to a class warfare political argument,'' said Representative Les AuCoin, Democrat of Oregon, who voted with his party's leadership. ''The American people, at this point of our history, are looking for leadership that argues for economic growth strategies.''
The debate over tactics and message is only part of the fallout from the capital gains vote. Sixty-four Democrats defected from their leadership for a broad range of reasons, an amalgam of local concerns, personal loyalties and regional ties. But the sheer size of the defection has given the Bush Administration and the Republican Party a sense of new possibilities in the House, a Democratic bastion for 35 years and a place where Republican Presidents must build coalitions to prevail.
It has also clearly wounded the new Democratic leadership team, including Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House, who drew a line in the sand that he could not defend.
 
Sharp-Edged Message
''It pushes Bush very much into the driver's seat on economic issues now,'' said Representative Mickey Edwards of Oklahoma, chairman of the Republican Policy Committee. ''It means he sits down at a bargaining table confident that on most major issues he's going to deliver all the House Republicans and Foley has no idea what he can deliver.''
In framing the debate on the capital gains measure, which is part of a huge budget bill that still needs approval from the House and the Senate, Representative Gephardt, from Missouri, presented a sharp-edged message that pitted the limousine set against the middle class, ''the super-rich'' against the first-time home buyer.
It was the kind of populist appeal that prompted Republicans to assert that the Democrats were ''campaigning to an America that existed 40 years ago,'' as Mr. Edwards put it.
But the criticism was not confined to Republicans. Representative Ben Jones, a Georgia Democrat who voted against the Democratic leadership, declared, ''The party I know and love and have worked for is not interested in class warfare cliches.'' Representative Ed Jenkins, the Georgia Democrat who led the drive for a capital gains reduction, said, ''I don't think that plays anymore.''
 
Portrayal of Tax Increase
Mr. Gephardt countered, ''To the extent there was a pointing out that this proposal for capital gains had an uneven, unfair economic aspect to it, it came out of the truth of the matter.'' Mr. Gephardt added that the Democratic leadership ''needed more time'' to get the full message across on its tax package, which included components like individual retirement account benefits for the middle class and a fund for reduction of the Federal budget deficit.
Some Democrats also worried that their party's package was being portrayed by Republicans as a simple tax increase, even though the increase it proposed would apply only to the 600,000 highest-income taxpayers.
And some Democrats remained troubled that in their biggest economic clash with the Bush Administration, the party had resorted to a traditional appeal that left it open to Republican charges that it was being divisive and backward-looking.
The extent of Democratic defections has led to comparisons with 1981, when the Reagan Administration forged an alliance with the Southern conservatives known as Boll Weevils to enact its economic agenda. But politicians from both parties said the capital gains vote was different.
Rather than a hard and lasting ideological cleavage, they said, the Democratic crossovers represented a mixture of political, regional and personal factors. The concerns of the timber industry played a role, for example, and so did longstanding commitments to Representative Jenkins, the architect of the measure, and the five other Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee who supported it.
 
A Shifting Coalition
''The people who came together were drawn from such a wide range of intersts and philosophies,'' said Mr. Edwards, that many ''are not going to be with us like the Boll Weevils of '81. It more signals a shifting coalition.''
Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, agreed, arguing that a coalition for Mr. Bush's programs in the House would not be a true conservative coalition but would have ''slightly different allies depending on the topic.''
Representative Jenkins argued that Congress is in an era in which ''we'll see more of a bipartisan approach than we've seen in the past'' on an issue-by-issue basis. He said, ''This President is not an ideologue.''
The Democratic leadership dismisses the notion of any lingering coalition emerging from the capital gains vote. But the precedent of Democrats' resisting their party's position and working with the Administration on such a high-stakes partisan issue is clearly ominous for the new leadership team, which took control only a few months ago. There was some talk in Democratic circles this week that the new leadership, which received much early praise for Mr. Foley's conciliation skills, could nevertheless use a shrewder, street-fighting edge.
Democratic leaders and their allies say they have lost a vote but gained a campaign issue that they will use against Mr. Bush in future elections. ''Losing is never winning,'' said Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, chairman of the House Democratic caucus. ''But nor is losing, per se, disarray. I think we got into the issue late. There was a very strong sentiment and the White House worked it very hard.''
Mr. Hoyer noted that Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker during most of the Reagan Administration, was widely criticized in 1981 for not controlling Democrats in the face of Mr. Reagan's legislative onslaught. He added that Mr. O'Neill was ultimately ''viewed as one of the most effective Speakers we ever had.''

HEADLINE: Another Colombian Crop Takes Off: Flowers

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EL ROSAL, Colombia

 BODY:
In the high Andean plains here, Reynaldo Garcia Navas lives in a world bounded by Thanksgiving, Valentine's Day and Secretary's Day.
''This carnation was cut 10 minutes ago,'' Mr. Garcia said, selecting a bright red flower in the cold storage area of his flower farm. ''Tomorrow, it will be in Miami. The day after, in a local florist.'' 
Coaxing Colombian flowers to bloom according to American holidays is part of a booming new export business.
In the last 20 years, Colombia's exports of fresh cut flowers have soared, from virtually nothing in 1969 to an expected $250 million this year, making it the nation's fifth largest export.
Today, Colombia is the second largest flower exporter in the world after the Netherlands.
The flower industry has taken hold in the high, sunny plateaus outside of Colombia's two largest cities, Bogota and Medellin. In a boon to areas with high unemployment, the labor-intensive industry now directly employs 70,000 people and gives indirect employment to 30,000 more.
In the year-round springlike climate here, millions of roses, carnations and chrysanthemums bloom under tented plastic.
With the eyes of the United States now focused on Colombia because of the Government's war with cocaine traffickers, Jorge Enrique Uribe Salazar, president of the Colombian Association of Flower Exporters, hopes to win tariff concessions for Colombian flowers.
Mr. Uribe's target is a 4.4 percent duty on American imports of Colombia flowers. The tariff was imposed five years ago in response to American flower growers who complained that the Colombians were dumping, or selling at below market prices. The Colombians admit that in July and August they are often forced to sell to brokers in Miami for prices that are below production costs. American flower prices traditionally are low at that time of year for a variety of reasons: there are few weddings, many people are on vacation and there are no major holidays associated with flower giving.
''Obviously, I don't want to sell below cost,'' said Mr. Garcia, general manager of Colibri Flowers. ''But flowers grow all year round and they are perishable. I have to sell them.''
To appease the Americans, Colombian growers say they have ended a series of Government subsidies - tax breaks, duty-free imports of agricultural implements and bank loans extended at below market rates.
American officials here do not seem to be moved by Colombia's complaints of protectionism. ''Don't look at the lawsuits, don't look at the arguments,'' said an official at the American Embassy here. ''Look at the final figures, look at the enormous gains for Colombian flowers in the United States.''
The American official noted that Colombia's flower exports to the United States this year are expected to be 20 percent higher than last year's level. #15 Cows or 1.6 Million Flowers But, production here is expanding as more and more ranchers discover that the acreage that supports 15 cows will also support 1.6 million flowers. Several industry analysts say the Colombians should explore new markets.
Japan would be a natural market, but exporters here say they are handicapped by poor airline connections and by Japanese protectionism.
''Japanese prices are so high that Colombian flowers would be very attractive,'' said Mr. Uribe. ''But they have a very high level of protection. There are no duties, but when the flowers arrive at Narita Airport, they are inspected one by one.''
Another solution is to induce Americans to buy more flowers. Americans buy only $15 worth of flowers a person each year. Europeans buy between $35 and $65 worth of flowers a person.
''I compare flowers to wine,'' said Mr. Uribe, warming to the idea of a joint Colombian-American effort to promote flower consumption in the United States. ''Twenty years ago, Americans really didn't drink wine. Now you have flowers entering America's mainstream - they are sold in supermarkets and chain stores.''

HEADLINE: In Brazilian Race, a Communist Stands Out

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Flipping through Brazilian television channels one recent evening, viewers had the choice of a comedy, ''Cockroach Cabaret,'' an action show, ''Tank Commando,'' or a one-hour interview with Roberto Freire, one of 28 minor-party candidates for President.
The next morning, pollsters discovered that the highest audience share, 23 percent, went to Mr. Freire, a congressman who is the first Communist presidential candidate in Brazil since 1945.
Despite the engaging smile and commanding voice that helped him attract the television ratings, Mr. Freire, a 47-year-old lawyer, is given virtually no chance of winning the election here on Nov. 15. 
Although the race is far from decided, the current front-runner, Fernando Collor de Mello, a centrist former Governor, has scored 39 to 45 percent in public opinion polls since May.
Mr. Freire's candidacy highlights the wide range of electoral diversity in Brazil, the world's third most populous democracy after India and the United States.
The country was ruled by generals from 1964 to 1985, and to justify dominating politics for two decades the military frequently cited the need to purge Brazil of Communism.
Forced underground, the Communist Party splintered. Several factions took up arms against the military Government, and hundreds of Communist militants were arrested and tortured. Dozens were killed. Democracy Embraced Today, the Communists are above ground, opening campaign headquarters and chasing after voters under the slogan, ''With Democracy to Socialism.''
One day, the heavyset Mr. Freire is filmed puffing around a soccer field, pursuing Brazil's national pastime with a team of Rio intellectuals. Another day, he is in Recife, leading a campaign parade of dune buggies down a beach-front avenue. Another night, he is sipping beer at a college campus fund-raiser.
''For years, we let our adversaries define us,'' Mr. Freire said this week while resting on a couch at a private residence here. ''Brazilian society is still deeply prejudiced against Communism.''
Brazilians are cautiously welcoming the Communists back. Most of Brazil's 80 million voters came of age under military rule. In recent weeks, many undoubtedly have been startled to see Mr. Freire cordially received by Sao Paulo industrialists, Roman Catholic archbishops and Roberto Marinho, the conservative president of the powerful Globo television network.
Wrapping controversial opinions in a congenial demeanor, Mr. Freire has won wide press coverage disproportionate for his low rating in the opinion polls.
 
Atheism Explained
In a campaign where candidates seek not to offend, Mr. Freire never shrinks from stating his positions: legalization of abortion; a moratorium on repaying Brazil's debt of $120 billion owed to foreign bankers; big investment in education and health and distribution of unproductive farmland to landless peasants.
Asked which line in his campaign speech draws the most applause, Mr. Freire replied readily, ''Brazil is the eighth-largest market economy in the world, but it ranks below 50th in living standards.''
In a country with the largest population of Roman Catholics in the world, the Communist candidate spends much time explaining his atheism.
''The great mass of Brazilian society calls itself Christian,'' the candidate said on a recent radio talk show. ''Nevertheless the society is perverse and spawns crying social injustices.''
Press reports often mention his church wedding to Leticia Baltar and that his wife attends Sunday Mass regularly.
When interviewers persist on the religion issue, he likes to cite Pedro Casaldaliga, a left-leaning Roman Catholic bishop, who said recently, ''It's preferable that an atheist like Roberto Freire become President than a corrupt Catholic.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TICKER: GBO (LSE) (51%);

HEADLINE: Alaska Oil Fund's Dividend Is Second Largest

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: JUNEAU, Alaska, Sept. 30

 BODY:
This year, when thousands of people in Alaska felt the effects of the nation's largest oil spill, the state's residents will receive their second largest annual check from Alaska's oil wealth savings account.
This year's dividend from the $10.5 billion Alaska Permanent Fund will total $873.16 for each resident, state officials announced on Thursday. That is more than $46 over what was paid last year. 
Checks will be mailed beginning Oct. 9, more than six months after the tanker Exxon Valdez went aground in Prince William Sound and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of oil.
Voters created the trust fund in 1976 to save a portion of the state's oil revenue. The idea was to make sure the state would benefit from its oil wealth long after the oil was gone.
 
Residency Requirements
Since 1982, a portion of the fund's earnings has been given each year to every Alaska resident who meets the residency requirements, regardless of age or income. To qualify as a resident, a person must live in the state from October of the previous year through March.
The largest check, $1,000 for each resident, was given out the first year. The amount being given out this year is the largest since then.
''For many families, the annual dividend distribution is anticipated as a welcome and necessary part of their annual income,'' Hugh Malone, the Alaska Revenue Commissioner, said in announcing this year's dividend The state estimated that 517,693 people were eligible this year to receive the dividend. The fund's earnings in the year ended June 30 totaled $868 million, up from $789 million in the previous fiscal year. Of that, $452 million was made available for dividends.
The fund's principal cannot be spent. The portion of the earnings not used for dividends is used to protect the principal from inflation and to raise the earnings reserve account.

HEADLINE: Cutting Capital Gains Tax: New York Boon and Burden

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
A boon to the wealthiest New Yorkers and a burden on local governments already struggling with severely diminished Federal support was one scenario sketched by executives and public officials last week as they assessed the possible effect in New York City if the capital gains tax rate is reduced.
At the heart of the debate over whether the measure would help or harm the city - or even make a difference - is the question of how much it would stimulate the economy and offset a drop in Federal tax revenues.
As passed Thursday by the House of Representatives, the top tax rate on capital gains - primarily from the sale of stocks - would be reduced to 19.6 percent, from 33 percent, through the end of 1991. The reduction will now be considered by the Senate. 
Every Democratic member of New York City's delegation - except Robert Garcia of the Bronx, who is a defendant in a Federal bribery trial -voted against the tax rate reduction. The two Republican Congressmen from the city voted to approve it.
The Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation estimated that 60 percent of the benefits from such a cut would go to taxpayers earning more than $200,000.
 
View From City Hall
Citing that figure, Deputy Mayor Stanley E. Grayson, who oversees finance and economic development from City Hall, said: ''I'm not sure, in an environment where economic growth has slowed, that capital gains affecting, in large part, people with incomes over $200,000, will serve to reverse the direction things are going - i.e., slower growth. I just don't believe that.
''The end result will be that state and local governments will have to do more because the Federal Government will have less,'' Mr. Grayson said. ''And I think that is a very real concern.''
''The offsetting benefits derived from lowering capital gains are certainly not immediate and, at best, in the long term. And I think the effects of the lowering of capital gains on cities and states will be a lot more immediate.''
But Craig M. Hatkoff, a managing partner of the Victor Capital Group, which deals in commercial real estate and real-estate investment, said, ''It's clear that when people feel richer, they tend to spend more.''
''Any time there is a tax cut, it is good for the psychology,'' he said. ''It will be a bit of a boost for the securities industry, but given the predominance of the institutional investor, it will not have much of an impact.''
 
No Opposition by City
''To the extent it helps the securities industry,'' Mr. Hatkoff said, ''it has a ripple effect in New York, helping law firms and accounting firms. It could help the downtown real-estate market, which is soft. But I don't want to overstate the effect. I don't think it will be very dramatic for commercial real estate.''
The city did not formally oppose the measure on Capitol Hill but did make its concerns known, said Judy L. Chesser, New York City's chief lobbyist in Washington. ''There are estimates that the capital gains tax cut is a $21 billion loss to the treasury over nine years,'' she said.
''State and local governments have already lost roughly one-third of the Federal money they got at the beginning of the 1980's,'' Ms. Chesser said, ''and this puts on pressure to cut them even deeper. We can't afford to take further cuts.''
There seems to be agreement that the measure, if passed, would stimulate a surge in sales of assets before 1992 to take advantage of the lower rates. An earlier surge occurred three years ago, as the rates were about to go up.
In New York State in 1985, for example, the amount of net taxable capital gains was $16.1 billion, according to the office of State Comptroller Edward V. Regan. In 1986, just before the rates rose, capital gains soared to $31.5 billion. In 1987, after the increase, they plummeted to $14.1 billion.
 
'An Incredible Distortion'
''Our people feel that it's conceivable that the same scenario would occur,'' said Marvin Nailor, press secretary to Mr. Regan. ''This is a very, very tricky area. That's why we cautioned about it last year and the year before, in terms of relying on capital gains as a predictable revenue.''
It is not just the loss of money that bothers the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. ''This is going to result in wild swings in revenue for the states from year to year,'' said Charles Loveless, associate director of the union's legislation department. ''This is going to result in an incredible distortion of economic behavior.''
But not everyone is alarmed by the prospect of a surge.
''Wall Street is tied to transaction turnover, and this should stimulate that,'' said David Bostian, president of Bostian Research Associates, an economic consulting firm. ''It probably is a positive for Wall Street, and the financial-services industry is significantly tied to the overall economy of the New York area. But it isn't a massive thing.''
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, said, ''It will have a one-shot effect on loosening up people who have been sitting on assets.''
''People may be more disposed to shift to other assets,'' he said. ''That will mean more volume, so it will have a stimulating effect on the activity in the markets, and the markets are tied into the New York economy. So it will have a positive effect on New York, but it is a quite minor plus.''
Mr. Ehrenhalt, however, shared the concern of local officials and said, ''If this leads to a tightening of the budget situation, and therefore to cuts in Federal expenditures, then it may have a negative effect.''
Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Democrat who represents Harlem, voted against the tax reduction. Mr. Rangel ''agreed with those who said the benefits were heavily skewed toward the wealthy,'' said an aide who asked not to be identified, and he was ''not convinced that changing the rate will considerably improve the economy.''
Mr. Rangel's aide added, ''It's sure not going to make a lot of difference at 125th and Seventh.''

HEADLINE: High-Stakes Strike Looms for Hospitals

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

 BODY:
Pinning its fortunes to a sharp escalation of a long-simmering contract dispute, the state's largest hospital workers union is preparing for a high-stakes strike Wednesday against most of the New York City area's private hospitals and nursing homes.
Public health experts, union leaders and analysts of organized labor say the outcome of the threatened strike, by roughly 50,000 members of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Workers, will determine for the near future the cohesiveness and influence of one of the largest, most dynamic and, recently, one of the most troubled labor unions in the city.
Weighing in the balance as well, these observers say, are the economic fortunes of a hospital industry experiencing serious financial difficulties and personnel shortages made worse by growing numbers of poor and uninsured patients and by AIDS and crack.
 
Last Strike in '84
The last prolonged hospital strike by the 100,000-member union, a 47-day walkout in 1984, created havoc in the hospitals and hurt them financially. But that strike's failure to secure the workers' wage demands was seen as a bitter defeat for the union and led to the rank and file's jettisoning of its leadership. 
During months of negotiations, the union has held out for terms similar to the two-year pact reached last June with four private hospitals run by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York providing for annual salary increases of 8.5 percent.
The League of Voluntary Hospitals, which represents most of the city's other private hospitals, has consistently answered that its members cannot afford such an increase at a time of mounting deficits in many institutions and uncertainties over the future of the state-designed hospital reimbursement system that largely determines revenues for all health-care providers.
 
Shortage of Workers
The League has offered a 4.5 percent salary increase with a one-time signing bonus of $500 for the workers, whose weekly wages are typically in the range of $300 to $400.
The union has argued that without larger wage increases hospitals will continue to suffer shortages of its member workers, like nurses aides, laboratory and X-ray technicians, social workers and orderlies.
Friday evening, North General Hospital in Harlem broke with the hospital league, reaching a tentative agreement providing essentially the same terms as the Catholic hospitals.
North General is the third of the 54 hospitals represented by the League to choose the cost of such a pact over a strike's disruption of services.
 
Stepping Up the Pressure
Since its old contract expired on June 30, Local 1199 has carried out a carefully measured policy of gradually increasing pressure on the hospitals.
An array of politicians, including much of the New York City Congressional delegation and local officials like David N. Dinkins, the Democratic mayoral candidate and Manhattan Borough President; Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President; Borough Presidents Claire Shulman of Queens and Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx; much of the City Council, and numerous members of the State Assembly have repeatedly turned out for breakfasts and rallies to show their support.
 
Short of Benefits
Over the summer the union conducted three short-term walkouts, meant to gradually raise the discomfort level of the hospitals while focusing public attention on the impasse.
But faced with the imminent collapse of their benefit fund, which has been depleted in the absence of a contract, union officials say that they have been forced, with some trepidation, to resort to an open-ended hospital strike against close to 60 hospitals and nursing homes.
Union leaders and public health experts say that one of the union's concerns - that a strike could derail Mr. Dinkins's campaign - has ebbed as recent polls have shown Mr. Dinkins with a sizable lead over his Republican opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani.
 
'A Scary Prospect'
''All of the political muscle in the world did not move these guys,'' Barbara Caress, a senior adviser to the Local 1199 president, Dennis Rivera, said, referring to the League.''Now we come down to the big one - a strike -and it's a scary prospect.''
''A strike is like the economic equivalent of warfare,'' said Victor Gotbaum, the former union leader who is Samuel Gompers professor of labor-management relations at the City University Graduate Center. ''At this point nobody can really want a strike, and no one can predict the outcome, but it looks like one is pretty likely right now.''
Until the landslide election of Mr. Rivera earlier this year, Local 1199 had been for years a divided and dormant force on the local labor and political scenes, crippled by its past failures.
 
A Career on the Line
If the coming strike drags on, many say, mounting salary losses could again sharply divide members, leading them to question the leadership's tactics. And outright failure could blight the career of Mr. Rivera, seen by many as the bright and ambitious rising star of New York labor.
William J. Abelow, president of the League of Voluntary Hospitals, minimized the pressure a strike would place on his members. ''While it may create a crisis, it won't produce a settlement,'' he said.
Mr. Abelow said the hospitals were prepared to cope with the strike, but called the union's plans to strike the New York Blood Center, whose contract with Local 1199 has also expired, ''potentially threatening to patient lives,'' and ''irresponsible.''
But others who are privy to the debate among hospital administrators say there is a growing, althouth still minority, sentiment in favor of a settlement similar to the Catholic hospitals' contract to avoid a costly disruption of services.
 
Lengthening Patient Stays
By robbing hospitals of experienced workers, a strike would inevitably increase the length of time the average patient would remain hospitalized. Since the state's reimbursement system pays hospitals on the basis of patient diagnoses, not according to their length of stay, delays in discharging patients would mean great losses in revenues.
Coping with a strike would also cause hospitals to cancel most elective or discretionary procedures - which are generally the most lucrative.
Many explain the League's reluctance to match the Catholic settlement as a product of its unease over current state efforts to redesign or alter the medical reimbursement system.
''For the hospitals, the strike threat is only one factor in a scene filled with uncertainty,'' said Robert D. Gumbs, executive director of the New York City Health Systems Agency, a public planning group.
Mr. Gumbs said that while several members of the hospital league are tempted to settle for essentially the same contract terms accepted by the Catholic hospitals, many others, especially the city's large and influential academic medical centers, feel they face too many financial unknowns to agree to anything more than modest wage increases.
For a settlement to be reached, Mr. Gumbs said, ''the union is going to have to be flexible, but the providers are going to have to do something more and so will the state.''

HEADLINE: Virgil Thomson, Composer, Critic and Collaborator With Stein, Dies at 92

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
Virgil Thomson, whose homespun, subtly sophisticated compositions and witty but trenchant criticism made him a central figure in American intellectual life for 55 years, died early yesterday in his suite at the Chelsea Hotel in Manhattan. He was 92 years old, and his health had been in decline for several months.
As a composer, Mr. Thomson is best known for two operas to texts written by his longtime friend Gertrude Stein: ''Four Saints in Three Acts'' (1934), which earned him a distinction among intellectuals that he never relinquished, and ''The Mother of Us All'' (1947). He also received a Pulitzer Prize - the only one ever awarded for a film score - for his music for ''Louisiana Story'' in 1948.
Mr. Thomson began sending music reports from Paris to The Boston Evening Transcript in 1921, and continued writing through the 1920's and 30's for journals like Modern Music. His ''State of Music,'' a lively but incisive overview of the musical scene, was published in 1939, and he continued his observations until very recently: his ''Music with Words: A Composer's View,'' is scheduled for publication this month by Yale University Press. 
But the bulk of his journalism came as chief music critic of The New York Herald Tribune from 1940 to 1954. His prose - ''sassy but classy,'' he called it - breathed a mastery of American prose style and a spunkily opinionated expertise that set Mr. Thomson apart from his critical peers.
 
Magnetic Force, Twinkling Eyes
Beyond his work, Mr. Thomson was a magnetic force within the social world of American intellectuals, with his sharp tongue, twinkling eyes and owlish face and figure. His dinner parties at the Chelsea Hotel were the stuff of legend. He seemed, up to the very end, to know everyone in the worlds of music, art, dance and letters.
''The death of Virgil T is a like the death of an American city: it is intolerable,'' said Leonard Bernstein. ''Virgil was loving and harsh, generous and mordant, simple but cynical, son of the hymnal yet highly sophisticated. He will always remain brightly alive in the history of music, if only for the extraordinary influence his witty and simplistic music had on his colleagues. I know that I am one twig on that tree, and I will always cherish and revere Virgil, the source.''
 
'Gift for Cracking Square Center'
Ned Rorem, the composer and a friend of Mr. Thomson's, said yesterday, ''I learned as much from him about being a professional musician as from anyone else.
''Using Virgil Thomson as an absolute, only three or four critics come up to par,'' he added. ''They may share Thomson's perception and even exceed his scope, but none boasts his unquenchable panache - his gift for cracking square center with that perfect little Faberge hammer.''
Betty Allen, a soprano who sang Mr. Thomson's music from the early 1950's and who now runs the Harlem School of the Arts, said: ''He was an intellectual, but his music wasn't pretentious. He had great ideas on the linkage between music and the English language, and the rhythm of it, and he was concerned about people and their lives.''
Virgil Garnett Thomson was born in Kansas City, Mo., on Nov. 25, 1896. He had his first piano lessons at age 5 from a cousin, Lela Garnett. He had enjoyed making music before any schooling. ''I improvised,'' he related in his autobiography, ''with flat hands and the full arm, always with the pedal down and always loud, bathing in musical sound at its most intense, naming my creations after the Chicago fire and similar events.''
From the age of 12, he received formal piano instruction from a succession of teachers, and also served as substitute organist at Calvary Baptist Church, which the Thomson family attended, and other Kansas City churches.
 
No Gift for Fiction
At Central High School in Kansas City, Mr. Thomson honed his writing skills, but soon decided that he had no gift for poetry and fiction, preferring either expository prose or the setting of words to music.
''I can describe things and persons, narrate facts, '' he later wrote. ''But I do not assemble my pictures and my people into situations where they take on memorability, which is what storytellers do. Nor can I make a language change its sound or words their meaning, which is the faculty of poets. Language, to me, is merely for telling the truth about something.''
By the time Mr. Thomson finished high school, World War I had begun, and he enlisted in the National Guard, studying radiotelephony at Columbia University and aviation at the University of Texas. He received overseas orders in September 1918, but the Armistice was signed on Nov. 11 before his troopship embarked for France.
Instead, in 1919, Mr. Thomson entered Harvard College. There his three most influential teachers were Archibald T. Davison, the French-trained conductor of the Harvard Glee Club; Edward Burlingame Hill, also French-trained, with whom he studied music history and orchestration, and S. Foster Damon, a poet, Blake scholar and composer.
 
Studied With Nadia Boulanger
''I remember him bringing me music and books he thought I ought to know,'' Mr. Thomson said of Damon. ''Some of these I found merely informative or charming. Others changed my life. Among these last were the piano works of Erik Satie, a pile of them four inches high, and a thin small volume called 'Tender Buttons' by Gertrude Stein.''
Harvard had a profound impact on his life. Satie influenced Mr. Thomson's music more than any other composer, and Stein became his most important collaborator, helping shape his musical prosody.
In 1921, after a tour of Europe with the Harvard Glee Club, Mr. Thomson remained in Paris for a year on a John Knowles Paine Traveling Fellowship. He chose to study organ and counterpoint with a young teacher named Nadia Boulanger, who subsequently became the doyenne of several generations of American composers, from Aaron Copland to Philip Glass. He also befriended Mr. Copland, Jean Cocteau, Darius Milhaud and Francis Poulenc, finding for the first time a circle of likeminded artists and intellectuals in which he felt fully at home.
Mr. Thomson's move to Paris also helped inaugurate a post-World-War-I shift in American musical allegiances toward France and its neo-classical ideals of lightness, clarity and humor.
Returning to Harvard in 1922 to complete his bachelor's degree, Mr. Thomson spent a year in New York and another in Boston, as organist and choirmaster of King's Chapel. He also gave the first American performance of Satie's ''Socrate'' with the Harvard Musical Club. In 1925, however, he went back to Paris and remained there, apart from brief visits to the United States, until 1940.
 
'I Felt at Home in France'
''I felt at home in France,'' he explained, ''with its music, its food, its people, its reading and writing.'' For him, it was no sacrifice to abandon the economic security of America for the financial marginality of Parisian Bohemia. ''I prefer to starve where the food is good,'' he said.
It was in Paris in the mid-1920's that Mr. Thomson's mature style took shape, with the ''Sonata da Chiesa,'' a chamber score; four organ pieces based on Baptist hymns, and the ''Symphony on a Hymn Tune.'' He also cultivated an impressive circle of friends, among them James Joyce, Ezra Pound, Igor Stravinsky and Pablo Picasso. But he disdained the idea of a ''lost generation'' of American artists in exile, which he called ''personal publicity for Ernest Hemingway.''
''We were no more lost than any other group of people is at any time,'' he said.
The key event of this period was his first meeting in 1926 with Stein, to whom he was introduced by the composer George Antheil. They remained close until her death in 1946, except for a four-year estrangement.He had set her poem ''Susie Asado'' before their meeting, and immediately afterward composed music for her ''Preciosilla'' and ''Capital Capitals.''
 
Stein Wrote Every Word
The two soon began work on the opera ''Four Saints in Three Acts.'' Stein wrote every word, including the stage directions, and the initial composition was completed by 1928. Originally a plotless effusion by celestial Spanish saints, full of whimsical questions and paradoxical mystical visions, the opera was pruned by Mr. Thomson and fitted to a pageant-like scenario devised by his longtime friend, the painter Maurice Grosser.
The meeting with Stein crystallized Mr. Thomson's conception of his own best gifts as a composer, which involved the setting of texts - particularly her texts - to a music that mirrored their childlike charm and refined intimations of an America momentarily forsaken but never abandoned.
''Poetry alone is always a bit amorphous,'' he wrote, ''and poetry as spontaneously structured as Gertrude Stein's had long seemed to me to need musical reinforcement. I do not mean that her writing lacks music; I mean that it likes music.''
The premiere of ''Four Saints in Three Acts'' took place at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford on Feb. 8, 1934, and it caused a sensation, which was reinforced by the production's subsequent travels to New York and Chicago. It was Mr. Thomson who decided, after the opera had been conceived and composed, that the cast should be entirely black.
Still living in Paris, Mr. Thomson subseqently composed a body of instrumental works, especially for string instruments; undertook a series of mostly piano ''portraits'' of friends that sought to capture their spirits in sound, a lifelong preoccupation; collaborated with the documentary film maker Pare Lorentz on two highly acclaimed films, ''The Plow That Broke the Plains'' and ''The River,'' and wrote ''Filling Station'' for Lincoln Kirstein's Ballet Caravan.
 
Style Owed Much to Satie
His musical style, now fully formed, owed much to Satie and French neo-classicism, but it was original and never bound by orthodoxies imposed by himself or others. In retrospect, the basic concerns and stylistic signatures of his music - open intervals, Baptist hymns, clear and sensitive text-setting, cheerful fanfares, almost proto-Minimalist repetition - seem distinctive enough.
Mr. Thomson once described Satie's music in terms that suit his own: ''It has eschewed the impressive, the heroic, the oratorical, everything that is aimed at moving mass audiences. It has valued quietude, precision, acuteness of auditory observation, gentleness, sincerity and directness of statement.''
His last two operas, ''The Mother of Us All'' and ''Lord Byron'' (1972), reached out to a larger public and more expansive level of rhetorical expression. Stein's text for the former paints a moving and more narratively coherent (if still wonderfully quirky) portrait of Susan B. Anthony and the struggle for women's suffrage. Asked later why he had not written more operas with Stein, Mr. Thomson said, ''It had not occured to me that both of us would not always be living.''
Jack Larson's libretto for ''Lord Byron'' is more conventional in its operatic depiction of personal passion and epic scale. That opera has not received the recognition of the two Stein scores, but Mr. Thomson always cherished it.
In 1940, with war engulfing Europe, Mr. Thomson returned to the United States, moved into the Chelsea Hotel, at 222 West 23d Street - where his grand apartment, awash with artistic memorabilia, became a cultural landmark - and assumed his critical post at the New York Herald Tribune.
His tenure there, ended at his own wish, was distinguished by a prose style at once tart, impassioned and instructive. The critical tone in New York then was mostly conservative and oriented toward the analysis of performance. Mr. Thomson concentrated on the music, new music in particular, and was sometimes airily dismissive of the idols of the day -- among them Arturo Toscanini and Vladimir Horowitz, whose pianistic repertory and style he dismissed as ''silk-underwear music.''
 
Snoozing During Performances
His opinions were sometimes outrageous and sometimes a little breezy -he liked to give the impression that he was seeing some Wagner operas for the first time, and may well have been. His snoozing during performances was also legendary, although he always insisted that he awoke if anything interesting happened. But his writing was always delightful, and it commanded a readership far beyond musicians and music lovers.
After 1954 Mr. Thomson continued his composing and his criticism, mainly for The New York Review of Books, although his appearances as a conductor and lecturer were eventually limited by deafness. His Herald Tribune reviews were collected in four books, his autobiography (''Virgil Thomson'') appeared in 1966, later essays appeared in ''American Music Since 1910'' (1971), and ''The Virgil Thomson Reader,'' a selection from his writing, won the National Book Critics Circle award for criticism in 1981. His ''Selected Letters'' appeared in 1988.
He also received many awards, including 16 honorary doctorates, membership in the National Institute of Arts and Letters and in the French Legion of Honor, and the Kennedy Center Award for Lifetime Achievement.
His end seemed almost exactly like that of his sister Ruby, who died in 1979 at the age of 93. At that time Mr. Thomson wrote a cousin: ''She was certainly entitled to die, and I am happy that she did not suffer. She merely faded away, largely stopped eating, then one night she didn't breathe anymore.''
There are no survivors. A memorial service has been planned for Nov. 25 at 3 P.M. in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. It would have been his 93d birthday.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 8, 1989, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Sunday about the composer and critic Virgil Thomson misidentified a performer whose repertory was dismissed by Mr. Thomson as ''silk-underwear music.''
Mr. Thomson made the comment about Jascha Heifetz, not Vladimir Horowitz.

HEADLINE: FRANK LANGELLA;
A Humbling Account

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Much as I respect and admire Frank Langella's work, upon beginning his article I was fully prepared for a brief and unsuccessful search for the single sympathetic bone in my body. A successful actor's plight? Spare me. And this I admit with no little shame, since as an employed clinical psychologist, generally I am in the sympathy/empathy line.
I am humbled. He put forth a moving account of living with frequent unemployment and the anxiety associated with constant evaluation by powerful others.
Thank you, Mr. Langella, for having the talent, perseverance and, dare I say it, courage, to keep the rest of us entertained.
 
JUDITH TUTIN

SECTION: Section 2; Page 27, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1334 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
An Opera Rivalry Rivals Civic Rivalry

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Those longtime California competitors, San Francisco and Los Angeles, are now engaged in an operatic rivalry that may wind up benefiting both cities. For decades, the San Francisco Opera perched alone on top of its roost as the West Coast's only opera company of national distinction. But today there is a flock of opera companies there that has attracted widespread attention, from Seattle through San Francisco to San Jose, Los Angeles, Costa Mesa, Long Beach and San Diego.
Of these companies, the one with the biggest annual budget ($11.5 million) after San Francisco's $31 million is the four-year-old Los Angeles Music Center Opera. And given the pre-eminence of San Francisco and Los Angeles among West Coast cities, a comparison seems particularly apt.
No grandiose conclusions can be drawn after one quick California opera trip, with two performances sampled in each city. But on the basis of that visit, along with conversations with Peter Hemmings and Lotfi Mansouri, who head the Los Angeles and San Francisco companies, respectively, as well as many previous visits, a few observations can be ventured. 
Despite a bad patch at the San Francisco Opera in the 1980's, and widespread local apprehension that the city was being outstripped economically and culturally by its southern nemesis, the company has plenty of artistic vitality left. And despite some flashy productions, an excellent theater for opera and bedazzling prospects, the Los Angeles company is still No. 2.
Los Angeles arrived on the operatic scene in the wake of the 1984 Olympic Arts Festival in that city, an event that, along with some bold new museums, attracted worldwide attention. And the opera arrived just when the San Francisco Opera was reeling from the retirement of its longtime general director, Kurt Herbert Adler, and the erratic artistic decisions and managerial skills of his successor, Terrence A. McEwen.
With bold repertory choices, splashy productions (Jonathan Miller and David Hockney are regulars) and a shrewd blend of young singers and stars (Placido Domingo was enlisted as ''artistic consultant'' and has appeared there steadily as both tenor and conductor), the Los Angeles company quickly established a hot image. It was thus able to attract both traditional opera lovers and a trendier crowd drawn from the West Los Angeles entertainment community and the sort of new-wavers usually seen at art museums or the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
According to Mr. Hemmings, its dapper English general director, the company has overcome its early money troubles. ''We certainly knocked up a healthy deficit in the first three years,'' he concedes. But, he hints, the only way to build the company on a big-time basis was to leap boldly onto the local cultural map and thereby to attract enough support to relieve the debt in the long run.
Right now, he says, the board oversees fundraising to the annual tune of $4.5 million, $1.4 million of which goes toward the relief of a debt that once totaled $5 million. When the debt is paid off, the extra money will help build a capital reserve. The company also receives $2.5 million annually from the Los Angeles Music Center United Fund.
Attendance the past two seasons has hovered around 83 percent (it was 93 percent in the debut season of 1986-7, but with half the number of performances as now), and Mr. Hemmings said the first two operas of this season have averaged ''in the 90's.''
Assuming continued audience and critical support and growing fundraising clout, the company's real prospects for growth will come after 1994, when the long-aborning, Frank Gehry-designed Walt Disney Hall is completed. At that point, the Los Angeles Philharmonic will move to the new hall and the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion will be turned over to the opera company - as well as to visiting orchestras and recitalists and ballet companies. Mr. Hemmings also hopes that there will be a 1,000-seat theater for smaller operas in the Disney Hall, complementing the 3,100-seat Pavilion, which everyone concedes is a better hall acoustically and visually for opera than it has been for the Philharmonic.
At that point, Mr. Hemmings plans a 12-week season in the fall, nine more weeks in the spring and four weeks of a musical in the summer. There will be four performances a week of two alternating operas, with another two in rehearsal at any given time. Each opera will be performed a total of six times.
Certainly the performances thus far have been promising, with mostly interesting repertory and productions, solid casting, good orchestral and choral work and a lively crop of younger singers under contract for the smaller roles. This fall, the season opened with a Brecht-Weill ''Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny'' that was solidly cast and conducted, rather blankly directed by Mr. Miller and handsomely designed by Robert Israel, with effective suggestions of the Hollywood ''city of nets'' of the 1920's.
Better still was a conventional production of ''Tosca'' sung and acted with real flair by Maria Ewing (a regular here), Mr. Domingo and Justino Diaz. Mr. Domingo had conducted the other performances of this run, stepping in at the last performance for Neil Shicoff, who was at a ''Traviata'' rehearsal at the Metropolitan Opera.
Up north, Mr. Mansouri's arrival this season to replace Mr. McEwen will probably bode well in the long run. The only problem is that Mr. Mansouri has won his reputation as a stage director through conscientious, uncontroversial but also unexciting productions. That gave some forward-looking members of the company's search committee pause, and when Mr. Mansouri accepted the post, he announced that he would restrain his directorial appearances in San Francisco and concentrate on administration - which he can do very well, as shown by his 12 years with the Canadian Opera Company in Toronto.
Unfortunately, for his debut season, Mr. Mansouri chose to take over a production of Berg's ''Lulu'' that was originally to have been borrowed from the Lyric Opera of Chicago. The result was flat and unimaginative, despite a strong musical performance highlighted by the 80-year-old Hans Hotter's cameo as Schigolch. But another San Francisco fall production, of Boito's ''Mefistofele'' by the Canadian team of Robert Carsen and Michael Levine, was a delight, frisky and stylish in the best eclectic post-modernist manner, with a strong cast and conducting.
San Francisco has a firmly based operatic tradition, with attendance steady at over 90 percent and with an established program of apprentice and touring companies. At 3,200 seats, the War Memorial Opera House houses only 1,000 more than the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in its opera configuration, but is - for better and for worse - an altogether grander theater.
San Francisco already has its separate symphony and opera halls, and Mr. Mansouri hopes gradually to erode the long-established tradition of a dense schedule of fall operas (born when the symphony was waiting impatiently to get into the hall in the winter and spring), and to spread out the season year-round. He wants ''a complete presence in the community all year.''
Mr. Mansouri concedes that the bold beginning of the Los Angeles company did give San Francisco a jolt. ''Things were a little complacent here in the Elysian fields,'' he said. ''If you stand still, someone is going to pass you by.''
But, he adds, the Los Angeles company is a little young to be judged as an ongoing Southern California rival. And in any event, both general directors stress cooperation over competition.
Mr. Hemmings talks of the ''total collegiality'' between the two companies. ''We help each other out,'' he said, ''checking about casts and standby singers, and we will share productions in the future.''
''I think it's wonderful,'' Mr. Mansouri said. ''If Los Angeles is good, it stimulates everyone along the West Coast to be better. I find this kind of artistic competition to be very healthy.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-DATE: October 1, 1989

SECTION: Section 2; Page 27, Column 5; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 911 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC VIEW;
Academia: Safety Net Or Threat?

BYLINE: By Donal Henahan

 BODY:
Trying to identify musical trends in a crazy-quilt culture can be frustrating. Even as the prophets of serious pop proclaim the dawn of a new age of democratic art, equally earnest thinkers for whom pop may be no more than a sound made by a very small gun examine the evidence and see Western music being homogenized and trivialized beyond hope by the new levelers. Since history never moves in only one direction at a time, both camps of seers may be right, if that is any consolation.
In the same mail recently I found messages from two writers who examine this question from different viewpoints. In the fall issue of Chamber Music, David M. Rubin reports on a financial survey he made of American string quartets. Mr. Rubin, a professor of journalism at New York University, gathered confidential data from six unidentified ensembles of widely varied experience and success: the youngest has been in existence ''under five'' years, the oldest ''over 15.'' In 1988, individual players in these groups earned, respectively, $4,772, $11,089, $12,497, $41,313, $53,505 and $114,268. Without knowing the quality of the quartets, it is possible to be shocked at the lowest figure, which falls far below the poverty line. It is also possible to be surprised at the highest figure, which is more than double the guaranteed annual salary of musicians in the highest-paid American symphony orchestras. 
Mr. Rubin's article paints a gloomy picture for all but the most famous ensembles. Managements siphon off 20 percent of all concert fees, which means they take more than any of the four players. Cellos also are a problem, in that they must fly as passengers, not luggage: ''One reason Quartet C made no money touring is that it laid out $3,968 for cello airfare in 1988, nearly a third of what each player had left to live on at the end of the year.'' Fees are not only low but frequently discounted: Quartet A played four concerts in a two-week tour for $3,200. And so on, in much depressing detail.
Looking at the balance sheets, Mr. Rubin concludes that the more a young quartet tours the more money it must lose - unless it augments income by finding residencies at colleges or other subsidizing institutions.
Several points may be overlooked in such a bottom-line report. In the last 50 years, the number of quartets touring America has grown beyond the audience's power to absorb them. Besides the handful whose names are recognizable to most music listeners, scores of ad hoc faculty ensembles exist at colleges throughout the land. Each wants its share of the string-quartet audience, which was always a small piece of the concert-business pie, even in the days when only the Budapest could hope to draw an audience in the hinterlands. Furthermore, it is a rare musician who exists solely on chamber-music income: at least in the formative years of an ensemble, teaching privately or on a faculty is a collateral way of life.
What is most interesting about Mr. Rubin's survey, however, is his conclusion that most quartets can only survive by finding places to roost in the subsidized world. If true - and his figures support the thesis - such a movement into the cloister would run counter to the trend hopeful observers perceive in the composing profession. There, the retreat from academia has evidently become so pronounced that one composer has taken to worrying that his colleagues are actually becoming too concerned about pleasing the public - too ''polite,'' as he puts it.
The other writer dealing with this subject is David Lang, a composer. Writing in Premiere, a newsletter of the American Composers Orchestra, he contends that the era when composers wanted to work in the sanctuary of academia has indeed passed: ''All the institutions those composers rejected, we now want. Everyone is writing orchestra music and operas and symphonies; young composers now want to write music and not teach it. Most of us feel these are improvements in our world view . . . ''
It concerns Mr. Lang, however, that in ''trying to plug ourselves into the mainstream,'' he and his fellow composers may lose their appetite for confronting or provoking the public. Populism may have gone too far. In fact, ''one reason why New York's downtown composers often seem refreshing is because they have found ways to avoid confronting the traditions of American music, finding inspiration in pop music or the music of non-Western cultures instead. It is much easier to appropriate another culture than to overthrow your own.''
Leaving aside the dubious proposition that the aim of composition should be to overthrow one's culture (a debater's overstatement, possibly), Mr. Lang's argument makes a certain quirky sense. He is especially annoyed that while Congressmen frequently attack the visual or literary arts as subversive, contemporary composition seems immune to persecution. He thinks this an embarrassment for composers, a tacit admission that they are afraid to rock the boat now that they have had some success in steering it into the mainstream.
So we have, on the one hand, young string quartets being advised to choose the subsidized life with its institutional comforts and dangers of isolation from the musical public. And, on the other, composers being warned that life outside the scholastic cocoon holds the peril of a sellout to a consumer-driven economy. The musician's lot was never an easy one, but was it always so complicated? Probably.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (91%);
