13 of 768 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1989 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 1, 1989

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2912 words

HEADLINE: Japan's Giant Banks on the March photos of Yuko Oana and John McGillicuddy after the CIT deal (NYT/Vic DeLucia);

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Dai-Ichi Kangyo, the world's largest bank, isn't trying to catch the fancy of millions of American consumers, as Toyota and Sony have. It will settle for a close relationship with 10,000 or so corporate treasurers.
When Dai-Ichi Kangyo agreed to invest $1.4 billion in the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation in mid-September, the deal underscored just how attractive the American banking market had become to the Japanese. After years of laboring quietly in the United States, buying a few banks in California and arranging low-profit loans to large businesses, more Japanese bankers have been raising their sights lately to take aim at the so-called middle market of business borrowers, the most profitable sector of all.
The deal with Manufacturers Hanover, for instance, will give Dai-Ichi a 60 percent share of the CIT Group, a major finance company with 50 offices around the country. Besides having a projected profit of about $135 million this year, CIT is an ideal network to gain entree to medium-sized companies. 
''Expanding in the U.S. is of primary importance to us,'' said Yuko Oana, a senior managing director at Dai-Ichi who orchestrated the deal with Manufacturers Hanover. Through its New York branch, and other offices in Los Angeles, Chicago and Atlanta, Dai-Ichi already has more than $30 billion of assets in the United States, a level that would put it among the 20 largest American banking companies. The American market is particularly attractive, Mr. Oana said, because it produces higher profits than Japanese banks can get at home.
Those profits have been the catalyst for several other deals by the Japanese in recent years, albeit not on the scale of the Dai-Ichi purchase, which was by far the largest American acquisition by a Japanese bank. Now, however, the Dai-Ichi deal is seen as a harbinger of other large purchases by the Japanese.
''The Japanese banks were slower than others to expand overseas, but they are clearly making up for lost time,'' said Thomas H. Hanley, managing director at Salomon Brothers, the New York investment banking firm. Flush with fresh capital from a series of new equity offerings, and readily able to raise more capital at a lower cost than other banks, ''the Japanese banks have a real competitive advantage,'' Mr. Hanley said. Future alliances on the magnitude of the recently announced merger of Mitsui Bank and Taiyo Kobe Bank, creating the world's second-largest bank, will not be limited to Japan, he added.
As might be expected, the prospect of more competition from Japan's banking behemoths is giving the jitters to at least some American bankers. They fear that the Japanese will compete so fiercely for business from middle-market companies that they will cut prices and make do with smaller profits than American banks are used to.
And there is plenty of room to maneuver. Over the past nine years, excluding 1987, when they suffered huge losses on Latin American lending, large American banks on average earned three times more per dollar of assets than their Japanese counterparts. The largest American banking company, Citicorp, is the world's most profitable, even though it is only the 10th largest in terms of assets.
The Japanese success in industries like cars and consumer electronics raises the question of whether banking faces a similar future, and if so, what the benefits and costs might be.
''We will receive a supply of good products as the Japanese buy their way into the forefront of the financial services business,'' said Richard W. Wright, a professor of international management at Willamette University in Salem, Ore., and co-author of ''The Second Wave: Japan's Global Assault on Financial Services.''
But the danger, he added, is that Japanese dominance in banking would be ''another threat to our overall competitiveness and innovative capacity.''
 
Benefits Are Seen For U.S. Economy
 Not everyone is worried. Economists claim that if businesses can borrow more cheaply because of Japanese lending, the American economy and consumers benefit. And it still has not been proved that Japanese capital can buy success in other key lines of the banking business, including retail banking or financial advisory services like arranging mergers and acquisitions.
Robert E. Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said there is no doubt that the Japanese pose a major challenge to American banks. But while that competition might prove painful to some banks in the United States, he sees little danger to its economy as a whole.
''The more alliances the Japanese banks form in the United States, and the bigger their market share, the less likely they are to rock the boat,'' Mr. Litan said.
And in Washington, there has been no move in the Senate or House of Representatives to investigate or limit the activities of Japanese or other foreign banks. In the past, legislators have threatened to prevent Japanese banks and securities firms from acting as primary dealers in Treasury securities. Primary dealers are a prestigious group of firms designated by the Federal Reserve that dominate trading in the Treasury securities market. But the threat of legislative action has become more remote as the Japanese gradually opened their financial markets to more American companies.
Much of the impetus for the push to expand overseas has come from the saturation of the Japanese banking market. Corporate lending opportunities for Japanese banks have been cut as large companies turned to the financial markets for their funding. With savings in Japan growing by about $1 billion per day, the keen competition for local investments keeps profit margins low and encourages banks to look elsewhere for new opportunities.
''At first in the 1960's and 1970's, Japanese banks just followed the industrial companies who were their customers in Japan,'' said Takanori Mizuno, New York director of the Institute for Financial Affairs, a Japanese information and educational organization. ''But about 1980, they began to approach U.S. corporations, and by the middle 1980's, they saw the opportunities in the middle market.''
The push overseas gained momentum in the past two years after banking regulators in major Western countries agreed on uniform financial standards that required Japanese banks to greatly increase their capital. After raising $26.5 billion of equity, or shareholder money, in the past year, the Japanese banks are comfortable with the new standards and have a new-found sense of their financial muscle.
Michiya Matsukawa, chairman of the Nikko Research Institute and a former senior official in Japan's Ministry of Finance, noted that the additional capital has put the Japanese banks in a position where they are more tempted than ever to gain market share overseas by shaving interest rates on loans.
That practice, while it benefits borrowers, is worrisome to bankers and regulators in countries where new capital cannot be raised as cheaply as in Japan. In those countries, including the United States, banks rely heavily on the higher profits to accumulate a cushion against hard times.
The Japanese banks got still another reason late last week to pay more attention to foreign lending opportunities when the Bank of Japan, in an effort to curb inflationary pressures, ordered the banks to reduce the growth rate of lending in Japan during the fourth quarter.
American bankers have for several years lamented the influx of foreign banks, which accounted for 27.5 percent of all outstanding domestic business loans by the middle of 1988, up from 21.4 percent five years earlier. Japanese banks account for half the foreign bank lending, up from a 34 percent share five years ago. Most of that growth, bankers agree, has come from ''bargain basement'' pricing of loans to large corporations that owe no allegiance to any bank, except the one offering the lowest price.
''The term 'house bank' is quickly disappearing,'' said Rainer E. Gut, chairman of Credit Suisse, Zurich, an internationally minded lender. And outside Japan, he said, ''Corporations are gradually losing their fear of entering business relationships with Japanese banks.''
Since the 1950's, when Japanese banks first began to appear on the American scene, they have concentrated on corporate banking, first with Japanese companies, then with American corporations doing business with those Japanese companies. While Japanese banks operate huge branch systems in their home country, they have yet to tackle the retail market here, except in California.
The strong presence of Japanese industrial companies and a large Japanese community have made California so attractive to Japanese banks that they now control about a quarter of the state's deposits and more than 30 percent of its business loans.
About 10 Japanese banks, including the Bank of Tokyo, Sanwa, Sumitomo and Mitsubishi, now own full-service banks in the state. Through a series of acquisitions in the past few years, they have dramatically increased their stake in the retail market, to the point where they now have 424 branches, up from 247 in 1982.
But even with these branches, the Japanese have concentrated on business lending rather than the consumer market. In line with that philosophy, they have not bought any savings and loans, despite the availability of many financially troubled savings institutions in California and other parts of the nation.
 
Big Purchases In California
 Two of the largest acquisitions they have made have been from British banks that found the California market too tough for their liking. The Bank of Tokyo, for example, bought the Union Bank, a San Francisco-based specialist in middle-market lending and construction financing, from Standard Chartered P.L.C. for $750 million a year ago, and now has the fifth-largest bank in California. Lacking a branch network in Japan, the Bank of Tokyo now has more than 9,000 employees in the United States and only 5,000 in Japan.
The other British deal came in 1986, when the Sanwa Bank of California, now the state's sixth largest, paid $263 million to acquire the Lloyds Bank of California.
Despite their growth, the Japanese in California have not broken the grip of the four largest American banks, which continue to control about two-thirds of the market. And so far, the Japanese have not managed to operate efficiently enough to generate the same amount of profit from each dollar of assets as the Americans.
Gary C. Zimmerman, an economist at the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank, noted in a recent study published by the bank that ''there is no compelling evidence that Japanese commercial banks have an advantage in providing retail banking services in California.''
The California experience has been humbling enough that some Japanese bankers, including those at Dai-Ichi, which operates the largest branch system in Japan, disavow any intention of making a major push into the American consumer market. In fact, Dai-Ichi sold its retail banking operation in Chicago this year.
Similarly, Hisaya Nara, deputy president of the Mitsubishi Bank of Tokyo, said he expects rapid growth to continue at the Bank of California, which Mitsubishi acquired in 1984, but not necessarily in the retail sector. Assets at the Bank of California, now the seventh largest in the state, are expected to rise to $10 billion within two or three years, from about $7 billion now. But rather than going after consumers in a big way, Mitsubishi's primary effort will be to pursue middle-market business customers, Mr. Nara said.
The middle market that the Japanese are courting more assiduously than before in the United States is loosely defined, but is generally meant to include the thousands of companies that have revenues above $5 million yet are not large enough to rank among the Fortune 500.
As the largest corporations have learned to bypass banks and borrow directly in the capital markets through the sale of commercial paper or bonds, bankers have avidly cultivated the middle-market companies. Because those companies lack access to the capital markets, they rely more on bank financing, and tend to pay higher interest rates than the largest corporations.
The average interest rate on loans to all borrowers at Manufacturers Hanover, for example, is 2.4 percentage points higher than what the banking company must pay for its borrowed funds. But at the CIT Group, which lends exclusively to middle-market clients, the interest spread is more than 5 percentage points.
Even if Japanese banks resist the temptation to gain market share by cutting prices, they gain other benefits from their financial strength. John F. McGillicuddy, chairman of Manufacturers Hanover (which continues to hold 40 percent of CIT), said that profits at the finance company would be helped as the backing of the capital-rich Dai-Ichi reduces CIT's cost of borrowing.
Japanese banks have long recognized the profit potential in the American middle market, but they have also recognized that it is a hotly contested area that relies more on personal relationships with borrowers than does lending to the largest corporations. So far, the Japanese have found it easier to gain middle-market customers through acquisitions, particularly from companies in some sort of financial difficulty.
Manufacturers Hanover, for example, did not want to sell control of CIT, a company that it had worked hard to improve after buying it from RCA in 1985. But the New York bank faced a dire need for capital to cover losses on its loans to Latin American countries. Besides giving up the 60 percent stake in CIT, Manufacturers sold 4.9 percent of its stock to Dai-Ichi in their $1.4 billion deal.
Earlier, in 1985, the Sanwa Bank bought a leasing unit with more than $500 million of assets from the Continental Illinois Corporation. That deal came at a time when Continental was selling most of its non-bank assets to recover from losses on fraudulent oil loans it bought from the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma.
In 1983, the Fuji Bank paid $425 million to buy the Walter E. Heller International Corporation, a struggling finance company that was about to be acquired by the Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles for $400 million. Although Fuji has since invested more than $1 billion in Heller, and has only recently begun to show a profit, it gained a foothold in thousands of corporate boardrooms through Heller's network of offices in 68 cities.
 
On the Prowl For Opportunities
 Not all the recent Japanese purchases have been from distressed sellers:
* In June, Security Pacific sold 5 percent of its consumer and commercial finance operations to Mitsui Bank for $100 million and gave Mitsui an option to buy another 5 percent at the same price.
* Later in the summer, Orix International, Japan's largest leasing company, bought the leasing operations of the Los Angeles-based First Interstate Bancorp for $190 million.
* And in mid-September, Daiwa Bank, Japan's 15th largest, paid $200 million to buy a pool of American middle-market loans from Lloyds Bank of London. Daiwa also picked up 15 offices in the United States from Lloyds, taking a shortcut around the normal process of obtaining approval from Japanese regulators for each new office.
According to Dai-Ichi's Mr. Oana, there are many other opportunities in the United States. While running the bank's New York branch during the past three years, he said, he was approached at least 10 times with offers to buy American financial companies. Last week, Dai-Ichi announced an alliance with Clayton & Dubilier Inc., a New York-based specialist in mergers and acquisitions, and promised to invest $100 million in a corporate buyout fund managed by the New York company. Dai-Ichi is still looking to acquire a California-based finance company that could operate in tandem with a small bank it owns in San Francisco.
The pressure to expand into American financial markets is not confined to the largest Japanese banks. So far, 32 of Japan's 64 regional banks have offices in the United States, along with 9 of the country's 68 ''sogo'' banks, a kind of mutual savings institution.
''Right now, there are only four or five regional banks that have gone beyond their Japanese customers to seeking business with American firms,'' said Bruce E. Aronson, a partner at the law firm of Hughes, Hubbard & Reed. ''But in three to five years I expect to see another 20 or 25 doing that.''
While the prospect of even more Japanese competitors is daunting to many American bankers, they should remember that the imposing size of the newcomers reflects the limited number of banks in Japan. The Japanese market is divided among only about 150 banks, compared with more than 13,000 in the United States.
The best way to help American banks meet the challenge posed by the powerful newcomers is to ''modernize the U.S. financial system by eliminating barriers to interstate banking and bank activities in the securities markets,'' said Lawrence R. Uhlick, executive director of the Institute of International Bankers, which includes several Japanese members.
''In a global economy, Americans have to recognize that there is going to be a significant segment of the U.S. financial market owned and operated by non-domestic institutions, just like American firms own and operate significant businesses in other countries,'' Mr. Uhlick added.

HEADLINE: A Doctor for Struggling Economies

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If Hollywood were casting it, Jeffrey Sachs might be the Indiana Jones of economics.
With outspoken views and a penchant for third world countries, the 34-year-old Harvard economist finds adventure wherever he goes. Last week, his presence was felt here throughout the annual International Monetary Fund meetings. On Wednesday, he was at the Polish Embassy, where officials of the Solidarity-backed Government unveiled an ecomomic plan to ''shock'' Poland into free-market reforms - a plan that Mr. Sachs helped devise. That same day, he appeared on a panel and jousted with world bankers over the Mexican debt plan. The day before he met with the President of Venezuela in New York.
For years, Mr. Sachs has been offering prescriptions for resolving the woes of troubled economies, primarily in Latin America. His flamboyant style, close ties to third world leaders and insistence that poor countries stop paying foreign debt has made him an enfant terrible of the Western banking establishment. 
Now, he has turned his attention to Poland, where he has proposed nothing less than an overnight transformation of an economy on the verge of bankruptcy. The ''Sachs Plan'' calls for the elimination of state subsidies, the lifting of price controls and a sell-off of state industries, with the cost being a rise in unemployment and prices. But Mr. Sachs promises that in six months the hyperinflation that has gripped Poland should end. Within two years, the country should be on its way to recovery.
This drastic perscription is vintage Jeff Sachs. It came after eight trips to Warsaw, where Mr. Sachs captured the ear of Solidarity leaders and Polish economists.
To be sure, many of his ideas were not new. But Mr. Sachs added a special spin, arguing that the changes must take place fast while the new Solidarity Government still enjoys popular support.
''Our big debate was whether to grow our economy step by step or to make it a Big Bang,'' said Witold Trzeciakowski, a Polish economic adviser to Solidarity. ''Jeffrey Sachs came at the right moment and stressed that things be done in a quick way. He played a very important role.''
Within the world of economics, Mr. Sachs is unusual and controversial - not only for his views but for his skill at promoting them and himself. ''I'm not a naive do-gooder,'' he said in an interview in his cluttered office overlooking Harvard Square in Cambridge, Mass. ''The funny thing is that a lot of the solutions that I proposed in 1985 for the third world crisis are now coming home to roost.''
He tries to put his theories about ending hyperinflation to work by staying on a first-name basis with political and economic leaders from La Paz to Warsaw to Capitol Hill. For instance, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, praises him. ''Jeff's experience working with politicians and policy makers in developing countries gives him a dimension that's often lacking in people who are more purely theoretical,'' Mr. Bradley said.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Sachs' high-profile ways have brought both admiration and carping from fellow economists. ''Jeff's style is flamboyant, although I'm not sure it's always productive,'' said Rudiger Dornbusch, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist. ''He's never stepped anywhere without being controversial. Take Bolivia. Most people hardly knew Bolivia existed until Jeff pounded the facts before the Treasury Department and the I.M.F. The press is always looking for the other side and Jeffrey Sachs represents that. He's loud and he's noisy in denouncing I.M.F. policies.''
Mr. Sachs' biggest claim to fame so far has been in Bolivia, where he is credited with helping reduce inflation from 40,000 percent to 15 percent in a matter of months in the mid-1980's by implementing a drastic austerity program. Despite this ackowledged success, he is continually at odds with the Western banking establishment over his pronouncements that the only way third world countries can escape hyperinflation is by renouncing their debt payments to the West.
But he is also strong in his insistence that third world countries repair their economies through tight budgetary restraints.
''Here I am viewed by banks as some crazy radical or someone who is trying to throw the banks' money away,'' said Mr. Sachs. ''In Latin America, I am often attacked as a crazy reactionary because I say that the key to economic success is in cleaning up their economic act.''
But it is not so much what he says as how he says it. He frequently wraps economic theory in impassioned, moralistic terms. For instance, he is not above linking banks' reluctance to write off troubled loans in Bolivia with a rise in the country's infant mortality rate.
''I don't say don't pay debt because this is some kind of a game,'' said Mr. Sachs. ''I say don't pay it because what you are paying is keeping people from eating and may cause the country to explode. There is no virtue in so strapping a people that you end up with social chaos.''
Words like that cause bankers to cringe or become angry, but what is particularly frustrating for the bankers is that they cannot ignore Mr. Sachs. ''He's been quite influential,'' said Karen Lissackers, a Columbia University economist. ''From the banks' standpoint, he's a radical. But because he's from Harvard and because he's a very able economist and because he has a lot of influence with borrowers, he's got clout. He may be anathema to them, but they have to pay attention.''
Executives at major banks can be scathing in their comments about Mr. Sachs, but as an indication of his stature, none interviewed were willing to have their names printed with their specific criticisms.
But in the third world, he is treated with first-name friendliness and glowing praise. For instance, in La Paz, Fernando Romero, the former Bolivian Minister of Planning and Coordination said: ''Mr. Sachs steps on a lot of toes because he is so blunt and direct and lots of people call him lots of names. But once you sit down to work with him, it's a formidable experience. He's brilliant. He has an extraordinary ability to grasp the core of problems and say, 'Here's how to do it.' ''
According to Mr. Romero, Mr. Sachs did not formulate Bolivia's drastic economic austerity program, but he helped refine and implement it.
''He was extraordinarily helpful in the process of implementing many of our measures,'' said Mr. Romero. ''In the toughest times, we would be on the telephone at 3 A.M. and 4 A.M. in the morning. He'd take the input of our economic behavior and say, 'Watch out for this or that.' ''
His specialty at Harvard has been hyperinflation - those periods of severe economic dislocation when the economy begins to make no sense, money looses its value and, often, social unrest and political upheavals are not far behind. Most of his work has flowed out of this academic interest. The Bolivian project, for instance, grew from an invitation from a former student.
At Harvard, which he attended as an undergraduate, he became a professor at age 28 and received tenure just a year later. Mr. Sachs is not shy about his academic accomplishments. His curriculum vitae runs some 13 pages and contains such tidbits as the fact that he graduated third in his Harvard class of 1,650 students. He took pains in an interview to note that he is a member of Harvard's elite Society of Fellows.
The bulk of his activities are paid for by various United Nations grants and by other agencies with development programs. His trips to Poland are paid for by the Stefan Vatory Society, which is funded by the Hungarian-American businessman George Soros.
There seems little doubt that his work with Poland will be his biggest challenge yet. Already the ''Sachs Plan'' has become a matter of debate between those who favor radical free-market reform and those who feel the new measure might cause hardships that would become politically intolerable, among them falling real wages, rising prices, a drop in the standard of living and up to a million jobs lost.
Mr. Sachs said he answers his critics with the words of one Solidarity economist: ''You don't jump over a chasm in two leaps.''
The flaw in his plan may be that Poland lacks the financial institutions to provide a sustained economic response once hyperinflation is tamed. ''He hasn't seriously thought through that this is a central planning economy,'' said Anthony Levitas, a Harvard doctoral student who has spent the last nine months in Poland studying the economy. ''The Poles don't have the kind of market infrastructure that will insure that workers will get work and goods will get put on shelves once you end inflation.''
Says Mr. Sachs: ''In Bolivia, the plan was attacked for having high social costs and that there would be hard times. It was called impossible. That's just like Poland now.''

CORRECTION-DATE: October 22, 1989, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 1 about the economist Jeffrey Sachs misidentified the sponsor of his trips to Poland. It is the Stefan Batory Society.

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
Sony Expands Into Hollywood

BYLINE: By STEVE DODSON

 BODY:
Sony is buying into Hollywood. Columbia Pictures accepted a $3.4 billion offer from the Japanese electronics giant. Columbia produces several successful television series but its movie division has lagged. The biggest attraction for Sony executives, led by the president, Norio Ohga, apparently was the 2,700 films in Columbia's library. The movies will provide the ''software'' for video devices that Sony makes, including its new Video Walkman. Sony was already a significant part of the American entertainment industry, having acquired CBS Records last year. Coca-Cola owns 49 percent of Columbia, and an analyst estimated that Coke's profit before tax would be $1.5 billion.
 
*
 A capital gains tax cut was approved by the House. The proposed reduction, from a top rate of 33 percent to 19.6 percent, would be in effect until the end of 1991. A tax break on profits from selling securities or real estate is a favorite idea of President Bush's. The proposal was called a gift to the wealthy by House Democratic leaders, but 64 Democrats joined the Republicans to approve the measure, 239 to 190. Senate passage, probably with some revisions, is thought likely. 
 
*
 Coors is buying Stroh Brewing in a $425 million deal. Stroh, which is family owned and based in Detroit, has about 10 percent of the American beer market, and Coors has about 9 percent. Together they would have a solid hold on third place, behind Miller, with 22 percent, and Anheuser-Busch, with about 43 percent.
Anheuser-Busch will pay $1.1 billion for four Sea World theme parks and other properties owned by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Anheuser already owns Busch Garden parks in Florida and Virginia. Analysts had expected that Harcourt, the nation's second-largest publisher, would get about $1.5 billion for the properties. Harcourt shares fell sharply as investors interpreted the low price as a sign of trouble for Harcourt's efforts to cut its debt through asset sales.
 
*
 The leading indicators were up three-tenths of a percent in August, the second straight monthly advance for the index, which is intended to forecast the economy's direction. The rise in July had been one- tenth of a percent . . . Orders for durable goods climbed 3.8 percent in August, the strongest advance in eight months.
 
*
 Saks and Marshall Fields are for sale. B.A.T., the British conglomerate that owns the two department store chains, said it would sell them as part of a revamping intended to ward off the $21 billion hostile takeover bid mounted by Sir James Goldsmith. The managements of both chains are expected to be among those making offers.
 
*
 Paul A. Bilzerian was sentenced to four years in jail, the stiffest penalty handed out so far in the three-year- old Government crackdown on securities law violations. The Government said Mr. Bilzerian, former chairman of the Singer Company, had concealed his holdings in takeover targets and then sold at a huge profit.
 
*
 Braniff entered bankruptcy again. The nation's 15th-largest airline had sought bankruptcy protection in 1982 and did not resume operations until 1984. This time it ran into trouble trying to finance a costly expansion program in a weak ''junk bond'' market. Braniff said it would try to reorganize as a smaller carrier serving 11 cities, rather than 36.
 
*
 The dollar was hammered down by strong central bank intervention following a meeting of finance ministers in Washington. During the week the dollar lost about 4 percent of its value against both the West German mark and the Japanese yen. The credit markets were troubled by the dollar's move, and bond prices fell moderately. But stocks had small gains. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 11.21 points for the week, closing at 2,692.82. Strong worldwide demand for oil helped prices hold firm, even though OPEC failed to agree on limiting the output of individual members.
 
*
 I.B.M. lowered expectations about its third-quarter profit. The computer maker suggested to analysts that their quarterly estimates, which were running at $2.10 a share to $2.30, should be cut to $1.40 to $1.80. Manufacturing glitches are causing delays in new products, while anticipation of new products is causing sizable numbers of customers to lease equipment rather than buy, the company said . . . I.B.M. is joining Texas Instruments in a venture that will seek contracts to automate large factories.
 
*
 Miscellanea. The Citizens and Southern Corporation of Atlanta will combine with Sovran Financial of Virginia to form the nation's 11th- largest bank, in terms of deposits . . . Arthur Andersen and Price Waterhouse gave up on their attempt at a merger that would have created the world's largest accounting firm . . . Toys ''R'' Us said it plans to open stores in Japan.

HEADLINE: Selling Yourself on Madison Ave.

BYLINE: By AIMEE L. STERN; Aimee L. Stern is a freelance writer based in Cambridge, Mass.

 BODY:
One day last March, Marc Eisenoff walked into the office of Ira Madris, deputy creative director at McCann-Erickson Worldwide advertising, to ask for a raise. The 39- year-old senior art director spotted one of the agency's executive recruiters. For a split second, he thought that might be standard procedure - but she wasn't smiling. He struggled with an overwhelming urge to turn and run. Then he was dismissed.
Lisa E. Levy, an art director at the Biederman Kelly & Shaffer agency met a similar fate last January, on Friday the 13th no less. Ms. Levy, who is 33, said she had had a false sense of security: She had been at Biederman five and a half years and recently they had nearly doubled her salary.
But on the 13th, she heard that Barry Biederman, the chief executive, was frantically searching for her. ''He looked kind of queer,'' she said. ''The minute he started talking I knew something was up. My co-workers thought I was kidding. I had to convince them I'd just been fired.'' 
 
*
 These two stories mirror those of scores of advertising executives who spent the summer of 1989 pounding the pavement of Madison Avenue. Since 1985, ad agencies have dismissed a steady stream of employees. In the last three years it is estimated that 4,000 to 5,000 ad executives in New York have lost their jobs, about one in six.
The industry was one of the first to feel the pinch of recession in the mid-80's, as corporations started cutting costs. Its problems were compounded by the wave of corporate mergers and buyouts. As the newly merged and often highly leveraged companies streamlined, advertising bugets again were often the first casualties. And with the 1987 stock market crash, recovery became even more difficult.
And the advertising industry itself was rocked by mergers and acquisitions, as some of its best-known names joined forces to form bigger and bigger agencies. New York agencies have also been hurt by increased competition with new, smaller regional agencies, which have lured clients away with promises of personalized service and fresh creative work.
Both McCann-Erickson and Biederman lost large accounts earlier this year and slashed expenses. In the ad business, 80 percent of overhead walks out the door every night, so the first cuts are usually of staff. When the industry was healthy, jobs were created when an agency won an account. Now, an agency is more likely to overtax employees or use freelancers during busy periods.
Those hardest hit, say executive recruiters, have been mid-level executives like Mr. Eisenoff, who has been seeking an annual salary of $70,000 to $100,000, and Ms. Levy, who asks for $50,000 to $65,000.
And despite widespread recognition of the slump, unemployment still carries a stigma. As the executive recruiter Jerry Fields, of Jerry Fields Associates, put it, ''In this business you're only as good as you're last campaign.''
With such warnings in mind, Mr. Eisenoff and Ms. Levy set out to find jobs. They agreed to take notes and meet periodically with this reporter. This is an account of their summer.
 
JUNE
 Mr. Eisenoff has retrieved his portfolio from the Ogilvy Group, where it had been languishing since early May. At first, Ogilvy's creative recruiter had seemed encouraging, holding out the promise of an art director's slot on the American Express Corporation account. But when he called back, she rankled him with the news that they had just instituted a hiring freeze.
But his strategy is to keep his portfolio, or ''book,'' from languishing over the weekend. He has three identical portfolios. Each costs about $500 to make and contains laminated advertisements he has done for companies like Shearson Lehman Hutton, A.T.&T., T.W.A. and Ciba-Geigy. He uses a diverse mix of ads, so he can send out the book for any position.
The next step is to get his book to another agency. He keeps a file of about 100 index cards with names of his contacts. This time he picks card No. 4: Frank Ginsberg, president of Avrett Free & Ginsberg Inc.
Maybe this was his lucky card. Mr. Ginsberg said an art director had just quit that morning. ''Where are you?'' he asked. ''Where's your book, and how fast can you get here?'' Fortunately, Mr. Eisenoff said, he was dressed appropriately for an impromptu interview: black shirt, shoes and slacks, and one silver earring. Although account executives wear suits and ties, the ''creatives'' are more casual, he explained, and Avrett is known as a ''hip agency.''
Mr. Eisenoff raced across Manhattan and got there in time to meet Mr. Ginsberg, chat, even compare suntans. He may have look poised, he said, but was actually scouring the room for hints of who the agency handles. He was unprepared, he said, and hates that feeling. Later, the associate creative director, Philip Davidson, joined them. The dynamics of such a meeting are crucial because copywriters and art directors work in tandem, like two comedians doing a routine. Halfway through the hour conversation, Mr. Davidson took a phone call, then, grinning, said: ''I hear you do magic. Could you do some for me?''
A good sign: They checked up on him. He has done magic tricks since childhood and tries to interject them at interviews to distinguish himself from other candidates. This time, Mr. Davidson was duly impressed as a five-dollar bill turned into a one-dollar bill. ''You'll have to show me more sometime,'' he said. Then they discussed salary, marital status and Mr. Eisenoff's commute from Long Island, all indicators that they were seriously interested. He left confident he would get the job.
 
*
 Like Mr. Eisenoff, Ms. Levy has been experiencing the mood swings of job-hunting. In April she had met with Jay Schulberg, the creative director of Bozell Inc. She thought the interview had been ''great''; his secretary had even called to arrange another, but then canceled it at the last minute. Now a letter has arrived: ''Sorry for the runaround. We can't have you join us now but maybe somewhere down the road . . . wish you all the best. . . . you are terrific.''
''We were very similar,'' she said. ''He really cared about the work. He wasn't an egomaniac and I was impressed by that.''
But there was good news too. She landed a freelance job at Grey Entertainment & Media. It may be temporary, but it means income and contacts that could lead to a permanent job. And when she approaches other employers, she will no longer bear the stigma of unemployment.
 
*
 After 10 days, Mr. Eisenoff could no long stand the suspense and decided to call Mr. Ginsberg again. Of course getting an agency chief on the phone can require extreme patience. When he doesn't want to leave several messages - and look like a pest - Mr. Eisenoff just keeps calling and hangs up on the secretary until by chance the right person answers.
This time he reached Mr. Davidson, who had hired an art director he had worked with before.
To compound his disappointment, an interview with Richard Levenson, chief creative officer of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, has been canceled for the third time. At first, it had looked promising. Mr. Eisenoff had run into a former colleague, John Nieman, in the lobby of McCann Erickson. Mr. Nieman said he was quitting McCann to join D'Arcy as chief creative officer of the domestic division and told Mr. Eisenoff to call Mr. Levenson and use his name. D'Arcy had won new business from Burger King and the Maxwell House division of General Foods, and Adweek reported that the agency was looking for 70 people.
Mr. Eisenoff called a friend at D'Arcy and discovered that they actually planned to hire just a few junior employees.
 
*
 Rather than relying just on the usual strategies of calling contacts and combing the classified ads, Ms. Levy believes in being as creative as possible when it comes to self-promotion, and often it has paid off. She has been named a runner-up in an amateur photography contest sponsored by Absolut Vodka. ''This could be a real break for me,'' she said. In 1987, she won $83,000 in an advertising contest for Hebrew National for an ad that pictured a slender, leotard-clad woman, with the headline, ''There's more fat on her than on our salami.'' And she earned an appearance on the stupid pet tricks contest of ''The David Letterman Show'' by getting her hamster, Bitey, inside a plastic ball and coaxing him down a makeshift bowling alley.
For the Absolut contest, she took fishing line and hung a vodka bottle in an instant photo booth to make it look as if it were photographing itself. The contest was judged by Absolut's agency, TBWA Inc, and American Photographer magazine published the winning entries.
While discussing the contest with a friend who is a TBWA copywriter, she learned of an opening there and a few days later dropped off her book. At a cocktail party that night, someone else mentioned the TBWA job, she said, taken aback by how small the New York ad business really is.
 
JULY
 For Mr. Eisenoff, the Fourth of July weekend brought no respite from job hunting. An associate creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide promised him a freelance job but insisted that he call on Saturday. So he left his wife and 8-year-old son camped at a remote Long Island beach, hitchhiked to a pay phone, stood in a sweltering parking lot, jotting down notes on a scrap of paper, and made his call.
Then, Ralph Lederman, creative director of Towne, Silverstein, Rotter Inc., a 35-person shop in Greenwich Village, left four urgent messages for him. He needed a freelancer right away. Mr. Eisenoff, who worked with Mr. Lederman 17 years ago at his first job in advertising, was elated. It was his first offer for full-time freelance work.
After a week, Mr. Lederman broached the idea of hiring him permanently, and then left for the West Coast, where a TV commercial was being shot.
 
*
 Ms. Levy said her Aunt Henrietta keeps asking why she doesn't switch to another field. Most of her relatives are government workers and simply do not understand why anyone would work in a business where employment is so tenuous.
Headhunters have sent her two books to agencies, but so far there have been no replies. She is still freelancing at Grey Entertainment and reasonably happy there, she said. She bumped into a copywriter she knows, who told her she's ''lucky to be working.''
 
AUGUST
 Mr. Lederman is still on the Coast and Mr. Eisenoff is still looking for a job. ''I'm keeping everything alive until I get my first paycheck,'' he said, ''but I have slacked off a little.'' He believes his every move is part of the application process: he arrives early, leaves late and is excruciatingly polite.
 
*
 Ms. Levy called Peter Hoffman, a group head at Ally & Gargano/MCA Advertising to say, ''Hi, it's lunch time; it's Monday; can I come by?'' The call, she explained, was not really so casual. She had called before about a job opening and he had told her to just ''stop by'' some time. The job had been filled, but he was still interested in meeting her.
She wore her usual interview outfit, carefully planned, she said, to convey just the right image. It is a peach-colored linen dress, with jewelry she made herself, including a necklace of cut-up American Express gold cards and tie-dyed earrings.
She brought props, like a Stealth bomber T-shirt she designed and a copy of American Photographer with her award-winning photograph. ''I had all the stuff in my purse,'' she said, ''and I pulled it out and said, 'Look, see I am creative, really. I felt I made an impression. I'm good with people, and interviews usually help me. In the end, he said something like 'Let's keep in touch.' ''
 
*
 Mr. Lederman returned, looked at Mr. Eisenoff's commercials on Aug. 22 and that day offered him a position as a senior art director, and within the salary range he had been seeking. He was thrilled but anxious. ''I can't explain it,'' he said. ''Its like dating someone. It may feel right but sometimes you have to stop and think about it for a moment before you accept.'' After stalling for a day to see what might happen with J. Walter Thompson, he accepted.
 
SEPTEMBER
 Ms. Levy has begun a freelance job in the sales promotion division of Scali McCabe Sloves and she, too, is earning within the range she had sought. After her first day, she went to the video store and rented ''The Agony and the Ecstasy.''
''It reminded me of working in advertising,'' she said. ''The Pope is like the client and Michelangelo is the creative genius. They haggle over price. The Pope wants him to change things. But in the end Michelangelo has created a masterpiece and the Pope respects his work.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: TRADING WITH JAPAN;
Something Basic Is Wrong in America

BYLINE: By AKIO MORITA; Akio Morita is chairman of the Sony Coporation.

 BODY:
A serious look at the composition of the United States-Japan bilateral trade imbalance shows that the United States is becoming highly dependent on Japanese high-tech industrial products.
From 1982 to 1988, the volume of American imports of consumer durable goods from Japan fell 34 percent. This decrease is largely offset, however, by an increase in American imports of capital goods, like high-tech devices, components and equipment American industry needs to make its own products. Imports of machinery over all increased 82 percent. This is one reason why the total United States-Japan trade imbalance does not appear to improve. 
It is, of course, an indication of the integration of the United States and Japanese economies that for many products design and final assembly are done in the United States while manufacturing is carried out in Japan or elsewhere. But America's loss of competitiveness in so many areas of high-tech manufacturing suggests that there is something fundamentally amiss in American industry. If the United States loses too much of its high-tech manufacturing base, it also loses its ability to be a technology leader in the coming century.
This is something Americans should be concerned about. But it is also a global concern that American industry regain its competitiveness.
The real key to competitiveness lies not in trade policy and protection of high-tech industries, but in increased investment, strengthened research and development and work-force development. Basic education and on-the-job training need to be improved.
My most basic message is that the United States Government and American companies should shift their time horizons. Investments are needed today that will pay dividends in 10, 20 or 30 years. The short-term orientation of corporate management in the United States encourages the neglect of long-term investment vital to industry, depriving it of the ability to create attractive products. Both Senator Lloyd Bentsen and Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, have recently made similar points.
Mr. Darman courageously used the phrase ''now-now-ism'' to accurately describe the American obsession with getting quick results at the expense of long-term considerations.
Seeking hasty results is especially dangerous in manufacturing industries, where it takes 10 years to develop a new technology, 10 more to apply it to a new product, and maybe another 10 to turn that product into a profitable business. Patience, consistency and continuity are required. Yet the financial community seems to concentrate on 10-minute time frames.
In the financial sector, now-now-ism causes currency fluctuations that undermine the future-oriented manufacturing industries and weaken the global economy. Because manufacturing is fundamental to a healthy economy, the most important role of the financial community should be to provide manufacturers with the best economic atmosphere.
There are two other challenges to be considered with regard to international competitiveness and the trade imbalance. First, successful international companies must emphasize localization and globalization of business operation.
Localization is the first important step for a global enterprise. That is why I established the Sony Corporation of America in 1960 with local management and with an ongoing commitment to manufacturing, research and development, and engineering activities in the United States.
Through localization we can get the best talent and performance available in each location. If we accomplish this locally, we can achieve the full potential of our global work force. But we must also globalize operations, conducting our worldwide operations with a common business philosophy. One reflection of this global-localization at Sony is that we have named an American and a Swiss national to our board of directors.
The second challenge is one faced collectively by all industrial nations. It is obvious that we need larger markets for the future development of the global economy.
To this end, I agree with Prime Minister Lee of Singapore. The countries of Southeast Asia must become consumer societies, and Japan too must exercise a powerful import pull. Then America, Europe and Asia - including Japan - could be three important regions contributing to worldwide economic development.
People in business face many challenges. If we cannot offer attractive products that satisfy customers, and cannot afford long-term investment, it will be difficult to succeed. But no nation, and no company, can by itself address the compelex issues of competitiveness, trade imbalances and long-term commitment to manufacturing that lie at the heart of commerce. On the business map there can be no boundaries.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: TRADING WITH JAPAN;
Japan's Market Is Closed Drum Tight

BYLINE: by EDWARD L. HENNESSY JR.; Edward L. Hennessy Jr. is chairman and chief executive of Allied-Signal Inc.

 BODY:
Just over a decade ago, the company I work for decided to enter the Japanese market with a high-tech amorphous metal alloy we had developed in our New Jersey laboratories. Determined to avoid the pitfalls that had doomed the efforts of so many other foreign companies on Japanese soil, we named a Japanese-born and educated executive who worked for Allied-Signal Inc. in the United States to head the effort in Tokyo. Fluent in the language and schooled in the nuances of doing business in Japan, he seemed an excellent choice to help us establish a Japanese beachhead. He also had the advantage of a joint venture with a Japanese business group, and a long-term commitment from Allied-Signal.
Our man in Japan recently returned home - frustrated and empty-handed - after running headlong into one roadblock after another. We are determined to keep at it, and recently managed to obtain a Japanese patent that we filed 12 years ago. But we are repeatedly cautioned by Japanese insiders that our aggressive efforts to compete are disrupting the harmony of their markets. 
There is no denying that Japan is a virtually impenetrable market for many foreign businesses today. My company is certainly not the first - nor the last - to learn this firsthand. As an American business executive, however, my intent is not to condemn the Japanese, nor tell them how to manage their country. Instead, I feel we must make a genuine effort to understand the Japanese way of doing business as a crucial step toward correcting our trade imbalances.
Clearly, we can't delude ourselves into thinking that Japan plays by the same economic rules and imperatives as the rest of the world. In the course of achieving its astounding postwar success, Japan developed its own distinctive views of competition, open markets and free trade. Indeed, national economic development and security are placed well ahead of global interests. As Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, noted recently, the very idea of trade reciprocity simply is not understood by Japanese companies.
The current $52 billion trade imbalance between the United States and Japan confirms what many Americans have suspected about Japanese trade practices. That deficit is barely down at all from when the dollar was strong, while over the same period the American trade deficit with Europe was cut in half. A recent Business Week/Harris poll showed that by a 3-to-1 margin, respondents felt that Japan's economic challenge posed a greater threat to America's future than the Soviet military. It appears that mutual suspicion is fast becoming an unfortunate fact of life between our two countries.
The severity of this country's trade gap certainly cannot be ignored or minimized. We should be working hard to erase it by making low-cost, high-quality products that the world needs, and is willing to buy. All too often, the United States has failed to turn its scientific excellence into marketplace winners fast enough and convincingly enough. We have lagged seriously behind not only Japan, but other countries as well.
A growing number of American companies are facing up to the problem. They are forming teams of marketing, manufacturing and research and development people at a project's earliest stages. Such collaborative efforts get products into the market much faster.
American companies are also awakening to the fact that to be competitive in the 1990's, they must embrace the long view. That is, they must respond to the need for long-term investment in research and development and for risk-taking strategies that position their companies in new markets and technologies - and not be overwhelmed by the cry from the financial community for short-term profits and dividends.
As American companies address their needs at home, however, so must the Japanese face the fact that they are widely perceived throughout the world as a protectionist nation. This perception - whether based on fact or misunderstanding - and the resentment it spawns, harms the global marketplace.
But recriminations and external sanctions are not the way to go. Change must be internal: Japanese executives and policy makers must recognize and accept the fact that the world needs to do business with them.
A book published earlier this year in Tokyo, and co-authored by Sony's chairman, Akio Morita, is entitled, ''The Japan That Can't Say No.'' Instead of a Japan that can say no in its relations with its trading partners, I believe the world urgently needs a Japan that can say yes - yes to open markets, to a mutuality of benefits, and to greater understanding and cooperation among nations.
The global economy is fast unfolding, creating opportunities for countries and citizens on every continent. But without the active support of all the free market nations, that opportunity could be lost.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: DEALING WITH GLOBAL WARMING;
Power From Space Is Pollution Free

BYLINE: By PETER E. GLASER; Peter E. Glaser is vice president of space operations for Arthur D. Little Inc. He has served on the NASA Task Force on Space Goals and was a member of NASA's Advisory Council for the ''Lunar Energy Enterprise Case Study.''

 BODY:
Most of the discussion about preserving the ecology of our planet has focused on Earth-based solutions. These have been aimed at protecting the environment and providing energy to meet the demands of the planet's expanding population. In the near- to mid-term, these are important and valuable steps. But in the long term, a key to humanity's continued evolution will be the penetration of space and the economic and scientific exploitation of the solar system's inexhaustible resources and unique physical characteristics.
A few months ago, President Bush outlined some challenging steps toward this goal. His proposal, made on the 20th anniversary of the first lunar landing, called for the establishment of a base on the moon to be followed by a manned mission to Mars. But unlike President John F. Kennedy's earlier proposal to go to the moon, the Bush proposal contained no timetable and no guidelines for financing. He left those issues to the National Space Council, headed by Vice President Quayle. 
Pursuing space missions is important, but not just for economic and scientific reasons. It is also important as a means to meet the future energy needs of this planet without creating further ecological deterioration.
During the first two decades of the space age, the exploration and uses of space were conducted primarily by the United States and the Soviet Union. Now other countries have begun making long-range, multibillion-dollar plans for space exploration and exploitation. These nations, in many instances, wish to participate in international space missions and to share both in the gains and the costs.
But the real key to entering space is the development of an infrastructure that can be expanded signficantly over an extended period. This infrastructure of permanently manned space stations and orbiting industrial parks will be able to support a broad spectrum of scientific investigations, technology development and commercial ventures. A prerequisite for space-based infrastructure will not only be the transportation of material and people, but also the availability of adequate electrical power.
The Soviet Union and Japan already have ambitious plans for generating power in space, at first for use in orbit and subsequently for use on earth. Plans for a long-term Soviet space power development program were presented at the International Astronautical Federation Congress in 1985 and were followed by statements from several leading Soviet space technologists. A recent article in a Soviet scientific journal about that nation's space program written by V.S. Aveyevsky, a Russian expert on manufacturing in space and a winner of the Lenin Prize, stated that ''the idea of satellite electric power stations generating energy for consumers in space and on the ground has grown into one of the most fundamental space research programs.''
Japan's Space Activities Commission recommended in 1987 that Japan should endeavor to become an important participant in space activities by the beginning of the 21st century. The commission stated that to conduct space activities on a large scale, Japan should promote research and development into the efficient utilization of solar energy for the generation of electricity in space.
The space power systems capable of capturing and converting solar energy and then beaming that energy from orbit to a receiving site in space or on earth were studied by the Department of Energy and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in the late 1970's and early 1980's. At the time, these power systems were judged to be too expensive because of the high cost of transporting propellants, materials and space structures into orbit from earth.
Since Mr. Bush's recent speech, there appears to be an opportunity for the United States, and other nations, to develop a lunar base and the lunar resources necessary for large-scale projects like space-based power generating systems. The economic justification for using lunar resources instead of earth resources includes a significant reduction in transportation costs from the moon into an earth orbit, compared with launchings into orbit directly from the earth. Launching materials into an earth orbit from the moon would also alleviate the environmental impacts that would result from multiple earth launchings. THE development of space-based power systems will extend well into the next century. New systems will be needed to supply the power needs of space shuttles, free-flying platforms and space stations in high-earth orbits, and lunar bases. Development of space-based power sources, can - and should - begin with a modest test project to demonstrate the feasibility of new solar energy technologies to collect and beam power between objects in space and to the earth.
A cooperative international test project for space-based power systems provides a unique opportunity to advance this technology. Such a test project could lead to further cooperative efforts among nations that expect to benefit from space-generated power. International participation could also make it easier to obtain agreements on the use of orbits and the portions of the electromagnetic spectrum necessary to transmit energy to earth from space. A test program could also lead to an international consensus on the future course of space power development.
Based on activities already under way in several nations, a power generating program for space could form the basis for the development of space-based industries and support structures. An industrial infrastructure in space could help humanity meet its future energy needs without exacerbating the ecological deterioration resulting from global warming.
The significance of an international test project has been recognized and recommended as part of the activities for the International Space Year in 1992. It is now time for industry in the United States, in cooperation with NASA, to take the initiative and join with other nations in this test project. The rewards for joining in this project could be as vast as space itself and ultimately could conserve the resources and ecology of the earth.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEW IN PORK;
Pork That is Pinker and Purer Appeals to the Japanese

BYLINE: By DAMON WRIGHT

 BODY:
The Japanese don't like the pale, watery pink color Americans seem to prefer in pork. They like their meat to be deeper in color.
This may seem like a bit of trivia, but to American pork producers, it is of the utmost significance. Achieving a redder meat requires them to tinker with their standard chilling and packing techniques, which determine color. 
Considering such things as the growth of the Japanese's population and economy and its healthy appetite for pork, American hog producers view it as the export market with the greatest potential. Japan currently imports about 11.5 billion pounds, or 25 percent of the nearly 46 billion pounds of pork, measured by carcass weight, it consumes annually.
In an attempt to capture more market, Americans are doing everything in their power to appeal to Japanese tastes. Last year, American pig producers shipped less than 1 percent of their production to Japan, or 88 million pounds. That is a 100 percent increase over the year before. This year, they expect to export 1.1 billion pounds to the country, pushing up their share to about 10 percent of Japanese imports.
Most of America's gains have come at the expense of Taiwan, the major exporter of pork to Japan, whose share of the import market fell to about 60 percent in 1988. Taiwan lost position when it was unable to respond as quickly as the United States to demands by Japan for pork with lower levels of chemical residue. When Japan discovered in March 1988 that pork from both the United States and Taiwan contained sulfamethazine residues that exceeded the established tolerance level, it temporarily banned shipments from both countries until they tightened their inspection procedures. Sulfamethazine is an antibiotic feed additive used to keep hogs healthier, helping them reach the market more quickly.
While Taiwan was out of the Japanese market until late last fall, the United States was able to resume shipping almost immediately and take advantage of its rival's hiatus.
American producers had taken the offensive even before Taiwan's troubles. In an attempt to take advantage of the weak dollar, the Pork Council in October 1987 began an ''export initiative'' that includes trade missions to Japan to promote American pork directly to the country's consumers and grocers. Certain staff members of the United States Meat Export Federation, one of the primary promoters of American meats abroad, began to plan their lives around ''meat month'' in Japan.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEW IN PORK;
A Drive to Improve Products and Compete With the Price of Chicken

BYLINE: By DAMON WRIGHT

 BODY:
Three developments could profoundly reduce production costs and, in turn, consumer prices for pork:
* Introducing fecund Chinese pigs into this country's hog population could eventually increase litter sizes.
* The impending commercial availability of a breakthrough growth enhancer - porcine somatotropin - could speed the growth of individual hogs by up to 11 percent.
* And a new breeding philosophy called the all-in/all-out method could help move animals to market faster.
But these techniques may not yield widespread benefits any time soon because of Government precautions, an increasingly activist public and the limited means and entrenched attitudes of producers. 
It took 11 years of negotiations with the Chinese Government before Dr. Roger J. Gerrits, national program leader for animal production at the Agriculture Department's Agricultural Research Service, landed 140 rather odd-looking Chinese pigs on American soil this spring. And it will be at least five years more before these pigs are available for commercial breeding, as researchers at Iowa State University and the University of Illinois study the ramifications of introducing the new breeds into the general population.
American breeders have looked longingly at Chinese pigs because their litters are twice as big as the eight-piglet average of American breeds. Through either cross-breeding or genetic engineering, scientists hope to use the genes of the Chinese pigs to raise the average American litters by one or two piglets. Without the Chinese genes, it would take 25 generations of genetic selection to increase their size, Dr. Gerrits said.
While the hormone porcine somatotropin could be on the market in the early 1990's, the public could impede its widespread use. Witness the trouble the dairy industry experienced with bovine somatotropin. The drug has so far been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for only selected use. Yet in August, five major supermarket chains refused to carry milk from cows treated with the drug because of pressure from consumer groups.
The European Community has banned meat raised with any hormones. And some American hog producers fear that whence goes Europe, goes Japan, their biggest customer for pork.
Of the five companies preparing porcine somatotropin for market, four - Pitman-Moore, Upjohn, Monsanto and Smith Kline Beecham - have made a preemptive public relations bid. In late 1988, they formed a consortium to promote the safety of the drug, a point upon which Federal regulators seem to concur.
To create commercial quantities, the drug is cultured in the lab. And critics claim that the long-term effects of the slight molecular changes that result are unclear. What's more, production increases could lead to lower prices that would endanger small producers' already fragile profit margins and possibly drive them out of business, said John C. Stauber, an organizer for the Foundation on Economic Trends, a Washington-based group that studies the social and economic implications of agricultural biotechnology.
The all-in/all-out breeding method isn't controversial, but it requires farmers to completely reconfigure their breeding compounds - not to mention their way of thinking. That may prevent it from catching on.
Under customary rearing methods, pigs of all ages live together until each reaches a marketable weight of about 230 pounds. Piglets virtually enter the world at one end of the barn and exit for slaughter at the other. The process usually takes 205 days because piglets often pick up diseases from older hogs, wasting their feed to restore their health rather than to gain weight.
By protecting piglets from germs, the all-in/all-out method could trim 41 days off the process. Piglets born within the same week are housed separately until slaughter, according to Dr. L. Kirk Clark, president of the American Association of Swine Practitioners. The trouble is, farmers need to build several new pens. ''We've built all these capital structures based on poor health control methods,'' said Dr. Steve Henry, a veterinarian in Abilene, Kan.

HEADLINE: The Airlines Industry Is a High Flyer

BYLINE: BY ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
When America West Airlines, a midsize carrier based in Phoenix, sent recruiters to schools that train mechanics, it often ran into a problem. ''An outfit like Delta Airlines would come in a day ahead of us and hire the entire class,'' said Leroy Paulson, vice president for technical services.
America West has since arranged a program with a community college in Phoenix - alternating work on the job with study on campus - to help guarantee a supply of mechanics. ''As fast as they can advance, we promote them to the higher positions,'' Mr. Paulson said.
Fueled by a growing demand for air travel, the airline industry is rapidly expanding its fleets and hiring thousands more employees than in years past. In particular demand are pilots, flight attendants and mechanics. 
In fact, during the next decade prospects for all airline jobs are bright, industry experts say. ''It's boom time,'' said David A. Swierenga, assistant vice president for industry data at the Air Transport Association, a trade group based in Washington. ''The industry has been growing across the board.'' Today the airlines employ 480,000 workers, a 46 percent increase over 1978, Mr. Swierenga said.
And despite the irregular work hours and grueling itineraries that may include seven cities in one day, airline jobs are still considered ''glamour careers.'' The most prized perquisite is unlimited free air travel for all full-time employees, and often their families.
But the airline industry is also among the most vulnerable to an economic downturn. As recently as 1983 the airlines furloughed thousands of employees. Still, analysts say that the industry, which has consolidated into fewer carriers in recent years, is now better equipped to weather a recession. During the next recession, Mr. Swierenga said, ''We hope that we can keep the work force we have without laying anyone off.''
The demand for air travel has grown at a prodigious rate. In 1978 the airlines carried 250 million passengers; last year they carried nearly double that number, 450 million. During the next decade, the number of passengers is expected to grow at about 5 percent annually for domestic flights and 10 percent for international flights.
Perhaps the skills most in demand are those of the airplane mechanic, of which there are about 60,000 currently employed by airlines. As new Federal rules requiring extensive modifications to older jets take effect, the need for skilled mechanics has become more acute. ''The older the planes get, the more work they'll need,'' said James Conley, a spokesman for the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents most mechanics.
A recent survey by the Air Transport Association found 4,000 vacancies for mechanics among the nation's 21 largest carriers. ''There's a fairly serious shortage of qualified mechanics,'' said Louis Smith, president of the Future Aviation Professionals of America, a career-consulting firm in Atlanta. He forecasts openings for 50,000 mechanics in the next 10 years.
In particular demand are mechanics skilled in sheet metal, who repair cracks in aging planes, and those who work on cockpit electronics. In the next few years, the airlines will be required to install collision-avoidance and weather-detection devices on their fleets, which will require thousands of work hours.
The starting salary for mechanics, who must attend mechanics' school for two years, is about $27,000 annually, with top pay as high as $52,000. Because of the growing shortage, salaries have climbed about 10 percent in the last year.
Although the major airlines do most of their own repairs, some contract their work to the approximately 20 independent shops that can handle big jetliners. It's at these schools - and others that repair smaller planes -where the shortage is most severe. The annual attrition rate at these shops is as high as 50 percent, as workers move on to higher-paying airline jobs.
''We're barely able to maintain our work force,'' said William Thomas, president of Elsinore Aerospace, which owns a repair shop in Waco, Tex.
Some of the smaller shops that work on private planes are turning away customers because of the shortage. ''We're desperately advertising and we can't get people with two or three years' experience,'' said Frank Stephenson, president of Skytech, a repair shop in Baltimore.
Several airlines besides America West have formed alliances with colleges to help replenish the supply. American Airlines, the nation's largest, is considering opening a school in Chicago that would train 500 to 600 mechanics a year, said James Brown, a company spokesman.
Nearly as much in demand are airline pilots. The nation's airlines are rapidly expanding their fleets, with 1,500 airplanes on order. In addition 16,000 pilots, many of them trained during the Korean War, are expected to retire in the next decade. As a result, the airlines hired a record 10,000 pilots in the last year, according to the Future Aviation Professionals of America. The airlines have lowered some of their ''soft'' requirements for pilots. Until recently they hired only pilots under the age of 30 who had 20/20 vision and were at least 5 feet 6 inches tall. Today, pilots need not meet those criteria.
But experience levels remain high. Last year, pilots hired by the major airlines had an average of well over 3,000 hours of flight time. ''Airlines are still looking for quality-trained pilots,'' said Gennie Hall, manager of pilot development at Trans World Airlines. That airline, like several others, has opened a training school for pilots.
One reason is that the traditional source of pilots, the armed services, has begun to dry up. The Air Force and Navy are offering their pilots attractive bonuses to retain them, so today the airlines hire more pilots with a civilian background.
Most of the current crop of pilots start by learning to fly small planes and then ''building time,'' or logging flight hours as an instructor. The next step is usually a job with a smaller commuter airline. At some of these airlines, traditionally a steppingstone to a job with a major airline, annual turnover can be as high as 100 percent.
Salaries for pilots vary widely. A senior captain at Delta earns $166,000 a year, among the highest in the industry, while a captain at Continental Airlines earns $102,000. Starting salaries as a flight engineer, which is the job most airline pilots begin by filling, are about $20,000. Several years ago the industry adopted ''B scales,'' in which newly hired employees, even if they have equivalent experience, are paid at lower rates than veterans of the airline. At most airlines, the pay scales merge after five years. One result of the frenzied pilot hiring is quicker promotions. Pilots are currently promoted to captain, the highest rank, within 10 years at some airlines, while five years ago, the rule was that such rank would take 15 or 20 years to attain.
Demand for flight attendants is also high. Generally, the airlines hire two attendants for every one pilot hired. In the last two months alone, the nation's airlines hired 17,000 attendants. Their average starting pay is $15,000 annually, rising to a top of $39,000. Mainly because of the lower salaries and tiring working conditions, turnover is high.
Job prospects for computer reservation agents, gate agents and baggage handlers are also bright. As of last year the airlines employed 212,000 such workers, compared with 96,000 10 years ago. The jobs pay considerably lower than those for mechanics and even flight attendants, starting as low as $5 an hour.
