HEADLINE: Stagflation for Female Engineers

BYLINE: BY JOHN ARUNDEL

 BODY:
When Andrea Robertson began studying electrical engineering five years ago at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, she was usually the only woman in the lecture halls.
As she prepares to graduate, few things have changed. ''I still have classes where I'm not only the only woman but I'm the only black,'' said Miss Robertson, 21, a National Merit Scholar whose father, a safety engineer, was her role model. ''But that's an incentive to do well so that others can take my place.'' 
Miss Robertson's optimism is rare. Among America's 2.4 million working engineers only 4 percent are women. And while the percentage of undergraduate women in the nation's 281 engineering schools is four times that, at 16 percent, and the number of women entering those schools has increased 12 percent since 1973, figures from the National Science Foundation show a steady decline since the early 1980's.
''Women traditionally haven't been attracted to engineering,'' said Sue Kemnitzer, executive director of the Congressional Task Force on Women, Minorities and the Handicapped in Science and Technology.
Like other traditions, this one is proving difficult to break.
''We shortchange them by not setting high expectations for them in the workplace and by throwing up barriers in promotion and progression,'' Ms. Kemnitzer said. Upon graduating, some women engineers earn better starting pay than their male classmates but end up losing the salary competition several years later. ''The gap between men's and women's salaries widens each year,'' said Ms. Kemnitzer. ''This must have some negative feedback for women in school who are planning their own careers.''
While about 95 percent of the women who graduate with degrees in engineering choose to stay in that field, a growing number have been discouraged and have instead chosen to pursue careers in business, banking and the law.
The outlook is often just as bleak for promotions. ''There is a wide feeling that a male and a female's career will parallel for three or four years,'' said B. J. Harrod, acting executive director of the Society of Women Engineers, a New York-based organization with 14,500 members. ''But then the woman will find a glass ceiling in which her progress is stifled while the man's career continues to grow.''
Some women, however, do not find this to be the case. ''I probably was promoted a little faster than others,'' said Deborah Bales, 36, the manager of industrial engineering at Disneyland and president of the Southern California branch of the Society of Women Engineers. ''I was the first female engineer at Disneyland and while they were cautious at first, I personally have not run into much resistance to my being a woman in this position.''
Because only 3 percent of the nation's engineering faculty members are women, many say that female students lack role models. ''One problem women share with minorities is there are so few role models,'' said Ronnie Denes, vice president of the National Action Council for Minorities in Engineering, a private group based in Washington, D.C.
Miss Robertson at SUNY and a generation of other female engineering students hope to fill this leadership gap. As a volunteer tutor at junior high schools on Long Island, she is working to dispel a myth among teen-agers that one must be male to be an engineer.
''There's an image problem that starts on the high school level,'' said Christine Shoemaker, a professor of civil and environmental engineering at Cornell University. ''To study engineering means you have to commit yourself to the career at a very young age. Whereas men are usually ready to make that commitment early on, many girls are not.'' Congress is currently considering a bill proposed by Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, and Representative Doug Walgren, Democrat of Pennsylvania, that would provide Federal funds for two engineering scholarships for every Congressional district. The two-year, $10,000 awards would be given each year to 876 sophomore engineers, one man and one woman, based on academic achievement.
 
An interim report, ''Changing
America: The New Face of Science and Engineering,'' released last year by Ms. Kemnitzer's task force, predicted dire economic consequences for the U.S. economy if engineering schools failed to attract the growing ranks of women and minorities joining the work force. ''With foreign competition gobbling up the high-tech markets we can't afford to waste any talent,'' Ms. Denes said.
Among the report's findings were that American leadership in engineering cannot be maintained unless the ''education pipeline'' from prekindergarten through graduate school is repaired. It also reported that racism, sexism and prejudice against the disabled was narrowing access to careers in engineering and that universities were not enrolling enough students in the field of study.
The report's 15 recommendations encouraged action by industry, the Federal Government, local school boards and universities. It called for scholar-incentive programs, more summer internships and increased recruitment at engineering schools. It also called on the entertainment industry to portray engineers in television programs and films as more dashing and less as narrowly focused drones with little character.
Women who leave engineering to start families find when they return that the technology has changed so dramatically that the transition back into the work force is made easier if they return to school for a master's degree or doctorate.
But the number of women choosing this option is still marginal. In 1987 less than 12 percent of graduate engineering students were women, a 1 percent decrease from the year before, according to figures from the National Science Foundation.
''The number of women we have in our graduate school is trivial,'' said Ruth Erbar, a professor of mechanical engineering at Oklahoma State University. ''The salaries being offered to our women B.S. graduates are so high that it would take an enormous economic incentive to stay for graduate school.''
Other roadblocks for women persist as well. A chronic shortage of American professors in the last decade has led many engineering schools to hire legions of foreign-born professors, many of whom come to this country with negative attitudes toward women that stem from their cultural backgrounds.
''Women don't find themselves easily embraced when so much of the faculty is foreign-born,'' Ms. Denes said. ''The prejudices against women as achievers in the math and science-based fields are ingrained into these professors because they come from countries where women's talents in these areas are not solicited.''

HEADLINE: If Your Line Is Cellular, Give a Ring

BYLINE: BY CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
After Shayna Felts, a computer-science and engineering major, graduated last spring from Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., she did not have to look hard for a job. Ms. Felts, 22 years old, was recruited by Bell Laboratories, the research and development arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, to write software for high-level computers.
The overall employment rate remains slow in the telecommunications industry, which is downsizing and recovering from worker strikes. But A.T.&T. and other telephone companies are actively recruiting recent science and liberal arts graduates to work as network planners, technical operations personnel, engineers and sales and marketing representatives.
The major career opportunities are in the mobile cellular telephone sector, which has shown explosive growth in the last year. Most positions are at the entry level, and telephone companies are planning major recruitment drives this fall on college campuses. 
''It has not been the best year for the telecommunications professional looking for a job, but there are jobs out there, especially for technical experts,'' said Jay Jacobson, president of Personnel Resources International Inc., a telecommunications recruiting firm. Although opportunities have been sluggish in the equipment and vendor-service sectors, Mr. Jacobson remains bullish on the long-range outlook for the telephone expert.
The telephone companies are not alone in their work-force demands. With the telephone playing an ever-larger role in the way people conduct business, large corporations, as well as the Federal Government and state governments that operate their own telephone systems, are looking for qualified technical and design personnel to manage their private networks.
Applicants should have a good understanding of telecommunications technology, communications skills and a broad understanding of economics and business.
''There is a big difference between what you learn in the classroom and how you apply it.'' said Ms. Felts, who turned down opportunities with Exxon and Salomon Brothers to take advantage of Bell Labs's graduate education program. ''I have learned so much about the application of technology to real-life situations.''
Business is booming in the long-distance segment as rates for calls continue to drop and demand grows for services like toll-free 800 numbers, computer-data lines, facsimile transmission, international calling and private telephone networks.
Industry analysts expect the market to grow at double-digit rates for the next five years.
However, telephone companies have installed a variety of automated and digital technologies in their networks that have eliminated a large number of lower-level positions.
Providers of cellular service are expanding their networks, installing digital technology to accommodate the expected growth in subscribers. That has created a continually growing need for people in the technical as well as marketing and administrative areas.
Most in demand are people experienced with paging, trunking and cellular systems, according to Mr. Jacobson, who said that employers were seeking installers, repairers, engineers and service managers. The demand is mainly in major metropolitan areas but cellular providers in medium-size markets are also looking for qualified people, he added.
''The market is expanding so rapidly that we have a dire need for design engineers and technical people in radio frequency who can deal with congestion problems from the increase in cellular phone traffic,'' said Mark A. Hickey, director of human resources for Pacific Telesis Group, the regional Bell phone company that serves the West Coast and owns the Pactel Corporation, one of the biggest players in the cellular industry.
Mr. Hickey said that a college degree was not a major requirement for employment in the cellular industry. More important, he said, is ''a good understanding of the workings of the technology,'' which applies to those seeking jobs in any specialty.
A cellular system transmits telephone calls on radio frequencies and relays the calls over telephone wires. Each service area is divided into cells - hence the name cellular - of up to 16 miles across. As a car moves from one place to another the phone conversation is handed off from one cell to another.
The best employment opportunities are in densely populated cities like New York, Los Angeles, Dallas, Chicago, Houston and Phildelphia, where demand for mobile phone service is greatest.
A.T.&T., the nation's largest long-distance carrier, expects to hire about 2,000 college graduates in the next year, mainly in the engineering and technical fields. Howard Burlingame, A.T.&T.'s director of human resources, said that although the giant telephone company had been consolidating its operations since it spun off the regional Bell phone companies in 1984, it was still looking for product managers, systems and software engineers, sales and marketing people. Since divestiture, A.T.&T. has reduced its work force to 300,000, from 370,000.
''We are looking for good academic records, demonstrated leadership and analytical skills, the capacity to understand business situations and the ability to connect with a group of customers and understand their needs,'' Mr. Burlingame said.
A large number of A.T.&T.'s new hires will come from engineering and computer-related areas and will be assigned to its Bell Labs research division and other technical operations. But some of the new employees are expected to have liberal arts and business backgrounds and be assigned to marketing and sales. ''Liberal arts people,'' Mr. Burlingame said, ''are open to new approaches and new solutions and they have a deeper appreciation for communicating with people. We need these skills in our company.''
A.T.&T. continues to hire holders of master's degrees in business administration for corporate planning and other management functions. As the company expands overseas, opportunities are particularly good for those who specialize in the international arena.
At the MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier, recruiters plan to visit about 50 college campuses in the next year to fill about 200 entry-level positions in engineering, computers and other technical areas. These hires will be rotated throughout the company, serving in a variety of technical capacities like network, research and development, systems and customer accounts.
MCI, based in Washington, D.C., plans to hire 250 more employees in nontechnical areas such as sales, marketing and corporate development. John H. Zimmerman, MCI's senior vice president for human resources, said that while the company was looking for liberal arts majors with experience for these positions, it was also hiring at the entry level. A.T.&T. and MCI said they were making a special effort to hire women and minority-group members.
Although most of the nation's seven regional Bell phone companies are reducing their operations, several will be recruiting on college campuses this year for management and network training programs.
Average salaries for entry-level people in the telecommunications industry are $25,000 to $30,000 for liberal arts and technical graduates. M.B.A.'s start at about $35,000.

HEADLINE: In 1990's, What Price Scarce Labor?

BYLINE: BY SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
Workers in the 1990's will have one advantage they have lacked for nearly 25 years: scarcity. This shortage will have profound implications for both managers and employees into the 21st century, economists and labor experts say.
The flood of baby-boomers that have entered the labor market since the mid-1960's will slow to a trickle because of lower birthrates. According to projections by the Census Bureau, next year the number of 18-year-olds will drop by 8 percent and will not reach the levels of 1989 until 2003. As a result, companies will be forced to reach out to inner-city minority and immigrant neighborhoods, to older workers, part-time workers and women with young children, offering lures such as day care and flexible hours. Many of these new employees will be unskilled, requiring companies to train them and turning cities and regions that can boast well-educated workers into meccas for business.
A shortage of adequately trained entry-level employees is but one of several trends that will shape job opportunities and management strategies in the coming decade:
 
* Industries that need well-educated workers capable of making independent decisions will continue to expand, increasing the pressure on schools to educate students better and on supervisors to change an authoritative management style to one that encourages teamwork and initiative.
* Entry-level jobs will demand workers with new skills - because even simple clerical work now requires computer knowledge, bank tellers need more knowledge of financial transactions and sales techniques, and foreign competition means that assembly-line workers need more sophisticated understanding of mathematics and computer-aided manufacturing to cut costs and improve quality.
* Fast-improving telecommunications and computer technologies enable businesses to move crucial staff members to less expensive locations, intensifying regional and international competition.
* Information technology, once the exclusive purview of systems managers, must now be an integral part of corporate strategy, requiring extensive training of senior executives and providing more opportunity for the computer-literate.
* The nation's elderly population will grow, but the largest population increase will be in middle-aged and mid-career Americans - the baby-boom generation.
Economists looking to the 1990's labor force say these trends offer clear guidelines for job seekers. According to Howard Fullerton, a demographic statistician with the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, the five fastest-growing industries from now until the year 2000 will be computer and data-processing services, health services and outpatient facilities, personnel services such as temporary agencies, health practitioners and miscellaneous business services such as credit reporting.
Other fast-growing jobs include paralegals, medical assistants, physical therapists, data-processing equipment repairmen, home health aides, podiatrists and computer systems analysts. It is clear, too, Mr. Fullerton said, that there will be an acute shortage of nurses.
All these openings are in service industries, underlining the historic shift away from manufacturing. Manufacturing has enjoyed a rebound in many parts of the country, but economists say it is unlikely to regain its position as the dominant employer in the United States. Last year, for the first time, service jobs outnumbered manufacturing jobs in the United States, according to Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional Commissioner of Labor Statistics for the New York area. Service industries also reflect the continuing explosive demand for computer expertise, the boom in health care as the population ages and an anticipated labor shortage that increases demand for companies that find workers, such as temporary-employment, or ''temp'' agencies.
The SERVICE industry will offer not only the fastest pace of job growth but also the greatest number of job openings. Specifically the most job openings, a projected 1.2 million, will be for retail sales workers, followed by waiters and waitresses, registered nurses, janitors and cleaners, general managers and cashiers.
More broadly, said Audrey Freedman, an economist at the Conference Board, a business-research organization in New York, the best opportunities, and the greatest demand, will be for jobs that require independent thinking and skills of at least high school level. Even entry-level jobs that used to employ relatively unskilled workers are becoming more demanding, Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
The problem, he and Ms. Freedman agreed, is that these skills are not being taught well enough in schools and that many children are not learning them at home either.
''These jobs require reasoning and logical ability, self-control and the ability to diagnose and take action,'' Ms. Freedman said. ''All these are what people learn when they are very young, as part of family background and how you were raised. This is one area where we're not so sure that children are doing well.''
Jobs that used to absorb large numbers of relatively unskilled workers are being lost as industries decline or companies move some of these jobs overseas to countries with lower wages. The Bureau of Labor Statistics predicts that the biggest drop in job openings will be for electronic assemblers and electronic semiconductor processors, as more companies automate these jobs or subcontract them abroad. Other big drops will be in installers of telephone stations, metal and mining work, leather-products manufacturing and blast-furnace and steel-foundry operators.
Educational requirements are rising in a broad range of jobs, Mr. Ehrenhalt said. ''Those who remain as tellers are being upgraded. They now are being seen as the primary sales force of the banking industry. A bank vice president told me that five years ago he hired 297 high school graduates and 3 college graduates, but in May he hired 150 college graduates and 150 high school graduates.''
Certain kinds of entry-level jobs that used to be steppingstones are being eliminated or transformed by automation. ''What does this do for the prospects of young black women, for whom clerical work was a prime avenue for middle-class jobs and status?'' Mr. Ehrenhalt said. ''The largest group coming in is the one with the most educational deficiencies.''
White non-Hispanics will still dominate the labor force and provide two-thirds of new entrants from now to the year 2,000, Mr. Fullerton said. But at the same time other white non-Hispanics will be retiring from the labor force, reducing their numbers by 5 or 6 percent, and the number of minorities will increase. As a result, for the first time more than half the net growth in the labor force will be from minority groups.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics projects that the labor force will increase over all by 17.8 percent between now and the year 2000. Hispanics will increase by 74.4 percent, Asians and other minorities by 71.2 percent and blacks by 28.8 percent. While many members of these groups have managed to acquire needed skills and move to successful careers, dropout rates are high and English ability low for many others, particularly low-income inner-city residents.
The labor shortage that demographers predict for the 1990's will largely be for entry-level and junior positions, because the large baby-boom population is moving into mid-career and senior positions. This shortage means that companies will have to reach out to groups, and cope with problems, that they could overlook when they had more applicants than jobs.
''During the 1970's,'' Ms. Freedman said, ''corporations saw waves and waves of young people. With such an abundance of new entrants they could be very, very selective. So they selected white young men. Now for every 10 jobs there may be eight applicants; four are women and three are immigrants, and the three are young men, only two of whom are white, and one may take drugs. This shortage of white young men is going to cause companies to discover there are other kinds of people than the kinds their conventional wisdom has directed them toward, and probably will change the way they evaluate and develop people.''
Some corporations have already begun working to improve public education, ''adopting'' schools and sending employees to work with students. Most are enlarging their own training programs to compensate for the gap in worker skills. They are having to reach out to young mothers, offering day-care incentives, and to recruit elderly workers.
The trends spell job opportunities for corporate trainers, human-resources personnel and temporary agencies that supply skilled labor or clerical help.
Along WITH intensifying foreign competition and continued technological advances, these developments emphasize the continuing need for computer literacy among senior managers, and those who want to advance to such positions. According to a five-year management study conducted by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management, managers in the 1990's will have to integrate information technology into all facets of their businesses.
This means job opportunities will increase in computer and data-processing services, the fastest-growing source of employment between now and the year 2000 projected by the Bureau of Labor Services. Consulting services in research management will also rank in the top 10, the bureau found.
All the trends that will shape the 1990's - a job-skills gap, the predominance of service- and knowledge-intensive industries, the boom in health care services, the increasing importance of global competition -have been true in the New York region in the last decade, and will intensify in the next one, Mr. Ehrenhalt said. He predicts that this will increase competition between regions, and with other countries, as corporations move to areas with the best work force.

HEADLINE: REMEDIAL WORK;
Paying Attention To the Schools Is a National Mission Now

BYLINE: By EDWARD B. FISKE

DATELINE: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.

 BODY:
MANY educators and state officials feared that President Bush's ''edu-cation summit'' last week at the University of Virginia would be little more than an extended photo opportunity for the man who has vowed to be ''the education President.'' But afterward, there was growing agreement among the experts that something more substantive had occurred.
''It was a historic event,'' said Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. ''The President and the governors acknowledged the national interest in education in a dramatic fashion. What they said and did will shape public schooling in America for years to come.''
Not everyone was as sanguine as Mr. Boyer. But there was remarkably little demand from the governors for a significant increase in Federal spending on education. (Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York was a notable exception.) And praise came from education experts, a group that had initially been critical, largely because of Mr. Bush's decision to exclude educators from the conference. The meeting was, after all, less to shape school reform than to gauge the political climate for such change. 
The bipartisan goodwill did conceal a disagreement over whether the Federal Government should assume more responsibility for nutritional and other programs that are supposed to assure that poorer children arrive at the schoolhouse door with unimpaired learning abilities. In the end, Mr. Bush made a commitment to ''more Federal support'' for preschool programs like Head Start.
The most notable product of the two-day meeting was an agreement between the President and the state leaders to work together to improve schools. ''This is the first time in the history of this country that we have ever thought enough of education to commit ourselves to national performance goals,'' said Gov. Bill Clinton, the Arkansas Democrat who was an architect of the agreement.
American education has always been viewed as a state responsibility and a local enterprise. Talk of a ''national curriculum'' has been tantamount to embracing Communism.
 
Soaring Concern
But in the face of competitive pressures of the global economy and of a national prosperity becoming increasingly dependent on the management of information, the concern over how well states and local school boards perform has soared.
Alarms have been sounded before, each broader than the last. Thirty years ago, the Soviet Union's surprise launching of the first satellite frightened Washington into increasing support for math and science education. And six years ago, the National Commission on Excellence in Education issued a report called ''A Nation at Risk.'' It deplored the ''rising tide of mediocrity'' in the schools and called for tougher high school graduation requirements, more core academic courses, higher teacher salaries and other measures.
Now the President and the governors say that something more, and different, is needed. ''We share the view that simply more of the same will not achieve the results we need,'' their agreement declared. ''We must find ways to deploy the resources more effectively.'' Or as Mr. Bush stated, ''The American people are ready for radical reforms.''
To begin with, the meeting pushed for ''national education goals'' that address dropout rates, adult literacy, teacher quality, drugs and the physical readiness of kindergartners to learn. The governors and the White House hope to have a list ready for the National Governors Association's meeting in February.
Listing goals is easy enough. Much more important, the agreement calls for ''annual report cards'' not only on students and schools but also on the actions of states and the Federal Government. Mr. Bush and the governors have thus not only made some promises but propose to give critics a tool for judging whether they keep them.
Other new directions take the form of what Mr. Bush and the governors called the need to ''restructure education.'' Such changes, many of which are already in place in some school districts, include:
* Decentralized management of schools. Local school boards in Miami and other cities have given individual schools more control over budgets, staffing and other decisions. Chicago is now carrying out a plan that will transfer power from the central education board to parent-led councils.
* Parental choice. Some school systems like District 4 in East Harlem let parents select the school their child will attend. Political conservatives like the idea because it introduces competition into the education, but many liberals and educators argue that it could lead to increased racial imbalance in some urban school systems.
* New routes into teaching. New Jersey pioneered a program to provide teacher certification to college graduates who do not have education degrees, and other states have followed its lead. The idea has drawn fire from some teachers' unions, but many politicians and educators see it as a way to bring new blood into the classroom.
* Accountability. Teachers and school administrators are currently judged not on how much students learn but on the extent to which they comply with legislative and school board regulations. A movement is under way to base such evaluations on academic results, as in a plan now being developed in Vermont.
One of the first results of the governors' meeting is expected to be a plan to make existing Federal education programs more flexible by giving local officials a measure of discretion in carrying them out. Currently, the conference agreement noted, computers purchased under the Chapter I program for disadvantaged students cannot be used in the evening for adult education.
Recognizing the tensions over the issue of Federal spending, Mr. Bush emphasized in his speech at the conference that ''our goals must be 'national' not 'Federal.' '' But if the governors were willing to let money matters rest for now, it was at least partly because Washington accounts for less than 7 percent of spending on public education. So a marginal increase in Federal financing next year would hardly be noticed.
''We're here for the long haul,'' said Governor Clinton. ''If we can demonstrate the urgency of the issue, set some goals and get the President and the governors to accept responsibility for meeting them, then I sincerely believe the money that is needed will begin to flow.''
 
HIGH HOPES IN CHARLOTTESVILLE
Here are excerpts from remarks made on Thursday at the national education conference.
No modern nation can long afford to allow so many of its sons and daughters to emerge into adulthood ignorant and unskilled. The status quo is a guarantee of mediocrity, social decay and national decline.
To those who say that money alone is the answer, I say that there is no one answer. If anything, hard experience teaches that we are simply not getting our money's worth in education. Our focus must no longer be on resources. It must be on results. - President Bush
This is the first time, ever, any group of public officials have ever committed themselves to a national effort to restructure the schools of the United States - something every educator who studied it says is the single most significant thing we could do.
And this is the first time a President and governors have ever stood before the American people and said, not only are we going to set national performance goals, which are ambitious, not only are we going to develop strategies to achieve them, but we stand here before you and tell you we expect to be held personally accountable for the progress we make in moving this country to a brighter future. - Gov. Bill Clinton, Democrat of Arkansas
I think one of the reasons that we're all so excited about the results of the last two days is that the report addresses the financial role of the Federal Government in education, albeit in a limited role, but an extremely important role. And the understanding is that the money that becomes available will be applied to the issue of early childhood education and Head Start and preparing young people for the day that they enter school. - Gov. Booth Gardner, Democrat of Washington

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: A Voice From Bogota;
War on Drugs, for Real, With Casualties

BYLINE: By ENRIQUE SANTOS CALDERON; Enrique Santos Calderon is a columnist for El Tiempo, a newspaper in Bogota.

DATELINE: BOGOTA

 BODY:
HOW can I describe what a journalist in Colombia thinks and feels in these times? How can I explain the fear, the rage, the frustration that engulf journalists every time they sit down in front of their computer screens to perform the professional ritual of commenting on a situation that floods Colombians every day with surreal brutality?
The fear is urgent and palpable; it rises like the roar of an assassin's motorcycle, approaching from behind as you wait in your car for a light to turn green. At its heart, it is a fear born of knowledge that death is stalking our profession so closely; it strikes home each time someone is shot down in the streets or a bomb rips into a newspaper building.
The rage is at a cowardly dictatorship of intimidation, bloody and implacable in its quest to silence the press as the public's conscience. When the drug traffickers murder a judge or a policeman, they have a specific purpose - to stop a legal proceeding or to get rid of an individual who stands in their way. When they kill a journalist, they are trying to eliminate the symbolic voice of the community itself. 
And the frustration rises with the growing certainty that so many deaths and heroic acts of defiance may be for nothing. The blood is being spilled in a war whose outcome ultimately doesn't depend on what happens in our own country or on the courage of honest Colombians.
The frustration comes from knowing that now more than ever before Colombia may be in danger of losing its institutions, its democratic tradition and its best people, and that the drug traffic will continue - as long as a gram of cocaine continues to cost $5 here, $60 in Miami and $100 in Paris. As long as millions of avid customers in the United States and Europe are willing to pay those prices. Those elements of the problem originate and survive outside the borders of Colombia, a country that has already accepted a disproportionate share of sacrifice.
But even if the conditions are not the most favorable, there are wars that must be fought for a nation's dignity and the survival of its system of government. The assassination of the presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan was the drop that made the cup overflow, the final provocation that forced the Colombian Government to order a total offensive. And it appears to have given President Bush added inspiration in declaring his own offensive - another war against drugs, recalling those declared by Presidents Johnson and Nixon, Carter and Reagan.
By chance, I was in the United States three years ago when President Reagan announced the war against drugs that was to be fought inside his country's borders. I was enthusiastic about this first explicit acknowledgment that the battle would have to begin in the streets and neighborhoods of his own country before it could be fought in the cities and jungles of Colombia. I remember well the splash this change of strategy made in the press and the impact it had on the public. It was Congressional election time.
But it turned out to be more words than deeds. The supposed anti-drug campaign slackened and the crack gangs grew stronger. The domestic front that Mr. Reagan opened in the international war against drugs didn't withstand the enemy's attack.
And now comes the Bush strategy. Colombian television broadcast his speech live, with simultaneous translation. I listened to it, as the whole country did, in the midst of a bombing campaign in the very real war that had broken out here. In addition to skepticism, I felt anger and frustration. Even though it offers more coordination, more will to fight and more indignation than previous strategies did, it is full of inconsistencies and weaknesses that make me fear that the United States is entering - and sending its allies into - another swamp with no way out.
How serious can a war be if it doesn't cost one penny more in taxes? How can a war against drugs be financed by taking away funds from social programs that fight poverty? What real help is being sent to the fronts where the drugs are produced - Colombia, Peru, Bolivia - when the $260 million Mr. Bush has requested represents not even 4 percent of the projected total cost of the war? It is less than the United States spends each year on El Salvador, and it is less than half the cost of one Stealth bomber.
Certainly this is a military war, but first and foremost it is an economic one. And it will be hard to have any success as long as the United States holds to commercial policies that sap the legal economies of those countries. Colombia is to receive more than $100 million in new anti-drug assistance. But it will lose $500 million each year because of the United States-inspired dissolution of an international coffee agreement.
The result of such policies will be to block expansion in the Andean countries of the cultivation of legitimate crops for the American market.
According to William Bennett, the objective of the Bush plan is to cut in half the number of drug users in the United States in 10 years. If the plan works, in other words, within 10 years only half the market will remain. Or as a Colombian journalist in exile, Antonio Caballero, has said, ''Only half the bloodletting will remain.'' And the Colombian mafias, with only half of their resources, will be killing only half the number of judges, policemen and journalists that they kill today.
If that is the case, if the outlook is for us to become simple guinea pigs in an underfinanced low-intensity war against the international drug cartel, it would be better to think about other alternatives: legalizing cocaine, for example, or forgetting about this war and instead launching a Marshall Plan, which is what we really need.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In Europe, East Prevails Upon West

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: BRUSSELS

 BODY:
NEARLY 50 years after the Western democracies lost Eastern Europe to Communism, they are beginning to see how they can help Poland and Hungary find a way back. What they lack, diplomats here say, is an overall strategy for the effort, one that will probably require leadership from the United States.
Last week, the industrial democracies appeared to have ended the debate about whether it was in their interest to encourage change in Eastern Europe, and they showed the first signs of willingness to provide at least some of what it will take: many billions of dollars.
The Western debate about Eastern Europe is easier to resolve than the argument about what the West should or could do to help Mikhail S. Gorbachev to change the Soviet system. The Western Europeans, led by the West Germans, have been arguing for months that the problems of Hungary and Poland are less intractable, and they have been waiting for the United States to declare forcefully where its interest lies. 
After weeks of pressure from Congress and the allies, President Bush signaled last week that he had come down on the side of doing more, though how much more was not clear. Mr. Bush was more tentative when he visited Poland and Hungary last summer, but now that a new Polish Government led by Solidarity has promised to dismantle the Communist centralized economy, he said the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank should provide money and advice.
''The United States intends to be out in front of this effort,'' Mr. Bush told a joint meeting of the two bodies Wednesday.
But Poland's needs - emergency food shipments, credits, interest payments on its $39 billion debt, renovation of obsolete industrial plants - are so enormous that Warsaw has hesitated to put a price tag on them, lest it scare off potential donors. From what Polish officials said in Brussels and Washington last week, $2.5 billion for next year alone sounds like a conservative estimate.
Hungary's needs are not so acute, but it has even more ambitious plans to wipe out the effects of 40 years of Communist domination.
Outlining blueprints to do that last week, both Hungary and Poland convinced Western governments that aid would not be money down the drain, as it was in the 1970's. But they will need not only money but also bankers, computer technicians, plant managers and retailers to help them rebuild economic mechanisms and instincts that the Communists tried to eradicate for four decades.
Discussions among the industrial democracies about how to help have been fragmented. The economic summit meetings that bring together Japan, Canada, the United States and the Western European powers are held only once a year. The I.M.F. and World Bank are in Washington. The European Community is short of expertise on Eastern Europe, but it was asked by participants in the economic summit in July to coordinate aid from the 24 countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
Last week the community's executive commission made its proposals, suggesting that the 24 come up with $660 million in aid for 1990. The enthusiastic response made it clear that most of them thought this was a good start, but only that. The biggest potential donors - West Germany, the United States and Japan - did not say how much more they would provide.
The United States has held back, NATO diplomats in Brussels say, to encourage Europeans to take the initiative. But now that they seem ready to act, these diplomats say, the United States should take the lead.
The full implications of change in the East are complex. Should the European Community broaden its plans for economic unification in 1992? Even more troublesome, if the Warsaw Pact withers away, is there any need for NATO? Some diplomats are alarmed by statements like one made last week by the West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, in an interview with the newsmagazine Der Spiegel: ''Do we really want to acquire new nuclear rockets that can reach the Poland of Lech Walesa and democratic developments, or the Hungary of humaneness and democratization?''
In the Vienna talks now under way, both sides could well agree to reduce conventional forces. Even so, some NATO experts believe, both the Western alliance and the Warsaw Pact will be needed to insure compliance. And, just as Greece and Turkey and inhibited from armed hostilities because both belong to NATO, the world might be more comfortable with Hungary and Rumania both in the Warsaw Pact rather than outside it.
Bonn has its own agenda in Eastern Europe, focused on East Germany and the possibility of unification. Until recently, its pleas for a joint allied strategy fell on deaf ears.
But now, President Bush has sent a signal, and the European Community has made a start. Perhaps new international institutions, bold and large scale like those that helped Western Europe recover from the war, are needed to help Poland and Hungary show the East a way out of the ashes. Europe has not been such an exciting place in years, but much of the excitement is in the unknown.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Midwest Tries to Slow The Flow of Eastern Trash

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
EACH week, the trucks roll westward and southward from New Jersey, New York and, to a lesser extent, Connecticut, filled to overflowing with one of the East Coast's rising new exports. It is garbage, tons and tons of unsorted household refuse and miscellaneous municipal waste, stuffed into semi-trailers and headed for landfills in western Pennsylvania and elsewhere.
As communities in the Northeast run out of disposal space, there has been a rush to find dumps in other states, where private landfill operators are willing to sell off some unused capacity. The Environmental Protection Agency estimates that New Jersey, which has strict dumping rules, now exports nearly half of its solid waste to other states. Many New Jersey towns and counties say it is less expensive to truck a ton of garbage 400 miles to Ohio, where dump fees are only a fraction of what they are in the East, than it is to bury it in one of the state's few remaining landfills. 
But in the Midwest and elsewhere - Kentucky and West Virginia are also net importers of trash - this unexpected boom in garbage imports is provoking outrage and giving rise to a new kind of economic and environmental protectionism. Alarmed that they are losing landfill space for their own needs, state officials and environmental groups are calling for tougher regulations to halt or at least reduce the flow of out-of-state garbage.
According to the National Solid Wastes Management Association, the trade group for haulers, landfill operators and other private waste disposal companies, 33 states have considered or enacted legislation in recent years that is intended to exclude, limit or more closely regulate imports of municipal and hazardous wastes.
Most common are measures that would allow counties to restrict disposal of trash from outside their area. In addition, Ohio and several other states are pushing Congress to exert more control over growing garbage shipments across state lines. One proposal would allow states to levy a $40 a ton tax on imported garbage.
Currently, states are powerless to impose tariffs or special taxes on imports of garbage. As a result of a 1976 United States Supreme Court case, in which New Jersey sought unsuccessfully to turn back garbage being shipped into the state from Philadelphia, garbage is regarded as a commodity in interstate commerce, not unlike television sets and automobiles.
Richard Sahli, chairman of Ohio's Solid Waste Management Advisory Council, a state agency, said that the states are having a difficult time managing their own growing waste problems, and need to be able to limit the amount of garbage coming from elsewhere.
''We can't handle New Jersey's problems and still plan rationally for own solid waste needs,'' he said.
Since 1971, Mr. Sahli said, the number of landfills in Ohio has declined, from 360 to 172. By 1991, he said, the state will have fewer than 130, as the dumps fill to capacity and are forced to close. Meanwhile, Ohio imported 2.4 million tons of garbage in 1988, twice the volume of 1987. Of that, 1.5 million tons came from New Jersey, with the rest coming from several other states.
It is not only the Eastern states that export garbage. Haulers in the St. Louis area, for example, transport about two thirds of their trash, or nearly 1.1 million tons a year, across the Mississippi River to landfills in Illinois.
The waste managment industry tends to oppose efforts to block interstate trash shipments. Allen Moore, president of the National Solid Wastes Management Association, said that efforts to restrict interstate garbage shipments could be counterproductive. ''There is a lot of anger out there and it is understandable, but I believe this is really just a temporary phenomenon,'' he said. ''What we really need to do is think more broadly.'' New Jersey officials say they hope that by 1992 their strategy of recycling or incinerating more trash will sharply reduce the amount of exported solid waste. Richard Fulton, a spokesman for the state's Department of Environmental Protection, said he sympathized with Ohio officials. ''Morally, it is an unfair burden to place on another state,'' said Mr. Fulton. But that is little solace for people in Ohio or Michigan, who watch a steady stream of trucks with New York and New Jersey license plates hauling garbage to local landfills.
''They go through all the trouble of siting a new landfill, or working out a recycling program, and they think they have done themselves a favor,'' said Bruce Weddle, the director of the E.P.A.'s municipal solid waste program. ''Instead, they wake up one day and find they did New Jersey a favor.''

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
How Much Does New Jersey Really Like Republicans?

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
ON a recent visit to New Jersey, President Bush portrayed the race for governor as a referendum not only on eight years of Republican leadership in Trenton, but on the national party's values and policies in the 1980's. Calling the New Jersey election ''crucial,'' Mr. Bush said, ''This election will decide whether New Jersey continues to have the kind of leadership which balances a sound economy and sound ecology, and whether its leadership says 'no' to higher taxes and 'yes' to extending the prosperity of the last eight years.''
The Republican nominee for governor, Representative Jim Courter, picked up the President's theme, saying, ''If you liked Michael Dukakis, you'll love Jim Florio.''
At least that was the battle plan. But by last week politicians in both parties were saying that unless Mr. Courter runs a far more successful campaign in the next five weeks, an electorate that gave Mr. Bush a 57 percent majority in the state last year could turn the governorship over to a Democrat. Mr. Courter's opponent, Representative James J. Florio, an eight-term Democrat from southern New Jersey, and other Democrats seized on the President's remarks, saying they welcomed the chance to make the race a nationally watched referendum. 
''My friends in Congress are saying to me, 'Go to it, now you are carrying the ball for all of us,' '' Mr. Florio said last week.
He asserted that Republican strategists have taken too simplistic a view of why they have dominated New Jersey elections in the 1980's. While President Ronald Reagan and Gov. Thomas H. Kean were in office and New Jersey's economy boomed, Mr. Florio said, voters' anxiety was rising over issues like the environment and overdevelopment.
At first glance, New Jersey would appear the ideal proving ground to show that the Republican message of the 1980's still is vital. A traditionally Democratic, blue-collar state, New Jersey has voted for Republican candidates for President and governor in the 1980's races, including the landslide re-election of Mr. Kean in 1985, and lopsided victories for Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush. While voters favored the Democratic Party by 31 percent to 22 percent in 1980 and 1981, voter preferences are nearly equal today, according to surveys by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.
From the viewpoint of national Republican leaders, who initially planned Mr. Courter's campaign, the candidate seemed the perfect symbol: youthful, at ease on television and unswerving in his devotion to the Reagan agenda of smaller government, the free market and conservative social policies. Mr. Courter's election, like Mr. Bush's election last year, Republican analysts said, could prove that popularity lay in the party's policies after the retirement of Mr. Reagan.
But even Republicans around Mr. Kean have criticized Mr. Courter's campaign as a Washington invention that has not been attuned to recent trends in New Jersey.
Although voters were plainly dissatisfied with economic stagnation and high taxes in the Democratic administrations of President Jimmy Carter and Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, polls showed that they were not necessarily opposed to the social changes of the 1960's and 1970's.
Recent surveys by the Eagleton Institute also show growing dissatisfaction with some of the fruits of the largely unregulated economic boom in the most densely populated state. Many citizens have grown increasingly frustrated at traffic snarls on the highways and have come to regard environmental protection no longer as an issue put forward by liberals but as an essential goal.
Supporters of Mr. Courter, a six-term Congressman from the state's rural northwest corner, acknowledge that he made some missteps after winning the June primary. For a decade he presented himself as a supporter of the anti-abortion movement. But after the United States Supreme Court appeared to shift more responsibilities to the states for regulating abortion, he said that he would not ''simply pose my personal views on the women of New Jersey.'' Both supporters and opponents of abortion accused him of vacillating.
In August, Mr. Courter proposed a ban on homosexuals as teachers and in other jobs that put them in contact with children. In September, he changed his position and denied that he had ever proposed the ban, although television stations played videotapes of Mr. Courter stating his earlier views.
Roger Stone, the Washington consultant who originally planned the Courter strategy and left the campaign in July, said that the missteps can still be overcome. Most voters, Mr. Stone said, have not been paying attention to the campaign and will make up their minds based on the television commercials and news reports they see in the final weeks. Robert Franks, a Courter strategist, said that after a difficult summer the campaign is finally on track. ''We're just about where we want to be now,'' he said.
But several polls released in recent days indicate that voters have noticed the campaign and favor Mr. Florio by significant margins. Some initial findings indicate that Mr. Courter's stand on abortion may have hurt him among Republicans. Even Republican officials concede that Mr. Courter faces a steep climb this month to give the President the vote of confidence he expects.

GRAPHIC: Representatives Jim Courter and James J. Florio before their first debate last week in West Long Branch, N.J. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Working Warily With Japan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
INSIDE the Austin, Tex., laboratories of Sematech, the research consortium struggling to restore American manufacturing skills in memory chips, the Japanese are distinctly unwelcome. The clean rooms where chips are fabricated are closed to most foreigners. When Sematech needed a Nikon repairman to keep a vital piece of equipment running, he was walled off from the rest of the lab.
''The Japanese burned our industry and buried it,'' Turner Hasty, a former Texas Instruments executive who is a Sematech top strategist, told a visitor in August. ''We are not about to give them a guided tour.'' 
But here in Tokyo, the same American companies that are financing Sematech can no longer afford such a hard-line stance. A few months ago Texas Instruments announced an alliance with Hitachi to design a 16 million-bit memory chip, the next generation. I.B.M. just signed an unusual joint manufacturing deal with Toshiba for making lightweight video screens for laptop computers, a field the Japanese dominate.
These days Japan is by turns America's desperate competitor and its indispensable ally. The ambivalence is hardly limited to high tech. Few question that Sony Corporation's $3.4 billion acquisition last week of Columbia Pictures Entertainment will help both companies in a world where high-definition television, satellite broadcasting and new video technologies are as important to making money in the movies as big-name stars, good plots and romantic tension. But there is a lurking sense that with each deal some critical skills - from making chips to movies - are ultimately improving profits in Tokyo, not at home.
Many economists have long argued that in these days of global markets, it is better to encourage interdependence than to build walls around American companies or, worse, around fundamental technologies. But in Congress at least, fewer and fewer legislators seem to subscribe to that theory.
 
The Case of the FSX
Earlier this year in the dispute over the FSX fighter jet to be co-developed by the two countries, there were cries that the United States was giving away critical technology that would be used against it. The FSX only became an issue because the agreement required Congressional approval. What Congress has yet to address is whether the same risk applies in private agreements between companies, where the lion's share of technolgical transfer - in both directions - takes place.
 
Cracking New Markets
Hardly a week goes by here when some Silicon Valley company does not strike a deal for research-and-development money it cannot raise at home. Often the quid pro quo is a technology that gives Japanese companies a quick entry into markets they could not crack. NEC last week introduced a microprocessor based on a promising design by a midsized Silicon Valley company, MIPS Computer Systems, that will be used for a new generation of work stations.
With increasing frequency, the technology also goes in the other direction. Steve Jobs, the mercurial founder of Apple, obtained an advanced optical disk drive from Canon Inc. for the computer developed by his new company, Next. But Canon got a big stake in the company and marketing rights in Japan.
So far the Government cannot seem to decide when such alliances are good and when they are not. The Bush Administration spent much of the spring talking about a national effort to develop high-definition television without collaborating with the Japanese. But the first image cast on the high-definition screen was the price tag. Japanese industry has already spent nearly a billion dollars on this technology. In recent weeks an Administration nervous about where to get the money has begun warming to the idea of an alliance.
In recent visits to Tokyo, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and Vice President Dan Quayle have done little to clear up the confusion. Both endorsed the idea of Japanese and American companies working side by side. But asked at a forum of American business leaders here whether that meant letting the United States affiliates of Japanese companies into big government projects, Mr. Mosbacher changed the subject. Mr. Quayle toured a satellite plant and talked about the need to cooperate in space. Asked how that squared with the Administration's complaint that Japan is protecting its industry by refusing to buy American satellites, Mr. Quayle said trade ''will be dealt with separately.'' He left his Japanese audience wondering how.
Underlying the seeming contradictions lies a continuing effort to decide which industries are vital to national security. Robert Noyce, the co-inventor of the chip and Sematech's chief, argues that if American inability to compete in mass production of memory chips leads to the demise of the companies that build chip-making equipment, then the country's defense base is threatened. Americans should avoid growing dependent on Japanese technology ''even if that means depriving ourselves of Japanese products,'' he says.
In reality, Mr. Noyce admits, Americans are unlikely to give up their VCR's, stereo systems, video cameras, fax machines and laptop computers in the vague hope of rebuilding American industry. Americans are hooked on Japan. If it is any consolation, Japan is also hooked on the United States. Sony bought Columbia, and promised to keep its hands off it, because American movies are so popular around the world. And it continues to buy American military hardware, even though many argue here that Japan now has the strength to scorn American technology altogether.
For both sides it is probably too late for such thinking. The technological alliances between the two countries are so intertwined that the old labels, ''Made in America'' and ''Made in Japan,'' are meaningless.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 1, 1989

SECTION: Section 4; Page 22, Column 2; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1979 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS: 'A Jeffersonian Compact';
The Statement by the President and Governors

 BODY:
AT the end of the education conference last week at the University of Virginia, President Bush and the country's governors issued what they called ''a Jeffersonian compact to enlighten our children and the children of generations to come.'' Declaring that ''the time for rhetoric is past,'' they issued this statement.
 
The President and the nation's Governors agree that a better educated citizenry is the key to the continued growth and prosperity of the United States. Education has historically been, and should remain, a state responsibility and a local function, which works best when there is also strong parental involvement in the schools. And, as a nation we must have an educated work force, second to none, in order to succeed in an increasingly competitive world economy.
Education has always been important, but never this important because the stakes have changed: Our competitors for opportunity are also working to educate their people. As they continue to improve, they make the future a moving target. We believe that the time has come, for the first time in U.S. history, to establish clear, national performance goals, goals that will make us internationally competitive. 
The President and the nation's Governors have agreed at this summit:
* to establish a process for setting national education goals;
* to seek greater flexibility and enhanced accountability in the use of Federal resources to meet the goals, through both regulatory and legislative changes;
* to undertake a major state-by-state effort to restructure our education system; and
* to report annually on progress in achieving our goals.
This agreement represents the first step in a long-term commitment to reorient the education system and to marshal widespread support for the needed reforms.
 
NATIONAL EDUCATION GOALS
The first step in restructuring our education system is to build a broad-based consensus around a defined set of national education goals. The National Governor's Association Task Force on Education will work with the President's designees to recommend goals to the President and the nation's Governors. The process to develop the goals will involve teachers, parents, local school administrators, school board members, elected officials, business and labor communities, and the public at large. The overriding objective is to develop an ambitious, realistic set of performance goals that reflect the views of those with a stake in the performance of our education system. To succeed we need a common understanding and a common mission. National goals will allow us to plan effectively, to set priorities, and to establish clear lines of accountability and authority. These goals will lead to the development of detailed strategies that will allow us to meet these objectives.
The process for establishing these goals should be completed and the goals announced in early 1990.
By performance we mean goals that will, if achieved, guarantee that we are internationallly competitive, such as goals related to:
* the readiness of children to start school;
* the performance of students on international achievement tests, especially in math and science;
* the reduction of the dropout rate and the improvement of academic performance, especially among at-risk students;
* the functional literacy of adult Americans;
* the level of training necessary to guarantee a competitive workforce;
* the supply of qualified teachers and up-to-date technology; and
* the establishment of safe, disciplined, and drug-free schools.
 
THE FEDERAL-STATE PARTNERSHIP
 
Flexibility and Accountability
The President and the Governors are committed to achieving the maximum return possible from our investments in the nation's education system. We define maximum return as the following: significant and sustained educational improvement for all children. Nothing less will meet the nation's needs for a strong, competitive work force; nothing less will meet our children's needs for successful citizenship and economic opportunity.
Federal funds, which represent only a small part of total education spending, are directed particularly toward services for young people most at risk. Federal laws and regulations control where and for whom states and localities spend this money. State and local laws and regualtions control what is taught, and how, for all students.
At present, neither Federal nor state and local laws and regulations focus sufficiently on results, or on real educational improvement for all children. Federal and state executives need authority to waive statutory and regulatory provisions in return for greater accountability for results.
The President and the Governors have agreed:
* to examine Federal regulations under current law and to move in the direction of greater flexibility;
* to take parallel steps in each state with respect to state laws and administrative rules;
* to submit legislation to Congress early next year that would provide state and local recipients greater flexibility in the use of Federal funds, in return for firm commitments to improved levels of education and skill training.
The President and the Governors have agreed to establish a working group of Governors and the President's designees to begin work immediately to accomplish these tasks.
We know that other voices need to be heard in this discussion - voices of educators, parents, and those whose primary interest is the protection of the disadvantaged, minorities, and the handicapped. We need to work with the Congress. The processes we will set up immediately following this conference will involve all parties.
The urgent need for flexibility in using Federal funds can best be illustrated by a few examples.
First, the Federal Vocational Education Act, which mandates specific set-asides that often result in individual awards that are too small to be meaningful and that prohibit the money from being spent to achieve its purpose. One state reported being required to divide $300,000 in aid among far too many categories and set-asides.
Second, similarly, the Chapter 1 program requires that equipment purchased to provide remedial education sevices cannot be used for non-Chapter 1 institutions in areas such as adult education. Several states report that large numbers of computers purchased by Federal funds are idle at night, while adult education classes that need them either do without or use scarce tax dollars to buy other equipment.
Third, the requirements that children who benefit from Federal funds for compensatory and special education be taught separately often undermines their achievement. Waivers that permit these students to return to regular classes and receive extra help have produced large increases in their test scores. This option should be available for all school districts.
These commitments are historic steps toward ensuring that young people with the greatest needs receive the best our schools and training programs can give them, and that all children reach their highest educational potential. In a phrase, we want to swap red tape for results.
 
The Federal Government's Financial Role
State and local governments provide more that 90 percent of education funding. They should continue to bear that lion's share of the load. The Federal financial role is limited and has even declined, but it is still important. That role is:
* to promote national education equity by helping our poor children get off to a good start in school, giving disadvantaged and handicapped children extra help to assist them in their school years, ensuring accessibility to a college education, and preparing the workforce for jobs;
* and second, to provide research and development for programs that work, good information on the real performance of students, schools, and states, and assistance in replicating successful state and local initiatives all across the United States.
We understand the limits imposed on new spending by the Federal deficit and the budget process. However, we urge that priority for any further funding increases be given to prepare young children to succeed in school. This is consistent with the President's recommendation for an increase in the number of children served by Head Start in this year's budget. If we are ever to develop a system that ensures that our children are healthy and succeed in school, the Federal Government will have to play a leading role.
Further, we urge that the Congress not impose new Federal mandates that are unrelated to children, but that require states to spend state tax money that could otherwise go to education.
 
COMMITMENT TO RESTRUCTURING
Virtually every state has subsantially increased its investment in education, increased standards and improved learning. Real gains have occurred. However, we still have a long way to go. We must make dramatic improvements in our education system. This cannot be done without a genuine, national, bipartisan commitment to excellence and without a willingness to dramatically alter our system of education.
The President and the nation's Governors agree that significant steps must be taken to restructure education in all states. We share the view that simply more of the same will not achieve the results we need. We must find ways to deploy the resources we commit to education more effectively. A similar process has been going on in American manufacturing industry over the last decade with astonishing results: an increase in productivity of nearly 4 percent a year.
There are many promising new ideas and strategies for restructuring education. These include greater choice for parents and students, greater authority and accountability for teachers and principals, alternative verification programs for teachers, and programs that systematically reward excellence and performance. Most successful restructuring efforts seem to have certain common characteristics:
* a system of accountability that focuses on results, rather than on compliance with rules and regulations;
* decentralization of authority and decision-making responsibility to the school site, so that educators are empowered to determine the means for achieving the goals and to be held accountable for accomplishing them;
* a rigorous program of instruction designed to ensure that every child can acquire the knowledge and skills required in an ecomony in which our citizens must be able to think for a living;
* an education system that develops first-rate teachers and creates a professional environment that provides real rewards for success with students, real consequences for failure, and the tools and flexibility required to get the job done; and
* active, sustained parental and business community involvement.
Restructuring efforts are now under way in many states. The nation's Governors are committed to a major restructuring effort in every state. The Governors will give this task high priority and will report on their progress in one year.
 
ASSURING ACCOUNTABILITY
As elected chief executives, we expect to be held accountable for progress in meeting the new national goals and we expect to hold others accountable as well.
When goals are set and strategies for achieving them are adopted, we must establish clear measures of performance and then issue annual Report Cards on the progress of students, schools, the states, and the Federal Government.
Over the last few days we have humbly walked in the footsteps of Thomas Jefferson. We have started down a promising path. We have entered into a compact - a Jeffersonian compact to enlighten our children and the children of generations to come.
The time for rhetoric is past; the time for performance is now.

HEADLINE: For U.S. Coins, a Great Day Is About to Dawn;
Eliminate All Bills

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I wish to improve on Donald T. Regan's idea of a one-time exchange of old bills for new bills so that cash-hoarding drug dealers may be identified (''The Color of Money Can Stop Drugs,'' Op-Ed, Sept. 18).
All cash - that is, green currency - should be eliminated. We can convert to an economy in which only checks and credit cards are used. The elimination of cash would hamper drug dealers, who generally use cash in their transactions. Prosecution of traffickers would be facilitated by police analysis of the financial records of suspects to determine the flow of their funds. Al Capone was convicted by the auditing of his records. Nothing else worked in fighting the powerful black marketeer of alcohol during Prohibition; nothing else will work in policing our illegal drug market. 
Crimes such as loan sharking and kidnapping, requiring cash, would be more difficult. Auditing in criminal prosecutions could cover tax evaders, arms traders and all black markets.
We would face inconveniences in a checking and credit card economy. It seems absurd to write a check for bubblegum or to use a card at a hot dog stand, but coins could still be used.
Elimination of paper cash may be inflationary. The expense of credit would be added to the price of all transactions. This could be offset by advances in the efficiency of charge card use, for instance, machines through which cards are quickly passed. Retailers and 24-hour bank tellers use this equipment already.
A checking and charge card economy will not be drug free, of course. Sophisticated dealers will still conduct transactions using phony corporations, wire transfers and precious metals. Nevertheless, most dealers would have a tougher time and most law enforcement agencies would have an easier time: trails are left by checks and charge slips, but not with cash. Moreover, more drug profits could be taxed.
 
PAUL RAMPELL
 Palm Beach, Fla., Sept. 21, 1989

HEADLINE: 'Liberal Democracy' Almost Defines Japan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Awaiting the Great Boredom'' (editorial, Sept. 11), about Francis Fukuyama's theory of the end of history, was on the mark for two-thirds of the way. The last third, stating that Japan and the example it sets for East Asia affords a very different global model from the liberal democracy of the West, goes off track.
You assert that Japan is not a liberal democracy because a powerful bureaucracy and not elected officials set major policies, leading to forced conformity, powerless individuals and economic benefits for producers and not consumers. A few recent writers have made these criticisms, but a reader of your paper would have seen little to support them. 
You waffle on the distinction between ''democracy'' and ''liberal democracy,'' but no matter what the definition, it is hard to establish that Japan is not a democracy. It has perhaps the most liberal constitution in the world (written by the American occupation), which is generally accepted and applied by the people.
Laws are debated and passed by the Diet, even if most of them are drafted by an experienced and qualified bureaucracy. The power of the ruling party is now being tested, as an alert electorate prepares itself for an election, women are participating more in the political process, budget procedures are open and more rational than in most other big countries, a lively Communist Party operates freely, and the nation is going through a huge consumption boom.
True, Japan has many problems, such as ethnocentrism, a weak sense of international responsibility and inflated domestic prices. But a nation such as ours, battling problems of race, crime, inferior education, voter indifference and a grossly mismanaged budget, is not in the strongest position to throw stones at the Japanese. And finally, to equate Japan with its Asian neighbors is distasteful to all of them.
If we try to make Japan our ideological foe in order to keep history alive, we would be much better off helping it die.
 
RICHARD B. FINN
 Bethesda, Md., Sept. 13, 1989
 
The writer was State Department Director for Japan, 1969-70.
