HEADLINE: The Graying of America's Countryside

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
WHEN Helen Augelli retired as the principal's secretary at Newtown, Conn., High School in 1986, she and her husband, Joseph, moved to Kitty Hawk on the North Carolina Outer Banks. They had summered there for years, bought a building lot a few years ago, and when the time came, moved into their beach house to stay.
So did Perry Ayscue, who was her partner recently in a puzzle-making session at Dare County's impressive new community center for retirees. He came from Staunton, Va., while Herb Barr retired to Dare County from the bookkeeping department at what was called United States Steel Corporation, since renamed USX Corporation, in Pittsburgh.
''We wanted to get away from cities,'' Mrs. Augelli said. ''We liked it here because there's no pollution, the cost of living isn't as high and it's halfway between Florida and Connecticut. We think it's perfect.'' 
What Mrs. Augelli and her friends on the Outer Banks of North Carolina have in common with hundreds of thousands of other retired Americans, according to the Federal Department of Agriculture, is that they chose a rural county, rather than such established urban retirement centers as Miami, San Diego or Honolulu, as the place to spend their leisure years.
Using Census Bureau figures, the department classifies as a non-metropolitan retirement county one in which at least 15 percent of population growth was due to the arrival of people 60 years old or older. The agency counts 487 rural retirement counties among the country's total of 3,107 counties. It is studying such retirement patterns for clues to potential benefits for depressed rural economies, such as solutions to the problem of dwindling farm employment. But a heavy influx of retired people can have unwanted side effects, too.
Sullivan County, in the Catskill Mountains, is New York's prime rural retirement county, Connecticut has none and New Jersey used to have two - Cape May and Ocean - but the Department of Agriculture recently reclassified them as urban.
Because so many summer-home owners end up moving to Sullivan County permanently when their working years end, the county grew in population by 23 percent between 1970 and 1980, for example, with 23.2 percent of that growth due to the arrival of people 60 years old or older, from outside the county, according to the Census Bureau.
From 1980 to 1988, the county population increased by 10 percent, to 71,700, and although hard numbers on the influx of retirees will not be available until the census next year, county officials attribute a quarter of that growth to them, meaning that overall growth is slowing while retirement growth is holding steady.
IN choosing the countryside, the retirees have a far greater impact on the lives and jobs of their new rural neighbors than they would if they had added their numbers to a big and economically diverse urban setting.
For example, rural retirees drive up property prices rapidly and often bring a new slant to local municipal priorities, attaching more importance, municipal officials say, to things that have high priority among the aged, like street lighting and sidewalks, than, for example, to a new high school basketball court.
What jobs they create are in the service industries, not the better-paying manufacturing and technical employment that isolated counties usually covet. In fact, by simultaneously driving up land and housing prices and aging the population, some experts believe, the arrival of a large retirement population in a sparsely populated county tends to discourage industrial development, whose entrepreneurs prefer low land costs and a young work force. This, of course, means fewer ratables and higher residential property taxes.
But the retirees' Social Security checks and company pensions help provide a steady inflow of money into rural counties, helping buffer the local economy against depressions in agricultural prices. Moreover, retirees are also prolific volunteers, donating their time and skills to local education, libraries, community centers and fund-raising. And they put no additional demands on what is by far the biggest part of any county's budget - local classrooms.
Nina Glasgow, a senior research associate at Cornell University who has made a specialty of rural retirement migrations, said that for many counties, the retirees started coming just in time.
''My research shows that nonmetropolitan retirement counties continued to grow in both population and employment during the 1980's,'' she said, ''and this is at a time when much of rural America has been in a state of economic decline and a net out-migration of people. The retirement counties have been very conspicuous in their population expansion, and some people have been writing about nonmetro retirement counties as the growth industry of the 80's and 90's.''
Several states have developed economic development plans aimed at attracting retirees the way other states court defense installations or automobile plants. Backed by real estate and construction lobbies, Idaho, Arkansas and Alabama promote rural retirement in hopes the newcomers will soak up some of their surplus vacation homes and help diversify struggling agriculture-based economies.
In New York State, where there are 57 counties outside New York City, Schoharie, in the northern Catskills, and Yates, in the Finger Lakes region, are, with Sullivan, the only U.S.-classified rural retirement counties drawing large numbers of retirees, according to the Census Bureau. Greene County, midway between New York City and Albany, was listed as a rural retirement county in 1980 but has since been reclassified by the Census Bureau as urban.
In Colorado, Grand County is drawing retirees into an important fruit-growing district with bargain housing left over from the collapse of the shale oil boom of the late 70's.
Dare County, site of the Wright Brothers' National Memorial at Kill Devil Hills, registered some of the highest rates of retirement immigration in the country between 1970 and 1980, when 69 percent of a 91 percent population increase consisted of people more than 60 years old.
Today, pending the latest Census Bureau figures, officials estimate the county's over-65 population at 33 percent, compared with 12.3 percent for the country as a whole.
Although beach properties on the Outer Banks are still almost laughably inexpensive by the standards of Long Island or the Jersey Shore, housing prices have more than doubled in this decade, Dare County officials say, and the children of longtime residents feel the effect.
''I think we have been pretty successful in diversifying our economy with tourism and retirement,'' said Raymond P. Surza 2d, Dare County's planning director, ''but a byproduct of this is a housing market that is so expensive that 90 percent of the local people can't afford to buy.''
''The market for the retirement homes is oriented toward the Northeast corridor, and that means the retired military personnel, government people, people from union shops that pay high wages, and the disparity is so great that local people can't afford to pay $150,000 for a 3,000-square-foot cottage.''
WHEN amenities such as waterfront properties are scarce, the planner went on, they are quickly picked up by the highest bidder.
''That marina where our fishermen used to tie up their boats has been sold to a developer for condos,'' Mr. Sturza said. ''Now pleasure boats are tied up at rents the fishermen can't afford.''
For real estate brokers and developers, the higher prices are good news, and James Strong, who operates Southern Shores Realty, in the village of Southern Shores just north of Kitty Hawk, said that the retirees follow a familiar pattern of first coming to visit, then staying.
''Right now most of our sales are to people who are planning to retire down here in a few years,'' he said. ''They come down from New York or Washington and buy a place, they rent it out for a few years to get some help with the mortgage, and then they move in and stay.'' Oceanfront houses, most of them two-story, four bedroom models on half-acre lots in Kill Devil Hills, Kitty Hawk and Nags Head on the Outer Banks, are on the market for under $300,000, and houses on Albemarle Sound, on the western shore of the Outer Banks, are going for $100,000 less than that.
A glance at the distribution of rural retirement counties shows them concentrated where one would expect retireees to go - near water or in areas of special natural beauty.
The rural retirement counties hug the two coasts, spread up and down the Alleghenies, the Ozarks into the Texas Plains, arc around the southern rim of the Rockies and dot the shoreline counties of the upper Great Lakes states.
Ruth and Orville Hawes retired to Livingston Manor in Sullivan County almost nine years ago, when Mr. Hawes's doctor told him the mountain air would be better for his emphysema than the traffic and industry of West Haven, Conn.
Their daughter had a summer home in the area, and when Mr. Hawes retired from his work as a roofer and steeplejack, he and his wife paid $50,000 to buy and fix up a two-bedroom house on a half acre at the end of a quiet street.
''I HAD pretty much dropped out of things with the idea that once we came to the rural country I would retire and just enjoy nature,'' said Mrs. Hawes, who is 76 years old. ''But that lasted about two months.''
Mrs. Hawes did what many retirees, more than most other citizens, have the time to do: She got involved in politics. She lobbied the state for more funds for the Community General Hospital in Harris and for a room tax on visitors to the Catskills' resorts to increase funds for social programs. And she monitored the county's tax re-evaluation to keep newcomers from being burdened with higher bills than long-time residents.
''Older people are becoming much more active politically in this county,'' said James Galligan, director of the Sullivan County Office for the Aging. ''They are better organized, they are better educated than retired people used to be, they have a little more money and a lot more time.''
Ms. Glasgow said her research at Cornell indicated that teachers' salaries tend to lag in counties where retirees constitute a high percentage of the general population and that expenditures on health care correspondingly increase.
In North Carolina, Dare County also responded to pressure from the elderly newcomers in building the $800,000 Thomas A. Baum Center to house activities for the county's burgeoning elderly population.
The retirees are similarly leading a fight against offshore oil drilling and in favor of stricter growth controls, along with lesser demands they make on county government officials in Manteo, the county seat.
''A lot of our visitors enjoy it here so much because of the quiet and the open land,'' said Terry L. Wheeler, the acting county manager. ''But the moment they retire and move in to stay they discover that they don't have sidewalks, they don't have streetlights, they don't have a hospital and they want to know why.''
Mrs. Hawes, in Sullivan County, conceded that elderly retired rural voters have special concerns. But, she said, she and her fellow retirees strive to interest themselves in issues that go beyond the traditional concerns of the aged in health and social services.
And in following their daughter to the Catskills, the Haweses followed a pattern that seems to work both ways in retirement counties, with children following parents or the other way around, resulting in multi-generational moves into the countryside.
After Mr. and Mrs. Augelli retired to Dare County from Newtown, for example, one of their daughters bought a condominium nearby and another acquired a building lot. Then a niece moved down from the Berkshires in Massachussetts, and then her brother from Danbury, Conn., also bought a vacation/retirement condo.
Mr. Strong, the real estate broker, said it was a familiar pattern, often led by parents moving in to retire and having their children follow.
''We didn't plan it that way,'' Mrs. Augelli said. ''Usually retiring means being on your own more. But the more my family came down to visit us, the more they liked it here.''

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Photo Exhibition Opens;
Land-Use Debate

 BODY:
A sweeping land-use change, the Lower Density Contextual Zoning Amendment, has prompted heated controversy since it was adopted by New York City's Board of Estimate in June. Requiring new residential construction to be compatible with existing housing, it will affect half the city's residential land. 
The measure is welcomed by those seeking to preserve small-scale residential neighborhoods. But will it aggravate the shortage of affordable housing? And is it practical in a city whose neigbhborhoods are as economically and architecturally diverse as New York's?
The controversy is the subject of ''Housing in Context: Maintaining the City's Low-Rise Neighborhoods,'' an exhibition that will run through Oct. 30 at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, near 51st Street. The exhibition, with photos and text, is co-sponsored by the Municipal Art Society and the Department of City Planning.
A related forum at the center Thursday at 8:30 A.M. - like the exhibit, it is free and open to the public - is entitled ''Maintaining the Character of Neighborhoods Through Zoning.'' Panelists will include experts who helped draft the new policy or have studied its implications.

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
Advantages of a Hand Scraper

BYLINE: By JOHN WARDE

 BODY:
BEFORE sandpaper became popular, woodworkers, especially cabinetmakers, relied on a simple tool called a hand scraper for smoothing wood prior to applying finish.
Many professionals still prefer a hand scraper to sandpaper for this purpose. Although hard to find (woodworking supply stores carry them, but hardware stores generally do not), hand scrapers are well worth acquiring if you build, repair or refinish furniture or other fine woodwork like molding and trim.
A hand scraper is nothing more than a small piece of thin steel similar to that used for making handsaw blades. The most popular shape is rectangular, and is used for smoothing flat surfaces. Curved scrapers for smoothing concave and convex surfaces also are available, but are difficult to sharpen. 
Rectangular scrapers measure about two and a half inches wide and six inches long. Typically, both long edges are sharpened in a way that creates a fine ridge, called a burr, on each side.
When the tool is held nearly perpendicular to the wood and pushed or pulled across the surface, the burr acts like a blade, slicing fine shavings from the surface in much the same way as a plane or chisel.
A scraped surface is smoother and more receptive to finish than one produced by normal sanding, even when sanding is performed in stages, using successively finer grades of abrasive. Unlike sandpaper, a sharp scraper does not shred wood fibers as it rubs against them, nor is dust created that clogs wood pores, inhibiting absorption of finish.
Other advantages of a scraper are speed - a scraped surface can be achieved in a fraction of the time required for sanding with several grades of paper - and economy. Dull sandpaper must be discarded and replaced; a dull scraper need merely be resharpened.
But perhaps the most agreeable aspect of using a scraper is that it does not create the clouds of irritating dust that sanding, particularly with a power sander, does. Wearing a dust mask is not necessary, and even most allergy sufferers who might experience distress from breathing sanding dust can usually use a scraper with no ill effects.
For versatility, a set of three rectangular scrapers is best: one thin (0.4 to 0.6 millimeters) and very flexible for delicate work, another slightly thicker (0.6 to 1.0 millimeters) and less flexible for smoothing bare wood and a thick (1.0 to 1.5 millimeters) nearly rigid scraper for refinishing. The set should cost less than $10. A new scraper must be sharpened before it is used. For this and subsequent sharpenings, you will need a vise, a 10-inch, smooth-cut mill file with a handle, an oilstone and a special tool called a burnisher. This is a round, triangular or oval rod of hardened steel about eight inches long and with a handle. It is available where scrapers are sold.
Begin by clamping the scraper in the vise, with the edge to be sharpened pointing up. Use strips of wood between the scraper and the vise jaws to protect it.
Grip the file at both ends and rest it across the edge of the scraper, perpendicular to the sides. While applying light, even pressure, slide the file back and forth across the edge of the scraper to smooth the edge and square it to the sides.
File until you can detect a slight ridge or burr on each side of the edge with your fingertip. Then place a few drops of oil on the oilstone and remove the burrs by sliding the stone lightly back and forth several times along each side of the scraper.
When the burrs are gone, spread a little oil onto the burnisher. Grip it and rest it across the edge of the scraper, as you did the file. But instead of holding the burnisher perpendicular to the sides of the scraper, tilt it at an angle of 5 to 10 degrees toward one side.
Slide the burnisher along the edge of the scraper 6 to 12 times, using hard pressure. This should form a new burr along one side. Then tilt the burnisher the same amount toward the scraper's other side and form a second burr.
Sharpen the scraper this way on the remaining long side and, if you wish, on one or both short sides.
To use a scraper, simply fasten the wood to be scraped securely to a workbench or sawhorses, just as you would for sanding. Stand so that you can either pull or push the scraper over the surface, following the same direction as the wood grain.
Hold the scraper with both hands. If you decide to scrape by pulling the tool toward you (best for smoothing broad areas), place your fingers over the top of the scraper and extend them across the blade, perpendicular to its long edges. Extend your thumbs across the other side (parallel to your fingers) to afford a grip.
If you decide to push the scraper - this is better for smoothing knots and small areas of complicated grain - extend your fingers across the blade from the sides so that your fingertips are toward each other. Then press against the rear with your thumbs to curve the blade. Place the scraper on the wood and tilt the upper edge in the direction you plan to move the tool. Then scrape, adjusting the angle so that the blade produces fine, curly shavings while sliding easily over the surface.
Removing only enough wood to create a smooth surface takes some practice. Be careful not to scrape surfaces unevenly.
When scraping produces dust instead of shavings, a sign of dullness, use a different burr. Even when all the burrs are dull, re- burnishing is often all that is necessary to restore the edges for a short time to nearly their original state.
If the scraper was well sharpened to begin with, reburnishing usually can be performed two or three times before complete resharpening, including using the file and oilstone, is necessary.

LENGTH: 1145 words

HEADLINE: Hearing Set on Aged, Disabled Poor

BYLINE: By States News Service

 BODY:
A CONGRESSIONAL hearing in Central Islip this week will throw a national spotlight on an innovative Suffolk County program that can better enable localities to shoulder the burden of their growing population of the elderly and disabled poor.
It also will bring to light a new profile of the typical recipient of Supplemental Security Income on Long Island, a profile the Nassau County Health and Welfare Council calls ''startling.''
The Health and Welfare Council of Nassau County is a private, nonprofit health and human services planning agency that receives funds from such sources as the United Way and Nassau County.
First to testify tomorrow before the Subcommitee on Human Services of the House Select Committee on Aging will be Patrick G. Halpin, the Suffolk County Executive, who is expected to answer in the negative the question posed by the special hearing: ''S.S.I. Outreach: Is the Federal Government Doing Enough?''
 
Downey Calls Hearing
The first such meeting covering this topic, the hearing will be held jointly with the State Assembly's Standing Committee on Aging. It will be chaired by Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Amityville. 
There are 24,000 S.S.I. recipients on Long Island, 13,000 in Suffolk County and 11,000 in Nassau, according to the Health and Welfare Council. To qualify for S.S.I., an individual must be 65 years old and blind, elderly or disabled, with a monthly income of less than $454 or an annual income of $5,448. Couples must earn less than $655 per month, or $7,866 a year.
A member of the House Ways and Means Committee, Mr. Downey introduced legislation into the House deficit-reduction measure that directs the Social Security Administration to establish the first permanent national S.S.I. outreach program. This $16.6 billion reconciliation bill is currently on the House floor.
In his capacity as chairman of the House Aging Committee's Subcommittee on Human Services, Mr. Downey is holding this hearing to demonstrate the need, as well as to find ways to improve, S.S.I. outreach, according to John Olinger, subcommittee staff director.
Joining other New York experts on the fiscal and administrative shortfalls involved in caring for the area's poor, Mr. Halpin will testify to the increased financial hardships faced by local governments in supporting the needy.
Mr. Halpin will outline a money-saving S.S.I. outreach program that meets those needs in Suffolk, and that he feels can be replicated by localities across the country.
''Suffolk, the largest suburban county in New York, receives half as much Federal aid as it did 10 years ago,'' said Mr. Halpin. Suffolk spent $19.1 million on its Home Relief Public Assistance Program in 1988.
To aid needy recipients, Suffolk established the Disabled Client Assistance Program, an outreach project that helps Home Relief clients previously denied S.S.I. benefits to switch back to Federal welfare rosters.
 
What Program's Staff Does
Under the Disabled Client Assistance Program, its staff members pore over public assistance records, searching for welfare recipients denied S.S.I. benefits. They then review the case files and obtain documentation from the individual's physician or psychiatrist to help the Suffolk County Department of Social Services appeal on his or her behalf.
With a 90 percent success rate, this procedure resulted in the overturning of 82 cases in 1988 alone, the department said, netting Suffolk $732,000 last year and representing projected welfare savings of $6 million.
''And this year, after expanding the program, we expect to save about $3.3 million, and this is in addition to reducing our total projected welfare burden,'' Mr. Halpin said, adding that families also receive more benefits from S.S.I. than from Home Relief program. .
''So their actual standard of living is increased, plus they lose the stigma of being on welfare.''
 
Government Policies Blamed
Mr. Halpin will be among several witnesses at tomorrow's hearing who blame Government policies for the burden that localities are facing.
''The Reagan Administration is representative of a whole movement talking about Americans as all being in the economic mainstream. All they have to do is will it, and they can succeed financially,'' said Jack O'Connell, director of the Health and Welfare Council of Nassau County.
''But a whole bunch of disabled people are locked out of this mainstream, and all the employment counseling in the world can't help them.''
Mr. O'Connell will discuss his organization's new profile of the S.S.I. population on Long Island, a study he said reflects those individuals ''right on the precipice'' of dire poverty.
''I expected the typical recipient to be an aberrant type, drug addicts or people with personality disorders,'' he said. ''But what was startling was that S.S.I. people are just like the lady who lives next door to you, except that she's trying to live on Long Island on $368 a month.''
 
Shift in Burden Urged
Arguing that S.S.I. funds and outreach programs need to be increased, Mr. O'Connell believes that the localized burden also must be shifted.
''The main thrust in Washington and in Albany is that things should be paid for locally,'' he said. ''But services are being greatly reduced because local governments can't afford them.'' Representative Downey agrees. ''It is important to understand that policy decisions we make in Washington have a real and measurable impact on the lives and pocketbooks of Long Islanders,'' he said. ''If the Federal Government fails to provide S.S.I. outreach, the burden falls on state and local governments.''
Also attending the hearing will be Paul Harenberg, Democrat of Bayport, chairman of the State Assembly's Standing Committee on Aging; and Mr. Downey's House subcommittee colleagues, Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York, and Representative Ben Blaz, Republican of Guam.
 
'Too Many Roadblocks'
Said Mr. Downey, the author of legislation that would establish a permanent S.S.I. outreach program:
''An aggressive outreach effort must be an integral part of the S.S.I. program. Too many people do not know that they are eligible, and there are just too many roadblocks that prevent them from finding out.''
Also testifying to this need to improve S.S.I. outreach will be Arthur Pitts, the Babylon Town Supervisor; Edwin Mendez Santiago, director of Raices, a Hispanic service group in Brooklyn, and Andrew Koski, public policy coordinator at Hunter College's Brookdale Center on Aging.
Also, Linsley Piper, a specialist with the state's Office of Mental Health, and Lou Krieger, a member of the National Legislative Council of the American Association of Retired Persons.
The hearing will begin at 10 A.M. tomorrow at the Clayton Central Islip Senior Citizens Center, 555 Clayton Street, Central Islip.

HEADLINE: T.G.M.F. (Thank God, More Fridays)

BYLINE: By P. M. Rinaldo; P. M. Rinaldo, a retired chemical engineer, is the author of ''The Five-Day Weekend.''

DATELINE: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y.

 BODY:
There's no compelling reason for the week to have seven days. Different cultures have different lengths of the week, ranging from four days in the Bantu and Ibo tribes in Africa to eight days in ancient Rome.
Our seven-day week appears to have arisen because of superstition. In the Near East, the number 7 was considered unlucky and all activities were avoided every seventh day. 
But there would be a number of rational advantages to changing the week to five days: Fridays, for instance, would come around much sooner. Of course, this would require eliminating two of the present week days. Which two? The third day of the present week honors the Roman god of battle, Mars; his Norse equivalent was the god Tir or Tiw, whose name gives us Tuesday. Thursday honors Thor the Thunderer, the Norse God whose modern arsenal would include the atomic bomb. Let's stop honoring war and thunder and scrub Tuesdays and Thursdays.
Our calendar could be adapted easily to five-day weeks. There would be 72 weeks in the year, arranged in 12 months of 6 weeks each, plus 5 holidays. Most people now work about 240 days a year. The same working days could be maintained in the new calendar by working three and a half days a week for 68 weeks. Or people could work five days, followed by a five-day weekend.
The latter arrangement of alternate five-day weeks would require the employee to have a ''job partner'' who would work during the off-week. Not only would the five-day week, when combined with the alternate-week work schedule, provide the employee with more leisure time for sports, hobbies, travel and cultural activities, but also it would allow time to be home when the repair man calls or to visit city hall to protest taxes. City hall, of course, would be continuously open with alternating crews of clerks.
For two-income families with small children, the arrangement would allow one parent always to be home with the children. Husband and wife could share equally in earning family income and doing domestic chores, rather than forcing the wife to work a ''second shift'' at home in addition to her stint at the office.
Employers who adopt the alternate-week work schedule could operate continuously, thus increasing utilization of their assets by 40 percent. Service industries, ranging from ski slopes to brokerage houses, would immediately gain a larger potential clientele from that proportion of the population enjoying the long weekend.
Where productivity could not be increased to offset the reduced working hours, more employees would be needed. A rough calculation shows that in the United States about 15 million more people would be required. These people could come from the present unemployed and underemployed, which some estimates show may number 20 million. Obviously, a great deal of training would be needed, but the nation would end up with a healthier economy at a higher level of gross national product.
So, who needs Tuesday and Thursdays?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

COUNTRY: AFRICA (88%); UNITED STATES (79%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (90%); 

CITY: ROME, ITALY (57%);

LENGTH: 1314 words

HEADLINE: New Orleans Resists High-End Condos

BYLINE: By LETTICE STUART

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
JEROME GOLDMAN, a local developer and marine architect, had always dreamed of a home with a view of the Mississippi River. When a downtown site on the river became available in 1984, he decided to build a 14-story condominium there so he could enjoy a panoramic view of the city and the waterway from his penthouse.
Now Mr. Goldman's high-rise condominium, called One River Place, is nearing completion, but there was a nightmare delay along the way: With the $50 million project, at the foot of Poydras Street, suffering from the city's depressed economy and cost overruns, the lender called a 13-month work stoppage to re-evaluate the project. But many in the real estate industry fear its worst problem may be a low level of acceptance of high-rise, high-end condominium living. Here and in other cities, this kind of housing appeals to a narrow market.
Stephen Manshel, the project's manager, does not agree. Admitting the project has had its share of problems, he maintains that it is on track now and said he anticipates an 18-month sellout of the building's 91 units. They are priced from $195,000 for a 1,600-square-foot, one-bedroom on a lower level to $1.3 million for one of the building's two 5,100-square-foot, three-bedroom penthouses. Mr. Goldman has taken the second penthouse, scaled down to just half the original dream home he had envisioned. 
Marketing began four years ago, was suspended for 17 months while the building was being redesigned to increase the units from 66 to 91, and then resumed last March. While no sales have been completed, 36 contracts have been signed, Mr. Manshel said.
Wade Ragas, professor of finance and director of the Market Data Center at the University of New Orleans, said he doubts the building can sell out in 18 months. With a median household income of $33,000 in this metropolitan area of 1.3 million residents, he said, there just aren't that many people who can afford Mr. Goldman's prices who want to live in a downtown high-rise.
According to Professor Ragas, there is little demand for condominiums, with 350 to 450 units sold each year for the last three years. Those units, he said, are for the most part in somewhat lower-priced town-house complexes, which have been selling ''fairly well.'' The chief reason he cites for sluggish sales is the availability of inexpensive single-family houses in the metropolitan area, where the average house sells for $83,000.
''People don't want to pay more for less living area in a high-rise,'' he said. Moreover, he said, residents of the Crescent City just aren't used to high-rise living since the older multifamily housing here consists, for the most part, of two to four apartments in a building. ''Yard space and outdoor living, which are difficult to get with condos, are very important to people here,'' Professor Ragas said.
High-rise condominiums in other parts of the city have not fared too well, either. One case involves Henry T. Isaak, a developer who moved to New Orleans in 1979 from Ann Arbor, Mich., where he specialized in high-rise, multifamily residential buildings.
To test his belief that there was a market for similar projects here, he selected a choice spot on Lake Pontchartrain overlooking a 240-slip marina. His 19-story Lake Marina Tower opened in 1982 as the city's tallest residential building and the first waterfront condominium.
Four years later, with only half of the 77 one- to three-bedroom units, priced from $165,000 to $300,000, sold, Mr. Isaak decided to cut his losses by auctioning the rest. He netted about half of what he had originally expected. He then moved to Florida.
A SIX-STORY, 28-unit building erected in 1985 on the west bank of the Mississippi directly across from the central business district had even worse luck. Cost overruns forced the lender to shut the project down when it was only 80 percent complete.
The $6 million building, which was to have been the West Bank's premier condominium development featuring balconies with dramatic views of the French Quarter and the city's downtown skyline, was sold last year for $650,000 to Joe Somario, a Boston developer who has since completed the project and is now renting the two-bedroom units at rents ranging from $800 to $1,600 for 1,400 to 2,200 square feet.
One moderately successful new high-rise condominium so far is Park VII, a 10-story building in the city's expensive uptown area at Audubon Park and the Mississippi River. In July 1986, not too long before its completion, the $11 million project was taken over by the lenders who have steadily plugged away at sales since then.
The 36-unit building is now 70 percent sold. The units are priced from $279,000 for a 2,000-square-foot, two-bedroom on a lower floor to $675,000 for the 3,800-square-foot, three-bedroom penthouse.
John Hebert of Hebert & Smolkin, a real estate consulting firm with offices in New Orleans and Palo Alto, Calif., puts condominium buyers into two categories - those who cannot afford single-family homes and those, usually 55 or older, looking for release from home ownership. The problem is that it is difficult to get the older buyers to move. According to Mr. Hebert, only about 4 per cent of that group move each year.
Developers in many other cities have experienced the same resistance toward high-rise, expensive condominiums.
IT has been four years since Edward B. DeSeta built the 22-story Park Plaza, the first high-rise condominium in downtown Wilmington, Del. Five of the 125 units still have not been sold despite attractive financing, and plans for a twin tower, originally scheduled for completion two years ago, have been put on the back burner.
Herschel H. Quillen 3d, senior vice president of Edward B. DeSeta & Associates, said the biggest problem has been getting people to change their perception of housing from single-family to a high-rise. Buyers had to be educated that even though they could buy a large home on a half-acre lot minutes from downtown for the same price as one of the $375,000 larger units at Park Plaza, what they were getting instead was a whole way of life with service, amenities and convenience.
''We had to sell a life style more than real estate,'' Mr. Qillen said.
But that life style only appeals to a select group, according to David Peterson, a real estate appraiser in Phoenix, Ariz., where high-rise living has not met with success either. Mr. Peterson said his company, Real Estate Science Corporation, has done market studies that showed the profile of buyers in high-rise buildings, at least in Phoenix, are from New York, Chicago or Beverly Hills and are usually 45 to 50 years old.
''If you don't have enough of that group, then a high-rise residential building will not be successful,'' Mr. Peterson said.
That's what he told the developers of the Regency, an 11-floor condominium built in midtown Phoenix in the early 60's.
''We told them not to build, but they did anyway and were not able to sell the units,'' he said. Mr. Peterson claimed sales are very slow at another high-rise condominium under construction in midtown. There just aren't enough people in Phoenix who want that life style to make a project viable, he said.
Before downsizing the units at One River Place, Mr. Goldman's Normandie Company planned an even grander scale in both size and price for its apartmets - one- to three-bedrooms with 2,000 to 4,500 square feet of floor space and 500- to 1,000-square-foot terraces. Prices were to have ranged from $491,000 to $1.6 million. Mr. Goldman's penthouse was to have encompassed the entire top floor, with 10,000 square feet of floor space and a 10,000-square-foot terrace.
''The project originally was geared to 0.10 percent of the marketplace,'' said Mr. Manshel, the project manager. ''But by downsizing the units and reducing prices, we've greatly increased our market.''

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY Q & A: SAMUEL J. LEFRAK;
Developer's Empire Keeps Growing

BYLINE: By JEFFREY HOFF

 BODY:
WITH more than 94,000 apartments in his company's portfolio, Samuel J. LeFrak, 71 years old, is among the nation's largest landlords. The Lefrak Organization is the principal developer of the massive Newport complex, an office, residential, shopping and marina complex that is the largest development along the Hudson River in New Jersey.
Mr. LeFrak, the son of an immigrant who acquired a valuable farm plot in Brooklyn early in the century, became prominent with the construction of the 5,000-unit Lefrak City apartment complex in Queens in the 1950's.
At the helm of his family-owned company, Mr. LeFrak has diversified into music, movies and oil and is now a billionaire. Forbes magazine estimates his total worth at more than $1.5 billion. 
Q. Is publicity important to business? Does it bother you that Donald Trump, Leonard Stern and Leona Helmsley get more publicity than you do?
A. Look, I am an unusual guy and I am working very hard on my craft. I have not arrived yesterday. You don't see my name in the newspaper. You don't see indictments. You don't see me involved in scandal. I don't put my hand in the garbage pail. My grandfather says, ''You put your hand in the garbage pail, you are going to come up dirty.'' And he also says, ''When a politician says something, make sure it's in writing.''
Q. James Rouse has made a commitment to low- and moderate-priced housing. Do you feel you have a similar responsibility to build low- and moderate-priced housing?
A. I am working on it. But, you see, if you go and open up Forbes magazine, you will see where I am and you will see where Mr. Rouse is. (Mr. LeFrak is near the top of Forbes's list of the 400 wealthiest Americans. Mr. Rouse is not on the list.)
Q. Well, is that important? Is money life's report card?
A. Money is the ingredient that you need for staying power.
Q. Do you recognize the difference between middle-income and low- and moderate-priced housing, providing housing for people who can't afford any down payment?
A. Well, I build for all. I build for the handicapped. I build for the senior citizen. I build for the working poor. I build for the moderate. I build the affordable and I build for luxury. I build office buildings, shopping centers. I build industrial parks. I do it all. But I also make movies. I also make music. Do you see this lady? (He pointed to a four-foot-tall cardboard cutout of Barbra Streisand behind his desk.) I found her. She was a tenant of mine in Brooklyn, and I want you to know I gave her her first booking. I can only tell you I have been lucky. Maybe I have been able to forecast and see a lot of things that other people can't see.
Q. What is the best thing about having so much money?
A. I don't look at money. Forget about it. I live very moderately. I don't live any more luxuriously than yourself. I still live in the house I built 40 years ago, and to me it is my Golden Pond. To me, money is just a means. It is one of the natural resources that is needed to get the fuel, to get the engine going.
Q. What is the significance of that (a bronze plaque of Romulus and Remus, the mythological wolf cubs who built Rome, nursing from their mother)?
A. Everybody is feeding off me. I am feeding Romulus and Remus.
Q. You don't see yourself as either Romulus or Remus?
A. No, I am the guy who brings jobs to people. I am the guy who brings housing, affordable housing. I am the guy who does the impossible and makes it possible. I am the guy that invented new math -one plus one equals three - and says nothing is impossible. This (the bronze) is something I bought many years ago in Italy right after the war. And this represents my contractors, my tenants and the people I do business with, and I am the guy that is bringing this to the world. And the buildings I have built.
Q. What kind of influence and relationship do you have with people in government?
A. It's the respect that they have. Look, I have title. (Mr. LeFrak was knighted by the King of Norway.) I also am a doctor. (He has received a number of honorary degrees.) And I'm also a guy who has done some very exciting things in my life, and life isn't over at 65. I will give you a perfect example. I am getting a Social Security check. It's ridiculous. I give it away to charity. My life, the great stuff is coming. I have some great plans. Read some of the things I have written. I have a school, the Lefrak Brick and Mortar College, and if you go to Oxford University St. Cross College (in England), you will see a big plaque at a library I donated there. I am a person that is very well known. That is why I am being invited to talk before the Parliament in Finland. I am asked to come to China to build cities. In Egypt they call me Ramses III. The point is, don't compare me to these little builders. Not that I have any criticism - you know a long march starts with the first step - but I have been up to the top of the mountain. I have tremendous years of experience. Do you know what is sitting in the memory bank of my computer? Do you realize the work that I have done? Do you realize how many impossible things I made possible?
Q. What is the toughest part, the bricks and mortar or getting through the government regulations and the politics?
A. They all have their problems, believe you me. But if I am going to be a person that has a problem, that is one thing. Thank God the problem doesn't have me. That is the difference. I know how to ride with the punches. I am a survivor.
Q. Do you feel you get the respect you deserve?
A. Absolutely - just the other day they called me world class.
Q. Who?
A. The Mayor (of Jersey City, Gerald McCann) and also Janiszewski (the Hudson County Executive, Robert C. Janiszewski). They are honored to have me there. Hey, listen. The Lefrak name is a big important name. Go to Koch, ask him about Sam LeFrak and he'll say, ''My hero.''
Q. Will you build low- and moderate-priced housing in New Jersey?
A. I am doing it at Salem Lafayette (in Jersey City). And I'll do more. Why not? I have the capability.
Q. I am asking because it's a very big issue.
A. But not with me. I voluntarily walked into this and the first four buildings I built (in Jersey City) were under a program where I said I am going to take care of everybody. I am not building the Chinese Wall. I am not building for the rich. I am building for everybody.
Q. Do you have a sense the problem is easier than it appears to be?
A. It's a problem because if politics would step out, free enterprise would solve the problem. Free enterprise always solves these problems. I know in Short Hills you are not going to build welfare housing for the poor. On the exterior they give you some kind of a picture, but when you penetrate their facade you see bigotry, and it's in New Jersey as well as New York. You need certain things in order to do it. The Federal Government won't give you a dime. You know H.U.D. is filled with scandals. You know the local community and the state have to kick in tax abatements. As the interest rates come down, you go to the state finance agency and you will raise bonds with the state's guarantee.
Q. So the private sector could do it with Federal help?
A. You need their assistance. No question. But they are not going to give you money outright and say build public housing because that program is dead. Listen, let's not be Joan of Arcs. There is a time and place. All of your public housing was built during the recession. This is 1989 - in 10 years you are in the 21st century. A lot of things are happening; a lot of technology is being developed.
Q. What does that mean? Fewer people can afford to buy a home today than ever before. We have homeless people on the streets. Mr. Rouse has made a commitment and formed a foundation to build low-income housing. How many has he built?
A. I can't tell you. How would the problem be solved? The problem is solved if the politics are going to make it possible for you to do it. That's the whole basis. There is an old story, ''I believe in the project, but not in my backyard.''

GRAPHIC: Photo of Samuel J. LeFrak at the Newport center in Jersey City (NYT/F. N. Kinney)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 1, 1989

SECTION: Section 2; Page 5, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2010 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
In Monology, to Play It Right Do It Yourself

BYLINE: By IRENE LACHER; Irene Lacher often writes about entertainment and the arts.

 BODY:
Ten years ago, no one in television would have dreamed of scouting out jarring forums of New York downtown theater for material that could play in Peoria. Yet this November, HBO will feature Reno, one of downtown's most promising monologuists, performing at P.S. (Performance Space) 122, a former public school on the Lower East Side that's becoming a breeding ground for cable specials.
These days, the world of the performance avant-garde is meshing quite nicely with the world of commerce, and increasingly the performers connecting the two are practitioners of a new hybrid art form that has blossomed in the post-modern 80's. Monologuists have been confounding traditional notions of what plays at the box office. They have been courting full houses Off Broadway with such unlikely come-ons as spare sets - no more than a table or music stand - and that most uncommercial virtue of all: the demand that audiences meet them halfway using their own imaginations. At that midpoint, monologuists create entire universes, frequently cast with figures from their own past. 
A few artists who began as downtown solo performers have scaled the heights in Hollywood or are on their way - most notably Whoopi Goldberg, but also Ann Magnuson, who is joining the cast of the ABC sitcom ''Anything But Love,'' and Sandra Bernhard, a David Letterman regular who is filming a movie version of her Off Broadway show, ''Without You I'm Nothing.'' The movie ''Talk Radio,'' a vehicle for the writer-performer Eric Bogosian, sprang from his one-man show at the Public Theater. And John O'Keefe, whose solo work ''Shimmer'' played at Second Stage last summer, has been tapped by HBO to write a movie about the 60's.
While monology has been a springboard for performers to find fame and fortune in more traditional, collaborative forms, the great maw of commercial entertainment has also opened for solo work. Mr. Bogosian's one-man character studies have aired on HBO, and Spalding Gray, another HBO grad, starred in a movie version of his monologue ''Swimming to Cambodia,'' directed by Jonathan Demme, that stayed true to the stripped-down format he pioneered at the Performing Garage a decade ago. David Cale performed his Bessie award-winning monologue ''The Redthroats'' for a national audience last year in an HBO special with Bette Midler as master of ceremonies. And in recent years Lincoln Center has provided monologuists with the opportunity to reach uptown audiences in its ''Serious Fun'' series.
When looking for talent, HBO is interested in a ''unique personality with a unique point of view that translates to other media,'' says Stu Smiley, senior vice president of original programming for HBO's Comedy Channel. ''And when you see someone wowing an audience, you judge the response. It's important not to be too precious in terms of the audiences you please. It's part of a mind-set for performers - what they really want to do, whether they want to reach a bigger and bigger following.''
Some avant-garde performers who haven't yet managed to snag a Showtime special are hustling to get one, pointing to a dramatic shift in attitude. ''I think a lot of downtown people want to make it big,'' says the monologuist Frank Maya. ''I know some performance artists who are about 10 times more ambitious than any actor I've ever met or anyone I know from Los Angeles.''
Even someone like Karen Finley, a monologuist whose fascination with treading on taboos has limited her to fringe venues, is cutting dance records that are being played in Miami discos and has been approached by MTV. ''I think that artists of my generation, who grew up in the 60's and 70's, really feel it's good to reach more people,'' Ms. Finley says. ''If you can be moving someone in a positive way, you can affect their life. Being selfish with it sometimes can mean keeping it inaccessible.''
Ms. Finley is one of the few monologuists who springs directly from a ''purist'' tradition of performance art, crediting 70's conceptual performers like Vito Acconci and Chris Burden as influences for her own work. Yet as performance art leaves the galleries for the theaters and nightclubs of the 80's, it's concerning itself more with the traditional aim of popular theater, which is to entertain. And monology is most easily making the leap because the form is, as the P.S. 122 director Mark Russell put it, ''light on its feet. You can do it in a big hall like Lincoln Center. You can do it at a teeny spot like [King Tut's] Wah Wah Hut. There's not a lot of set. You've got one personality. It crosses into TV real fast and then, God forbid, they're good on Letterman, and then it's nationwide. That's why there's a lot of focus on this stuff: it's good, it's different, it's contemporary and it can move into other mediums.''
Monologues appeal on an even more basic level; they're the contemporary incarnation of storytellers, that most primal form of theater tricked up with loans from stand-up comedy and conceptual art, rock-and-roll, the punk esthetic and German cabaret.
Click to the 80's and a generation of youth spoon-fed as much on rock concerts as on any other experience in a theater. Mr. Bogosian, who created a wide range of arresting characters in his one-man shows ''Drinking in America'' and ''Funhouse,'' considers himself an heir to the singer-songwriters who began to emerge in the 60's.
''When a rock band performs, there's one single person who stands in front of the band usually and performs to the audience and that person always is affecting a persona,'' says Mr. Bogosian. ''We think we know something about them and we go to see them perform on stage in that persona.
''Their songs constitute a voice like a playwright's voice or a poet's voice. It's a kind of theater that is performed solo for the most part. You go to see the frontman.''
Even Reno, whose performance flirts with stand-up comedy, is working with Pat Place, formerly of the new-wave band the Bush Tetras, to create new work interweaving monologues with music. Her new piece will have its debut at Dixon Place tonight. ''My particular kind of monologue, being that its stream of consciousness, is very comparable to music in that it's like jazz improvisation,'' she says.
Perhaps the most influential monologuist has been Spalding Gray, who is credited with creating the contemporary epic monologue. Mr. Gray's work was very much a product of its time. ''It's just a reaction to the surrealistic fragmentation of the 60's, which got done, really done well and then done to a fare-thee-well,'' Mr. Gray says. ''It got too messy. It got too fragmented.'' Simply sitting at a table, Mr. Gray crafted intricate, humorous evenings from his experiences buying a country home, which led to ''Terrors of Pleasure,'' and acting in the film ''The Killing Fields,'' which resulted in ''Swimming to Cambodia.''
He also pointed the way toward a confessional approach to theater. Mr. Cale's ''Redthroats'' features a young misfit named Stephen Weird who is obsessed with Judy Garland, much like his creator. Ms. Hughes's ''World Without End'' unflinchingly finds poetry in her own incestuous past. Mr. Gray's autobiographical approach was being crossed with another esthetic of the 70's, the punk movement, which said anyone could be in a band. ''This was anyone can be a performance artist,'' says Mr. Russell. ''People were going, 'I can just perform my story and I don't have to make it into a fiction. I don't have to write it down. I can just go out there and start talking about what happened to me last week.' ''
But with humor the motor behind much of the solo work, monologuists commonly tip their hats to comedians like Lily Tomlin, Richard Pryor and Lenny Bruce. The monologuist Penny Arcade, who creates offbeat characters in the style of Mr. Bogosian, tweaks critics' inclination to draw comparisons. In a closing bit of her recent run at P.S. 122, she does a ''Jeopardy'' spoof that clusters monologuists under a category she calls ''The New Lenny Bruces.''
But while humor sugarcoats monologuists' barbs, an underbelly of serious concerns separates their work from that of the typical stand-up comedian. In fact, Reno, who manically lambastes trendy New Yorkers' penchant for ''pretty food'' and corporations that label AIDS a ''lifestyle illness,'' had only sporadic success when she tried the conventional comedy circuit.
''I still think I could be considered a stand-up if I wanted to be one myself, but now [the group of them] is often racist, always sexist, and if they bother at all, homophobic,'' she says.
There's a difference in rhythm as well. Whereas stand-up comics pepper their delivery with a succession of punch lines, monologuists are more likely to stumble across them in the course of delivering a cohesive narrative.
''The thing about these shows is that the imagination clicks in so hard that it creates an impression that really lasts,'' says Mr. Maya. ''A woman from VH-1 [the video channel] came to see me at a time when I was fretting about not being enough of a stand-up comic, and she said, 'I see stand-up comics every week, and I never remember a word they say. I remember every word you said in your show.' The solo people give you a strong image if they're good, and those images just stick and stick.''
Prosaically enough, simple economics have had the most catholic effect on the boomlet of monologuists. Mr. O'Keefe wrote ''Shimmer,'' a solo piece recalling his boyhood in juvenile homes, after money problems derailed his plans for a play with five actors that had been commissioned by American Inroads in San Francisco in 1987.
''There wasn't enough money to pay them all, so I asked if I could do a solo, and they said, 'Sure,' '' says Mr. O'Keefe. ''It was a lot more money with one guy and I just used lights and a music stand and I wanted to keep the overhead next to zip.''
Yet the simplicity of monologues has its own appeal that transcends the question of dollars and cents. According to Mr. Maya: ''Someone said being a stand-up monologuist is almost like being a film maker. You get up and create your whole world in an evening, except you don't need the sets. You don't need the budget. I like that.''
 

 
'Taken Over By Me'
This is an excerpt from ''The Redthroats,'' a performance piece by the monologuist David Cale.
 
 And the wood duck were looking at us because they'd never seen a plane full of singing people. And I leap to my feet and I start yelling, ''I'm gonna take my life in my hands and shake it and shake. Till all the bad parts fall out. Till they've all dropped out of me. Like dead leaves shaken from a living tree. There they go. All those rotting leaves. There they go. I'll shake and shake till only the living, the present, the alive is left. No dead leaves. No dead leaves. No past. I'll shake off the past. Let the past get past. Let the past get past.''
Then I realize, I'm saying what I feel. Doing what I want. I get nervous again. I'm afraid of what I might want to do. I'm scared of what'll come out of my mouth. But I can't stop. I'm being taken over by me! The me I haven't been yet. The me I'm going to be when I start being myself. The frightened. The angry. The me that got buried in thestet childhood. All of the me's are all out at once. All acting and singing, asserting, saying, ''Let's see where the future can go! Let's see where the future can go!'' Then applause. Cheers. Clapping passengers. I'm a hit. Karen Black comes out of the cockpit and she says, ''I don't know about you guys but I'm just about ready to hit the ground. Safety belts belted? Extinguished cigarettes? Luggage where it should be? We're coming in to land. Any minute now. We're gonna be landing.'' Build yourself a life and live with it!
''Coming in to land. Any minute now. Coming in to land. Any minute now. Coming in to land. Any minute. Now.
Welcome to America.''

HEADLINE: ISRAEL ASKING U.S. FOR AID ON HOUSING FOR SOVIET EMIGRES

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Israel has asked the United States for $400 million in loan guarantees to finance the construction of housing for Soviet Jewish emigres, and Israeli officials said some of the housing would probably be built in the West Bank.
The extent of Jewish settlements in the West Bank has been a source of debate not only among Israeli politicians, but also between Israel and other countries, including the United States. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has called on Israel to ''stop settlement activity'' in the West Bank, which it has occupied since 1967. The future status of the territory is an important issue in the Arab-Israeli conflict. 
An Administration official said today that he knew of Israel's desire for housing loan guarantees, but that the Administration had not formally reviewed the proposal or taken a position on it. #100,000 Emigres Expected Israel says it expects to receive 100,000 Soviet Jews in the next three years, in part because the United States has adopted new procedures restricting their admission to this country. For years, Israel has pressed Washington to encourage Soviet Jewish emigres to go to Israel rather than to the United States.
Israel estimates that it will need $3 billion to provide housing, jobs, education and other services for the Soviet Jews. The cost for housing alone is estimated at $2 billion.
Federal loan guarantees, under a program to finance housing projects in developing countries, would allow Israel to borrow money from commercial banks at low interest rates. But Congress would need to expand the program to accommodate Israel's needs because the worldwide total of loan guarantees under the program is $125 million in the coming year, and under current law no country can get more than $25 million a year.
On a visit to Washington last week, Finance Minister Shimon Peres asked for American help. In a meeting with members of the House Appropriations subcommittee responsible for foreign aid, Mr. Peres acknowledged, in response to a question, that the current Israeli Government would probably build some of the housing in the West Bank. The United States has said for years that the establishment of additional settlements posed ''an obstacle to peace.'' Supporters of such settlements say they enhance Israel's security and fulfill a mission to live in all the biblical land of Israel.
Arab countries have expressed alarm at the prospect that significant numbers of Soviet Jews might settle in the West Bank. Clovis F. Maksoud, the Arab League representative in the United States, said such migration would contribute to a ''creeping annexation'' of the occupied territories by Israel, undermining prospects for peace in the Middle East. Mr. Baker has called on Israel to ''forswear annexation'' of the territories.
Israel estimates that it will need to build 30,000 housing units for the 100,000 Soviet Jews, at an average cost of $65,000 a unit. Israeli officials said Soviet emigres would decide where to live based on such factors as where they could find jobs and where their relatives lived. Inevitably, the officials said, some emigres would want to live in the West Bank.
''Should we bar them from the West Bank?'' one official asked. ''I cannot imagine the Government of Israel, as it's constituted today, accepting such a restriction.''
 
A Promise to Repay
Congressional aides said that lawmakers might seek assurances that Israel would not use the money to build housing in the occupied territories.
In a summary of its proposal, Israel said the loan guarantees would not increase the budget deficit of the United States Government because Israel would repay the money it intends to borrow from private American banks.
Israel said it could not afford to borrow the money from commercial banks without Federal loan guarantees. The Israeli Government said it ''contacted several American financial institutions and learned that the most favorable conditions we could expect'' on such loans ''would make the program unfeasible.''
Until September 1988, the United States assumed that Jews leaving the Soviet Union had ''a well-founded fear of persecution'' and were eligible for admission to this country as refugees. However, since then, the United States has closely examined each applicant and has denied refugee status to 5,884 Soviet Jews, or 19 percent of those who applied in the last year.
Starting today, Jews leaving the Soviet Union on Israeli visas will no longer be able to change their destination and apply for visas to the United States in Vienna or Rome, as thousands have done in the last decade. Soviet citizens wishing to come to this country will have to apply at the American Embassy in Moscow, rather than in Vienna or Rome. Israeli officials say they hope this will end the phenomenon of Soviet Jews' not going to Israel after they leave Moscow.
Last week, Mr. Peres said he hoped the new housing would be ready when Soviet Jews arrive in Israel, and he added, ''I don't think there is anything more important in our own life than to have the Russian Jews come to Israel.''
Israeli officials said their Government would pay $2 billion of the resettlement costs with its own resources. They said they hoped the United Jewish Appeal and other private organizations would raise $600 million. This is in addition to the $400 million they hope to borrow with the help of loan guarantees from the United States.
 
4 Palestinians Killed
JERUSALEM, Oct. 1 (AP) - Israeli soldiers shot and killed three Palestinians in clashes in the occupied lands today, and Palestinian militants stabbed to death a man they accused of collaborating with Israel, the army and Arab hospital workers said.
Arab residents of the Gaza Strip were banned from entering Israel for a third day as Israelis celebrated Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year. The ban remains in effect until Monday morning.
