HEADLINE: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

SERIES: THE SPREADING WEB OF CRACK: LAST OF TWO ARTICLES

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

 BODY:
With the growth of crack addiction in the middle class, treatment specialists have discovered that affluent addicts are more likely to deny their problem at first, and more able to hide addiction's devastating costs.
Once in treatment, affluent addicts typically have more effective support from family and employers and an education level that makes them more receptive to health concerns.
Despite these advantages, there are no guarantees that even the best treatment will work. Expensive private treatment programs have increased markedly in recent years as the addiction in the middle class has grown. But treatment specialists say they still have much to learn about what particular strategies work for which patients, and why. 
The addicts themselves, some of whom have squandered not only money but marriage, family life and self-respect on crack, describe in detail a recovery process that is not just painful but never-ending.
 
'Collision With Reality'
The addict with social and economic support does not normally seek treatment until driven by some ''private collision with reality,'' in the words of Dr. Michael Sheehy of the Silver Hill Foundation in New Canaan, Conn., an institution with long experience treating addicts.
''For instance,'' the doctor said, ''nothing focuses the attention of your average middle-class person quite so quickly as a felony arrest.''
Many addicts arrive for initial treatment feeling that they are doing it for someone else - an attitude which, if continued, rarely presages success. ''Inner city addicts can hardly not face the reality of their addiction and situation,'' said Lee Chase, a Michigan drug counselor. ''But the middle class has the greatest denial instincts you can imagine.''
William Hopkins, director of street research for New York State's Division of Substance Abuse, agrees: ''In the poor neighborhoods, everyone knows every user and every dealer, so there is no public image to protect. Middle class addicts have both a public and a self-image to protect with denial.''
 
A Slide Into Paranoia
Typically, crack addicts who work become so paranoid about their addiction and the risk of discovery that they confine smoking to evenings or weekends, and usually do it alone. They smoke as much crack as they have and afterward may ease their depression by drinking and sleeping.
''They are incredible,'' agreed Joel Dannewitz, director of the crisis clinic for Aquarian Effort in Sacramento, Calif. ''They say, 'Well, yeah, I do some crack every day, but I'm not really an addict because I'm not poor. I don't go to crack houses. I don't use needles. And I don't hang around on street corners.' So we say: 'Well, then why is it your wife is leaving? And your boss is threatening to fire you?' They've got to see that bad is bad even when it's better than.''
 
THE ACCOUNTANT
Mike L., a 30-year-old accountant, had learned an important lesson about the personal and social corruption wrought by drugs. On his way to buy cocaine, he was stopped for a traffic violation in a small New York town and then arrested when the officer discovered marijuana in the car.
Mike soon found himself in the local judge's basement. ''That's a lot of money,'' said the judge, eyeing the $500 in Mike's wallet. ''Now, you don't want a drug arrest on your record, do you?''
The young man took the hint. He left $350 in the basement as a ''fine.'' Mike got no police record. Neither did he get any drug treatment.
In recent years, he began smoking crack in his bedroom at night and on weekends, when his daughters and wife would flee this strange new person. ''I never used a crack house, though, so I knew I wasn't a crack addict.''
He sold family property, consumed family bank accounts. ''Unless you go for help, I'm leaving,'' his wife said. And her lawyer's letter confirmed it. ''Find me someone to go to,'' said Mike.
 
Days of Craving
She did. The day Mike was to begin a one-month residential treatment, he left his family at a coffee shop. Instead of taking the train to the hospital, he bought more crack and hid in his bedroom. His wife found him there later and put him in a taxi. He smoked more crack on the train.
There followed days of craving. Hours of pacing. Drug dreams. Group therapy. There were private sessions with a psychiatrist and counselor. There were emotional highs and lows, and Mike was told to practice handling each.
''I just could not see myself as a drug low life. I was a nice guy. I manage lots of people at work. I'm in control. It was hard to admit that I wasn't in control of myself. Very hard.''
After a month Mike returned to work (only a company counselor knows of his addiction and treatment) and began attending daily meetings of Narcotics Anonymous. ''Sober life has frightening moments. The drug becomes your best friend and closest enemy at the same time. Spare time is frightening. Watching TV is frightening. And coming home from work now, seeing all the dealers just around the corner is difficult, I gotta say.''
 
Counting His Clean Time
Twenty-two weeks after his return home Mike slipped. He smoked marijuana - and the crack craving returned, as the doctor had predicted. Mike went out to buy some, but no dealers were around. After admitting his mistakes to his N.A. group, he started counting his clean time all over again. He walks home on different streets now. ''A slip is not always a fall,'' said Mike's doctor.
''It's frightening,'' said Mike, ''to think that right now I am determined never to smoke again, but three hours from now I could be out there. I got to be on guard forever.'' But his daughters no longer fear him. His wife remains understanding, if reserved. ''It's difficult to trust someone again after all those lies,'' Mike says. ''But there's definitely healing under way.''
The other night his wife gave him a compliment. She had just returned from getting money from their bank's cash machine. She said how nice it was to check the balance and find that someone had not emptied it. All Addicts Are Not Alike ''We're just beginning to get a sense of what treatments work,'' says Dr. Arnold M. Washton, who operates a New York treatment center.
Experts are finding that, although the addiction's power and destruction cut across class lines, the effectiveness and psychology of differing treatment strategies do not. As Dr. Sheehy put it: ''An addict is an addict is an addict. But a patient is not a patient is not a patient. Every one of them is different, from the inner city to the suburbs.''
Treatment skill comes in mixing and matching the medicines and therapies to the individual's addictions and underlying emotional problems.
''There is no magic bullet,'' says Dr. Jeffrey S. Rosecan, director of cocaine abuse treatment at New York's Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
Numerous private programs have emerged in the last three years to serve the thousands of working addicts with the insurance or private funds to cover residential treatments that normally last at least a month and may cost more than $1,000 a day.
 
Addiction's Wide Swath
Both the older private programs, which tend to rely on discreet doctor referrals, and the spread of new private addiction programs, a few of which advertise on radio and television, are now showing that most new patients are ''polyaddicts.'' They are addicted to more than one substance -crack and alcohol, for instance.
According to the National Institute on Drug Abuse surveys, the number of treatment centers and patients has risen sharply in recent years, from 3,018 with 173,479 patients in 1982 to 5,360 centers with 260,151 patients in 1987. Self-help groups report similar increases. Narcotics Anonymous says it had 2,000 active groups of addicts in the 50 states in 1982. Today, it estimates 14,000 groups - at least one in every county in the nation - with 2,000 more groups in 50 other countries.
There are no definitive figures on success rates, in part because there is no one standard treatment to judge. Some counselors say privately that some of the new treatment centers will only treat addicts as long as insurance lasts. These counselors are concerned about the quality of treatment at the new centers; they say the centers are not monitored or investigated.
 
The Motivation Factor
And unlike purely medical problems, much of any addiction treatment's success depends on each patient's personality, especially motivation.
''Addiction treatment,'' Dr. Washton said, ''is the only health care field where effectiveness is judged by results among significant numbers of people who don't want our help. It's like saying, 'Why is penicillin so ineffective among those patients who refuse the drug?' ''
Some studies and anecdotal experiences suggest treatments are successful with only one or sometimes two of every three patients staying clean. ''Recovering from addiction is a lifelong day-to-day struggle every day,'' said Mr. Chase, himself a recovering addict. ''Down the line, most patients relapse. They have to road-test our teaching.''
Counselors also find potent denial even among relatives who may be addicted not to a drug, but to the dependence of the person on the drug. Any change can seem to threaten their lives and that stability, even if that stability is painful and costly at times.
Treatment strategies vary from long, military-style regimens to looser out-patient clinics. But three ingredients have emerged as crucial: effective detoxification; longterm counseling, both individual and in groups dealing with the addiction and underlying problems such as depression or low self-esteem; and followup support.
Many complain that private treatment is too expensive and public treatment underfinanced. But, at least for initial help, support groups such as Narcotics Anonymous, Cocaine Anonymous or Alcoholics Anonymous remain free and without waiting lists, and with virtually hourly meetings in every city are open to anyone any time.
 
THE BUSINESSMAN
''I stopped smoking crack a couple of times by myself,'' said Brian B., a Midwesterner who is 30 and was married to a nonaddict. ''It was terrifying.
''But then I'd start getting clear-headed again, and I'd have some opinions - and my wife would go out and buy me some more. And I'd light it up and sit in front of the TV.''
The owner of a video-game leasing business in the Middle West, Brian is the son of an office supervisor. His first memory of getting high came at the age of 5. when a friend's father laughingly encouraged him to drink a beer. By 14, he had more than just tried vodka and marijuana. ''Sometimes I got angry or sad or quiet, and I was always being told I shouldn't feel that way. Drinking and pot let me feel the way I really felt.''
One time, he saw a friend snort a gram of cocaine, jump up, run into a wall and collapse in convulsions, turning a deathly shade of white. So by some turn of internal logic, Brian switched to smoking crack, which eventually cost $800 a week.
Whenever he tried to stop, he found himself eating compulsively. His first rehabilitation, 90 days of out-patient care, failed. ''But then I wanted to not drink and do drugs, or I wanted to die and I didn't care which.'' After a 30-day in-patient stay, he felt so secure he was afraid to leave. But he did. He then began 12 weeks of out-patient sessions and now attends Narcotics Anonymous sessions. Often his 6-year-old daughter attends simultaneous Ala-Tot meetings of children of addicts.
He said he was very afraid before his first Narcotics Anonymous meeting. Then he saw six of his old high-school snorting pals sitting there, too. The Language Of Treatment Among the new approaches in this new field of middle class crack treatment, Mr. Chase has found that even something as simple as the language spoken in group sessions can make a difference. Many middle class addicts are put off as much by torrents of street language as some inner city members are by recommended readings or academic citations. Other counselors find that descriptions of crack's impact on health arouse more concern among middle class addicts.
But Dr. Forest Tennant, who operates 20 California clinics and is drug adviser to the National Football League, says real scare tactics or dire health warnings do not work with the 1,500 middle-class addicts his clinics treat annually.
''They may have done some dumb things,'' he said. ''And their sense of discipline may be dormant. But these are educated people. I give them a menu of 20 things - nutrition requirements, food supplements, physical and mental exercises, new hobbies, life style changes, and so forth. I say you need to do 12 of these. Pick them. With someone less motivated, I wouldn't give them the choice.''
 
Testing Is Constant
Dr. Tennant takes ''the 'attaboy approach.'' The urine of all patients is tested every 48 hours, and those detailed results, showing declining amounts of harmful chemicals, are shown to abstaining patients as encouragement, like a successful dieter watching the scales each morning.
''But without the education, the family support and the motivation,'' Dr. Tennant adds, ''I could talk to some patients all day about getting their body chemistry back in balance by developing a breakfast habit of high-complex carbohydrates, and that would produce zero change.''
''In many inner city apartments there may be several addicts in the same family,'' said Dr. Tennant ''In the suburbs, an addict's family and co-workers may be shocked, but I have no trouble involving them in support, because crack is so devastating so quickly that the memory of the real Harry or Sally is still fresh.''
 
THE LONELY MAN
Steve G. has lost track of all the treatment programs he has tried. ''The trouble with all these therapies,'' he said with a smile, ''is they ruin your high. You start feeling guilty.''
He has gone through a series of encounter groups, residential and out-patient treatments and psychiatrist's visits, seeking to whip marijuana-cocaine-alcohol-crack addictions that consumed, among other things, a $50,000 trust fund. He did not feel he was addicted because he was not injecting drugs. ''I was big on denial,'' he says, a few days into another program.
Crack seemed the answer to loneliness and lingering depression over his mother's death. ''I was looking for something destructive to put me back in touch with the pain I'd become so comfortable with,'' he said.
But this time his motivation is greatest. His days are filled with the usual meetings. His nights are often filled with long, bad dreams. ''There are a lot of ups and downs,'' he said. And he is debating his outright release versus a halfway house. Where he will go next week he has no idea.
But he does know where he won't be going - to Manhattan's 167th Street or Times Square, where he could easily buy crack from the many street merchants. ''I was feeling pretty superior to them,'' he said. ''Then one day I realized something. They were smiling every time they saw me coming.'' Signs of Hope Despite Worry Dr. Rosecan and others are worried about the future because recent generations of teen-agers have insisted on experimenting with drugs, and crack allows no room for mere experimentation. Still, there are glimmers of hope. The total number of reported cocaine users declined, from 23 million in 1985 to 14.5 million last year, according to the National Institute on Drug Abuse.
And while some insurance companies are increasingly reluctant to finance multiple treatments, counselors say many employers are quietly understanding about rehabilitation absences. The General Motors Corporation says post-treatment addicts are even better workers than before their addiction.
''But crack is not the real problem,'' said Bruce Hindenach, executive director of the Capital Area Abuse Commission in Lansing, Mich. ''Crack addicts have a way of getting help or getting dead. And there will always be another drug to abuse. The real problem is all of our national addictions.''
And the general longterm ineffectiveness of many drug war strategies from the police car to the psychiatrist's couch are beginning to raise larger social questions.
''We are an increasingly addictive nation,'' said Dr. Washton. ''Crack, booze, cigarettes. Two years ago, Turkey was the bad guy for opium. Now it's Colombia. This month, the concern is crack. Next month it'll be crank. And then ice and whatever. See, that way it's 'them' not 'us.' That lets us avoid facing the more important, the more frightening question of ourselves and our own addictions.''
''The drug war,'' said Mr. Hopkins, ''is going to be won not by folks getting off drugs but by folks not getting on drugs. The police can't do that, only parents can, by teaching values again from Day One.''
In his new book, ''Willpower's Not Enough'' (Harper & Row), Dr. Washton notes that the United States has 2 percent of the world's population but consumes 60 percent of its illicit drugs. And the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism reports that American alcoholics and problem drinkers total 17.5 million, or 3 million more than cocaine users.
''People worry about being mugged by crack addicts,'' said Mr. Hindenach. ''But drunk drivers have got nothing to do with Colombia, and they kill 25,000 Americans every year.''
Robert Wadman is chief of police in Omaha, where crack is a daily problem now. ''We adults,'' he said, ''are staggering around with a vodka in one hand and a government-subsidized cigarette in the other, telling our kids they shouldn't use mind-altering substances that are bad for their health.
''Now what's the lesson you would draw from that?''
 
WHERE TO GO TO GET HELP
Anyone desiring help for drug addiction can seek simple conversation or referral to treatment services by calling local offices of Narcotics Anonymous or Alcoholics Anonymous, which are listed in the white pages. In the New York area the 24-hour number for A.A. is 212-601-5817.
National headquarters for Narcotics Anonymous is c/o Box 9999, Van Nuys, Calif. 91409. Phone 818-780-3951. Hours are 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. Pacific time.

HEADLINE: 'People's China' Celebrates, but Without the People

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 1

 BODY:
The People's Republic of China celebrated its 40th anniversary today with colorful dances and fireworks, along with such stiff security that ordinary Chinese could not get within a mile of the birthday party in Tiananmen Square for ''People's China.''
The cacophony as nearly 50,000 fireworks burst in the air was strikingly reminiscent of the crackle of machine-gun fire at the same location on June 4, when army troops killed hundreds of protesters and crushed the democracy movement. Largely because of international outrage, no foreign heads of state or heads of government came to China to join the celebration today. Even many ambassadors stayed away, among them the American Ambassador, James R. Lilley. 
In the viewing stand on Tiananmen Rostrum, where Mao declared the founding of the nation on Oct. 1, 1949, China's elderly leadership gathered to watch the show, but from clips shown on Chinese television even they seemed unusually quiet and withdrawn. Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, who was making his first evening appearance in years, looked old and wan as he stared impassively at the fireworks.
''What happened in Beijing not long ago was bad,'' Mr. Deng told Li Jong Ok, North Korea's Vice President, on the rostrum. ''But in the final analysis it is beneficial to us, because it made us more sober-minded.''
 
Revision of a Remark
Mr. Deng's comment, prominently reported by the official New China News Agency, seemed intended as a revision of the remark last week by the Communist Party leader, Jiang Zemin, that the killings were not a tragedy. Mr. Jiang's comment was regarded by many Chinese and foreigners as particularly callous.
Mr. Deng's clarification was only the latest in months of mixed signals about China's attitudes and policies. While top leaders repeatedly insist that they will never retreat from the decade-old policy of change and openness, the dismissal of some of the leading advocates of restructuring and a new enthusiasm for harsh language about ''class struggle'' and ''dictatorship of the proletariat'' have made many Chinese and foreigners worried that the country is seriously drifting backward.
The 40th anniversary celebration was to have been an occasion when Mr. Deng could bask in public adulation and commemorate the extraordinary achievements of his decade in power. Five years ago, during the 35th anniversary celebrations, he rode in the parade and was hailed with enormous warmth and respect.
Now, however, attitudes toward the 85-year-old Mr. Deng have changed, and criticism on many counts is not hard to find. Among the charges are that he refuses to give up power, that he ordered the democracy movement crushed, that he allowed corruption and nepotism in his family, and that he permitted inflation and other economic problems to get out of hand.
In what may be a sign of his infirmity, Mr. Deng's daughter, Deng Rong, appeared to be seated behind him, apparently to repeat comments in his left ear, since he is deaf in his right ear.
The authorities were apprehensive that dissidents, some of whom possess machine guns taken from soldiers in early June, might mar the festivities, and security was remarkable even by the standards of Beijing under martial law. The Avenue of Eternal Peace, the main east-west thoroughfare, was blocked off by layer after layer of troops, police and ordinary workers who were deputized with temporary identification cards. Tens of thousands of troops and police officers seemed to be in the downtown area, many of them just out of sight in back alleys, and many were armed with machine guns.
 
A Shortage of Guests
No attack was known to have taken place, and the major obvious embarrassment lay in the shortage of guests on the rostrum. The official list of foreigners who met Mr. Deng was strikingly meager, including only such dignitaries as a Czech Politburo member, a senior Pakistani legislator, a Cuban Communist Party official, and cabinet ministers from Ecuador and Mongolia. The Soviet Union was represented by the deputy chairman of the Soviet-Chinese Friendship Society, identified as I. Arkiphov. The only American on the rostrum was former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who is on a private visit.
All the top Chinese leaders were on the rostrum, including the 84-year-old Chen Yun, who had not been seen in public for nearly two years. Mr. Chen, who appeared briefly on television and did not look well, is chairman of the Communist Party's Central Advisory Commission and may be second in influence only to Mr. Deng.
On Tiananmen Square itself, more than 100,000 young people danced together to celebrate the anniversary. The young people, who had been chosen carefully and had practiced for a month for the event, appeared more languid than either joyous or resentful.
During the 35th anniversary celebrations, there was a huge military parade around Tiananmen Square, but plans for another were canceled this year, apparently because Beijing residents had seen enough weaponry in recent months. A group of 45 soldiers, however, did goose-step on cue in front of the rostrum.
Early in the day, major city parks were opened for special festivities like martial arts exhibitions and concerts. As with the Tiananmen Square festivities, only the elite with special passes were allowed to enter the parks in the morning, when activities were under way. In the afternoon, the exhibitions and concerts ended and the general public was admitted.

HEADLINE: Mexican Leader in the U.S. for Talks

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 1

 BODY:
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico left for Washington today on his first official visit to the United States, intent on testing Bush Administration pledges to help restore his country's economy while avoiding entanglement in the American Government's new drug control strategy.
Relations between Mexico and the United States appear to be on their best footing in years. Speaking at the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund last week, President Bush praised Mr. Salinas, who took office last December, as a ''courageous leader'' who is ''turning away from state control'' of the economy and ''opening the door to private initiative.''
In an interview here with several American reporters, however, Mr. Salinas, who arrived in Washington this evening, argued that his sweeping economic program has not yet been answered by a corresponding opening of the American market to Mexican products. 
''I think that reciprocity in commercial relations is fundamental,'' he said. ''Isn't that what the United States is asking of Japan?''
 
Cooperation on Drugs
Though the Mexican President listed economic issues - trade, investment and debt among them - as his top priority in talks with American officials, he also recognized that drugs were certain to be a major item on the agenda as a result of international alarm over events in Colombia. Mr. Salinas said he plans while in the United States to ''insist on greater cooperation among governments'' in fighting drug trafficking, saying that ''a greater exchange of information'' on traffickers' movements is necessary.
''We have engaged in an intense battle, so intense that it has us concerned,'' he said of his Government. ''To have seized 22 tons of cocaine, the equivalent of one-third of total consumption of the United States, in nine months means that a lot of drugs are heading toward the United States, and an important part of that is coming through here.''
Mr. Salinas spoke on Thursday night, hours before American anti-drug forces seized 20 tons of cocaine in Los Angeles, said to have entered the United States via Mexico.
Mr. Salinas also made it clear he has no interest in taking part in the type of joint anti-narcotics field operations that the United States has begun carrying out with local authorities in countries like Bolivia, Colombia and Peru.
''The responsibility for combating drug trafficking in Mexico belongs exclusively to Mexicans,'' he said.
Even before announcing his new anti-drug program on Sept. 5, President Bush had said the United States military would be deployed ''to protect our borders'' from drug traffickers. Previous Mexican administrations have rejected Washington's requests that American forces be allowed to engage in ''hot pursuit'' of traffickers' planes and land vehicles as they cross the 1,952-mile border into Mexico, a stand Mr. Salinas reiterated.
''Along the border, Mexico will act on the Mexican side,'' he said. ''On the American side, those whom the Americans want to act will do so,'' he said.
On another perennial border problem, illegal immigration by Mexicans to the United States, Mr. Salinas said he would argue to the Americans he meets that ''the demand for Mexican workers is going to continue'' despite legislation aimed at halting it because ''the economic reality of the United States creates that demand.''
But Mr. Salinas, a 41-year-old economist who earned a doctorate and two masters' degrees from Harvard University in the mid 1970's, also linked the lessening of that migratory flow to economic recovery within Mexico, which since 1982 has been staggering under the burden of recession, annual inflation of as much as 160 percent and a foreign debt of $100 billion.
''I would prefer that Mexican workers stay and work here in Mexico,'' he said. ''That is why the recovery of our economic growth and the generation of greater job opportunities here in our nation so interests me. Without a doubt, that can attenuate the migration of Mexicans to the United States.''
 
Preferential Treatment Sought
With the aim of stimulating the Mexican economy in precisely that manner, Mr. Salinas said he would press for preferential treatment for his country's exports, such as textiles, steel and agricultural products. ''The permanence of Mexico's economic opening depends on our having reciprocity in other markets, which is why it is so important to have an agreement by sectors with the United States,'' he said.
Despite the policy differences, Mr. Salinas said he expected his meetings with Mr. Bush to be marked by ''cordiality and respect.''
''There is good faith and good will on the part of both administrations,'' he said. ''There will always be difficulties when you have so long a border and two economies that are so asymmetrical, but the atmosphere is positive and there are no sour themes in the relationship today.''

HEADLINE: In Nicaragua, the Election Observers Are Coming!

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DIRIAMBA, Nicaragua, Oct. 1

 BODY:
As national voter registration began today, Nicaraguans got their first look at what will be a huge international effort to preserve peace and supervise free elections in their war-battered country.
At registration centers here and throughout the country, dozens of two-member observer teams from the United Nations and the Organization of American States were sent out in shiny white jeeps to guard against fraud or other irregularities.
The Secretary General of the O.A.S., Joao Baena Soares, led an observer team to oversee registration in the heavily populated Pacific Coast region. United Nations technicians inaugurated a sophisticated radio and satellite communications network that will link hundreds of international observers across Nicaragua from now through February, when the elections are scheduled to take place. 
In New York and in Honduras this weekend, officials discussed final arrangements for two or three large new international contingents, including armed military units, that are being set up to monitor Nicaragua's borders and oversee demobilization of the contra rebel army. Those units are expected to begin operations in earnest over the next two months. A First for the U.N. ''It is the first time that the U.N. has been involved in a Latin American country in this kind of work,'' said Josue Cardoza Perdomo, a retired Colombian Air Force officer and a 20-year United Nations veteran who inspected registration procedures today as part of the observer force assigned to Diriamba, about 30 miles south of Managua. ''It is also the first time we have agreed to supervise elections in an independent country.''
The formidable international presence, established piecemeal under a series of regional peace accords, began to take shape six weeks ago and has quickly become a visible feature of Nicaraguan life. International officials hope the scale of the undertaking will, in itself, discourage conflict and election fraud and help promote a fresh start for this deeply divided society.
The most visible and unusual of the international contingents setting up operations are assigned the task of supervising the election process, from this month's voter registration to the conduct of the campaign to the final vote count. The two principal organizations will be the United Nations and the Organization of American States, which will conduct separate but coordinated monitoring efforts under an accord signed by the five Central American Presidents last February in Tesoro Beach, El Salvador.
 
Separate Mission by Carter
The two missions, of roughly equal size, will be augmented later in the campaign by former President Jimmy Carter, who has accepted a separate invitation from the Nicaraguan Government to lead a 30-member group to monitor the elections under the auspices of the Council of Freely Elected Heads of Government.
In contrast to efforts to monitor voting in countries like the Philippines, El Salvador and Panama, international officials say the effort in Nicaragua will place unusual emphasis on monitoring election conditions over the entire campaign period, rather than concentrating primarily on the voting day.
In Diriamba, Mr. Cardoza and his partner, Pedro Menendez Pareves, a Chilean-born United Nations economist, were given a respectful, even deferential reception by poll workers in school rooms, city buildings and other small offices that had been converted for use as registration centers.
The two observers heard complaints from some opposition poll workers who maintained that their credentials were rejected by local voting authorities. But the credential problems appeared to be associated largely with first-day difficulties of a large-scale registration process. Other opposition workers were accepted without problem, and Mr. Baena expressed satisfaction with the overall outcome of the day's events.
The acceptance of the observer role marked an institutional turning point for the United Nations, which has long experience in overseeing elections in partitioned territories or former colonies, but has never before monitored elections in a sovereign country. The political novelty of the mission was recently heightened by the choice of an American, Elliot L. Richardson, to be the personal representative of the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, in overseeing the mission.
 
'Almost Unheard Of'
''We've done something that is almost unheard of,'' said a senior United Nations official in New York, ''which is to appoint an American to oversee elections in a country with which the United States is virtually at war.''
Day-to-day operations of the observer force will be handled by a United Nations official from Pakistan, Iqbal Riza. But Mr. Richardson is to visit Nicaragua at important moments in the electoral process, and will have a central role in shaping the organization's final report on the conduct and fairness of the election. International officials hope that his participation will eliminate any doubt about the impartiality of the verification process, particularly for conservative Americans, whose opinion is considered important to broad acceptance of the election results.
''In that sense,'' the official said, ''The credibility of someone like Richardson might be bigger than that of the U.N. itself.''
 
Experienced Observers
The United Nations contingent now includes 29 full-time observers, technicians and specialists in electoral procedure. They are assisted by personnel from other United Nations agencies already operating in the country, together with 26 Nicaraguan drivers and secretaries.
A spokesman, Angelica Hunt, said that all of the observers, who wear light blue hats and armbands with United Nations insignia for identification, are experienced United Nations officers from countries other than Nicaragua, and that most are from Western Europe and Latin America.
Mrs. Hunt said that during the campaign, which is under way, the observer force will be charged with keeping track of all aspects of the election process, including voter rolls, the amount of air time and advertising space devoted to the campaign, the use of official property or personnel for political purposes and other politically sensitive issues.
 
Force to Grow
By November, the number of United Nations observers is expected to double, and then to rise again in February, when the overall number of observers is to reach at least 160. Those observers, assisted by personnel from other United Nations agencies, will form 80 mobile monitoring teams, a number that United Nations officials say will permit close surveillance of at least 10 percent of all polling stations in the country, yielding a clear statistical picture of any irregularities.
A similar number of teams will also be fielded by the Organization of American States, giving a separate but equally comprehensive picture of the elections, international officials say.
In mid-October, officials from a combined United Nations-O.A.S. task force, the International Commission for Assistance and Verification, will visit contra bases in Honduras to begin preparing for the repatriation or relocation of the estimated 6,000 to 10,000 anti-Sandinista guerrillas in remaining camps there. Under regional agrements signed Aug. 7 in Tela, Honduras, the commission will also be responsible for receiving and storing arms surrendered by the guerrillas. It will therefore have a military branch that will carry arms intended for defense, United Nations officials say.
 
Armed and Uniformed
Mobile units of United Nations military observers will be deployed in November. The United Nations Observers in Central America will use jeeps and helicopters to monitor all borders among the five Central American countries, but are expected to focus the largest share of their energies on the Honduran-Nicaraguan border. The units, in which there will be more than 100 trained observers from Spain, Canada, Venezuela and Colombia, will be uniformed and carry arms intended for defense, United Nations officials say. A technical planning mission for the force visited the region late last month, and approval of the final plan is expected from the Security Council this month.
A third, still larger United Nations military mission contemplated by the Tela accords would be a full-fledged peace-keeping force to prevent incursions along the Honduran-Nicaraguan border. United Nations officials have indicated their willingness to consider such a mission, but have said the two countries involved have not raised the issue directly since signing the Tela agreements. Such a force would require Security Council approval.

HEADLINE: Childhood Is Not Safe, Congress Study Warns

BYLINE: By JULIE JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
More children than ever are living in the streets or in families shattered by divorce, drugs or poverty, a Congressional study has reported.
It said that as cuts in Federal spending have worsened the plight of many poor people and as mounting economic pressures have squeezed the middle class, childhood has become ''far more precarious and less safe for millions of America's children.'' The bipartisan report, to be made public Monday, compiles grim statistics showing that conditions in the past decade have worsened dramatically for black and Hispanic families, leaving those children in greatest jeopardy.
 
The Hope and the Reality
And even among those children who seem destined for high achievement, the report said, hopes appear tempered by an acceptance that drugs, pregnancy or bad grades and bad jobs are overwhelming many of their peers. 
''This is now a problem of national scope,'' said Representative George Miller, Democrat of California, chairman of the House Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families, which prepared the report. ''It's not restricted to those areas without an infrastructure,'' he said. ''It's not restricted to an inner-city ghetto, and it's not restricted to those areas hardest hit by the recession.''
 
The 'Incremental' Gains
Other experts note that ''incremental,'' or partial, gains have been made: for example, new tax cuts for low-income families with children, and limited expansions in Medicaid, and the Federal and state health program for the poor.
Still, said James D. Weill, general counsel to the Children's Defense Fund, whose research underscores the House report, ''The progress that we're making is far too slow.
For those children at greatest risk, the report says, talk of incremental gains has little meaning in their lives, which concentrate on strategies of survival, often with little guidance from adults.
Last year more than half the nation's black children lived only with their mothers and fewer than 4 in 10 lived with both parents. By comparison, about 79 percent of white children lived with both parents in 1988. In 1980, 82.7 of American white children lived with two parents and 42.2 percent of the nation's black children did.
Violence, too, takes a heavier toll among black men and boys, and experts say the risks have grown more critical as urban drug wars increase. Black males from the age of 15 to 19 die by homicide, execution or as a result of police actions at the rate of 51.5 per 100,000.
 
Open Question: The Future
White males in the same age group die at the rate of 8.6 per 100,000 in the same circumstances. Among older black males, aged 20 to 24, the rate jumps to 107.7 per 100,000. What remains unanswered, said educators, public policy experts and lawmakers, is the question of what government must do to reverse the trends.
''It's a very demoralizing report with respect to the future of children,'' Mr. Miller said.
In large part, he blames the economic policies of President Ronald Reagan. He said they amounted to ''a massive social experiment on our children during the 1980's consisting of major changes in the economy and work force with cutbacks in public support.''
Republicans on the House panel take issue with such finger-pointing. But they acknowledge the fundamental shifts in family life in the last 10 years.
''The data in there is factual,'' said Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., Republican of Virginia, the ranking minority committee member, ''but to say that kids are victims of our economic system or of government policies is wrong.''
 
As the Statistics Tell It
The report is based on Federal statistics gathered by the Bureau of the Census, the Labor Department and other Government agencies. It is the third in a series that were begun by the House committee in 1983. Among its other findings are these:
* Children, especially the very young, are the single largest poverty group among all Americans. In 1987, 1 in 5 children of school age and 1 in 4 preschoolers lived in poverty; black and Hispanic children are two to three times more likely to be poor than white children.
* In 1950, 4 percent of all babies were born to unmarried women. The number of such births has increased by a factor of five from 142,000 in 1950 to 878,000 in 1986.
* Despite a widespread Government consensus that Federal programs like Head Start work, low-income and minority children are the least likely to be educated in their early chidhood.
* In 1988, 1 in 4 girls 15 years old reported that they had had sexual intercourse. Among 19-year-olds, 4 out of 5 reported they had had sex; among 19-year-old males, 88 percent said they had had sex.
* The proportion of homeless children in shelters rose to 40 percent in 1988 from 21 percent in 1984.
 
More Precarious, Less Safe
''The combined effects of persistently high rates of poverty, declining earnings, underemployment, and single parenting have made childhood far more precarious and less safe for millions of America's children,'' the report says.
Twelve-year-old Jose Navarro confronts risk day to day in the Ramona Gardens housing project of East Los Angeles.
In an interview, he called the gangs that dominate schools and sidewalks there ''the things that really interfere with your life.''
Jose aspires to be a genetic engineer, he said, ''because maybe I could change the facts of the world.''

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON TALK;
Aid to Eastern Europe: Almost an Afterthought

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
A group of Hungarians, Hungarian-Americans and others gathered for dinner one night last week, with Foreign Minister Gyula Horn, who had traveled from Budapest to the United States to speak at the United Nations and to meet with senior officials in Washington, as the guest of honor.
Given the stirring events in Hungary in the last few months - the decisions to hold free elections, to dismantle sections of the Iron Curtain, to open the gates of escape to thousands of East Germans - it was not surprising that an ebullient mood prevailed. But there was also an undercurrent of dissatisfaction, and as always, the sardonic Hungarians encapsulated it in a joke.
''The reason America can't send us any money,'' one of the visitors said, ''is that they're saving every penny to fix the streets in New York.'' 
Despite the Bush Administration's attempts to suggest otherwise, both the Polish and the Hungarian Governments are sorely disappointed by the amount of financial and other help Mr. Bush has provided as they struggle to find a new future.
Within the last week, State Department officials say, the Polish Government has done much to cut the intellectual legs from under one of the answers the Administration has been giving when asked why it has pledged only $169 million to help Warsaw and $25 million to help Budapest. We mustn't send too much, American policy makers have been saying, voices lowered so as not to give offense, because they don't know how to use it effectively.
That position will be harder to maintain now that the Poles have sent to Washington a detailed description of how they plan to restructure their economy, precisely so that it can absorb more foreign aid.
Likewise, the White House argument that there was just no money in the budget for large-scale United States aid has been undercut to some degree by the speed with which the President and Congress managed to find $1 billion to help repair the ravages of Hurricane Hugo.
Many people in Washington, if predictably fewer elsewhere in the country, think the situation in Poland and Hungary, so fraught with danger and so laden with opportunity, as all the foreign-policy experts agree, is an emergency every bit as worthy of American attention as the one in the Caribbean and the Carolinas.
As a matter of fact, Madeleine K. Albright, the Czech-born foreign-policy scholar who advised Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in his 1988 Presidential campaign, urged some time ago that the United States look upon the Poles and the Hungarians as victims of a political-economic earthquake.
By the weekend, there were reports that Mr. Bush was giving serious thought to new assistance to Eastern Europe. Indeed, at a conference in Brussels last Tuesday, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Ralph Johnson said additional commitments were possible. That pleased the 23 other non-Communist countries at the meeting, but neither they nor critics at home are yet convinced that Washington is ready to develop a comprehensive strategy for dealing with the surging change in Eastern Europe.
Even The Wall Street Journal teased the Administration on Friday, noting the contrast between the meager levels of aid to Poland and Hungary and the banners hung from the Treasury that boast, ''Financing Freedom for 200 Years.''
''We need to applaud early, clearly and emphatically every sign of movement toward democracy,'' said Sol M. Linowitz, who has held senior diplomatic posts under Democratic presidents. ''Countries that choose to follow our path have the right to expect something more than words, and they aren't getting it.
''Even if we step up aid to Poland now, the world sees us as giving in, kicking and screaming, and we lose all credit for aligning ourselves with the forces of freedom.''
Is there a third, unacknowledged reason why the Bush Administration has moved so slowly? Perhaps, say some analysts here; perhaps a caculation has been made that too rapid progress by some of the satellites would produce a backlash in Moscow, either prompting a crackdown as in 1956 or 1968 or toppling Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

HEADLINE: H.U.D. Ties of 2 Bush Nominees Raise Roadblocks

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
The disclosure of widespread mismanagement and political favoritism at the Department of Housing and Urban Development has placed roadblocks in the Senate confirmation process for two of President Bush's nominees who had ties to the agency.
Congressional officials identified the two as George W. Haley, who was nominated to direct the Federal Postal Rate Commission, and Brian W. Clymer, chosen to head the Urban Mass Transportation Administration. The Federal posts each pay an annual salary of $82,500.
H.U.D. documents show that Mr. Haley, a friend of former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr., lobbied housing officials for Federal aid, and there have been news reports that Mr. Clymer's auditing firm got no-bid contracts from a quasi-public agency in Pennsylvania that received H.U.D. money. 
Mr. Haley and Mr. Clymer did not return telephone calls last week, although Mr. Haley has said in the past that he did not use improper influence in his dealings with the housing department.
 
Vote Delayed Indefinitely
Congressional officials said the Senate was supposed to vote on Mr. Clymer's nomination late last month, but the vote was delayed indefinitely at the request of Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, which is responsible for overseeing H.U.D.
One official said Senator Riegle has asked aides to investigate the news reports about Mr. Clymer's firm.
H.U.D. files show that Mr. Haley is one of several prominent Republicans who lobbied Mr. Pierce and other H.U.D. officials for Federal assistance under the agency's Moderate Rehabilitation program.
Investigators at H.U.D. and in Congress have charged that because of political abuses, millions of dollars under the program were diverted to housing projects favored by well-known Republicans, including friends of Mr. Pierce.
''Obviously we want to know why Haley approached Pierce and whether Haley got any special treatment,'' said a Senate aide, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Mr. Haley's nomination to direct the Postal Commission was sent to the Senate several days ago. Among the commission's duties is recommending changes in postal fees and reviews other activities of the Postal Service.
 
'A Fair Shake'
In a Nov. 3, 1987, letter, Mr. Haley, a Washington lawyer and former Republican candidate for Senate from Maryland, asked for Federal assistance for a nearly $3 million housing project in a town in Puerto Rico, Trujillo Alto.
''I request your personal involvement to make certain the proposal gets a fair shake,'' Mr. Haley wrote to Mr. Pierce. ''I will be pleased to have my Puerto Rico associates and myself meet with you at your convenience.'' Attached was a copy of Trujillo Alto's proposal.
The letter concluded: ''Thanks very, very much. George.''
According to H.U.D. documents, the agency agreed the next year to provide Trujillo Alto with nearly $22 million in housing subsidies under the Moderate Rehabilitation program.
The documents show that earlier in the year, Mr. Haley had lobbied the housing department on behalf of the Comprehensive Housing Investment Corporation and that he had been granted a meeting with several senior H.U.D. officials; Mr. Pierce participated in the meeting by phone.
''It was especially gratifying to my team and to me that you participated in the conference from home,'' Mr. Haley wrote on Jan. 15, 1987. ''We believe very strongly in the product displayed and believe that it will make a significant impact in affordable attractive housing.''
The company and the product were not described further in the letter, and it was not immediately clear whether Comprehensive Housing Investment received a H.U.D. contract. The company does not have a telephone listing in Washington.
In interviews earlier this year, before his nomination to the postal commission, Mr. Haley gave conflicting accounts of his H.U.D. lobbying activities, and at one point said that he could not recall any involvement in a Puerto Rico housing project.
But he insisted that if he was involved in the Puerto Rico project, he did not receive any lobbying fees, and his name did not turn up in an internal H.U.D. audit of the Moderate Rehabilitation program.
The Senate investigation of Mr. Clymer was begun Senate after news reports that his accounting firm received contracts from the Delaware County Partnership for Economic Development without competitive bidding, as required by Federal regulation.
The agency, which receives H.U.D. assistance, was founded by Representative Curt Weldon, a Pennsylvania Republican, and Mr. Clymer was Mr. Weldon's campaign treasurer in his last three election campaigns.
The Urban Mass Transportation Administration is charged with promoting urban development through improved mass transportation systems.

HEADLINE: TOPICS OF THE TIMES;
Why Subsidize Gridlock?

 BODY:
A growing crush of commuter traffic threatens the economic vitality and air quality of the nation's cities. Yet present Federal tax policy actively encourages people to drive to work. Legislation now pending in the Senate could help erode this perverse tax bias.
Under the Federal tax code, employers may offer the full cost of parking near the workplace as a tax-free benefit to employees, and deduct the whole amount as a business expense. That's a huge subsidy: a parking space in midtown Manhattan can cost up to $400 a month. In contrast, the tax-free reimbursement available to workers who commute by subway, train or bus is limited to a paltry $15 per month. If the employer pays more than $15, the entire benefit becomes taxable. Small wonder, then, that most employers don't consider it worth the administrative hassle to offer transit vouchers.
A measure sponsored by Senators Alfonse D'Amato and Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and William Armstrong of Colorado would raise the limit on transit vouchers to $30. If an employer provides more than $30, only the excess would be taxable. That's still low: Long Island Railroad commuters, for example, pay an average of $140 a month. But it's a step in the right direction.

HEADLINE: Let Nicaragua Vote Without Our Intervention;
Marines Didn't Do It

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Reporting the nomination of Violeta de Chamorro as the opposition presidential candidate in Nicaragua, you say the Somoza family ''was installed by the United States Marines in 1934'' (front page, Sept. 4).
The reality, as analyzed by Mark Falcoff in the fall 1983 issue of This World, is that ''there was no direct relationship between the U.S. and . . . the creation of the Somoza dictatorship . . . [which neither] figured in U.S. plans or policies nor [was] greeted by the State Department with satisfaction or even tacit approval.'' 
I might add that all the marines had left Nicaragua in 1933, consistent with President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Good Neighbor Policy.
This is not a small factual error. It is widely believed and has exaggerated American guilt feelings about recent events in Nicaragua. As Mr. Falcoff says, ''No one can dispute that [the Somoza coup] could never have taken place in Nicaragua without U.S. intervention in 1912.'' But there is a vast difference between that statement and your assertion.
A reading of Nicaragua's bloody, authoritarian, exploitative history demonstrates that Nicaragua's continuing tragedy is largely home grown.
 
LAWRENCE E. HARRISON
 Cambridge, Mass., Sept. 5, 1989
The writer directed the Agency for International Development mission to Nicaragua, 1979-81.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Some Enchanted 'Saigon'

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Seems not so long ago that I produced an NBC radio broadcast from Mary Martin's dressing room after the London opening of ''South Pacific.'' That smash hit was an American artistic export based on stories growing out of the American victory in World War II; some enchanted evening.
The hottest ticket in London today is ''Miss Saigon,'' an Anglo-French theatrical collaboration growing out of the American military defeat in Vietnam. As musical spectacle, it's right up there with the same producer's ''Cats'' and ''Les Miserables'' - rousing, poignant, breathtakingly staged -with the big moment of the helicopter leaving our allies behind to suffer and die at least comparable in impact to the crash of the chandelier in his ''Phantom of the Opera.'' 
Although the plot - with its return to the Orient of an American serviceman and the heartbreak of the girl he left behind - is sure to evoke comparisons with ''Madame Butterfly,'' the message of this drama is blunter: ''You're not the only one we betrayed,'' says one G.I., and the second act's big number features a pimp deriding ''the American dream.''
Theater reviewing is not my thing. However, like the satirist who purported to review the gamekeeping passages in ''Lady Chatterly's Lover'' for Field and Stream magazine, I have an interest in looking at the politics behind the making of the Vietnam myth, to which this extravaganza contributes.
That myth has been set forth in dozens of apocalyptic films, novels, mini-series, biographies and memoirs: the Vietnam War was an unjustified intervention by the West in the world of the East; the experience brutalized, desensitized or traumatized the soldiers forced to go; the whole business caused tragedy for individual Asians and brought international humiliation for an absurdly anti-Communist United States.
You cannot find a drama about the nobility of trying to save an ally from invasion, or a show blasting the indecision that kept us from striking hard early with an eye to winning the war. Such theses invite only derision and would sell no tickets. Besides, right-wingers make lousy dramatists.
Instead, the story that is continually hammered home, often violently on film and more tenderly in this love story on stage, is a variation of this theme: We were self-righteous, well-meaning ideologues who broke faith, broke heads and broke hearts. That's the only dish being served up to the next generation. Go argue with a myth.
I like to think that somewhere in Hanoi a young Vietnamese dramatist-novelist-musician is thinking of writing a show. His hero is General Giap, the most successful military figure of the past generation, and his heroine, a beautiful granddaughter of Ho Chi Minh, is infused with anti-colonialist fervor.
In the first act, the brave partisans throw the French out of Dien Bien Phu and assert their nationhood, modeled on strict Leninism. Then Ho sends Giap south, and despite a succession of American bombing halts, the resolute general - nicknamed ''Missile'' Giap by a young American Presidential candidate - defeats the corrupt puppets in Saigon. The act ends with a helicopter taking their American protectors away. Long intermission of 15 years, during which the world changes.
The final act is a downer. Vietnam, now united, is a mess. The people in the South are conquered and sullen, wondering if they should have tried to escape in boats; the people in the North are poor, hungry, resentful and confused. The Soviets cannot help, the Chinese hate them, the West is unwilling to trade. Where are the promises of the long-dead Ho? Where is the spirit that once sprung from suffering and discipline? What was all the sacrifice for?
In a poignant scene, General Giap reviews the men who were once his inconquerable army: tired men straggling home from inconclusive years in Cambodia, coming home to unemployment and singing the Khmer Rouge Blues. At the end, Ho's vibrant granddaughter, disillusioned and broke, grabs a boat to Hong Kong, where she becomes a bar girl in a British-American club and joins the colonialists in dreading the inexorable Chinese takeover.
Needs work, of course; our unknown composer-poet in Hanoi would have to liven it up because Communist audiences desperately need escape from the despair that Western audiences enjoy escaping to.
No, ''Miss Ho Chi Minh City'' could never be the megahit that ''Miss Saigon'' is sure to be. Its derivative concept has this great flaw: True art never follows real life.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

HEADLINE: BENSONHURST ON STAGE: PLOT IS SADLY FAMILIAR, THE PLAYWRIGHT SAYS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL FREITAG

 BODY:
There were times when he was growing up in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, Frank Pugliese said, when he felt afraid - afraid of the angry young men who hung out at street corners and candy shops getting drunk and picking fights, and afraid that he might become one of them.
''When I went to college, I saw myself on the edge,'' he said. ''I knew I could go either way.''
But in college, Mr. Pugliese said, he found a way to deal with his conflicting emotions. He wrote a play. 
Set in Bensonhurst, ''Aven' U Boys'' is ''about people I knew and stories I heard growing up,'' said Mr. Pugliese, who is 27 years old and now lives in Greenwich Village. The title refers to a street in Bensonhurst where the characters gather.
 
Similar to Hawkins Killing
The play, which runs through Oct. 8 at the Space at 114 West 17th Street in Chelsea, is striking not only for its raw emotions but for its similarities to the recent killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins, a black youth who ventured into Bensonhurst to look at a used car and was surrounded by white youths and gunned down.
One of the play's plotlines centers on the fatal beating of a black man who, in search of a sandwich, crosses into a white neighborhood. The three young men who participate in the beating act as if they are unfazed, but display hints of guilt.
The play opens with the three men idly punching each other and casually bragging about the beating.
''They ain't human. They come from some African animal or somethin','' one of them says.
 
Similarities Sadden Playwright
''They know enough to know he shouldn't come around for no . . . sandwich,'' the same character says later. ''If he stayed on his side of the tracks, none of this woulda' happened.''
The similarities between the seven-year-old play, written in Mr. Pugliese's second year at Cornell University, and the murder of Mr. Hawkins did not surprise Mr. Pugliese so much as sadden him. Bensonhurst, he said, is a tightly knit community of hard-working Italian-Americans. But it is also a neighborhood where some frustrated young men are so full of racial hatred that they are capable of murder, he said.
''I don't like the feeling in the air there - it's not that optimistic,'' he said. ''A lot of people are feeling threatened. Crime is on the rise, the dropout rate is on the rise and unemployment is on the rise.''
The play, Mr. Pugliese said, is neither an attack on nor a defense of Bensonhurst. Rather, he said, it is an attempt to explore the motivations of some of the people who live there.
 
Theme: Violence Unacceptable
Nonetheless, Mr. Pugliese acknowledged that his play has a message: ''The bottom line,'' he said, ''is that violence is unacceptable.''
The play ends with one of the men confessing to his black girlfriend that he watched the racial attack. Rather than empathizing as he expects, she kicks him out of her apartment.
''I can't believe this,'' he says. ''I didn't have to tell ya.''
''Yes you did!'' she replies. ''But I don't have to forgive you.''
 
'That Stuff Never Happens'
''Linda,'' he says, ''life is short. The past is past. Let's worry about us. When the bomb hits we're all gonna die anyways.''
''The world's not going to end with a bomb,'' she replies. ''It's going to end with people like you standing around doing nothing.''
Fisher Stevens, who portrays one of the three men, said that when he first read the play, he thought it should be set in 1958, because ''that stuff never happens anymore.''
But a week after the play went into rehearsals, he said, Mr. Hawkins was killed.

HEADLINE: JUDGE UPSETS RULE REQUIRING MINORITY CONSTRUCTION HIRING

BYLINE: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

 BODY:
A judge has struck down a regulation that Mayor Edward I. Koch imposed in 1980 to require contractors to hire ''economically disadvantaged'' trainees for construction projects that are built and financed by New York City.
The city's Corporation Counsel, Peter L. Zimroth, said last week that the city would appeal the decision and would also prepare legislation to reinstate the trainee program, which has helped hundreds of members of minorities to enter the construction industry.
''It has been a very effective program,'' Mr. Zimroth said, ''and we do not want to lose it.'' 
Justice Leonard N. Cohen, who ruled against the program in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, praised the purpose of the program. But he found that the Mayor lacked the authority to impose it with an executive order without legislative approval.
 
'Good Intentions'
In his decision, which was signed on Sept. 22 and received by city officials last week, Justice Cohen noted that the city ''argues that the Mayor has the power and obligation to implement programs designed to prohibit discriminatory hiring practices.''
''The good intentions of the Mayor's executive order, a commendable and socially desirable investment in people, is not at issue here,'' the judge said. ''Rather, the issue is whether the Mayor is legally empowered to issue this affirmative remedial order in the absence of a grant of legislative power.
''Here,'' he continued, ''there has been no City Council or other legislative grant of power to permit an executive affirmative remedial plan which mandates trainee employment preferences for economically disadvantaged persons involving city contracts.''
 
Another Ruling
Citing an earlier case, Justice Cohen noted that the state's Court of Appeals had invalidated another executive order, which provided that 10 percent of all construction work awarded by the city must be given to local enterprises in ''economically depressed areas.''
The Court of Appeals ruled that the executive order was an ''unlawful usurpation'' of legislative authority, Justice Cohen said. He pointed out that the City Council later adopted legislation that reinstated the program to aid local enterprises.
Justice Cohen's decision grew out of a lawsuit that a contractor, L. K. Comstock & Company, filed after a city agency withheld payment of $179,000 for the company's electrical work in the construction of the South Street Seaport. The payment was one of several withheld on the ground that contractors had failed to comply with the trainee provisions of Executive Order No. 50.
The executive order, Justice Cohen said, provided for a training program that required contractors to make ''a good-faith effort to achieve the ratio of one trainee to four journey-level employees of each craft on each construction project.''
 
Trainee Provisions
Commenting on the judge's decision, Mr. Zimroth said it barred the city from enforcing the trainee provisions of the executive order for city construction projects. But he said the decision did not apply to state-assisted projects in the city because the State Legislature has passed a law authorizing the Mayor to use part of the program for construction receiving state benefits, like tax incentives.
The trainee program is both effective and constitutional, Mr. Zimroth said, noting that it is based on economic disadvantage, not race, while most of its beneficiaries are minority members.
The director of the city's Bureau of Labor Services, Oliver J. Gray, said the city needed the trainee program because there was still a ''significant problem'' of getting minority members and women into the skilled construction trades.
He said the program had succeeded in bringing more than 1,000 trainees into the industry.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Companies
 
McKinsey is seeking the Information Consulting Group, which was created last year by several executives from Arthur Andersen and other accounting firms. The move is a sign of the growing importance of information technology and systems-related expertise in general management consulting. [Page D1.] 
 
Florida laws that prohibit accountants from soliciting business were ruled unconstitutional in a suit brought by a West Palm Beach accountant. [D2.]
 
The Economy
 
Public officials are not dealing with the capital gains issue as a question of tax policy and its consequences, but rather as one of political principle - and they are using misleading statistics in the process. News Analysis. [D1.] The Senate majority leader predicted he could marshal enough votes to block passage of the House's plan to reduce the capital gains tax rate. [D7.]
 
Few Wall Street executives and real estate developers think the capital gains reduction, if passed by the Senate, will have any significant impact on their business or on stock prices. [D7.]
 
The stock market showed surprising strength and resilience over the last three months, advancing on takeover activity and encouraging economic data, despite an unstable ''junk bond'' market and expectations of lower corporate profits. [D1.]
 
International
 
Competitive international telephone service has come to Japan. After four years of preparation, two new competitors for a longtime Government-approved monopoly tossed switches that connected them to every telephone in Japan. Instantly, telephoning the U.S. became, in some cases, 20 percent cheaper than calling from the U.S. to Japan. [D1.]
 
Investment bankers say the Japanese are more discerning in their American acquisitions. Deals like Sony-Columbia Pictures are growing rarer, they say. [D1.]
 
The stock markets of Japan, the U.S. and Britain grew by about 10 percent in dollar terms for the third quarter. Stocks in Austria, Hong Kong and New Zealand shone, while share prices in Finland sagged. [D8.]
 
The Media Business So far the only parties aggressively ringing alarm bells over Sony's entrance into American television are the three networks, which see a lobbying opportunity. Television. [D10.]
 
The Hartford Courant is trying to offer hometown coverage -and attract hometown advertising - in 82 towns from Long Island Sound to the Massachusetts border. [D10.]
 
The Sunday Correspondent is Britain's first new national Sunday paper at the serious end of the market since The Sunday Telegraph was started in 1961. In many areas around London, the first issue on Sept. 17 was a sellout. [D10.]
 
Since last year, at least 10 publishers have added either divisions or lines of children's books. [D10.]
 
Marketers should build better bridges to their customers and each other if they want to survive the 1990's, FCB/Leber Katz says. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D11.]
 
 Today's Columns
 
A tax provision intended to prevent affluent families from escaping gift and estate taxes has prompted many anguished protests from tax professionals. Tax Watch. [D2.]
 
Investors are more bullish on stocks, but the fund managers who invest the money seem to be having a harder time finding values. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]
 
Long-term interest rates could continue to rise in coming weeks, analysts say. Credit Markets. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Stocks Post Solid Gain in Quarter

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Over the last three months, the stock market showed surprising strength and resilience, advancing on takeover activity and on encouraging economic data, despite an unstable ''junk bond'' market and expectations of lower corporate profits.
''The big excitement in the third quarter was usually the takeover and restructuring plays,'' said Michael Metz, portfolio strategist for Oppenheimer & Company. ''Generally the market gave a pretty good performance until early September, and then it foundered.''
On the New York Stock Exchange, the Spain Fund, a closed-end fund that invests in the booming Spanish market, rose 168.4 percent as Japanese investors bought it heavily. The fund, which was the largest percentage gainer on the exchange in the quarter, has been valued at a hefty premium to its asset value. 
 
Similar Funds Thrive
The sharp rise in the Spain Fund pulled up other single-country funds. The Germany Fund ended the quarter with a 67.7 percent gain. On the American Stock Exchange, the First Iberian Fund posted an 84.5 percent gain.
Leading the Big Board losers was the Lomas Financial Corporation of Dallas, which lost 77.1 percent of its market value and ended the third quarter at $2 a share. Late last month, Lomas became one of the largest financial services companies to seek protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. It halted payments on $2.1 billion of debt held by 47 creditors.
On the American Stock Exchange, the biggest loser was Sorg Inc., a financial printer that also filed for bankruptcy protection in the quarter. The company never fully recovered from the drop in financial printing after the October 1987 stock market collapse.
The biggest gainer on the Amex was the Graham Corporation, a Batavia, N.Y., company that designs vacuum and heat transfer industrial equipment. The company, which rose 235.8 percent, to end the quarter at $37.375, reported sharply higher second-quarter profits and announced that it would resume its quarterly dividend payment of 5 cents a share.
In the quarter, advancing stocks on the Big Board, the Amex, and the over-the-counter market led declining issues 3,124 to 1,880, with 275 unchanged, according to Media General Financial Services.
On the New York Stock Exchange, rising stocks led losers by a margin of more than 2 to 1, with 1,038 up, 513 down and 54 unchanged. In the over-the-counter market, 1,692 were up, 1,064 were down and 189 unchanged. On the Amex, 394 stocks rose and 303 fell, with 32 unchanged.
On the over-the-counter market, Energy Ventures Inc., a Houston oil and gas exploration company, was the largest gainer. The stock had a 200 percent gain, ending at $37.50, after a London investment firm increased its stake in the company.
The big over-the-counter loser was the Pantera's Corporation, which fell 90 percent, to end the quarter at 50 cents after the St. Louis fast-food restaurant company filed for bankruptcy protection.
 
Dow Industrials Up 10.36%
Despite a slight decline in September, the market made strong gains in the third quarter, which ended Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.36 percent for the quarter, and 24.17 for the year to date. The Dow fell slightly in September, largely because of jitters in the high-yield junk bond market that depressed stock prices, particularly those of takeover stocks.
The junk bond market was seriously rattled after the Campeau Corporation, a Canadian developer, defaulted on some of the interest on debt it accumulated to acquire two major United States retailers in a leveraged buyout.
''Notwithstanding September's moderate decline, it has been a good quarter,'' said Steven Einhorn, chief portfolio strategist for Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''It was an admirable showing given the turmoil that developed in the junk and L.B.O. markets. September should be viewed as a slight interruption.''
Mr. Einhorn added that despite these weaknesses, the market's advance was still on solid ground.
Positive economic data helped to maintain investors' faith in the market, analysts said. Among these, the unemployment figures for August were lower than many expected, while inflation appeared to be under control.
''The economy demonstrated that we're not going into a recession for 1989,'' said Monte Gordon, an analyst with the Dreyfus Corporation. ''The inflation risks obviously have been overblown, and the dollar has not lost its allure and attractiveness to foreign investors.''
Takeover activity also propelled the market for much of the quarter. One of the biggest areas of activity was in the airline industry, where the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, was bid for by Marvin Davis, a California financier. UAL, which advanced 102.2 percent, was the third-largest gainer on the Big Board, ending the quarter at $282. The airline has agreed to a $6.7 billion buyout by members of management, employees, and British Airways. The deal is subject to approavl by Federal regulators.
The activity in the stock of UAL and other airline companies, like NWA Inc., parent of Northwest Airlines, drove the Dow transportation average to record highs. The transportation average gained 49.51 percent in the quarter and was the center of attention for most of the last three months.
 
Losses for Braniff
One airline stock that posted heavy losses for the quarter was Braniff Inc., which was among the biggest losers on the over-the-counter market. Braniff filed for Chapter 11 protection at the end of September, after the company reported a severe cash shortage.
Among the other takeover stocks that were big gainers were the Anchor Glass Container Corporation of Tampa, Fla., which advanced 68.1 percent to end the quarter at $19.125. That gain was the eighth-largest on the Big Board. The money-losing glassmaker received an offer of $20 a share, or $280 million, from Vitro S.A., a Mexican company. Although the Anchor board has resisted the tender offer, analysts have said they expect the company to accept it, helping to push up the stock price.
Another big gainer was the Squibb Corporation of Princeton, N.J., which announced that it would merge with the Bristol-Myers Company. The deal, valued at about $12 billion, would create one of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies. Squibb jumped 66.8 percent in the quarter, to close at $127. That was the 10th-largest percentage gain on the New York Stock Exchange.
In addition to Lomas, several other financial services companies were among heavy Big Board losers. The Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara, a savings and loan association that suffered heavy losses, lost nearly half of its market value in the third quarter. It was the fifth-largest percentage loser on the Big Board.
Integrated Resources Inc., which lost 43.8 percent of its market value, was the seventh-largest loser on the New York Stock Exchange. The financial services company, which has replaced its management, defaulted on $955 million in outstanding debt and filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this year.
