HEADLINE: Europe Takes On Auto Pollution

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
With environmental concerns rising and the influence of the European Community growing, the nations of Western Europe have begun to take united action to curb air pollution from automobiles.
In June, environmental ministers from the community's 12 member nations agreed to impose emission standards for new small cars in 1992 similar to those in place in the United States since 1983. In general, Europe has lagged well behind the United States in auto emissions rules.
In addition, there is talk about tightening the currently lax pollution standards for trucks and other heavy-duty vehicles and imposing a communitywide speed limit. Some countries are taking or considering other actions, like tolls at the entrances to big cities, expanded rail and bus systems and restrictions on driving in congested areas. 
There are currently no mandatory communitywide standards for emissions from small and medium-size cars which account for 60 percent and 25 percent, respectively, of the approximately 10 million cars a year sold in Western Europe. Standards for large cars are scheduled to go into effect on Oct. 1, but some countries, notably Britain, are resisting them.
The attitudes of European governments toward auto emissions have varied greatly in the past. In countries like Britain, France, Italy, Portugal and Greece relative indifference reigned until recently, and smaller cars with polution control systems were a rarity there.
But in some countries the damage to forests and other parts of the environment by auto emissions has increased the strength of the environmental movement and encouraged stiffer regulations. These countries, including West Germany, Scandinavia, Austria, Switzerland and the Netherlands, have encouraged the use of unleaded gasoline as a precursor to other actions to reduce pollution.
Since lead in gasoline poisons the catalytic converters that are essential to most pollution removal systems, the switch to unleaded fuel needs to be made before emissions standards are toughened.
West Germany and the Netherlands have tax breaks and lower fees for cleaner cars. By Oct. 1, 1990, all new cars sold in Denmark will have to meet American-style emissions standards. In the last year or two, emission standards like America's have also gone into effect for all new cars in Austria, Sweden, Switzerland and Norway, which belong to the European Free Trade Association.
In Britain, some auto companies are trying to make cleaner air a selling point. Both Volvo and Audi announced this summer that they would offer catalytic converters on their cars in Britain at no extra charge. Car makers have been charging as much as $1,300 extra for vehicles equipped with pollution control systems that include converters.
 
Royalty in the Act
The royal family has also gotten into the act by spending what industry executives say must have been a royal sum to retrofit its vehicles to use unleaded fuel. That example, and a tax change that widened the price advantage of unleaded over leaded, have increased unleaded's share of the market to about 25 percent from 5 percent in the spring.
Motorists who stray from main highways in countries like France, Spain, Portugal and Greece may still have trouble finding unleaded fuel but industry executives expect that circumstance to change over time as the community pushes national governments to make unleaded widely available.
Other governments have followed Britain's lead by using taxes to make unleaded gasoline cheaper, but it has taken some time to find out how great a differential was needed to stimulate demand. Unleaded now retails for 10 to 20 cents a gallon less than leaded in many Western European countries.
 
Lead in the Environment
Europeans are still pouring a lot of lead into the environment, compared with the United States, where removal of lead has been a national objective since the late 1960's. In the European Community, lead emissions from vehicles totaled 23,891 tons last year, according to Dr. Ian Berwick, director general of the United Kingdom Petroleum Industry Association. Just 3,306 tons were emitted in the United States in 1987, compared with 123,865 tons in 1978.
The impetus behind these actions is a growing public concern about the environment in Western Europe, where water and air quality is sometimes worse than in America. ''Air quality in large European cities is comparable to that of some of the worst cities in the United States, including Houston, Denver and New York City,'' said Paul M. Stolpman, director of the pollution control division of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
The growing environmental sensitivity of European public officials has been linked to the increasing power of the Green Party and similar political groups. The Greens have long been a force in West Germany and Belgium, and they amazed political analysts by winning 15 percent of the British vote in the elections for the European Parliament last June.
 
Green Movement Strengthens
''The situation has changed dramatically as the Green movement has gained force,'' said John Phelps, technical manager of the International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers in Paris.
Another important factor is the approach of 1992, the year that trade barriers within the community are due to be dismantled. At that time differing emissions standards may be regarded as barriers to trade. So if West Germany wants to get tough on automotive pollution, it has to persuade the rest of the community to go along, which could result in stiffer requirements all over.
In addition, if one nation unilaterally takes action, it risks putting its auto industry at a competitive disadvantage, said Russell Seal, head of the British Petroleum Company's refining and marketing operations. While a catalytic converter itself costs auto makers only about $80, the cost of the fuel-injection and engine-management systems needed on cars with catalytic converters runs into hundreds of dollars.
Indeed, small-car buyers may also be in for sticker shock when the community rules go into effect. Experts say catalytic converters and related engine changes will add $500 to $800 to the price of each vehicle.
 
Debating Further Steps
Even though the community's emission standards are not due to go fully into effect until 1992, government and industry officials and environmentalists are already debating further steps to cut auto pollution.
Mr. Seal of British Petroleum predicts that the European oil industry will quickly follow the lead of the Atlantic Richfield Company in the United States in offering reformulated gasoline that reduces pollution.
Because of traffic congestion and concerns about global warming, there is also talk, and some action, on lowering speed limits, spending more on rail systems and buses, and increasing restrictions on car use. The European Community plans to take up the issue of a communitywide speed limit. But the Germans, who are passionate about having no speed limits on their main highways, have opposed the idea.
Other efforts to reduce congestion are also under way. For instance, Oslo, the capital of Norway, plans to build a system of toll gates at approaches to the city to discourage driving. To avoid long delays, the system will be electronic, with motorists buying passes that can be read quickly at the tolls.
Manchester, England, recently announced plans to build an ambitious commuter rail system. And Britain's opposition Labor Party last week proposed higher taxes for vehicle use, taxing the use of company cars, restricting car use in central cities at peak hours and improving rail, bus and subway services.

GRAPHIC: The nations of Western Europe are moving to curb air pollution from automobile emissions. On a highway outside London, traffic moves through a heavy smog. (NYT/Jonathan Player)

HEADLINE: A Price War In Japan on Foreign Calls

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 1

 BODY:
One of the most expensive services in Japan, the land of $70 watermelons, $150 cab rides and camera gear that costs twice as much as in New York, is making international telephone calls. But this weekend, a price war broke out.
Since well before World War II, Japan has been connected to the outside world by a single Government-approved monopoly. And for as long as most of Japan's notoriously docile consumers can remember, it has always cost far more to call from Tokyo to the United States than the other way around. 
That all ended this morning. After four years of preparation, two new competitors in international telephone service tossed switches that connected them to every telephone in Japan. Instantly, telephoning to the United States became, in some cases, 20 percent cheaper than calling Japan from the United States.
 
Enormous Profits Cited
''Maybe this will demonstrate to the Japanese that things here do not always have to be more expensive than they are everyplace else in the world,'' said Nobuo Ito, the executive vice president of International Telecom Japan Inc., one of the fledgling competitors. ''Japanese industry makes enormous profits by simply overpricing everything here. Maybe this will encourage them to set some reasonable prices.''
Few share Mr. Ito's optimism that a new era is dawning for Japanese consumers, because Japanese industry usually abhors competing on price. Discount houses and department store sales are rare. Manufacturers of video cameras and fax machines, for example, pack more and more options into their goods rather than lower the price of each new generation of equipment.
Earlier this week Japan's Economic Planning Agency issued a devastating report on the high cost of living, attributing much of it to Japan's distribution system, Government subsidies to the rice industry and unnecessary add-on services that require more personnel in department stores.
The arrival of competitive international telephone service comes at a politically fortuitious moment. It happened just as the Bush Administration was pressing Japan to give its own consumers a break - a theme that a parade of United States officials have struck here in recent weeks in their efforts to spur demand for American goods.
But no one expected a price war, an event so rare here that it has a lot of people openly nervous. And the most nervous may be the top officers of KDD, formerly known as the Kokusai Denshin Denwa Company, which has held the monopoly on international communications services since 1871, when the first telegraph cable was laid between Nagasaki and Shanghai.
''We've never faced any competition before, and even though we had time to prepare it is quite a shock,'' Takazo Ishii, the president of KDD, said last week at the company's office tower in Tokyo. Company officials fear that a plan to cut KDD's staff by 20 percent over the next few years may not be enough.
 
Size of Cut a Surprise
''We could not expect that prices would fall this fast,'' Mr. Ishii added. Apparently, no one at KDD, which had $1.95 billion in revenues last year, expected the competition to start its service with prices that undercut KDD by more than 23 percent.
And when KDD last week announced a price cut to take effect in a month, it was accused of attempting to kill off its competition. Mr. Ishii responded that it was unreasonable to expect KDD not to react competitively.
Only 10 years ago, KDD charged more than $15 for a prime-time three-minute call to the United States, about 50 percent more than the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's charges for calls to Japan. Under Government pressure, KDD's prices have fallen gradually but steadily.
It is too early to say how much of a market share International Telecom and the other competitor, International Digital Communications, will capture. Each company says it needs 10 or 15 percent to prove truly viable.
 
Drive for Clients Is Starting
And now the race to attract customers is on. When service started this morning, a three-minute call to the United States on one of the services ranged from less than $3 to about $4.85, depending on the time of day. KDD's prime-time rate is $6.35, though it was forced to announce the major cut last week that will take effect in a month. By comparison, A.T.&T. charges $6.02 for a prime-time three-minute call, and $3.78 for its least costly call.
For all the Japanese reluctance to offer discounts, price may be the only way to differentiate among competitors in telephone service. All use the same methods of transmission - the same Intelsat satellites and the same undersea fiber-optic cables to the United States. The only difference is that users of the two new communications companies have a significantly higher chance that their calls will go across the fiber-optic cable.
That should work to the favor of the new entries because the cable provides far clearer connections than the satellites. For now, however, the two upstarts are only connecting to a limited number of countries, with most those where calling volume is highest.
 
'Skimming the Cream'
''They are simply skimming the cream of the business,'' said Mr. Ishii, who complained that KDD spent millions of dollars connecting Japan to low-volume locations like Africa.
But KDD can sustain competition much longer: The property it owns throughout Japan is worth hundreds of millions of dollars, including its office tower in Shinjuku, one of Tokyo's most expensive business neighborhoods. One competitors, in contrast, is in rental space opposite Tokyo's fish market.
Interestingly, Japanese regulators who examined the breakup of the Bell System have chosen a far different approach in promoting competition in their own telephone network. During the Bell breakup, customers had to select a primary long-distance service. That led to expensive campaigns by companies like the MCI Communications Corporation and the U S Sprint Communications Company, with each viewing it as essential to ''lock in'' consumers to their service.
 
Choice Made by Dialing a Code
In Japan, consumers vote every time they pick up the telephone. By dialing a three-digit number, they get KDD. But by dialing a different code they get the alternative services, which bill them automatically at the end of the month. ''Compared to the efforts and hardships that MCI and Sprint went through, we consider ourselves very lucky,'' said Mr. Ito of International Telecom. ''But we only have one chance. If people place a call and the quality is bad, they will go back to KDD.''
For both competitors, the key to success will be their ability to draw big corporate users, although for both companies many of Japan's biggest corporations are already investors.
International Telecom's shareholders include holding companies like the Mitsubishi Corporation and the Sumitomo Corporation; trading companies like Mitsui & Company, the Marubeni Corporation and the Nisho Iwai Corporation; banks like the Bank of Tokyo, and electric companies like the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and the Tokyo Electric Power Company. The other competitor, International Digital Communications, is primarily run by C. Itoh & Company, the Toyota Motor Company, Cable and Wireless of Britain and one American company, Pacific Telesis.

HEADLINE: Capital Gains: Politics and Poor Data

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
In the debate last week before the House of Representatives voted to lower the capital gains tax rate, both sides buttressed their positions with misleading statistics.
These tactics will doubtless continue as the debate shifts to the Senate. The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, has been highly critical of the House's approval of the plan, which is backed by President Bush. The Maine Democrat said today that he could marshal the votes to block the House plan, although he acknowledged that some form of a capital gains tax reduction was likely to win approval. [Page D7.] The public officials are not dealing with a question of tax policy and its consequences, but rather with one of political principle. Many proponents of the tax cut, mostly Republicans, have long held on faith that tax breaks for the wealthy would lead to economic growth for all. Others, mostly Democrats, hold that the wealthy should pay more taxes to raise money to help those who are less well off.
Various arguments have been made in defense of the differing philosophies. 
Arguing that a capital gains tax reduction would benefit people of moderate means, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told the Senate Finance Committee last week that about three-quarters of capital gains were generated by tax filers who had other income, like wages, interest and dividends, of less than $50,000. Capital gains are the profits from the sale of stocks, bonds, real estate and other assets. That proportion, Mr. Brady said, proved that a large share of capital gains represented one-time-only sales of businesses, farms and homes.
Richard G. Darman, President Bush's budget director, embellished the point. ''A vote against capital gains is a vote against farmers, small owners of timber stands, people who raise Christmas trees and a father who builds a little, say, submarine stand as a business and his children want to do something else and he may want to sell it,'' he told a news conference.
But according to the Internal Revenue Service, 76 percent of all the money from capital gains in 1987 went to filers with total incomes of more than $50,000. In that year, 68 percent of tax returns showing a capital gain were filed by people with total incomes below $50,000. But 89 percent of all tax returns were filed by people with total incomes below that level.
 
Calculation Not Challenged
The nonpartisan staff of the Joint Congressional Committee on Taxation calculated that 60 percent of the benefit from the measure approved by the House would go to the two-tenths of 1 percent of taxpayers with incomes over $200,000 and that 80 percent would go to the 1 percent of filers with incomes over $100,000. That calculation has not been challenged.
In 1985, the last year for which the data are available, 82 percent of the money received in capital gains was realized by taxpayers who sold more than one asset during the year. Mr. Brady's statistic, tax specialists said, reflected the fact that the income of many wealthy investors comes almost entirely from trading securities and did not primarily denote one-time sales of homes or businesses.
On the floor of the House, the main argument of the proponents of a lower capital gains rate was that it would help new business ventures raise capital by creating, in Mr. Brady's words, ''incentives for the kind of risk-taking that leads to new technology and a competitive edge.''
Yet the best year ever for new venture capital was 1987, the first year that capital gains were taxed at the same rate as other income.
 
Provided by Pension Funds
About half the venture capital that year was provided by tax-free pension funds. Much of the rest came from foreigners who do not pay United States income taxes or corporations, endowments and other institutions that would not be affected by a rate change. Individual investors, who would benefit from a lower rate, contributed less than 10 percent.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee and is the chief Senate proponent of expanded individual retirement accounts, says his proposal would induce additional personal savings in the United States.
Yet from 1981 to 1986, the period when tax-deductible I.R.A.'s were available to all working Americans, the rate of personal savings in the country dropped sharply. It was about 4 percent in those years compared with an average postwar rate of about 7 percent.
Senator Bentsen also said his proposal would ''help average families,'' as opposed to the well-to-do. But the vast majority of taxpayers, people with incomes below $35,000 and couples with incomes below $50,000, are still entitled to tax-deductible I.R.A.'s.
 
Participation Is Small
Relatively few of them participate. A study in 1985, when all workers were entitled to I.R.A.'s, showed that 60 percent of taxpayers with incomes over $50,000 invested in I.R.A.'s, 30 percent of those with incomes of $30,000 to $50,000 and only a tiny fraction of those with lower incomes did. Yet the ''average'' American has an income below $30,000.
Why are such unreliable statistics bandied about? Because no reliable ones exist. Economists simply do not know how much a lower capital gains tax encourages investment, if at all, or whether I.R.A.'s significantly encourage savings or merely lead people to switch savings from a taxable account to a deductible one.
''The techniques we have to study these issues can't give you the answer,'' said Jane Gravelle, a senior specialist in economics and tax policy at the Library of Congress. ''These are just very tough problems to tackle empirically.''
But that does not stop public officials. No one in the House debate defended the short-term nature of the proposal, which would lower the tax rate to a maximum of 19.6 percent only through the end of 1991, after which it would rise to 28 percent. Currently, the top rate is 33 percent, with taxpayers with incomes over about $200,000 paying 28 percent.
 
Provision Aided Passage
The supporters conceded that a temporary rate cut would be bad policy. They said they hoped the lower rate would be extended and acknowledged that they had put a temporary rate in the legislation only because it was the only way they could get enough votes for passage.
That is because at a time when lawmakers are looking for painless ways to cut the budget deficit, a temporary capital gains tax reduction would raise revenue in the short run because people would rush to sell securities to take advantage of the lower rate while it was available. The policy would cost the Government revenue in the long term, most experts believe, because the same assets would not be sold later.
Representative Bob Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, made the right point about tax policy and political principle. ''Ultimately,'' he told the House, ''this is a struggle not between two policies but between two philosophies. The Democratic leadership believes in redistributing the wealth.'' Those who favor a rate cut, he continued, ''believe in creating wealth.''
So, if they really want to take from the rich and give to the poor, why are most Democrats supporting expanded I.R.A.'s? Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, the Democrat most knowledgeable about tax policy, had a politician's answer: ''You can't beat something with nothing.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Insurers With a Niche Favored by an Acquirer

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
David J. Stone, a practitioner of the management buyout, thinks the insurance industry offers opportunities to acquire companies for prices that are not outlandish, and his company, DJS/Inverness, is on the lookout for insurance companies that have a niche in their industry.
In fact, DJS/Inverness is acquiring the Penncorp Financial group of companies from the Primerica Corporation for $300 million, a deal announced last week. Penncorp's niche is that it is one of the few life insurers that still sells policies door-to-door, Mr. Stone said. 
Mr. Stone said his company's philosophy was to make management ''a very significant owner in the company.'' He added, ''We may have to lend them the money to allow them to do it, but we want them very invested.''
The company has also done some deals in the restaurant business, an industry where it believes ''success and failure depends on the quality and morale of management,'' as Mr. Stone put it.
How does insurance management fit in? As for Penncorp, he said, ''You have agents knocking on doors and dealing with rejection every day. Management is absolutely critical in that business'' to keep such a sales force enthusiastic.
Mr. Stone's company, of which he is president, has participated in the buyouts of Jerrico Inc., operator of Long John Silver Seafood Shoppes, and the Steak & Ale Restaurant chain. It also structured and participated in the acquisition of CBS Magazines by Diamandis Communications.
Mr. Stone, 46, was born in Britain. He came to this country in 1963, joined Mobil and got a Ph.D at New York University, where he taught economics. During his careeer, he was also an economist at W. R. Grace, a vice president at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and an executive at the Commercial Union Leasing Company and at Carl Lindner's Great American Insurance Company.
AT D.L.J., where he was responsible for leveraged leasing and private placements, Mr. Stone met William M. McCormick, 49, who also worked there. Mr. McCormick, a former chief executive of the Fireman's Fund, is today part of the buyout group of Penncorp and will be chief executive once the deal is completed.
Mr. Stone started his own firm in 1977. The Inverness in the DJS/Inverness title refers to a company one of his senior associates ran before joining with Mr. Stone. One senior officer in the company is Mr. Stone's wife, Sara. They have a son and a daughter.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rise in Rates Seen as Temporary

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Credit market analysts say that long-term interest rates, which have tested the upper limits of a 7.75 to 8.25 percent range recently, could move higher still in coming weeks.
But any rise is likely to be short-lived, these analysts said, predicting that rates would move lower as additional signs of a slowing economy emerge during the fourth quarter.
The cautious near-term assessment is based on expectations about coming economic reports. The numbers are apt to show that the economy remained fairly strong in September, and that inflation, dormant for much of the summer, has reawakened. 
''The market is going to have to struggle through some strong statistics over the next couple of weeks,'' said John R. Williams, a managing director in the global markets economics department at the Bankers Trust Company.
''The September employment report will be strong,'' Mr. Williams continued, ''and because of rising energy prices the next producer price report, which is due out Oct. 13, is likely to be higher than it has been over the past few months. An uptick in market interest rates is certainly possible.''
Last week, long-term bond yields briefly rose above 8.25 percent for the first time since late June. The rise was not sustained, however, and by late Friday the Treasury's bellwether 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price to yield 8.23 percent.
Most economists predict that the employment report, scheduled for Friday, should show nonfarm payroll employment increasing by about 300,000 last month, with continued growth in the service sector. The rise would include about 76,000 striking telephone workers who returned to their jobs in September.
An increase of that size would make it difficult for the Federal Reserve Board's policy-making Open Market Committee, which meets in Washington tomorrow and Wednesday, to consider easing its grip on monetary policy.
''We do not expect the F.O.M.C. meeting to result in any change in money market conditions,'' Elliott Platt, chief economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, wrote in the firm's weekly economic commentary. ''The overnight Federal funds rate will consequently be left at 9 percent, and that may very well be the funds rate target prevailing over the balance of the year.''
 
Others Expect Shift
A number of analysts do not share that view, and say that economic weakness in the fourth quarter will persuade the Fed to ease policy.
''We are experiencing a spike in rates, which may last until late October,'' said Victor Chang, president of the VC Manangement Company. ''By then we may see the light for another downshift in rates. We have borrowed against retail sales in the fourth quarter, and business spending in the third quarter was not as strong as it has been in previous periods.''
The automotive sector, which during the summer was a vigorous contributor to employment and retail sales, is of particular concern.
Recent developments in Detroit have shown that the auto manufacturers are worried, too. Even before the 1990 models are introduced, General Motors and Ford said last week that they would offer rebates on their new cars.
''Paint the auto picture black in the fourth quarter,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''If car sales turn out as the companies think, let alone some of the industry analysts, that will have an impact on factory hours worked and on capital spending.''
The auto industry is not the only business that is having trouble in raising prices. And, while that development bodes well for inflation, it may not be beneficial to the economy.
 
'Hurts Profits'
''Businesses can only cut prices for so long before it hurts profits, and we are beginning to see that,'' said Paul L. Kasriel, a vice president and monetary economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. ''After a while, they will have to cut output.''
Any further evidence of weakness in the manufacturing sector is likely to persuade the Fed to ease policy futher, Mr. Kasriel said. Indeed, even though the central bank has lowered the Fed funds rate by 75 basis points since May, he maintained that Fed policy had remained extremely tight.
When movements in the Consumer Price Index are subtracted from the Federal funds rate, real interest rates had risen to 7.5 percent in August from 4 percent in the first quarter, Mr. Kasriel said. To make the overnight funds rate comparable to the Consumer Price Index, movement in the funds rate was compounded at an annual rate.
''In other times when the industrial sector has weakened, the real Fed funds rate has declined,'' Mr. Kasriel said.

HEADLINE: Senator Predicts Defeat for Tax Bill

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
In unusually blunt language, the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, predicted today that he could marshal enough votes to block passage of the House-approved reduction in the capital gains tax rate.
''I'm positive we can prevent that plan from passing,'' said Mr. Mitchell, a Maine Democrat, of the measure passed by the House in a 239-to-190 vote on Thursday. That vote was a significant victory for President Bush, who backs the measure. 
''It is so bad, so wrong for the economy,'' Mr. Mitchell said on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' adding, ''It will do for the deficit what crack does for the user: a quick, short high followed by a long, painful depression.''
 
Senate Momentum Is Strong
But Mr. Mitchell acknowledged that momentum in the Senate for some form of capital gains tax reduction is so strong that an alternative measure could win approval.
''Whether some modified plan will pass will depend upon the nature of the plan,'' he said. ''I think the vote there will be very close.''
The House-passed cut would lower the top capital gains rate to 19.6 percent from 33 percent for two years, after which it would rise to 28 percent. The reduction would apply to income from sales of stocks, bonds, real estate and some other assets. Gains from the sales of works of art, coins and other collectibles would be excluded from the reduction and would continue to be taxed at the same rate as ordinary income.
Mr. Mitchell did not indicate what provisions an alternative plan might have, although he said such a measure would include a proposal to restore the tax deductibility of individual retirement accounts. That proposal was put forward by House Democratic leaders last week and rejected in the vote adopting the Bush-backed plan.
 
Weighing the Alternatives
Senate Democrats are considering several types of capital gains proposals. Among them are measures that would restrict the cut to investments in high-risk start-up ventures, create categories of assets that would be subject to different tax rates or tie the tax rate to the length of time an asset has been held.
Some Senate Republicans do not like the two-year cut approved by the House and are seeking to make the reduction permanent.
Mr. Mitchell, who is opposed to any reduction in capital gains taxes, blamed President Bush for creating the environment that made a reduction likely in some form.
''Unfortunately, given the irresponsible position the President has taken,'' he said, ''it makes it extremely difficult to prevent any tax cut from occurring.''
On other topics, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, appearing on the same program, predicted that the catastrophic health care program for elderly Americans would probably be repealed in a vote this week.

GRAPHIC: The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, predicted yesterday that he could marshal enough votes to block passage of the House-approved reduction in the capital gains tax rate. He appeared on a television program with Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley. (AP)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
World Stock Markets Gained in 3d Quarter

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
With few exceptions and little variation, stock markets around the world posted strong gains in the third quarter.
The world's three largest markets - Japan, the United States and Britain - all grew by about 10 percent in dollar terms for the quarter through Sept. 28, and smaller markets followed. Stocks in Austria, Hong Kong and New Zealand shone, while share prices in Finland sagged, according to Morgan Stanley & Company's index of foreign stock markets.
Moderate inflation and economic growth worldwide appeared to be more important than any single political or economic event, said Mark H. Sladkus, a vice president at Morgan Stanley. ''Usually, you can at least put a highlight,'' he said, adding that the narrow range around 10 percent within which most countries posted results was also surprising. 
Weighting stock markets by size and excluding dividends, Morgan Stanley's world index of 20 countries climbed 8.7 percent in local currencies and 10.6 percent in dollar terms, as a falling dollar increased the value of foreign share price gains for American investors.
The index had risen 3.1 percent in local currencies for the second quarter, and 5.3 percent in the first quarter. Wall Street gained 9.5 percent for the third quarter.
 
Renewed Interest in Japan
The Japanese market managed an 8.7 percent gain in yen and an 11.1 percent rise in dollar terms. Japanese investors are showing renewed interest in buying shares in domestic companies as the growing volatility of currency markets makes the return on international investments less predictable, said Robert A. Brusca, the senior vice president and chief economist at Nikko Securities International Inc.
British stocks were up 6.2 percent in pounds and up 10 percent in dollar terms. The gain came despite high short-term interest rates as the British Government sought to dampen a boom in consumer credit, said Peter Wann, an economist in Paine Webber's London office.
Continued budget surpluses in Britain have prompted the Government to buy back and retire its bonds with longer maturities, Mr. Wann added. This has created a shortage of bonds and forced some institutions to buy equities, he pointed out.
The Paris Bourse had another strong quarter, gaining 12.8 percent in French francs and 17.2 percent in dollar terms. Stocks rose in anticipation of the lifting today of a rule that mutual funds must hold at least 30 percent of their assets in bonds, said Ricaldo Zavala, president of the international department at Magnin-Cordelle S.A., a Paris brokerage.
Strong corporate earnings and heavy Japanese investments also helped, he said. ''The main players were always the Americans and British'' until now, he said.
In West Germany, stocks climbed 9.5 percent in Deutsche marks and 13.6 percent in dollar terms. A boom in capital goods continues, said Jonathan M. Hoffman, an economist with Credit Suisse-First Boston Ltd. in London. A flood of immigrants from East Germany has pushed up prices of construction-industry stocks, as investors expect builders to find skilled employees more easily and benefit from greater demand for new housing.
 
Gains Led by Austria
Austrian stocks posted the quarter's best results by a wide margin, leaping 35.7 percent in Austrian schillings and 40.8 percent in dollar terms. Strong corporate earnings, new tax incentives for pension fund and insurance companies to invest at home and the growing likelihood that Austria will join the European Community all helped foster investor enthusiasm, said Fionnuala M. Corry, an Austrian equities analyst at Smith New Court P.L.C., a London brokerage firm.
The recent political thaw in Eastern Europe, possibly leading to an import boom for which Austria is well positioned, has also helped stocks, she said. ''You've got a lot of Austrians with a lot of experience in the Eastern bloc,'' she said.
In Spain, the Madrid Bolsa has been setting new highs for the last two weeks, said Juan Antonio Bertran, the director of equities trading and sales at Asesores Bursatiles S.A., a Madrid brokerage. Spain's four stock exchanges rose 6.4 percent in pesetas and 10.2 percent in dollars for the quarter. Institutional investors have been bidding up the shares of electrical utilities in particular, Mr. Bertran said.
 
Poor Results in Finland
The quarter's worst performers were Finnish stocks, which fell 13.6 percent in marks and 11.6 percent in dollars. Other Scandinavian stocks produced lackluster results. Finland's current account deficit has grown rapidly this year, raising fears that the Government may increase interest rates or take other steps to slow the economy, said Nigel G. Hugh-Smith, the director of European research at Hoare Govett Ltd., a London brokerage that is a subsidiary of the Security Pacific Bank.
Danish stocks fell 4.3 percent in krone after posting the biggest gains in the second quarter, while Norwegian stocks were up 3.2 percent and Swedish stocks rose 4.5 percent.
Belgian stocks were up 6.7 percent and Dutch stocks rose 6.8 percent in local currency terms. The Italian market gained 8.5 percent and the Swiss market was up 9.4 percent for the quarter. The Canadian market climbed 5.2 percent in Canadian dollars.
The Australian and New Zealand markets were up 12.8 percent and 22.2 percent respectively in their local currencies. Shares of Fletcher Challenge Ltd., a New Zealand conglomerate with extensive forest product operations, have done well, said Gavin R. Dobson, the president of United States operations for Murray Johnstone Ltd., a Scottish brokerage firm.
Stock markets in Malaysia and Singapore together rose 4.1 percent in terms of the Singaporean dollar and 3.9 percent in dollar terms, reflecting the strength of Southeast Asian economies, Mr. Dobson said.
The Hong Kong market rose 22.3 percent in Hong Kong dollar terms and 22.2 percent in United States dollar terms as that market partially recovered from heavy second-quarter losses that followed the military crackdown in Beijing.

Oct. 2, 1989, Sunday, National Edition

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1267 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Running the Drug Dealers Out of Public Housing

BYLINE: By DEBORAH MARQUARDT

DATELINE: PORTSMOUTH, VA.

 BODY:
Since 1988, when the Federal Public Housing Drug Elimination Act authorized the eviction of tenants involved in illegal drug activity, this city of 110,000 people, like other cities across the country, has been using it as a major weapon in a war against drugs.
While old Department of Housing and Urban Development leases called for evicting tenants involved in criminal activity, the 1988 measure changed lease language to specifically allow the eviction of tenants, guests or family members who make, sell or use drugs or who possess with intent to make, sell, use or distribute drugs.
Tenants could challenge evictions through a Federal lease-grievance procedure. This required housing authorities to hold a hearing before going to court. But last April 30, the H.U.D. Secretary, Jack Kemp, authorized the waiving of the hearing, letting housing authorities go directly to court. 
He based his action on a 1983 amendment to the Federal Housing Act of 1937, which said a grievance hearing need not be held if a local or state jurisdiction could provide due process.
Virginia, where a police officer was killed in a raid on an Alexandria crack house near the end of March, applied for and was granted the first waiver, on March 30; 28 other states quickly followed suit and 20 states are awaiting waivers.
The only state without a waiver that is not seeking one is New York. In New York City, a different legal technique, with similar effect, is used.
Some Legal Aid lawyers and others involved in civil rights say the eviction rules unfairly punish the innocent.
''If you want to take care of the drug problem, take care of it, but don't sweep innocent people into the net,'' said Catherine Bishop of the National Housing Law Project in California, which is helping in a National Tenants Association suit challenging principally the waiver policy, but also the singling out of drug suspects for eviction.
''How about the grandmother raising her grandchildren and one of the kids gets involved with drugs - should that innocent grandmother have her housing in jeopardy?'' asked Alfred W. Bates 3d, a Portsmouth Legal Aid lawyer.
Ms. Bishop and Mr. Bates say family members evicted from one project often are blackballed from others, forcing them into the streets or crowded public shelters.
The National Tenants Organization appealed to Congress to stop the waivers and a rider attached to an unrelated measure put a moratorium on the granting of waivers, although it had no effect on waivers already in effect. H.U.D. attorneys say they are confident that legislation soon will be introduced to lift the moratorium.
''We know that tenant groups and tenant organizations are overwhelmingly in support of what we're doing,'' said a H.U.D. lawyer, Frank Keating. ''In general, H.U.D.'s lease and grievance procedure is an impediment to removing drug dealers.''
Housing authority officials have said that the change let them increase and speed up evictions. For example:
* In Massachussetts, which has a waiver, the Boston Housing Authority, with 60,000 tenants, notes that there have been 105 evictions since January for reasons other than nonpayment, many of those involving drugs.
* Cleveland has taken 301 residents to court and evicted 260 in the last year; 75 percent of those cases are reported to be drug related.
New York City, whose Housing Authority has 180,000 units with 600,000 tenants - as large a population as all of Boston - processed 886 evictions in 1988 and expects as many as 1,200 this year; it is estimated that 45 percent are related to a program under which Federal marshals seize an apartment after two confirmed drug buys by undercover agents.
Here in Portsmouth, which has six public housing projects with 5,500 tenants, about 100 eviction notices a month are handed out. In the largest project, the 3,000-tenant, 633-unit Ida Barbour, the residents are making a strong effort to reclaim the streets. The attorney for the Portsmouth Redevelopment and Housing Authority, Ralph W. Buxton, said that the tougher measures plus increased police presence have decreased ''open market'' drug deals and that tenants feel better.
Last fall, Portsmouth asked H.U.D. to allow it to bypass grievance proceedings, but the agency was not prepared to rule at the time. The city had attempted to evict four women who were asked to leave the Jeffrey Wilson housing community after family members or guests were arrested for interfering with a police drug operation. The women sued, and the city eventually dropped the case because of lack of evidence.
''We had to have the grievance procedure in addition to going to court,'' Mr. Buxton said of the former system. ''One was an administrative procedure, the other a judicial one.''
When a public housing eviction was sought in Portsmouth, the tenant was entitled to a hearing attended by two members of the housing authority, two people selected by the tenant and a fifth person selected by those four panel members.
''There was a lot of back and forth, back and forth,'' said Mr. Buxton. ''It took months to get organized. We were remarkably unsuccessful in obtaining evictions.'' Now, he said, ''we've eliminated months of delay.''
He estimated that about 10 percent of the monthly eviction notices are sent to residents involved in drug activity. While conceding that the numbers are not as startling as those some major cities in the country, he noted that ''all you need is one crack house and you've got a problem.''
Sandy Fulghan, manager of Ida Barbour, said: ''Most people just want a good decent place to live. There had been a hopeless attitude, that no matter what they did, nothing happened.''
Ida Barbour is sandwiched on 50 acres between the downtown business district and an interstate highway, I-264. Although it is near the city's largest employers - a shipyard, a naval hospital and a Coast Guard facility - and just across the Elizabeth River from Norfolk and its huge naval base, unemployment is high. Portsmouth's unemployment rate is 5.7 percent, higher than Virginia's 3.8 percent. Louis Ruffin, volunteer president of Ida Barbour's new tenant advisory panel, said that he is ''100 percent behind'' the new eviction procedures and that ''the people I come in contact with feel the same way.''
The panel, he said, will ''screen prospective clients before they rent'' - interviewing prospective applicants, then making a home visit. It will inquire, said Linda Powell, a management aide, about child-care arrangements, discipline and housekeeping, and ask what the potential resident feels is his or her responsibility to the community. It also will have a say on how the project is run and how money is spent and will meet with management to discuss lease terminations.
Mr. Buxton said he has had 40 cases pending since the waiver went into effect, a ''substantial number'' involving drug-related offenses. About six, he said, are being contested by Legal Aid. One may result in a jury trial, he said, adding that he is confident of being able to get evictions in most cases.
The new eviction policy has given even private landlords courage to crack down. James Epperson of Portsmouth has notified tenants in the 2,396 units apartments he owns that if they or someone in their household is arrested for a drug-related offense they will be evicted. He receives regular computer printouts from the Portsmouth police narcotics unit.
Mr. Epperson said he moved cautiously, consulting with the Commonwealth's attorney's office about the Virginia Landlord Tenant Act before instituting the rule.

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: RACINE, WIS.;
From Gas Plant To Mixed Use

BYLINE: By LONG HWA-SHU

 BODY:
TWELVE acres unused since the Wisconsin Natural Gas Company stopped making gas from coal nearly 40 years ago are being reclaimed for a $75 million mixed-use project along Lake Michigan.
The development, Gaslight Pointe, is a project of Synthesis Development Corporation, whose president is James C. Mastandrea. It will include 22 two-story town houses, 104 one- to three-bedroom condominium apartments ranging in price from $100,000 to $175,000 in two three-story buildings, 100,000 square feet of retail space anchored by two restaurants and a 135-room, seven-story hotel, 125 boat slips and a 10,000-square-foot health club. 
Within three days of the start of sales early in September, five one- to three-bedroom town houses were sold for $275,000 to $400,000. Ground was broken in July and the town houses are to be ready by next spring, with the entire project complete by 1994.
Synthesis is a joint venture of Wispark Corporation, the economic development subsidiary of Wisconsin Energy Corporation, and Midwest Harbor Development Corporation, a subsidiary of Midwest Development Corporation, which was founded by Mr. Mastandrea.
The site is on a peninsula at the mouth of the Root River. It is just east of the $21.5 million Rees Point Marina in Racine harbor, whose 921 boat slips have been leased since it opened in 1987, according to Robert Gibson, executive director of Downtown Racine Corporation, a nonprofit organization that oversees downtown improvements.
Security Pacific Realty of New York was hired to develop plans for the project, said Richard A. Abdoo, president of both Wispark and Wisconsin Electric Power Company of Milwaukee. Both Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Natural Gas are subsidiaries of Wisconsin Energy Corporation.
According to Mr. Abdoo, Wisconsin Gas and Electric, the forerunner of Wisconsin Natural Gas, made gas from coal in the plant until 1950, when the state hooked up to a natural-gas pipeline from the Southwest. The plant was closed and dismantled. Wispark bought the property from Wisconsin Natural Gas in 1986.
As part of the downtown revitalization, the city, 60 miles north of Chicago, will spend $8.5 million on the project for seawall construction, a half-mile walkway along the river and Lake Michigan, two public viewing areas, a four-story parking ramp and road improvements, according to Thomas Wright, director of city development. It will issue tax-exempt revenue bonds to finance the spending, he said.

LENGTH: 1310 words

HEADLINE: HOUSE PANEL VOTES STRICT NEW LIMITS ON CAR POLLUTION

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
A House subcommittee voted unanimously today to tighten automobile tailpipe emission controls, establishing national pollution standards as strict as California's.
The measure, approved 22 to 0, would phase in from 1994 to 1996 an emission control program modeled after the toughest in the nation. The six New England states along with New York and New Jersey agreed this summer to bring their emission laws in line with the California standards. The House move would basically extend those rules to the 41 other states.
Environmentalists hailed the action, while auto makers, expressing disappointment, said it could hurt fuel economy and increase the cost of vehicles. The Environmental Protection Agency estimated that the new standard would add $100 to the price of a new car in the first phase and $500 when the most stringent standards go into effect. The industry did not offer an estimate. 
 
A Political Milestone
The plan, a compromise between two longtime Democratic adversaries, Representatives Henry A. Waxman of California and John D. Dingell of Michigan, is a political milestone in the long effort by environmentalists and others to strengthen provisions of the Clean Air Act of 1970 aimed at reducing smog.
The agreement will probably become the position adopted by the House of Representatives. The standards it embraces go beyond those proposed by President Bush in his new clean air bill but are less restrictive than emission measures specified in a bill pending in the Senate.
A White House spokesman, Stephen Hart, said the Administration thinks that its bill was more ''cost-effective'' than the subcommittee's measure but is ''glad to see the President's package is moving forward.'' The White House is not expected to seek changes in the House bill.
 
Turning Point in Relations
Members of the House Subcommittee on Health and the Environment today described the agreement as a landmark. It represents a turning point in relations between Mr. Waxman, an advocate of stronger controls to combat the smog that hangs over his hometown of Los Angeles, and Mr. Dingell, whose constituents include Detroit's auto makers.
Spokesmen for environmental groups, who were generally pleased with the vote, said Mr. Dingell accepted the compromise because he thought it was the best deal he could make for auto makers. There is considerable support among House members for tougher auto emission standards, since motor vehicles are responsible for 50 percent of the nation's smog.
 
'Momentum Was Building'
''I think Dingell could see momentum was building and discretion was the better part of valor,'' said A. Blakeman Early, a Washington representative of the Sierra Club, a national environmental group.
In a news conference after the subcommittee vote, Mr. Dingell described the auto makers' reaction as ''unenthused.''
Mr. Dingell would not directly address why he changed his position on auto emission standards. Calling the measure a ''fair compromise, honorably achieved,'' Mr. Dingell said it would be ''very hard'' on the auto industry but provide a ''stable manufacturing situation.''
Through the 1980's, Mr. Dingell has frustrated moves by Mr. Waxman, chairman of the subcommittee, to toughen the Clean Air Act, last amended in 1977. Mr. Dingell is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, where clean air legislation originates. Mr. Dingell said today's agreement probably marked the first time he has sided with Mr. Waxman on motor vehicle pollution controls.
The two men said subcommittee members had agreed to push for adoption of the auto emissions measure by the full House without amendment. Mr. Waxman said he expected a House-Senate conference committee to consider a revised Clean Air Act within the next six weeks and that Congress could accommodate the President's request for final legislation by Jan. 1.
The measure adopted today, while stronger than the White House bill, which was co-sponsored by Mr. Dingell, is weaker than the one proposed by Mr. Waxman.
Under the bill's first stage, California's auto emission control program would be phased in for new cars nationwide from 1994 to 1996. The program requires reductions in emissions of hydrocarbons, oxides of nitrogen and particulates. That timetable is about one year behind the California schedule.
The measure also requires that pollution control equipment last for 10 years or 100,000 miles, as in California. Under the Clean Air Act, that requirement is 50,000 miles.
 
Compromise on Standards
Mr. Waxman's original bill called for a second phase to cut emissions even further, beginning in the year 2000. Under the compromise, the Environmental Protection Agency must study the need for tighter standards in the years 2003 to 2006. The agency can retain existing standards or establish new ones. If it does not establish new standards or formally reaffirm existing ones, new and tighter standards go into effect.
''We're disappointed that they went as far as they did in their proposal,'' said Timothy C. MacCarthy, director of government liaison for the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association.
He said the provisions are more severe than air quality problems would dictate and that they could result in higher automobile costs, loss of fuel economy, a shortage of available models, problems with driving and more recalls. Mr. MacCarthy said the industry could not estimate how much the measures might add to the price of a vehicle.
''The House compromise on auto pollution control standards is a welcome and constructive step that will greatly improve chances of early enactment of a revitalized Clean Air Act,'' said Richard E. Ayres, chairman of the National Clean Air Coalition, an organization representing environmental and other groups.
But Mr. Ayres added that the agreement had shortcomings because the strictest standards would be delayed 13 years, and may never go into effect if the E.P.A. decides they are unnecessary. He said a program authorized by the bill to control substances like benzene and formaldehyde, which are contained in emissions but do not contribute to smog as such, could also be strengthened.
The auto industry had suffered two earlier defeats in the subcommittee, which environmentalists suggested may have led Mr. Dingell to move ahead with a compromise on tailpipe emissions.
In one, the panel voted to require tougher auto pollution standards car by car. The Administration had wanted manufacturers to meet the standards on average, which might have permitted some cars to emit more pollution than they do right now.
In a vote last week, the subcommittee moved to force auto makers to install special canisters in 1994 models to reduce emissions during refueling.
Members of the subcommittee also said today they hoped the compromise reached on auto emissions would carry over to other contentious areas the subcommittee has yet to address. These include acid rain, toxic air emissions and alternative fuels.
 
Stricter Auto Standards
 
A House subcommittee voted yesterday to apply California auto emission standards, the strictest in the country, to all 50 states.
 
What would the measure do?
 
New cars would be required to carry equipment that would sharply reduce three major pollutants: carbon monoxide, hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxide. Pollutionj control equipment would have to be built to last 100,000 miles, twice as long as it must now.
 
What would it cost?
 
The Environmental Protection Agency estimates that th emeasure would add $100 to the price of a car during the first phase, and $500 per car when the most stringent limits take effect. Automobile manufacturers say it could reduce fuel economy.
 
When would it take effect?
 
The measure would begin to take effect with 1994 models and be fully effective in 1996.

HEADLINE: Texas Court Rules Rich-Poor Gap In State School Spending Is Illegal

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
The Texas Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the state's system for financing public schools is unconstitutional because of ''glaring disparities'' between what rich and poor school districts spend on education.
The court's 9-to-0 decision found that this inequity violates a provision of the Texas Constitution requiring the State Legislature to support and maintain ''an efficient system'' for the ''general diffusion of knowledge.''
The court did not prescribe a specific remedy for the problem, but it ordered the Legislature to change the way the nation's second-largest public school system, after California, is financed. The court set a deadline of May 1. Gov. Bill Clements, who had feared that the court would mandate remedies for school financing, welcomed the ruling, saying, ''I am extremely pleased that this is back in the hands of the Legislature where it belongs.'' The Republican Governor also announced formation of a study group that will make recommendations on school financing to a special session of the State Legislature, which opens Nov. 14. 
Eventually, Texas may have to enact a state income tax, said public finance and education experts.
Texas schools receive most of their money from property taxes levied by each of the state's 1,034 independent school districts, which gives a big advantage to those school districts rich in oil reserves, commercial property or other economic resources. The state and Federal governments supplement the local funds.
 
Other States Challenged
School financing systems have been challenged in court in at least 10 other states, including New Jersey and Connecticut, on similar grounds, and some of the suits have been successful. Others are still before the courts. Connecticut's financing formula was thrown out several years ago, and a challenge to the New Jersey system is scheduled to be decided soon by the State Supreme Court.
The standard response by state governments has been to increase their contribution to local districts, with most of the new money going to the districts least able to raise tax money for education. Since the early 1970's, the average state share of the cost of education has increased to more than 50 percent from less than 40 percent.
The Texas Supreme Court opinion, written by Justice Oscar H. Mauzy. stated: ''More money allocated under the present system would reduce some of the existing disparities between districts but would at best only postpone the reform that is necessary to make the system efficient. A Band-Aid will not suffice; the system itself must be changed.''
The ruling came in a five-year-old suit brought against various state agencies by 68 school districts in property-poor areas. The state's property-rich districts can set relatively low property tax rates and finance big school budgets while districts with far fewer taxable assets must set high tax rates and can still only only try to meet minimum education requirements. In the state's 100 poorest school districts, the average spending for each student is less than $3,000 a year while in the 100 richest the average is more than $7,000.
Arguing that low taxes and good schools are important in attracting new industry or development, Justice Mauzy wrote, ''Property-poor districts are trapped in a cycle of poverty from which there is no opportunity to free themselves.''
Justice Mauzy's opinion noted that rich and poor school districts often exist side by side in the same county, but the ruling did not address allegations of racial discrimination made by some of the plaintiffs early in the case. Many of the poor school districts that brought the suit contain large concentrations of black and Hispanic students.
 
Texas Defends System
Like other lawsuits that have attacked similar school financing systems, the plaintiffs in the Texas suit had to seek relief under the state Constitution. The United States Supreme Court ruled in 1973 that equal access to education is not a fundamental right under the Constitution and that Federal courts are thus not obliged to remedy disparities in financing of school districts.
Defending the Texas system, lawyers for the state argued that a ''simple and inexpensive'' school system could satisfy Texas constitutional requirements, Justice Mauzy said. In rejecting this view, the court applied a standard of equal opportunity.
While the present system is ''limited and unbalanced,'' Justice Mauzy wrote, ''children who live in poor districts and children who live in rich districts must have substantially equal opportunity to have access to educational funds.''
''Certainly, this much is required if the state is to educate its populace efficiently and provide for a general diffusion of knowledge statewide,'' Justice Mauzy said.
The ruling concluded: ''A remedy is long overdue. The Legislature must take immediate action.''
The justices left jurisdiction of the case in the hands of the court that originally heard the suit, the State District Court in Austin. The district judge in the case, Harley Clark Jr., will determine whether the state has come up with a school financing plan to meet its responsibilities. If he finds the state's efforts inadequate, he could order remedies. The plaintiffs won in the trial court but lost on an appeal by the state, after which they took the case to the state's high court.
The issue of the taxation systems for financing public schools was not on the formal agenda of the Governors' meeting on education organized by President Bush last week. But the meeting did strongly favor local decision-making in schools.
In his decision, Justice Mauzy said that ''an efficient system will actually allow for more local control, not less.'' He said, ''It will provide property-poor districts with economic alternatives that are not now available to them.''
Last spring the State Legislature voted $450 million, primarily for the poorer school districts, to help equalize financing among the districts over the next two years. The court recognized the state's effort but demanded more drastic action for a school system that spends $12 billion annually.
The Equity Center, an association of poor Texas school districts based in Austin, has developed a plan that it says will equalize school financing at the level now spent in the most wealthy district, which it said would cost about $2 billion a year in new state money. Other proposals have suggested that about $1 billion in new spending would be required. z
