The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 3, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2710 words

HEADLINE: The Turmoil On Madison Ave.; A special report.;
Shifts in Marketing Strategy Jolting Advertising Industry

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
After five years of stagnation, the American advertising industry is facing a dim and uncertain future.
Madison Avenue grew and flourished by selling mass-produced goods to mass audiences through mass media. But the nation's consumer market is not what it once was, and advertising agencies are adapting only fitfully to a profound change: the splintering of the mass market into hundreds of smaller markets, and the development of new ways of communicating with them.
To tell consumers about hundreds of new brands of cereal and dozens of new toothpastes, America's largest companies are grasping for ways to communicate with people who are paying far less attention than they once did to 30-second network television commercials. Supermarket shoppers are bombarded by Muzak laced with commercials, and ads are popping up in books, high school classrooms and even in children's games. 
For consumers, the turmoil has meant constant discounting and rebates on many products.
The rules are changing ''as the cracks between the pieces of life get filled up with commercials,'' said Stuart Ewen, a professor of communications at Hunter College and the author of several books on advertising and mass culture.
As a result, the growth of mass advertising has come to a virtual halt, agency profit margins have been cut in half, and advertising agencies are going through a painful consolidation that is reaching into the deepest corners of the industry.
''We're not nailing diving boards to the windows, but things are changing and changing for the worse,'' said Martin F. Puris, the chief executive of Ammirati & Puris, whose agency advertises BMW automobiles.
''It's a crisis more than a transition,'' said Don E. Schultz, a professor of advertising at Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism. These opinions are echoed by numerous consultants and academics, as well as ad agency and corporate marketing executives, some 350 of whom are gathered in Hot Springs, Va., for the 80th annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers.
Marketing experts cite several factors contributing to the turmoil in advertising:
* An explosion of new products has glutted supermarkets, contributed to advertising clutter and made creative advertising breakthroughs difficult to achieve.
* The mass media that once made the Jolly Green Giant a frequent household guest are giving way to a broad range of new approaches. Network television's share of the prime-time audience dropped to 67 percent last year from 92 percent a decade ago. ''The inability to efficiently reach consumers with the benefits of a new brand is tied directly to the decline of the influence of network TV,'' said Roy J. Bostock, the president of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, the world's 11th-largest ad agency.
* Technological innovations like bar-code scanners are giving retailers increasing power to analyze customer preferences. This detailed knowledge has enabled retailers to put pressure on manufacturers to shift spending out of national advertising and into discounting, fees for retailers and other promotions.
 
Impact on the Industry
Growth Rate Slows And Staffs Are Cut
These forces have resulted in a sharp slowdown in advertising's growth rate. Although total advertising expenditures in the United States nearly tripled between 1978 and 1988, to $118.1 billion from $43.3 billion, according to McCann-Erickson Worldwide, the rate of annual growth slowed to 7.7 percent from 15.7 percent in the same period.
And the picture may actually be gloomier. After nine years of steady growth as measured against the gross national product, ad spending in the major media - newspapers, consumer magazines, outdoor advertising, radio and television - has remained at 1.5 percent of G.N.P. since 1984, according to a study by John Philip Jones, chairman of the advertising department at Syracuse University's Newhouse School of Communications. The last similar stall came between 1961 and 1966.
This stagnation has led the world's advertising giants to turn their attention overseas, where advertising has been growing at a far faster rate. In 1988, for the first time, the amount spent on advertising overseas exceeded expenditures in the United States, by about $3 billion.
Despite the slowing of domestic advertising growth, global companies have acquired American agencies in recent years in part because of their expertise in reaching specific geographic markets.
The domestic impact has been severe. In 1987, the top 16 agencies reduced their United States staffs by a total of 4.6 percent, said James Capel, a London brokerage.
The cuts are clearly not over. This summer, Lintas U.S.A., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, dismissed 5 percent of its domestic employees. And the Ogilvy Group, a unit of the WPP Group, dismissed its entire mail room staff. The move was laden with symbolism, because in agency lore the mail room is a breeding ground for the industry's leaders.
 
The Agencies' Response
Some See Gains; Others Are Glum
To be sure, ad agencies are not withering away. Numerous corporate marketing executives still rely on their agencies and say they are performing well despite the reductions and changes. ''Our communications partners have the fundamental understanding of what the need is, and they're a lot better at it now than they were last year,'' said Philip Guarascio, the head of worldwide advertising at the General Motors Corporation.
Indeed, Robert J. Coen, McCann-Erickson's highly respected director of forecasting, said the industry's condition was less a slump than a correction after years of overheated growth fueled by things like the emergence of personal computers and the airline fare wars, all of which required widespread advertising.
Yet other executives say the slowdown reflects changes in the marketplace that have rendered their agencies less able to conduct market research, keep pace with media developments and even create ads that effectively touch consumers.
''Agencies try to present themselves as part of the avant-garde, but I am convinced of the opposite - they are slow to change,'' said Clay S. Timon, the director of worldwide advertising for the Colgate-Palmolive Company.
Such sentiments have contributed to deep pessimism among some agency executives.
''Fear and loathing is the tenor of the times,'' Mr. Puris said.
 
Outside Forces
Competition Brings Flood of Goods
Agencies are being lashed by several separate but allied trends. Slow population growth has compelled companies to try to raise market share by stealing customers from their rivals, which they are doing by cutting prices and by creating products with slight differences to appeal to specific audiences. Technological development overseas has also forced American manufacturers to battle foreign competitors using price as a weapon.
But in lowering their prices and their economies of scale, American companies also began producing more goods, flooding the market with wares, many of them barely distinguishable.
The number of cereal brands that sell at least $1 million annually at retail has grown to 150 today from 84 in 1979, said SAMI, a market research firm. Food stores now sell 31 million-dollar brands of toothpaste, up from 10 a decade ago.
''As brands proliferate, they become more alike,'' said William M. Weilbacher, a consultant who helps companies find agencies. ''Advertising cannot serve to differentiate those brands.''
 
Creativity Seen Affected
One result Mr. Weilbacher says he has seen in the dozens of agency presentations in which he participates each year is ''a long-term downtrend in creativity.'' He said the industry was not spawning the creative giants it once did, people like Leo Burnett, William Bernbach and David Ogilvy, whose names became household words.
Marketers have responded recently by curtailing product introductions. Gorman's New Product News, a newsletter, says that product introductions grew by 3.7 percent in 1988 from the year before; in 1987, new products jumped 26 percent.
The slump in new-product activity ''affects agencies dramatically,'' said Mr. Bostock, the president of D.M.B.&B., whose clients include consumer-products giants like Procter & Gamble and Kraft General Foods. ''Our growth in the 1960's and 1970's was fueled by new products.''
Average agency profit margins are now 10 percent, down from 20 percent in the 1970's. Agency executives and consultants say the pressure on profits has resulted in the gutting of some agency functions, notably market research.
According to the American Association of Advertising Agencies, research as a percentage of total agency payroll expenditures dropped by 2 percent between 1968 and 1988, the largest area of decline. Mr. Weilbacher, the consultant, said the research cutbacks had impinged on the ability of agencies to help their clients.
The association says the payroll in other areas has increased, notably for creative personnel, but it would not provide figures.
Agencies have also been hurt by the marked shift in marketing budgets away from advertising and toward promotions intended to induce retailers to stock a product and customers to purchase it. Advertising traditionally accounted for two-thirds of a company's marketing expenditures, with promotions making up the rest. Several studies now indicate that ratio has been reversed.
 
'Quantifiable Hits'
''Advertising is a slow build,'' said Paul N. Mulcahy, the vice president of advertising for the Campbell Soup Company. Promotions, he said, particularly trade promotions, ''represent quick and quantifiable hits, so we've taken the money and moved it.''
On the surface, this movement does not appear to have harmed all conventional mass media. The three major television networks, for example, sold more than $4 billion worth of advertising time for their current season in their pre-season sales period this summer, a record.
But the broader view is darker for the major media. Between 1978 and 1988, the shares of domestic advertising expenditures going to newspapers, magazines, network television and radio declined, according to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. Direct mail, whose effects can be easily measured, grew substantially.
 
New Gimmicks
A Board Game Sells Advertising
Disenchantment with traditional advertising has led some companies to take unusual steps to reach consumers. Continental Airlines, Courvoisier cognac and 23 other companies each paid $30,000 to buy sponsored spaces on a new board game, ''It's Only Money,'' aimed at parents and children.
Marketers and the media are also increasingly blurring the line between advertising and television programming or magazine articles.
In an intricate arrangement, Family Circle magazine, a publication of The New York Times Company, ran several articles this year about the renovation of a house by Martha Stewart, the home-entertainment writer. K Mart, the nation's second-largest retailer, purchased all the advertising space around the stories. Ms. Stewart, a paid consultant to K Mart, used its products in the renovation and appeared in television ads for the company showing her at work and endorsing specific products available to K Mart shoppers.
There is concern among marketers that these new tactics will merely increase advertising clutter, alienating consumers.
''People need to care about that because the things that motivate the market are economic and profit-oriented, and not always in the best interests of society,'' said Professor Ewen of Hunter.
The largest advertising companies in the United States and abroad have reacted to the slowdown in main media advertising by building their capabilities in sales promotion, direct marketing, package design and other disciplines.
 
Agencies of the Future
Advertising May Be Secondary
As they are shaping up, tomorrow's agencies will have a far different look, with advertising itself actually taking a back seat.
At D.M.B.&B. and Young & Rubicam, for example, ancillary services now account for 30 percent of total corporate revenues, executives say.
''It is possible - and this is heresy - that in the late 1990's one of the big advertising groups will have more revenues from non-advertising services than advertising services,'' said Mr. Bostock of D.M.B.& B. Still, even the largest agencies are not recapturing all the advertising revenues they are losing. Many of the alternative selling methods do not return to agencies the traditional 15 percent commission on media billings.
Last year, for example, Campbell Soup put 80 percent of the marketing budget for its dry-soup division into advertising inside stores. To give its agencies an incentive to use alternative media in their marketing plans, Campbell decided in August to pay them a commission for in-store ads. But the commission is less than 15 percent because Campbell is doing its own research and ad placement -work ad agencies used to do routinely.
''I remember a time when agencies would be battling each other to be the first in to brief you on a new media development the week after it was announced,'' said Mr. Mulcahy of Campbell. ''That doesn't happen any more.''
 
Retailers' New Power
Scanners Giving Stores Advantage
The crucial battleground these days is inside the stores.
Bar-code scanners are now used in half the supermarkets in America, upsetting a balance of power in marketing. Where manufacturers once had the most knowledge about where and why their products sold, today retailers know exactly which products are moving, and at what prices.
Many retailers now use a computerized system to determine the value of shelf space by the cubic inch. To increase that value, store owners are increasingly asking manufacturers for fees to stock a product, called ''slotting allowances,'' which generally cost $4,000 a product for each store, said Group EFO Ltd., a product-development consultant in Norwalk, Conn.
Slotting allowances, which typically come out of ad budgets, now take 44 percent of all marketing budgets, up from 34 percent in 1980, according to Donnelley Marketing.
Scanner technology also allows retailers to compile detailed records of their customers.
 
Studying the Shopper
A Citicorp subsidiary, for example, is testing a frequent-shopper program in the Ukrop's Super Markets chain in Richmond. In return for discounts and other incentives, shoppers who enroll - 180,000 have so far -use magnetically coded cards at the checkout counters, enabling the chain to learn who is buying what, and to target appeals accordingly.
Professor Schultz of Northwestern, who has studied the impact of scanners, said this bodes ill for national advertising.
''Once they start to build customer data bases, then retailers can start talking directly to those people, through direct mail or other means, and they can motivate those customers to change their shopping habits,'' he said.
In Canada and Britain, several grocery chains are experimenting with creating their own high-priced private-label brands, which are more profitable to them than national brands. In turn, the chains are deeply discounting the national brands to lure customers.
''That's potentially disastrous to national advertisers and their agencies,'' Professor Schultz said.
 
Some Optimism
While the transformation of consumer markets has forced gloom on the advertising business, a salesman's optimism still occasionally peeks through.
Professor Jones of Syracuse believes the stagnation in ad expenditures might lead to a flowering of creativity in the industry, especially among newer, smaller agencies.
The last time advertising spending stalled, he points out, the industry's ''creative revolution'' followed - the period in the late 1960's and early 70's when Doyle Dane Bernbach regaled the nation with an ad for Volkswagen cars headlined ''Think Small.''
Mr. Timon of Colgate expressed the ad world's new sentiment. ''I do not think ad agencies as we know them will disappear.'' he said, ''But they will go through many hiccups and ups and downs. And this will be a constant transition instead of a change to a new status quo.''

HEADLINE: Tokyo Chief Asks a Reappraisal

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 2

 BODY:
In his first major policy speech as Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu sounded today much like Japan's critics, declaring that the time had come to lower domestic prices, halt a growing disparity between rich and poor, and stop ''concentrating single-mindedly on economic efficiency.''
Mr. Kaifu's speech came at the opening of debate in what is likely to be Japan's most contentious parliamentary session in decades, and the first in 35 years in which his governing Liberal Democratic Party does not hold the majority in Japan's upper house.
The shift in the balance of power was obvious, as Mr. Kaifu reached out to groups of people who until recently have been considered peripheral to Japan's political process - most notably consumers, the elderly and women. 
Mr. Kaifu announced no major changes of foreign policy, saying he would work to strengthen Japan's alliance with the United States but would ''speak out frankly'' in trade negotiations in which both nations have sharply criticized the structure of the other's economy.
The unusual element in the speech today was that Mr. Kaifu's repeated suggestion that, in its enthusiasm to create an economic powerhouse, the country had lost sight of ''the goal of creating a fair and spiritually rich society.''
''Japan has come to be regarded as one of the wealthiest of nations,'' he said. ''Yet do we Japanese have an inner sense of fulfillment, and can we bequeath today's Japan to future generations with confidence?''
In several recent polls, Mr. Kaifu's popularity appears to be restoring public confidence in the Liberal Democrats, who in July were handed their first major defeat in more than three decades. On Sunday, the party also won a by-election for an upper house seat that was vacant because of the death of a Liberal Democratic member.
On the key issues of dispute in Japanese domestic politics, Mr. Kaifu refused to budge today. He offered a spirited defense of Japan's new 3 percent sales tax on virtually all goods, a tax that has angered many consumers.
The upper house, now controlled by opposition parties, is expected to pass a bill revoking the tax, setting up a confrontation with the lower house, controlled by the Liberal Democrats.

HEADLINE: U.S. Cool to Housing Soviet Emigres in West Bank

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
The Bush Administration said today that while it wanted to help Israel with the cost of resettling Soviet Jewish emigres, it did not want to do anything to encourage or subsidize the construction of housing in the West Bank.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said President Bush discussed Israel's request for $400 million in housing loan guarantees last week with Finance Minister Shimon Peres in New York.
Israel estimates that 100,000 Soviet Jews will arrive in the next three years, in part because the United States has adopted new procedures restricting their admission to this country. Israel says housing, jobs, education and other services for the Soviet emigres will cost $3 billion, and officials have said some housing would probably be built in the West Bank. 
''We want to be helpful in any way we can,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. But, he added, ''We remain opposed to settlements in the West Bank, and also opposed to the use of U.S. aid for that purpose.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said that, although the Administration opposed additional Israeli settlements in the West Bank, ''we are very sympathetic'' to Israel's desire to accept Soviet Jewish emigres and to provide adequate housing for them.
Federal loan guarantees, under a program to finance housing projects in developing countries, would enable Israel to borrow money from commercial banks at low interest rates.
 
Separate Accounts
Israel is apparently willing to accept an arrangement under which housing built with loans guaranteed by the United States Government would be subject to American approval, so that none of those specific projects would be in the West Bank. But Israel reserves the right to use money from other sources, not guaranteed by the United States Government, to build housing for Soviet Jews in the West Bank.
American and Israeli officials said Israel received housing loan guarantees from the United States in the 1970's. The Agency for International Development stipulated then that no guaranteed loans could be used to build housing in the occupied West Bank.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, a Democrat who is chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee responsible for foreign aid, said today that ''Israel has a legitimate concern on housing for immigrants'' from the Soviet Union. But, he added: ''We will not use American foreign aid for settlements in the West Bank.''
Supporters of Israeli settlements in the West Bank say they enhance Israel's security, a contention disputed by critics of such settlements.
Under current law, no country can receive Federal guarantees for housing loans of more than $25 million a year. Until recently, the Agency for International Development separately reviewed and approved each project built with Federal loan guarantees. By insisting on such reviews, the United States could make sure Israel did not use Federal loan guarantees to build projects in the West Bank.
But an American aid official said that if Israel used American loan guarantees to finance construction within Israel's pre-1967 borders, it could free other funds to build housing in the West Bank. The official said that such an analysis applied to much of the United States' economic aid to Israel, not just the housing guarantees.

HEADLINE: New Fight in Old West: Farmers vs. Condo City

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DRIGGS, Idaho

 BODY:
The gentrification of the American West, promoted by some people as the best economic hope for the future of many communities that have fallen on hard times, is meeting stiff resistance in this alpine valley on the western side of the Teton Range.
Several hundred potato farmers, ranchers and conservationists are fighting a Forest Service proposal to allow construction of an Italian-style community of 880 condominiums at a ski resort bordering Grand Teton National Park.
The farmers say the proposed condo city would more than double the population of Teton Valley and bring heavy traffic, real estate speculation, pollution and housing clutter to this area in eastern Idaho near the Wyoming border.
They also worry that their children and those who work in the valley but do not now own property will not be able to afford land here if real estate prices soar after the development is approved and the condominiums are built. 
 
Tourism Seen as the Answer
The private developer and the Forest Service, which owns the land on which the condominiums would be built, say such change is inevitable. They contend that given the speculative pressure on fast-growing Jackson Hole, Wyo., just over the Teton Range from here, the valley should seek a more prosperous future through tourism instead of trying to preserve a fading past.
But the issue now dividing Teton Valley and other rural areas of Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, Washington and Oregon is more than economic; it goes to the very character of the West as the last decade of the 2Oth century approaches.
With resource industries like mining, logging and oil in decline, some residents of small towns in the West have mixed feelings about a future based on selling the spectacular scenery.
''The folks who live in the valley now don't live here for money,'' said Boyd Bowles, an alfalfa farmer who leads a citizens' group fighting the development. ''We live here because we like it the way it is. Letting all those condos go up is going to change everything in this valley.''
 
Preservation by Diversification
Officials of the Forest Service, a Department of Agriculture agency that is the biggest landowner in this area, say the best way to preserve some of the historic character of the Rocky Mountian West while adding new jobs is to diversify the economy. And a major ski resort that includes a condominium city is less harmful to the environment, they say, than logging or mining.
''You can't stop the march of progress in the Teton Valley,'' said James Caswell, supervisor of the 1.8 million-acre Targhee National Forest, which forms the western border of Yellowstone and Grand Teton national parks. ''It's just going to happen, no matter what we do. So let's take the opportunity to plan accordingly.''
The plan proposed for the Grand Targhee Resort, a ski resort that has been in operation for 20 years and is about an hour's drive from the more popular Jackson Hole area, calls for building the condominiums on a mountain ridge in the western shadow of the three biggest peaks in Grand Teton National Park. The new community would overlook the sparsely populated Teton Valley and its small family farms and ranches.
The developer, Mory Bergmeyer, who owns Grand Targhee with his wife, Carol, says he wants to build a residential community modeled after Alpine villages in northern Italy. Mr. Bergmeyer, an architect who moved to the Grand Teton area two years ago from Boston, says his design will blend with the scenery.
 
A Two-Tier Class System
Opposition to the development is centered here in Driggs, a weather-beaten Western-style town of 890 people who live in one-story stone and frame houses. Mr. Bergmeyer says that the valley around the town ''looks like Dogpatch,'' and that his critics therefore have no right to accuse him of trying to block their view of the Tetons with an eyesore.
Some of those who live here say they oppose the development not just because it would change the look and character of the valley, but also because it would create a two-tier class system: rich people in the condominiums on the ridge and struggling farmers and ranchers in the valley.
''We've been told that we're no good at farming and what we should do is get a job making beds for Mory Bergmeyer,'' said Jake Kittle, who lives in the nearby town of Wilson, Wyo.
Mr. Bergmeyer said that when he and his wife bought the resort two years ago they were considered saviors of the valley. ''Now I'm labeled as the bad developer,'' he said.
 
Court Delays Land Swap
Because the ski resort, one of three in the Jackson Hole area, is on Forest Service land and straddles two states, the condo community could be built only with the approval of Congress, which gave it last year on the provision that the Government be given some undeveloped land in return.
The Forest Service proposed a swap of 270 acres of Government land at the base of the Grand Targhee Resort in exchange for 700 acres of private land on the Snake River that the developer was going to buy.
But Federal District Judge Alan B. Johnson, in Cheyenne, Wyo., temporarily stopped the exchange with a court injunction two months ago, saying the Forest Service needed to study the environmental effects of the proposed development before the swap could proceed.
Since then the land on the Snake River in Idaho, an important wildlife area that the Forest Service wants to protect, was sold to another buyer. But Mr. Caswell, the Forest Service supervisor, said a swap could still be made if the Grand Targhee Resort came up with new land of equal ecological value.
 
Conservationists Skeptical
Conservationists, led by the Greater Yellowstone Coalition, a Montana-based group promoting preservation of the area around Yellowstone and Grand Teton national parks, were initially in favor of the land swap. But they have since become skeptical, expressing concern about what the development might do to water quality and wildife.
''What we and others did not know until recently was how extensive and visible the ski area expansion developments actually would be,'' members of the group wrote in a recent newsletter.
But Forest Service officials and Mr. Bergmeyer say the project would have a mimimal impact on the land around Yellowstone and Grand Teton.
''When people go around saying the Yellowstone ecosystem is going down the tubes I have a tough time believing it,'' Mr. Caswell said. Even though there are developments on Yellowstone's northern side and timber and mining operations near other parts of the parks, he said, nearly 75 percent of the 11 million acres of the Yellowstone ecosystem is still in a wild state.

HEADLINE: Blaming Others for Collapse of PTL, Bakker Completes Testimony

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 2

 BODY:
Jim Bakker finished a day and a half of testimony at his fraud and conspiracy trial today by blaming his fellow evangelist Jerry Falwell, who took over the Bakker ministry, for its collapse.
Much of Mr. Bakker's time on the witness stand in Federal District Court here was spent responding to withering questioning from a prosecutor about lavish bonuses he received as his ministry lurched toward financial ruin.
After he finished, the bankruptcy trustee for the ministry depicted it as hopelessly in debt when Mr. Bakker left it in May 1987.
Gone for the most part today was the composed, confident Mr. Bakker who began his testimony on Friday by telling jurors how visions from God had helped him build one of the most successful television ministries in history. 
 
Halting, Nearly Inaudible
Instead, Mr. Bakker spoke haltingly, at times almost inaudibly, as the prosecutor, Deborah Smith, outlined how he continued to receive millions of dollars in bonuses from the falterting PTL.
Mr. Bakker is charged with 24 counts of fraud and conspiracy in connection with the sale of vacation lodgings at his Heritage USA resort and theme park. The prosecution says that he solicited donations by offering vacations he often could not provide and that at least $3.7 million of the money was used to pay for his lavish life style.
The 49-year-old Mr. Bakker, whose ministry collapsed in 1987 after sexual and financial scandals, ended his testimony on a central theme of his defense: ''The real conspiracy to defraud came from the group of people who took over the ministry for their own gain.''
 
Depiction by Bankruptcy Trustee
He says that, had he been able to continue raising money, he would have met all the financial needs. But M. C. Benton, the bankruptcy trustee for the ministry, painted a bleak picture at the time Mr. Bakker resigned.
Mr. Benton said the ministry had $50 million in secured and unsecured debt and faced claims of $160 million by PTL investors, or ''partners,'' who bought the vacation agreements, $15.5 million in claims from contractors and tax bills of $59 million to $79 million to the Internal Revenue Service and $12 million to South Carolina. He put the value of tangible assets at $140 million.
Out of the presence of the jury, Mr. Benton said Mr. Bakker simply did not have the resources to deliver the vacation ''partnerships'' at Heritage USA that he offered donors who contributed $1,000 to the ministry. The partnerships were supposed to provide members with four-day annual vacations for the rest of their lives.
 
'A House of Cards'
Christine Howe, a former PTL reservation supervisor, said that every month in Mr. Bakker's last year at PTL, 1,300 to 3,700 lifetime partners were denied lodging they had requested.
Mr. Bakker repeatedly contradicted earlier witnesses, like six PTL board members who said they had never been told of the depth of the financial crisis. He said he got less than 1 percent of the money he raised as salary and in bonuses and the board was kept aware of the ministry's finances.
''I said to them not to give me the bonuses many, many times,'' Mr. Bakker testified. Ms. Smith said, ''And then you cashed the checks and used them to buy houses many, many times.''
Starting with the early 1980's, Ms. Smith outlined a worsening financial picture at PTL. She cited an accountant's report that questioned whether the ministry could survive, and its need for layoffs and hiring freezes.
 
But Bonuses Kept Rolling In
At the same time, Mr. Bakker and his wife, Tammy Faye, were receiving bonuses, including $600,000 in a six-week period late in 1986. Mr. Bakker said the board understood that faith in God would provide for the economic needs.
''We say that by faith, God will supply the need,'' he testified.
''How about truth?'' Ms. Smith shot back. ''Did you ever tell them the truth of what the financial situation was?''
Still, after the early uproar of the trial, Mr. Bakker's final testimony was rather tame. There was no mention of the sex scandal and hush money payment to Jessica Hahn that began his downfall. Both sides later rested. Closing arguments are scheduled for Tuesday and the case may go to the jury Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
An Image Polisher Leaves Nevada Neon to Sharpen a 'Beige' White House

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
He is a friend of Wayne Newton. His clients have included Frank Sinatra and Donald Trump. He wears well-cut Italian suits, Hermes ties, Bally loafers and a $3,000 Bertolucci watch. He drives a Mercedes sedan with a cellular phone.
Just when you thought the Bush White House was hopelessly beige and bland, a spritz of glitz has been added. Meet Sig Rogich, the wealthy Las Vegas advertising and public relations executive who is the President's new image-maker.
''I'm friends with Wayne Newton,'' the soft-spoken Mr. Rogich (pronounced ROGUE-ish) conceded, when asked about his acquaintances from the Las Vegas casino world. ''Even though I don't happen to like his song 'Danke Schon.' '' 
Mr. Rogich, who helped produce the Bush campaign's controversial commercials battering Gov. Michael S. Dukakis on prison furloughs and Boston Harbor, starts Wednesday as the new special assistant to the President for activities and initiatives. The job, raised to a cynical art form in the Reagan years by Michael K. Deaver, entails shaping the President's message and themes, planning his travel schedule and crafting the way his events should look for television.
 
Perspective of History
''I look at everything from an historical point of view because I think that gives greater impact to the message,'' said Mr. Rogich, who collects first-edition books, papers and photographs involving his two heroes, Winston Churchill and Theodore Roosevelt. ''It's important to look for the unusual setting that will be memorable. The Camp David accords wouldn't have been the same if they were the Washington accords.''
His predecessor, Stephen Studdert is returning to his home state of Utah, where he may run for office. In the official version, Mr. Studdert, who was accused inside the White House of being a self-promoter and outside the White House of arranging scattershot trips that garnered little national press coverage, was not asked to leave. But there was a feeling in the inner circle that it might be best if he headed West a little early.
In the beginning, Mr. Bush and his advisers tried so hard to shed the image of a stage-managed President that they ignored criticism that Mr. Bush was dissolving in a fuzzy video collage of puppies and horseshoes. Knowing that President Bush was not as telegenic as his predecessor, his advisers wanted to downgrade the importance of television and national news coverage.
But now officials concede that the big picture is blurry. They say they want to fix the problem while the President's popularity is high, before he runs into a crisis.
''This was one area where folks had suggested we needed a little bit of an extra dimension,'' said John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff. ''We needed a pro who understands how to emphasize what the President wants to convey without doing things that would make the President uncomfortable. We don't want anything ostentatious or over-orchestrated.''
 
A Formidable Footnote
In other words, while Mr. Bush still cringes at the term ''handler,'' he is willing to sit still for a glossier approach to showcasing his Presidency.
Enter Mr. Rogich, a man who has been so self-effacing in the last two Republican Presidential campaigns that he is missing from most Washington Rolodexes and mentioned only as a footnote in most campaign books. Like Mr. Bush, Mr. Rogich does not like turf battles or fighting for credit.
But insiders value him highly. In 1984, he was one of three directors of the ''Tuesday Team'' that orchestrated the slick $20 million advertising campaign for Ronald Reagan's landslide, and in 1988 he worked on Mr. Bush's team as the quiet partner of the garrulous Roger Ailes.
 
'A Special Relationship'
Since Mr. Ailes likes to take credit for clever work, and Mr. Rogich likes to give it, the two got along famously. ''We had a special relationship,'' Mr. Rogich recalled. ''I liked the way Roger allowed me to be creative, and he liked the way I did his shirts.''
Although he supervised the making of some of Mr. Bush's negative commercials, Mr. Rogich insists he preferred the softer advertisements, like the one of Mr. Bush's granddaughter running into his arms. He wrote one Republican Party spot that harkened back to tough economic times in the late 1970's under Jimmy Carter as the song ''I Remember You'' played.
Mr. Rogich is touchy about the aura that automatically clings to someone who has become one of the most powerful people in Nevada. He plans to sell his Mercedes and get a more modest four-wheel drive vehicle, and he is putting his advertising firm, which he has built into the largest in Nevada, in a blind trust.
Mr. Rogich, who once served as a boxing commissioner of Nevada and once owned a slot machine company, resigned from the board of Bally's casino in Las Vegas and sold his partnership in two small casinos in Fallon, Nev.
 
A Call From the Car
''Please don't portray me as some flashy Vegas gambler who's plopping into the White House in Italian suits and expensive watches,'' Mr. Rogich pleaded, calling a reporter from his car phone.
Indeed, while Mr. Rogich disdains the Brooks Brothers uniform favored by most White House officials, he does not gamble. ''I keep thinking I should be able to play baccarat because James Bond did,'' he said. ''I've always wanted to walk through a casino one day and say 'Banco!' just to be cool.''
In 1984, The Wall Street Journal wrote a story raising eyebrows over the presence of a Las Vegas public relations and advertising man as a Reagan campaign official. Hadn't Mr. Rogich helped Frank Sinatra get a gambling license? Hadn't he done public relations work for the casino operator Allan Sachs when Mr. Sachs wanted to improve the image of the Stardust Hotel after it had been linked to organized crime?
Mr. Rogich's wide circle of loyal friends in high places say that any criticism was merely a matter of prejudice against the image of Las Vegas as a neon Sodom and Gomorrah.
 
Angered Liberals on Campus
''There's an anti-Las Vegas bias in this town,'' said Paul Laxalt, the former Nevada Senator who filed and then later dropped a $250 million libel suit against the McClatchey papers over an article alleging skimming at a casino that his family once owned, ''and that attitude has a healthy dose of hypocrisy in it.''
Mr. Rogich got his start in politics as a Laxalt volunteer.
''He may have come from Las Vegas, but Sig is more rugged Western than glitzy Western,'' Mr. Sununu said, putting a positive spin on Mr. Rogich's roots.
The White House officials who have been getting to know Mr. Rogich are still getting used to his manner, which everyone concedes is ''different'' from conventional Washington fare.
Mr. Rogich has told people here that he is looking forward to working with the Cabinet because they are such ''beautiful people.''
Mr. Rogich may have helped produce some of the most notorious ads even in a Presidential campaign, but he has the soft, considerate, intensely sincere manner of the lead in a Frank Capra movie. He would rather talk about the plight of the Indians than the capital gains tax cut bill, and he would rather talk about helping the environment than about Wayne Newton.
 
A Wide-Ranging Mind
Indeed, unlike that of most Washington political types, Mr. Rogich's conversation jumps like a Renaissance grasshopper, from Basque restaurants to Puccini operas to vampire novels to Jackie Robinson and the old Brooklyn Dodgers.
Those who have worked with him in campaigns say he has an idealistic side uncommon either in a hard-bitten town like Las Vegas or a cynical business like political advertising. ''He really believes all that stuff,'' said Tom Messner, a Madison Avenue advertising executive who worked on the Reagan Tuesday Team.
Just as President Bush can get choked up when he stands on the Truman Balcony and talks about how special the White House is, Mr. Rogich can get overwhelmed when he sees the President in a historically steeped setting such as Monticello.
''It was awesome,'' he said quietly, after watching the President at Thomas Jefferson's home last week during the education summit.
 
A Dream as Real Life
The 45-year-old Mr. Rogich, a divorced father of two daughters whose hobbies include camping, collecting duck stamps, playing the guitar and reading about Indians, concedes he can sound hokey. ''I know it sounds corny for someone to tell you that they're patriotic and that they feel honored to do something like this,'' he said, ''but I believe deeply in this President because he's a good guy.''
His friends suggest that his idealism may stem from the fact that Mr. Rogich has lived the American dream. Born in Iceland, he started ''dirt poor,'' as his mother, Ranny, puts it, when the family lived in public housing and his father worked in a metals factory outside Las Vegas. His father went on to be a foreman at a company that made neon casino signs, and his sister was a dancer in a review that toured with Sammy Davis Jr. Sig Rogich worked odd jobs from the time he was small, and as he got older toiled as a busboy at casinos in Las Vegas, a bellboy in Lake Tahoe hotels and a folk singer in San Francisco bistros. He changed his name in college, from Sigfus to the less exotic Sigmund, although everyone calls him ''Sig'' anyway. By the time he turned 40, he was a multimillionaire, and one who quietly sends money to children in need of operations when he reads about them in newspapers.
His friends also say that he is more ''touchy-feely'' than most politicos and sometimes offers a hug in expressing emotion. As one Bush official explains, ''He's just very West Coast.''

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook; Don't Fiddle With the Fed;
It's the Politicians Who Need Discipline

BYLINE: By RICHARD E. MOONEY

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve System's independence constantly frustrates idealistic populists, economic monetarists and Presidents uncomfortable with the ambiguity of its powers.
Populists rail at its authority over interest rates and the secrecy of its deliberations. Monetarists want unswerving adherence to their money management doctrine. And Presidents get edgy when high interest rates threaten the prosperity that keeps them in office. At one time or another, all want more control over Fed policy. The current vehicle for their frustration is an ill-conceived bill by Representatives Byron Dorgan of North Dakota and Lee Hamilton of Indiana. This page has given the bill qualified support, but there's more to be said. 
In the name of democratizing Fed operations, the Dorgan-Hamilton proposal would politicize them. Making the Secretary of the Treasury a member of the Fed's board of governors would position the Administration to manipulate policy making. The Reagan Administration's eight years of fiscal irresponsibility should be evidence enough of the value of an independent central bank.
Another restrictive provision in the Dorgan-Hamilton bill would make the Fed disclose policy decisions immediately, instead of after six weeks. That would deny the Fed essential flexibility. The bill would also authorize policy audits by the General Accounting Office, creating another layer of kibitzing by Congress, which controls the G.A.O.
Congress created the Fed in 1913 intending that it operate independently, meaning outside politics. The Treasury had a seat on the board until 1935, when it was eliminated by law. The law's sponsor was Senator Carter Glass, a former Treasury Secretary, who said at the time: ''He [the secretary] is the dominant figure . . . and the system has been made a doormat of the U.S. Treasury.'' Representative Stephen Neal of North Carolina now offers a counterproposal to the Dorgan-Hamilton bill, with the same basic flaw - inflexibility. The Neal bill calls for eliminating inflation in five years. While that might be desirable, and while the Fed is clearly and specifically answerable to Congress, it makes no sense to risk forcing the Fed to bring on a devastating downturn.
On one point, the Dorgan-Hamilton bill does offer improvement, by letting a new President name his own man as Fed chairman. The Fed's seven governors have 14-year terms, well insulated from shifting political winds, but the chairmanship is for four years. Currently its timing is haphazard. Each chairman's four years run from whenever he's named. The Dorgan-Hamilton bill would start his term one year after each Presidential term.
For the most part, the Dorgan-Hamilton bill echoes ideas long proposed in past years by Representative Wright Patman, an outspoken populist and Fed critic. The current bill was initiated by Mr. Dorgan, but gets noticed because his co-sponsor is so distinguished, having gained national stature as chairman of the Iran-contra hearings. Mr. Hamilton, driven by neither populist nor monetarist ideology, is worried that vast power is being exercised without clear lines of accountability.
But there's a greater concern: Presidents should not be allowed to inject self-serving politics into the management of monetary policy. For the eight Reagan years, monetary policy compensated for irresponsible fiscal policies with admirable finesse. Critics in Congress who think that monetary management needs more discipline would be well advised to look first to the Government's reckless fiscal management.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: How to Help the Disabled Pay Their Own Way

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It's to be expected that any change as sweeping as extending civil rights to 43 million citizens with disabilities would create some opposition. That there has been so little opposition to the Americans with disabilities bill is a credit to Senate and White House negotiators who spent four months crafting legislation that balances business and disability interests.
Thus, it was all the more disappointing that you chose to align yourself against the President, a strong bipartisan Senate majority and 180 disability, religious and civil rights organizations. Even worse, your editorial of Sept. 6 (''Blank Check for the Disabled?'') exhibited an alarming ignorance of how the bill originated and what it would do. 
The Senate's 76-8 passage of the bill, far from being a rush to avoid ''political suicide,'' was the result of years of study, public debate and domestic diplomacy.
With small businesses crucial to the economy of my home state of Iowa, I have made sure this bill takes their concerns into account. That's why small businesses with fewer than 15 employees are exempted from its employment provisions. That's why the act would provide extensive phase-in for the public to learn about and make the often minimal changes necessary: for employers, two years; for public accommodations, 18 months; for private transportation companies, six to seven years.
You quote me as saying that ''costs do not provide a basis for exemption from the basic principles in a civil rights statute.'' The Congressional Record will show I also said: ''That is not to say, there won't be costs or that it is inappropriate to recognize cost in devising particular standards for inclusion in the bill. For example, cost was a factor in the decision that the bill should not mandate the retrofitting of existing buses; only new buses must be accessible.''
The vast majority of businesses want to employ and accommodate people with disabilities, not out of charity, but because it makes business sense. A 1982 study by the Department of Labor showed that only 22 percent of workers with disabilities require any accommodation to perform their jobs, and in two-thirds of the cases in which accommodations would be necessary, the average cost is less than $100.
The cost of adding a wheelchair ramp, for example, is more than offset by increased revenues from disabled customers or the increased productivity of talented and committed disabled workers.
It does indeed require little skill to ''write blank checks for worthy causes with other people's money.'' For too long, taxpayers have been writing a blank check (last year's was for $57 billion) to keep the disabled dependent, when clearly they want to be contributing members of society. With the Senate's strong approval of the bill, we all begin to get our money's worth.
 
TOM HARKIN
U.S. Senator from Iowa
Washington, Sept. 11, 1989
 The writer, chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on the Handicapped, is the lead sponsor of the Americans with disabilities bill.

HEADLINE: Working-Class Families Losing Middle-Class Dreams

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
Gilbert and Debra Matthews enter every penny of his subway motorman's salary on the giant lined sketch pad that serves as their budget, only to find they keep coming up short.
On his truck driver's pay, Harry Biolsi can stay in the Astoria neighborhood where he grew up only becuse he and his family live in his mother's house.
Reynell and Margaret Tyndall squeeze into a two-room apartment with their baby, sharing a kitchen and bath with her sister's family and dreaming of the day they can afford a home of their own.
These are members of an all but invisible class: one out of every four New York families, who earn between $28,000 and $35,000. They hold secure, often blue-collar, jobs -subway motormen, truck drivers, firefighters, factory workers. But they cannot live the middle-class life that seemed within their reach a generation ago. 
''When our parents had us, they had theAmerican dream,'' Mr. Matthews said. ''They said my kids will have more than me. The American dream is gone.''
Mr. Matthews's impressions are borne outby several nationwide statistics. Wages, adjusted for inflation, have not increased since 1973. While wages have been stagnant, the cost of housing has soared. These nationwide trends are magnified in New York City, with its sky-high housing costs and strained public services.
 
When It All Seemed Possible
A number of economists, including Frank Levy of the University of Maryland's School of Public Affairs, conclude that fewer jobs now than in 1973 pay enough to afford a middle-class life.
Many working-class New Yorkers still long for that life - when wives did not have to go to work, a 40-hour week paid the bills, and it seemed possible to save enough money to buy a home.
Some, like the Matthewses, act as if that dream were true - refusing overtime, having wives stay at home to raise children -but the tradeoff means they cannot save money. Others, like the Tyndalls, choose to sacrifice today's comforts in the hope that tomorrow will be better.
For all of them, life in this city feels harder than it used to be. They cannot buy their way out of New York's problems. They no longer trust the public schools to educate their children. They cannot hop a cab if the subway or bus is late. The neighborhoods they can afford to live in are more dangerous and drug-infested.
 
'Like a Biologist Staining a Slide'
''New York is sort of like a biologist staining a slide: it brings things out,'' said Elliott Sclar, professor of urban planning at Columbia University.
''The American dream was always very difficult to hold onto,'' he said. ''It's a dream that doesn't just depend upon your own little house and how well you take care of it. It also depends on how good the services are in the neighborhood, the commitment to good public education, fire and police protection. When you start to look around the neighborhoods of New York, you begin to see a city that has given up.''
But most working-class New Yorkers, even if they sometimes dream of getting out, choose to stay. Despite the urban ills they live with every day, many say they are afraid to gamble what security they have and leave for other cities where prices are lower and life might be easier. Ties to family and friends hold them fast. And most find a corner of New York to savor, and strike a balance between small pleasures and privations.
What follows is a portrait of three families and how they get by in New York.
 
Shards of Glass, Hopes of Flowers
Since the day she arrived in New York from Jamaica three years ago, Margaret Tyndall has clung to a dream. One day, she, her husband, Reynell, and their year-old daughter, Kristina, will have a house with a backyard, maybe even some flowers.
Now they live on a block of rundown brownstones in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, in a small two-bedroom apartment she shares with her sister's family. There are shards of broken glass in the street and graffiti on the boarded-up buildings. Boys shoot baskets through milk crates serving as hoops. Mechanic and Teller One Day, Maybe, A Backyard Sometimes, the Tyndalls said, garbage piles up for two weeks before it is collected. Although they shun Jamaicans in the drug trade, the police will appear at odd hours to show them photographs in case they recognize dealers.
''It's a crummy neighborhood,'' Mrs. Tyndall said as she sat in a living room decorated with maps of Jamaica and baby pictures. ''But at the moment I cannot do better than what I'm doing.''
 
Used to Doing Without
The Tyndalls live in Crown Heights so they can save. Between his job as a maintenance mechanic and hers as a bank clearance teller, handling foreign exchange and messages, they earn $37,000 a year. They are used to doing without.
''We're from the third world, and we know about saving,'' Mr. Tyndall, 33, said with a laugh. They share the apartment with his sister-in-law's family so they can split the $530 monthly rent. They carry their lunches to work. They clip coupons and shop at three different stores, looking for less expensive food. They seldom buy new clothes or eat out. Mr. Tyndall moonlights on weekends.
Their only indulgence is a long call to Jamaica now and then when they feel homesick. Nonetheless, they manage to save about $200 a week from their combined weekly take-home pay of $610.
Holding fast to a Jamaican custom, Mrs. Tyndall is part of a mutual savings group, or ''su su.'' Every week, she and a group of friends deposit $50 to $100 in a joint account. They take turns drawing out all the cash at once, so that they can get large amounts of cash quickly without resorting to bank loans. In another tradition, Mrs. Tyndall saves her silver - quarters and dimes - in a box for Kristina. When the box fills up, she buys savings bonds.
''I don't want her to have to struggle the way we are,'' said Mrs. Tyndall, who is 30.
 
Wealth All Around Them
But their life is not all privation. On their free weekends, they walk with Kristina to the park, take in an occasional movie, and have dinner parties with friends from Jamaica, their work or their church. And every year, they withdraw some of their savings and fly to Jamaica for two weeks.
Despite their qualms about New York - the schools, drugs, crime and services - they find much they like. The subways are convenient and, they say, usually run on time. Their church is close by. The Tyndalls would leave New York only if they found they could not afford to give Kristina a home or a place in Catholic school; they would not send her to public school, fearing violence and drugs.
They see wealth around them, but their dreams are more modest.
''To live like that is Hollywood, right?'' Mr. Tyndall said. ''You don't want to put your hat where you can't reach it.'' Subway Motorman Always in Debt Despite a Good Job Gilbert Matthews, 38, holds a $35,000 job that many who are worse off would envy. The father of four is a subway motorman with the Transit Authority. But he and his wife, Debra, feel little of the security his job might once have brought them.
''I grew up in this neighborhood and back then, it was easy, because homes weren't that much,'' said Debra Matthews, 33, soft-spoken and contained. 'We try to put some money away and build it up, but it's kind of rough.''
Their meticulously kept budget permits few luxuries: cable television, cigarettes, a night out once a month at a family-style restaurant like Red Lobster. Once a year, they leave the children with their grandparents and take a vacation in a warm place like the Bahamas.
But no matter how assiduously they watch their pennies, they still find themselves turning to credit cards. Mr. Matthews said he was always in debt, although he is careful not to fall behind in his payments.
 
Overtime or Meatloaf
''A lot depends on overtime,'' he said. ''If there's overtime, there's steak. If there's no overtime, it's meatloaf.''
In many ways, he and his wife know they are lucky. Most of their health- care costs, like the Tyndalls's and the Biolsis', are covered by benefits. They live in a large, four-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment in the Soundview section of the Bronx. Their living room contains a television, a large radio, their children's pictures and toys piled in one corner. They own a car.
Their $745 monthly rent is partly subsidized, because they live in a Mitchell-Lama apartment complex, built to offer affordable middle-class housing in New York. The apartment towers rise around a pleasant grass courtyard, filled with trees, benches and children running in the twilight.
New York City helped them by providing a relatively low-rent apartment, but they are less pleased with other services. During the day, Mrs. Matthews said, the city bus from Parkchester runs infrequently. Where they once felt safe, drugs are invading their neighborhood. And they are disappointed in the public schools, where they send their children because they cannot afford parochial-school tuition.
 
Penalties for Working Harder
Nor does Mr. Matthews see how he can afford to put his children through college. His oldest is 13; the youngest is 3. ''I think I'm making too much for them to get aid,'' he said. ''Maybe they should think about the service,'' he said, speaking of the military. ''That's a good, steady job.''
Mrs. Matthews said that she would like to work to bring in more money, but that it did not make sense. Most of the extra income would go to rent because in Mitchell-Lama buildings rents increase as incomes rise, and the family would probably end up worse off because Mrs. Matthews would have to pay for child care.
Nor is Mr. Matthews willing to sacrifice time with his family to earn more money.
''If my body was up to it, I could work so much overtime that I could make $60,000 or $90,000,'' he said. ''If I do that for two years, I might get a partial down payment for a home. But I don't want to wreck my body, because I've got to do this job for 20 more years.''
Sometimes they think about leaving New York, where they both grew up and where their parents still live. Mr. Matthews would choose Toronto. ''They have a transit system up there; the schools are fine,'' he said. ''But it's a question of saying I'm leaving my roots.'' Truck Driver Lucky to Live With Mother Flags flutter from doorways and windows. Elderly men sit in their undershirts on beach chairs, surveying the neighborhood from their terraces. A man stands on his roof, tending the grape leaves entwined around his trellis.
This is Astoria, the Queens neighborhood where Harry Biolsi grew up and where he feels lucky to stay. Here houses sell for $275,000 and even studio apartments begin at $500 a month.
Either would be far beyond his means, with his $30,000 truck driver's salary and a wife and four children to support. But Mr. Biolsi lives with his mother in the house she bought in 1944, with its tidy front gate and large backyard. They pay her a modest monthly rent.
''I'm very, very lucky,'' Mr. Biolsi, 48, said as he sat in his spacious living room. #12-Hour Days Not Enough It is hard enough, the Biolsis say, to get by on the salary he does bring home after 12-hour days driving a truck and loading office furniture. To earn a little extra, he will sometimes work on friends' houses, doing minor repairs and home improvements.
Even so, the money flows out faster than it comes in. When his company moved to Paterson, N.J., he bought a second car, because it became too exhausting to commute by bus and train.
Now the Biolsis have to budget two car and insurance payments. They send their 10-year-old daughter and 8-year-old son to Catholic school, because they believe the local public schools are not safe or strict enough. And they have loans and credit card debt to pay off, taken on to buy their television, videocassette recorder and Mr. Biolsi's prize Akita dog.
 
'Guilt Alone Would Kill Me'
''We only save for vacations,'' said Arlene Biolsi, who is 36. ''As soon as we save, something comes up. The bathroom sink plugs up, and we had to have a new dishwasher. We have debts on the card, but they are little things, because we don't let it out of control. We did that once, and never again.''
Mrs. Biolsi worked as a secretary before her children were born, but neither she nor her husband would consider her going back before the children are older. ''I wouldn't allow my wife to go to work,'' Mr. Biolsi said. ''I believe the wife should be with the children.'' Mrs. Biolsi hastened to agree. ''I would hate to have to leave the kids and go to work; the guilt alone would kill me,'' she said.
For the Biolsis, Astoria has everything they need: good shopping, pleasant streets, convenient bus and subway service, good neighbors. On free days, they go bowling together.
 
Perils and Failures
But the Astoria of today is not the safe working-class neighborhood Mr. Biolsi grew up in. The perils and failures of modern city life intrude. Mr. Biolsi bemoans the lost power of the police. He and his wife worry about drugs and violence, even in Astoria.
''I still walk the children to school,'' Mrs. Biolsi said. ''They're not allowed outside alone.''
Yet Mr. Biolsi is content because he can live in the neighborhood he wants. His friends are not so lucky. To find a $100,000 home, the best he could afford, one of his friends at work had to move 85 miles from New York City to Pennsylvania and continues to commute to New Jersey. In Astoria, his mother's friends all have their children moving back in with them.
''The American dream of owning a home - in the city, it's dead,'' he said. ''It might not be dead if you move to Montana, but you have to worry about jobs.''

HEADLINE: Conquering the Wishbone Behind a Small Force

BYLINE: By RALPH ROUTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLORADO SPRINGS, Oct. 2

 BODY:
People hear about this elusive little Air Force Academy quarterback named Dee Dowis, whose statistics have turned him into a Heisman Trophy candidate, and the same questions always arise.
How does he do it? How can someone that small, 5 feet 10 inches and 153 pounds, be so dominant in big-time college football? How can he lead the nation's Division I-A schools in rushing and scoring? Is he real or fictional?
The answer begins with his modus operandi, which he repeats dozens of times every Saturday.
 
From Snap to Finish
Dowis takes the snap from center, immediately reacts to defensive movement and either fakes to the fullback or hands off to him.
If Dowis keeps the ball, several swarming tacklers, all intent on slamming this wisp of a quarterback to the ground, are waiting for him. Their size dwarfs him by as much as half a foot and 80 pounds a man. Approaching from different angles, the defense converges rapidly and fearlessly. 
Then, at football's version of the hot corner and Dowis's own private stage, wizardry unfolds.
Sometimes the quarterback will cut sharply, dart inside his pursuers and accelerate into the open field before they can even think of changing direction. If the defense comes too close, he deftly pitches the football to a trailing halfback who cuts upfield.
If the pursuers play soft, giving ground, Dowis waits until the last possible instant before making his decision. Time after time, the defenders have to commit first. The ball, of course, goes elsewhere.
 
A Wishbone Story
That scene, with only a few subtle variations, tells the story of Air Force's basic offensive play: the wishbone triple option.
Few major college teams depend on that play for its well-being, mainly because, in the words of Air Force's head coach, Fisher DeBerry, ''It puts the entire game in the hands of the quarterback.''
Dowis is the quarterback into whose hands DeBerry puts the game, and every game brings new admirers into the fold. Opposing players and coaches praise Dowis as one who is elevating his skill to an art form.
After Dowis ran for 249 yards and six touchdowns in Air Force's season opener, a 52-36 victory over San Diego State, Al Luginbill, the losing head coach, was awestruck.
''That's the best performance I've seen by an individual player - ever,'' said Luginbill, who saw quite a few while building nationally prominent defenses at Arizona State. ''You wouldn't believe this, but yes, our game plan was to stop Dowis. His ability made it impossible to execute our game plan.''
After Dowis came back with 201 yards and two touchdowns the next week to lead a 45-7 rout of Wyoming, the response was similar.
 
Springboard to Heisman
''He's got to be one of the best wishbone quarterbacks in recent years,'' Wyoming's head coach, Paul Roach, said. ''You can probably go back 10 years and he will rank up there with some of the great Oklahoma quarterbacks.''
With those two games as the springboard, Dowis has catapulted into the Heisman derby. In a season with no apparent star runners, he must still be considered a long shot behind two other quarterbacks, Major Harris of West Virginia and Tony Rice of Notre Dame.
Yet, as the games go by with Dowis so prominent in the statistics, and unbeaten Air Force rising into the rankings, nobody is discounting the babyfaced kid from Royston, Ga.
Although Northwestern held Dowis to only 40 rushing yards on Sept. 16, his passing and execution of the triple option were sufficient for Charlie Weatherbie, Air Force's quarterback coach, to call it ''Dee's most complete game ever.''
So far this season he has run for 729 yards and 13 touchdowns; he is averaging 11.2 yards a carry.
 
Next Stop: Navy
The Falcons, 5-0 after a 46-21 victory Saturday at Colorado State, will showcase Dowis on the East Coast this week against Navy at Annapolis, Md.
Dowis's biggest opportunity for national attention will come Oct. 14 when Air Force faces Notre Dame at Colorado Springs. That will be Dowis versus Tony Rice before an overflow crowd of more than 50,000 and a national television audience.
''I don't think I'm a great quarterback,'' Dowis said. ''I'm just playing on a great team. Everybody on the team does their job. Nobody thinks they're the star. I just want to think about winning.
''I'm honored to be mentioned for the Heisman, but it's just something else to clutter up your mind.''
Certainly, Dowis's time is precious. He is taking 19 1/2 hours this fall semester, far more than most players at other schools. The courses aren't shabby, either: behavioral science, engineering, economics, geography and management.
Those academic accomplishments, along with his football feats, have roots deep in the story of Michael Dee Dowis.
 
Home of Ty Cobb
His father, Leonard Dowis, was the football coach at Franklin County High School near the small rural town of Royston, which is better known as the home of baseball great Ty Cobb. Leonard had played football at the University of Georgia; he wanted the same for his son.
Leonard, however, never saw his dream become reality. He died of a heart attack when Dee was 4 years old. Dee's mother was remarried three years later to Harold Brown. Two older sisters were already out of college, so Dee grew up as an only child.
Dowis was an all-state shortstop in baseball and also led Franklin County High to the Georgia football playoffs. He had excellent grades, but his lack of size turned off college recruiters.
Army, another wishbone team, took a closer interest, and a Georgia high school coach told Air Force's staff members about Dowis. Even on film, his potential was evident.
''We couldn't believe how little he was,'' DeBerry said. ''But he had great quickness, he was smart and you can't have enough guys like that.''
 
Skimpy Results
As a freshman he had a handful of playing opportunities, showing potential but with skimpy results.
Being so far from home and dealing with the rigors of cadet life were far tougher adjustments than those he made to college football. During spring break of his freshman year, Dowis visited Vanderbilt and Georgia Tech to talk about transferring, but eventually chose to stay at Air Force.
As a sophomore in 1987, Dowis set a national record for rushing yards (1,315) by a quarterback in leading Air Force to a 9-4 season and the Freedom Bowl. That led to higher expectations for his junior year, but hardly anything went right for him or the Falcons in 1988. He ran for 972 yards - disappointing to him - and Air Force's injury-plagued team slid from a 5-2 start to a 5-7 finish.
In the final game of the 1988 season, Dowis sank to new depths of frustration. He was pulled in the third quarter and had to watch the rest of the game from the sidelines.
During the off season this year, his teammates and coaches began noticing a change in Dowis. Whether it was a desire to vindicate himself or simply the reality of reaching his final season, Dowis became more forceful, suddenly willing to accept a team leadership role.
''He has matured by leaps and bounds in just one year's time,'' Weatherbie said. ''He knows he has to be confident and show that confidence to the team.''
Dowis agrees that he has a different outlook.
''It really hits you to think this is your last year,'' he said. ''I've been playing 15 years, and now suddenly to be coming down to the last one.''
 
Confident and Cocky
The only place where his personality really changes is on the football field. There he comes across as confident, even cocky, always bouncing up from hard hits, frequently altering called plays with audibles at the line of scrimmage.
''He has come into his own now,'' DeBerry said. ''There isn't anything he can't accomplish. The key thing for Dee is, don't try to make it happen. Just let it happen.''
Dowis has also figured out how to justify consenting to all the interview requests.
''If it's good for the Air Force Academy and for our team, I don't mind doing it,'' he said. ''But we've got just one goal, to win, and that's what I want to concentrate on.''
While Dowis takes that approach, everyone else watches his numbers.
''I'm not thinking about the yards,'' Dowis said. ''Our offense just takes what the defense gives us.''
