HEADLINE: Andean Culture Found to Be As Old as the Greaty Pyramids

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
ARCHEOLOGISTS working in Peru have unearthed stunning evidence that monumental architecture, complex societies and planned developments first appeared and flowered in the New World between 5,000 and 3,500 years ago - roughly the same period when the great pyramids were built in Egypt and the Sumerian city-states reached their zenith in Mesopotamia.
Stepped pyramids and huge, U-shaped temples more than 10 stories high. Bright multi-colored friezes with jaguar and spider motifs. Broad plazas flanked by residential areas. All these have been uncovered, or partly so, in the first few excavations, made in the last decade, by a number of archeologists working among literally scores of sites in more than 50 narrow river valleys that plunge from the Andes to the Pacific along the length of Peru.
The earliest sites are a thousand years older than their counterparts in Central America, traditionally regarded as the cradle of civilization in the Western Hemisphere, and they are consequently forcing a reassessment of pre-Columbian accomplishments in the Americas. Their antiquity also narrows the gap between the emergence of civilization in the New World and the Old. 
''This idea of the Old World being ahead of the New World has to be put on hold,'' said Richard Burger, a Yale University archeologist who is one of several working to uncover and interpret the remains of the ancient Peruvian civilization.
The ''whopping great monuments'' of the Andes ''invite favorable comparison'' with what was going on in the Middle East, said Michael Moseley, an archeologist at the University of Florida who has long worked in the region.
The culture of the early Andeans never reached the heights of Mesopotamia and Egypt. Neither they nor their descendants, including the Incas 3,000 years later, developed writing or used the wheel. Nor does even the latest evidence show the Andean culture to be nearly as ancient as that of the Fertile Crescent, whose origins date back at least 8,000 years. But some archeologists say that in their ability to construct planned communities and grand structures, organize labor, create art and devise a political system, the Andeans of four millennia ago might have shown up well beside their Old World contemporaries.
However that may be, the evidence of human settlement back then is ''much more spectacular on the West Coast of Peru than it is anywhere in Mexico,'' said Kent Flannery, an archeologist at the University of Michigan who has long worked in Central America. ''I think a lot of people who have worked in Mexico and haven't been to Peru will be surprised at how early and spectacular the stuff is down there.''
The biggest Andean monuments predate the rise of the Mayas in Central America by nearly 2,000 years, and the Aztecs by nearly 3,000. Those civilizations, like that of the Incas, came relatively late. The emerging picture of this earliest American civilization is that of a people tied initially to the sea, living off its bounty, but then moving abruptly - no one knows why - into the Andean highlands to build a flourishing economy based on irrigated agriculture that prospered in spite of the harsh, cold, arid climate at altitudes around 10,000 feet.
 
A Varied Diet
Based on the remains of buildings, art and contents of refuse piles, archeologists say these people dressed in cotton tunics, breechcloths, shawls and capes, and that they lived well on sweet potatoes, peanuts, beans, manioc, fish, shellfish and an occasional deer or sea lion, with guinea pigs a delicacy - ''sort of like caviar,'' Dr. Burger said.
They were no strangers to bloody terror, and may, like the later Aztecs farther north, have practiced human sacrifice.
Archeologists have done only a fraction of the work in the Andes that they have done in the Middle East, and the discoveries of the 1980's in Peru are so fresh that scientists are only beginning to understand the nature of the society that built there.
Some believe the most advanced settlements were urban city-states, governed by a powerful elite that controlled the economic assets, principally its food stocks. Others believe the settlements fell short of being truly urban. They also say there is no evidence so far of the force, oppression and exploitation that are commonly thought to have been a part of Old World city-states. The early Andeans, some say, may have relied instead on economic cooperation, with religion as the binding force, to organize their society.
 
A Different Development Path
In any case, there is wide agreement that the early Andeans took a developmental path different from that of the Old World and even from that of Central America. Not least, the Andean civilization appears to have been more diffuse and decentralized because the isolated valleys forced it to develop that way.
All of this is bringing about a third radical revision of thought about the origins of Andean civilization. First, the Incas took credit for having invented it. Then, early in this century, the Inca claim was disproved by the German archeologist Max Uhle, who found a long succession of pre-Inca cultures stretching back some 1,500 years. Uhle theorized that the advanced cultures of Central America had touched off the evolution of South American civilization.
This was challenged beginning in the 1920's by the Peruvian archeologist Julio C. Tello, who contended that Andean civilization was home-grown and that its progenitor was the Chavin culture, named for Chavin de Huantar, a monumental ceremonial center that flourished in the highlands of central Peru some 2,500 years ago. There, Tello contended, Andean civilization crystallized and spread to less developed regions in the highlands and on the coast.
 
Revision of Explanations
Archeologists accepted Tello's explanation for half a century. But now, on the basis of the last decade's discoveries, they are concluding that Chavin de Huantar was not the cultural fountainhead, but rather the culmination of developments that began some 2,000 years earlier in other areas.
The revision does not stop there. Donald Lathrap, an archeologist at the University of Illinois at Urbana, believes on the basis of archeological finds of items dating back 8,000 years, that both the Mesoamerican and Andean civilizations have common roots in neolithic chiefdoms that existed in the central Amazon 7,000 to 8,000 years ago. ''The cradle was there,'' said Dr. Lathrap, and the culture ''spread out both to Mexico and Peru.''
The Andean temples and secular structures of 5,000 to 3,000 years ago that are now being uncovered have burst on the archeological scene with what Dr. Moseley calls ''thunderingly dramatic'' effect and are the most compelling force in the reappraisal. They are even more dramatic because the dry cold of the Andes has preserved them exquisitely. Adobe friezes and sculptures that might have been destroyed in another climate are preserved almost intact, with their vivid reds, blues and blacks still showing. Seeds, pollen and animal skeletons are not fossils, but real.
It is something of a mystery to archeologists why any major civilization would develop in the Andean valleys and on the Peruvian coast. The region's altitude and aridity make it ''grossly hostile,'' said Dr. Moseley, who added: ''That anyone ever lived there is a bit of a surprise.''
But they clearly did, as evidenced by the remains of scores of ancient communities, from the Jequetepeque Valley of Peru in the north to the Lurin Valley in the south, that have been investigated in the last decade. Typically, each community has at its center a monumental public structure, usually built in a ''U'' shape.
 
Culture Started on the Coast
The earliest of these, documented by radiocarbon dating as having been built some time from 5,000 to 4,100 years ago, were established along the coast on sites as large as 140 acres. At most sites, the temples were surrounded by residential areas and refuse deposits. A representative temple of this period, at Aspero on the coast, was about three stories high and measured 98 by 131 feet at its base.
Around 4,000 to 3,700 years ago, activity abruptly shifted inland and irrigated agriculture replaced fishing as the main economic resource.
The temples themselves appeared to have both a religious and secular function. One of the few to be radiocarbon dated is at a site 3,100 to 3,400 years old called Cardal, south of Lima, excavated by a team headed by Dr. Burger. A huge three-story stairway leads up to the entrance to the four-story temple. At the top, flanking the entrance to the temple's inner chamber, are two enormous mouths, each with three-foot-long fangs and interlocking teeth, painted red and yellow.
 
A Pyramid 10 Stories High
When the Andeans moved inland, they increased the size of their monumental buildings. The largest to be discovered so far is a colossal stepped pyramid, more than 10 stories high, at a site called Sechin Alto in the Casma River Valley north of Lima. On the basis of preliminary radiocarbon dating, it is thought to be 3,400 to 3,700 years old.
Sechin Alto may have been in some sort of loose regional association with another Casma Valley complex, the most spectacular site to be excavated and dated so far. Called Pampa de las Llamas-Moxeke and dating back 3,500 to 3,800 years, it has been excavated by Dr. Shelia and Dr. Thomas Pozorski, a husband-and-wife archeological team at Pan American University in Edinburgh, Tex.
The site contains a U-shaped temple 10 stories high. Up a hill to the north is a three-story secular public building. Between them is a huge plaza, about two-thirds of a mile long, flanked by smaller buildings and dwellings.
Based on their excavations, the Pozorskis believe that the large secular building, which archeologists call Huaca A, or Mound A, was a food storehouse that held the community's accumulated wealth. The arrangement of the rooms was such that access would have been easy to control, and the Pozorskis say that some sort of a bureaucratic elite probably exercised power by controlling these economic assets.
''If our interpretation is true about this warehouse,'' said Shelia Pozorski, ''it was a very powerful economic weapon over the people.'' This, along with the complexity of the site, its size, its precise planning and the high degree of labor mobilization and organization required to build the monuments, leads the Pozorskis to conclude that Pampa de las LLamas-Moxeke was an early city-state.
But Dr. Burger and others believe that the Peruvian centers followed what Dr. Burger calls ''a special evolutionary path.''
He said there is no evidence in Peru of any kind of social stratification along economic lines. The right to use irrigation canals, he says, was probably tied to ''your responsibilities in construction of the monumental architecture, and in ceremonies. The glue would be religion.''
 
Evidence of Complex Society
Bigger than a football field and as high as a three-story building, the Peruvian warehouse reconstructed above is 3,500 to 3,800 years old. It testifies to a complex South American civilization from a far earlier period than previously thought. Called Huaca A, it is one of two dominant structures at the site, in the Casma Valley on the north coast; the other is the ruin of a 10-story-high temple. The many storage rooms may illuminate how the society was organized, with leaders controlling production, stockpiling and distribution of agricultural products and luxury goods. At right, a typical storage room with floor matting and mud-plastered walls.

HEADLINE: DOCTOR'S WORLD;
The Proper Time to Tell Doctors What Will Be Expected of Them

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D.

 BODY:
SEVERAL leaders in medical education and health care say the risks and responsibilities of becoming a physician should be explained clearly to students before they enter medical school, not during training as is now customary.
The concern reflects the impact of the AIDS epidemic, the growth of the medical profession as a public institution and increasing concern over professional misconduct.
Applicants to medical schools now receive piles of brochures describing the curriculum, the institutions, their contributions to medicine and tuition fees.
But they receive surprising little information about a physician's obligation to treat people. It would be the rare medical school, for instance, that sent applicants or entrants a suggested reading list about the traditions of the medical profession and the ethical obligations of physicians. 
Yet pressures are rising for schools to begin to provide, in future application forms and during interviews, more explicit information about the traditions of the profession and a young physician's duty to society. There is concern not only about the obligation to treat but also about such problems as cheating, fraudulent research, drinking alcohol on duty, drug abuse, and having sex with patients.
The current assumption is that students learn about their ethical duties as they advance along the educational ladder to become physicians. But the assumption has not always been correct.
Critics contend that the failure to specify principles and codes to students before admission to medical school leaves them free to say ''no one told me,'' even when they should have known such behavior was wrong.
Moreover, a student who strongly disagrees with the idea that a doctor must treat a patient who threatens the doctor's own health might learn about it too late to decide against going into the profession. Such a physician may face continuing unresolved dilemmas. A crucial issue is AIDS, which has created a controversy over physicians' ethical duty to treat patients when such care may pose health risks to them, their spouses and future children.
It is a a medical credo that physicians have a moral obligation to attend the sick, and most physicians have honored that ethic over the centuries. Yet a generation or two has forgotten the risks that doctors ran from polio, syphilis, tuberculosis and many other communicable diseases when they were dominant health problems. Willingness to risk their own health in the service of others is one reason why doctors have enjoyed high social status and incomes.
Yet because of a longstanding reluctance to force people to provide services against their will, it is unlikely that physicians will lose their medical licenses for refusing care.
Dr. Albert R. Jonsen, who heads the department of medical history and ethics at the University of Washington in Seattle, says American law does not require physicians to provide services to any particular person unless that person is already the doctor's patient.
''Nevertheless, the traditional ethics impose a strong duty to treat anyone in need of care even at cost or risk to oneself,'' Dr. Jonsen wrote in the magazine University of Washington Medicine, now Medicine Northwest.
Still, there is a growing realization that unless doctors are subject to penalty, statements by major medical societies about a physician's obligation to treat will be taken as empty, self-promotional slogans. A broader underlying reason for the change is the heavy taxpayer subsidization of the costs of medical education and the direct public payments for most costs of medical care and medical research. As medicine has become more of a public institution, there has been an increasing recognition that doctors owe society something that other professions do not.
But medical students may not realize that the Government could exact a price for this support.
For example, doctors frequently complain about losing autonomy through increasing government regulations without recognizing what they gain from public funds. Uwe E. Reinhardt of Princeton University, who is an expert on the economics of health affairs and medical education, said that medical students must be made to understand they cannot avoid dealing with the government when it pays for almost half the health care bill.
''Every entering medical student in this country should be duly warned'' about the obligations to patients and society and what professional life is going to be like, Dr. Reinhardt said. In a preface to ''Technology, Bureaucracy, and Healing in America,'' by Roger J. Bulger, (University of Iowa Press), Dr. Reinhardt said that such warnings should be chiseled into every medical school's portal.
''Not to warn medical students thus would be irresponsible,'' Dr. Reinhardt said. ''On the other hand, having been duly warned, it would be just as irresponsible for physicians to deny a legitimate role for government in health care.'' Understanding and accepting personal risk in the practice of medicine head the ideal list of the basic professional values and attitudes, the Association of American Medical Colleges in Washington said in a report on the AIDS epidemic and medical education published earlier this year.
''Institutions should state unambiguously their expectations that medical students and residents have a professional responsibility to provide care'' to patients who are infected with the AIDS virus and to whom they are assigned, the report said.
Yet the latest national survey of medical students found that 11 percent disagreed with the premise that physicians have an ethical obligation to treat patients with dangerous infectious diseases.
Dr. Robert F. Jones, who helped develop the report as a member of the medical colleges staff, said the association was considering preparing a pamphlet that could be distributed with applications from all medical schools. He said his association had discussed the possibility of developing videotapes that might be shown at the time students interview for medical school.
The report is not binding on the 127 medical schools in this country, and a spot check of medical schools over recent months found none that included such a statement in the material sent to applicants.
Dr. Robert G. Petersdorf, the president of the medical colleges association, said he was unaware of any schools that had carried out the report's recommendations, though some may be taking steps to do so.
Educational institutions often are slow to change their ways, and some critics contend that medical schools may need to be nudged to highlight the risks and obligations at a time when the number of applicants to medical schools has been dropping. The word profession is derived from the Latin meaning a public vow, and a hallmark of a profession is the traditions and values it passes on to new generations.
Dr. Michael E. Whitcomb, the dean of the University of Washington Medical School, said it might be better for students to be asked to take the Hippocratic Oath at the beginning of medical school, so they would be encouraged to think about the demands traditionally placed on doctors.
Medical schools have tended to focus the admissions process on the achievements of the students rather than the expectations of them as physicians.
''We should make it clearer to first-year medical students what our expectations are in terms of the ethical and moral behavior of physicians,'' Dr. Whitcomb said in a recent interview.
''If you come to this school and you refuse to care for an AIDS patient, or some similar problem, that is grounds for dismissal,'' Dr. Whitcomb said, ''just as you say if you cheat you are out.''

HEADLINE: USX Is Planning to Sell Texas Oil Unit Reserves

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The USX Corporation, the giant steel and energy company, said yesterday that it planned to sell the reserves of its Texas Oil and Gas Corporation subsidiary.
Texas Oil, which USX acquired in 1986 in a stock deal valued at $3 billion, has failed to earn a consistent profit in recent years. Its vast gas reserves include about 1.2 trillion cubic feet in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Louisiana, Colorado and Kansas. Its oil reserves are relatively small, at 28 million barrels. 
The Pittsburgh-based USX said it was selling the reserves, which account for about a third of the unit's sales, because of growing stock market interest in natural gas producers. ''The market for natural gas properties has improved,'' said William E. Keslar, a USX spokesman. ''It seemed like an appropriate time to see if we can sell.''
On the New York Stock Exchange, USX was up $1.75 yesterday, to $34.875. USX was the second-most-active issue on the Big Board, with 2.8 million shares being traded.
 
Move to Diversify
Texas Oil, based in Dallas, has been a disappointment since it was acquired three years ago by the former United States Steel Corporation, which was trying to diversify further from what was then an ailing steel industry. The steel giant had made a $6 billion acquisition of the Marathon Oil Company four years before acquiring Texas Oil.
Analysts yesterday viewed the move to sell the Texas Oil reserves as a plan to reduce the steelmaker's long-term debt further. The debt, largely from the Marathon acquisition, now stands at about $5.8 billion.
USX said the proceeds would be used to reduce the debt and to repurchase shares, although it said it had not determined how much would go to each.
The once-prosperous Texas Oil and Gas Corporation has been hurt in recent years by falling natural gas prices. USX's former chairman, David M. Roderick, and his successor, Charles A. Corry, have contended that the low-cost gas producer would show improved earnings once excess gas supplies fell in the early 1990's.
Indeed, Texas Oil posted operating income of $377 million in 1985, the year before it was acquired by USX. But under the United States Steel banner, Texas Oil's operating results fell to a loss of $21 million the following year.
The subsidiary earned $2 million in 1987, and then had an operating loss of $31 million last year, as natural gas prices dropped to an average $1.72 per thousand cubic feet, from $2.66 the previous year. Texas Oil had a $134 million operating profit for the first half of this year, and Mr. Corry, who became USX's chairman earlier this year, called that an indication that the market had bottomed for natural gas.
The gas fields involved in the planned sale include small- to medium-sized reserves, principally in the Anadarko Basin in Oklahoma and Texas and the Arkoma Basin in Oklahoma and Arkansas. After the sale, USX would still have the subsidiary's gas-gathering and transmission business. Also, USX would still have the substantial - 3.5 trillion cubic feet - natural gas reserves of Marathon Oil, which are nearly three times the size of those of Texas Oil. Marathon's reserves are primarily in the Gulf of Mexico and offshore Alaska.
USX said it would sell the reserves piecemeal or in one transaction. ''The timetable is difficult to assess, because, with property throughout six states, it will likely be a complicated transaction,'' Mr. Keslar, the USX spokesman, said.
 
Large Price Seen
The analysts were divided on how much the Texas Oil reserves would bring, but they agreed that the properties would be more attractive than a year ago.
''The Texas Oil and Gas reserves could go for as much as $1 billion,'' said Scott Jones, an analyst with the AUS Group, a economic forecasting company based in Philadelphia.
James S. Jordan, an analyst with Lovett, Mitchell, Webb & Garrison Inc. in Houston, said the Texas Oil reserves could bring as much as $1.5 billion. ''And that does not take into account the fact that there could be large probable reserves,'' he said.
''The Tenneco and Transco deals made it clear that there are buyers out there,'' he added, referring to divestitures of natural gas properties over the last year by Tenneco Inc. and the Transco Corporation. ''I expect there will be a lot of people looking at those properties.''
Tenneco late last year sold its natural gas reserves in a $7.3 billion divestiture of its oil and gas properties. The analysts then said they were surprised by the strength of the bids. Also, the Amerada Hess Corporation, earlier this year, agreed to pay $911 million - a price the analysts at the time said was surprisingly high - for most of the oil and natural gas reserves of Transco's Exploration Partners Ltd. unit.
 
Less Drilling This Year
Mr. James said natural gas drilling activity had declined by 5 percent to 6 percent this year, indicating that supply would likely come into closer balance with demand.
Meanwhile, earnings have improved at USX's Marathon Oil subsidiary and in the company's steel operations. Marathon's operating income was up, to $506 million last year from $125 million in 1987, and the unit had operating an profit of $498 million for the first six months of this year.
USX's steel operating earnings were up, to $501 million last year from $125 million in 1987, after a loss of about $1.4 billion in 1986. The company's steel business earned $270 million in the first six months of this year.

HEADLINE: Offstage Gains on Debt;
As Bush Faces Harsh Criticism by Bankers, Some Countries Are Earnestly Negotiating

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
While President Bush and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady have worked publicly in recent days to rebut criticism of the Administration's strategy for reducing third world debt, offstage developments demonstrate that important progress on debt is indeed being made.
 
In meetings at the
Treasury and the White House last week and in speeches at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, Mr. Bush and Mr. Brady were faced with critical bankers and some skeptical government officials.
The critics said the seven-month-old policy, which emphasizes debt reduction as an important part of solving the developing world's $1.3 trillion debt problem, raised expectations unfairly in debtor countries, adding that it had not been well thought out, put pressure on banks and diverted attention from the need for new lending.
The bankers also said the strategy, known as the Brady plan, lacked the financial backing needed to make debt reduction more attractive. 
But while these criticisms were aired, Venezuela and Argentina took steps to better their chances for successful debt negotiations, some banks stepped in to help and government officials suggested some regulatory policy changes that were needed.
 
'Pot of Boiling Emotions'
''The I.M.F. was a pot of boiling emotions, public turmoil, with very positive undercurrents,'' said John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, the leader of the bank negotiating teams. ''I think it will work out, but it has got to settle down a bit.''
The Venezuelans, whose negotiations with commercial bankers had been stalled for months, revamped their debt proposal and got an interim $600 million loan from 15 banks. The I.M.F. said it would release a $1.4 billion standby credit to Argentina even before an agreement with the country's commercial bank lenders to pay more than $4 billion of interest in arrears. The move should open the way to start negotiations on a debt reduction and restructuring package.
Government regulators indicated that they could take steps to make it more attractive for banks to lend money to debtor countries. Bankers at J. P Morgan & Company, which drew much criticism last week with its move to set aside a 100 percent cushion against bad third world loans, tried to indicate they were not sending such a negative message.
Another factor seems to be helping progress. That is the apparent commitment of some debtor countries to take the steps needed to open their markets, sell state-owned enterprises and attract both new investment and the capital that fled the country.
 
Commitments Can Disappear
These commitments can disappear. But they seem to be part of the same wave of economic realization that is touching the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and parts of Asia, which may make them more lasting.
Bankers have been waiting since March for some indication of what the United States and its allies would do to encourage debt reduction or new loans by changing or modifying existing accounting, tax and other rules.
E. Gerald Corrigan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, told them what they wanted to hear when he addressed the Group of 30 nations in Washington on Monday. Mr. Corrigan indicated in a speech, bankers said, that Federal bank regulators would be willing to go as far as prudently possible to limit the need to set aside reserves to cover new loans to Mexico and other countries. And Pierre Beregovoy, France's Finance Minister, said he would adjust tax rules ''to given incentives to French banks to get involved in the process.''
Morgan executives went out of their way to indicate that their move to increase their reserves against bad loans should not be taken as a signal that Morgan, or other banks that made similar moves, would cut off all new lending to debtor countries.
 
More Flexibility
Rodney Wagner, vice chairman of the credit policy committee at Morgan, said: ''We believe we have more flexibility and can do more in these countries than we have before. We're in a position where we can play a more constructive role.''
Venezuela dropped its demand for a 50 percent debt reduction across the board and, instead, will offer a sliding scale of debt reduction options to the banks. It has also included a new money option. Both changes were applauded by bankers, many of whom joined in the $600 million bridge loan. With it and $400 million of its own reserves, Planning Minister Miguel Rodriguez Fandeo said Venezuela will be able to wipe out its interest arrears by the end of the year.
The standby loan for Argentina is even a more important signal. It shows that a country still far behind on interest payments - which neither the fund nor the bankers like -can get a chance to get back on the recovery and negotiating tracks.
The efforts of Argentina's new President, Carlos Saul Menem, to overhaul the economy have impressed some bankers. But others are still worried about the nation's commitment. ''Argentina always starts with big hopes and then it deflates,'' said one banker who asked not to be named.
These developments came as Mexico, which concluded the first negotiation under the Brady plan, prepared to begin its road show to sell the plan to more than 400 banks.
 
Showing Some Progress
Together, these events show some progress, especially when compared with the last years of the Reagan Administration, when attempts to work out the debt problem basically came to a halt.
But that is all they show - movement where there had been none. There is no single success story yet and even Mexico could become a disappointment if it fails to get a proper mix of debt reduction and new money.
Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard economist and a critic of the Brady plan and the banks, foresaw a disaster. ''The noose is tightening on these countries,'' he said, adding, ''It's a dreadful failure.''
But A. W. Clausen, the chairman of BankAmerica, seemed to reflect a more benign vision. He claimed no success yet but argued that the leading bankers would move ahead, despite their criticism last week about the Brady plan.
''These banks are money center banks,'' he said. ''They are statesman-like banks.''

HEADLINE: Talking Business with Sikes of the F.C.C.;
Communication Challenges Seen

BYLINE: By Calvin Sims

 BODY:
Alfred C. Sikes was sworn in as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission in August, succeeding Dennis R. Patrick, a Reagan appointee who was a champion of deregulation. Mr. Sikes, who is 49 years old, had been administrator of the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, the communications policy arm of the Commerce Department, since 1986.
Mr. Sikes is expected to continue many of the free-market policies initiated by Mr. Patrick. In a recent interview, Mr. Sikes said competition, new technology and a globalization of the marketplace had created new challenges in regulating the communication industries.
 
Q. In this new era of competition and advanced communication technology, do we need more or less regulation?
 
A. You have to take a hard look at this new technology and formulate policies based on it. We need to revise some of the old laws in the context of risks and rewards. I think over all we need freer markets and consequently that would suggest less regulation and yet there is a need for more regulation in some areas. As markets are freed, lethargic enterprises can no longer be lethargic. They have to look carefully at their costs, service, prices, and at innovation. As a result, the consumer gets lower prices and better products. 
 
Q. What goals or agenda have you set?
 
A. One of our main goals is making the public telephone network more feature-rich and delivering more services. We also want these services delivered to the entire country and to all users. You have to look to smaller, more innovative companies for these services. So we need to find ways and incentives to get these smaller companies to participate in this marketplace. We also want to encourage innovation and efficiency in the use of the radio spectrum. We need a more efficient way of allocating and using the spectrum. In addition, I want the F.C.C. to be more global-minded. In the past, the commission made regulatory decisions that did not account for the ever-expanding international marketplace.
 
Q. Earlier this year, the commission adopted profit-incentive regulation in the form of ''price caps'' for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Should such regulation be extended to regional companies as well?
 
A. I believe strongly that we have to be able to provide the setting to cause local exchange carriers to reduce costs and invest in demand-inducing technologies. I support the broad notion of incentive regulation and we are looking at price caps for the regional phone companies.
 
Q. Some in Congress have suggested taking jurisdiction of the regulated phone companies away from Judge Harold H. Greene, who presided over the breakup of A.T.&T., and giving it to the F.C.C. Do you favor such a move?
 
A. I don't think a judge and a couple of law clerks should be regulating such a dynamic industry. We have approximately 1,800 employees who have schooled themselves in the communication area and it strikes me that we are more qualified to assess the risks and rewards of this industry.
 
Q. There is a move in Congress to reinstate the ''fairness doctrine,'' which required broadcasters to give contrasting views on issues of public importance. How would you respond to its reinstatement?
 
A. If Congress decides to reinstate it we would enforce it because Congress makes the law. I do not favor the fairness doctrine. I was a broadcaster and I have seen the practical effects of the doctrine. Broadcasters were so afraid that they would be cited if they carried more news on one subject or editorialized and that they would have to hire a slew of Washington lawyers to defend them. As a consequence, many broadcasters stayed out of the editorial business. Fundamentally, I think that broadcasting should be shielded by the First Amendment.
 
Q. Is the average consumer better off today with the breakup of A.T.&T.?
 
A. Do I think that Aunt Minnie was the recipient of great benefits as the result of divestiture? No, I do not. I think that as chilling as a monopoly environment can be, it can be somewhat appealing to the consumer because one-stop shopping is attractive. But as you look down the road, people will be more informed about their choices and in the final analysis choice is going to be an important engine for progress in this country.

HEADLINE: Stocks Climb Broadly as Dow Rises 20.90

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks reversed an early downtrend yesterday to register a solid and broad advance, but trading was slow.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 20.90 points, to 2,713.72. At the same time, gaining stocks on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded declining issues by 861 to 598.
Market participants pointed out that futures-related trading by institutions - which in this case involved selling the futures and buying the actual shares in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index - became a factor in the last hour as it has in the last few sessions. This also lifted volume about 15 percent in the final 60 minutes. 
''The fact that the Dow moved well above 2,700 on a closing basis should restore some of the technical momentum in the stock market,'' said Eugene E. Peroni, chief technical analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia. ''Equities are still saddled with the culprits of irregular volume and breadth momentum as well as only sharply focused leaership.''
Mr. Peroni said that earnings results and perceived interest rate trends could provide an inordinate impact in shaping the Dow's behavior through midmonth.
Stocks were off broadly but narrowly in early trading in the wake of a report by purchasing agents that was later released showing a drop in prices in August. As expected, this data provided an initial spurt for the long bond in the credit markets although it ended only slightly higher for the day.
 
Big Board Volume Tumbles
Volume on the Big Board was sharply lower, with only 127.4 million shares exchanging hands, down from 155.3 million shares on Friday.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 1.72 points, to 350.87, while the New York Stock exchange composite index gained 0.93, to 194.90.
Active blue chips included I.B.M, off 5/8, to 108 5/8; A.T.&T., up 1/4, to 44 1/4; General Electric up 1 1/4, to 57 3/4, and Eastman Kodak, up 1 5/8, to 48.
Among other individual issues, Kellogg dropped 2 1/4, to 71 3/8. The company said that as a result of intense industry competition, it expects to report lower earnings in the third quarter.
Zenith Electronics jumped 3 1/4 points, to 17 3/4. The company said that it expected to show a net gain of $22 million from the planned sale of its computer business to Groupe Bull of France.
USX rose 1 3/4, to 34 7/8. The company said that it planned to solicit bids for the purchase of the oil and gas reserves of its Texas oil and gas subsidiary and that it had retained the First Boston Corporation to help in the sale.
Coca-Cola, meanwhile, rose 1 1/2, to 68 1/2. The company said it would realize a $500 million-plus profit from the sale of its stake in Columbia Pictures Entertainment to the Sony Corporation.
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich dropped 1 7/8, to 10 1/4, and was the Big Board's most active stock, on a volume of more than 3.3 million shares. It was also one of the biggest percentage losers. The publisher recently sold six theme parks to the Anheuser-Busch Companies for $1.1 billion. The view of some analysts that the price was too low caused the stock to plummet last week.
Motorola slipped 5/8, to 57 1/8. The company said it would reduce its work force of 105,000 by 2,500 and take a pretax provision of about $43 million in the third quarter.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index added 0.90, to 389.66, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index jumped 2.27 points, to 475.19.

HEADLINE: Savings Agency Allocates $8 Billion for 5 Institutions

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
The Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created by Congress to clean up the savings and loan industry, set aside almost $8 billion on Friday for five severely troubled savings institutions under its control, its officials said today.
Regulators said the allocation of funds was in preparation for selling the institutions to investors. The size of the allocation suggests the final cost to the Government of paying for the losses at these institutions, which have total assets of $9 billion and liabilities of $12 billion. 
The allocation was done to meet a deadline set by Congress that required the trust agency to spend $20 billion on savings and loan resolutions by Sept. 30. ''We had a statutory deadline by which we had to spend the money, and we felt this was the best, safest and most prudent thing to do,'' said Steven Katsanos, chief spokesman for the agency.
Last Friday, the agency intended to lend $7.9 billion to the $1 billion Freedom Savings and Loan Association of Tampa, Fla; the $2.6 billion Hill Financial Savings Association of Red Hill, Pa.; the $1 billion Pacific Savings Bank of Costa Mesa, Calif.; the $1.8 billion Peoples Heritage Savings Bank of Salina, Kan., and the $2.6 billion University Federal Savings Association of Easton, Tex.
In return, the five institutions were to buy Government securities, which the agency was to hold as security on the loans.
The trust agency would not break down how much went to each thrift institution.
Last month, the agency announced that it hoped to sell the five institutions by Sept. 30. But confusion among regulators over guidelines governing the sale delayed the date. Regulators now predict the institutions will be sold within a week.
But instead of completing the transaction, Treasury officials blocked it and refused to transfer funds to the five institutions Friday, citing a provision that barred the investment of taxpayer dollars in Government securities. Treasury officials said late tonight that ''as far as we're concerned, there was no transaction.''
However, there was confusion on how failure to complete the transaction would affect the fiscal 1989 and 1990 budget deficits. The 1989 fiscal year ended Sept. 30. One Treasury official predicted that, as a result, the 1990 deficit would increase by $8 billion.
The savings and loan rescue law required that the agency spend $20 billion in the 1989 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30. The agency, according to Mr. Katsanos, spent $8.1 billion on replacing high-cost deposits at sick savings institutions with Government loans carrying a lower interest rate, almost $459 million to help sick savings institutions under its control pay off Federal Home Loan Bank and Federal Reserve Board loans, $1.8 billion on 24 liquidations and resolutions, $7.9 billion to the five institutions and $2 billion on an emergency liquidity fund.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
MBIA Buying All of Stock In Bond Investors Guaranty

 BODY:
Reflecting narrowing profit margins in the municipal bond insurance business, MBIA Inc., the industry's largest company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy all the common stock in the Bond Investors Guaranty Insurance Company, the fourth largest, for $275 million in cash.
A sharp decline in new municipal issues since the passage of the 1986 Tax Act has crimped margins for insurers.
''There is too much capacity in the business,'' said Harvey H. Bundy 3d, an analyst at William Blair & Company in Chicago. ''Bond Investors went aggressively for market share early on, but later there was a feeling among their shareholders that they weren't getting the return that existed when they first entered the business.'' 
MBIA bought the stock in Bond Investors from American International Group Inc., the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the Government Employees Insurance Company, Salomon Inc. and the Xerox Credit Corporation.
The shareholders founded Bond Investors in 1985.
William O. Bailey, MBIA's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement that ''when presented with the opportunity to acquire the existing portfolio of Bond Investors Group, we recognized its value to us and the economies of administration we could realize.''
Telephone calls to officials at Bond Investors were not returned yesterday.
Mr. Bundy at William Blair said, however, that MBIA might have spent too much to acquire the smaller firm.
''It strikes me as quite a rich price,'' he said. ''The shareholders in BIG certainly made a profit, even though it is not clear how much capital they put into the business.''
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, MBIA shares were unchanged at $27.50.
Upon completion of the transaction, which is subject to regulatory approvals and final action on documents, Bond Investors' municipal bond insurance portfolio will be reinsured by the MBIA Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of MBIA Inc. BIG will cede its unearned premium reserve and contingency reserve to the MBIA subsidiary.
As a result, MBIA's capital base will rise to more than $650 million and policyholders' reserves will be approximately $1.5 billion. As of June 30, MBIA's capital base was $565 million and policyholder reserves were $1.2 billion.
The transaction will reduce the number of municipal bond insurance companies to three. The remaining companies will be the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Citicorp, and the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Quiet Trading Despite Central Bank Sales

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose in quiet trading yesterday, resisting continued selling by central banks. Gold prices were mixed. ''Trading was dominated by profit taking, with central bank intervention less effective,'' said Ronald Holzer, a currency broker with the Harris Trust and Savings Bank. 
The Federal Reserve and foreign central banks continued for the second consecutive week to sell dollars in a concerted effort to push the dollar lower.
Last week, the dollar lost more than 4 percent of its value against the West German mark and the yen. The action followed a recent agreement by the Group of Seven industrialized democracies that the dollar's recent rise was inconsistent with longer-run economic fundamentals.
The seven nations in the group are the United States, Britain, Japan, France, West Germany, Italy and Canada.
 
Intervention Challenged
Currency analysts said many traders remained bullish and repeatedly challenged the intervention.
''The underlying pro-dollar sentiment was coming back out of the closet, and every time it came out the Fed came in and intervened along with other central banks,'' said Robert A. Feldman, a vice president of Salomon Brothers.
In New York, the dollar traded at 139.70 yen, up from 139. The pound fell to $1.6135, from $1.6195 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.8795 West German marks, up from 1.8720; 1.6285 Swiss francs, up from 1.6220; 1.1782 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1770; 6.3745 French francs, up from 6.3500, and 1,3740 Italian lire, up from 1,365.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $367.60 an ounce, up from $367.20 on Friday. Later, the Republic National Bank of New York said gold was bid at $366.10 an ounce, down from $366.25 on Friday. In trading on the Comex, silver bullion for current delivery fell to $5.22, from $5.226 on Friday.

LENGTH: 1060 words

HEADLINE: Mideast Peace: Bridge vs. Wedge

BYLINE: By Stephen P. Cohen; Stephen P. Cohen is director of the Institute for Middle East Peace Development, a public policy organization.

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
Strange how in the Middle East making peace looks so similar to waging political war.
Both sides in the peace process are using that process to drive wedges among their enemies. If they are not stopped - indeed, if bridges are not built precisely where they now seek to divide - real peace will be impossible. Yesterday, President Bush privately supported President Hosni Mubarak in his efforts to build those bridges. The Administration's polite words may yet prove too subtle to convince those who pursue political war vigorously and the peace process passively. 
In conflicts as long-lasting as those between Israelis and Palestinians, and Israelis and Arabs, the search for peace does not simply replace the pursuit of the conflict; rather, political victory remains even more vital than the goal of reconciliation.
Thus, the peace process is being carried on for the secondary tactical benefits of weakening the enemy, as well as with the hope that it might bring peace. The parties are maneuvering to weaken the resolve of their adversary and undermine its base of domestic solidarity and international support.
Israeli moves are dictated in significant measure by the desire to drive three wedges through the Palestinian camp.
First, they wish to open the gap between Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza and those outside the occupied territories. They're doing so by by blocking any form of Palestianian representation from outside the territories. They especially want to divide the nascent leadership of the uprising from the leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Second, they wish to exacerbate tensions between the Palestinians and their moderate Arab allies by exposing Palestinian unwillingness to board the peace train without knowing whether the final destination includes a state, even if the engineer is an Arab leader like Mr. Mubarak. Many Israelis look to arouse friction between the P.L.O. and its leadership in Egypt, Jordan and, if possible, elsewhere in the Arab world.
Third, Israelis would like to see the new communication between the U.S. and the P.L.O. cease or become strained, and are trying to break the link by pushing the P.L.O. to harsh criticism of U.S. peace diplomacy.
The Palestinians seek to drive wedges among Israelis and Israeli backers. Their first target is the fractious Israeli political system. Likud and Labor cannot agree on whether to cede territory, yet the Palestinians insist on just such a decision now.
Second, they wish to create a strain in the relations between Israel and American Jews. Third - and often the Palestinians' fondest hope - they want to create distance beween Israeli and American positions by exposing how little Israel will try to implement even its own initiatives, thus embarrassing the U.S. for its support for the Israeli election plan approved by the Cabinet on May 14.
These tactical attempts to wage political war through the peace process would not be so important if they were not built on real cleavages. There are, after all, real differences of interest and perspective, especially in the short run, between Palestinians under occupation and those who live under various Arab regimes.
Too, Arab moderates have been sorely tested by P.L.O. machinations, indecision and violence, and have cast more than a wary eye at their own Palestinian population. Also, there are substantial religious and ethnic cleavages in the Israeli political system that are given intense expression in Israel's democracy.
And, over the last years, there have been tensions between Jews in America and in Israel over Jewish issues, and over the intifada and its consequences.
These all are real wounds that some want to pour salt on and see fester. It is these wounds, however, that must be healed while the peace process moves forward, and for it to move forward. Neither Israelis nor Palestinians will sacrifice their basic national solidarity, and their political, economic and cultural support systems for vague hopes. On the contrary, both expect the dividend of peace to be found in the strengthening of their national cohesion and the reinforcement of their position among their friends and throughout the international community.
The mediator's task is to build bridges precisely where enemies try to create or inflame divisions. Both indigenous third parties, like Egypt, and external ones, like the U.S., must not only avoid the temptation of driving wedges but must subtly use the fear of these wedges to help the parties build bridges between themselves.
President Mubarak, both through his dialogue proposal and in recent discussions with the Israeli Defense Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, has been designing a process that builds bridges.
The interests of West Bankers, East Jerusalemites and Gazans must be given greater weight in Palestinian decision-making, and the Israeli election plan, as interpreted by Mr. Mubarak's 10 points of clarification of the Israeli plan, would do that.
The proposal also takes account of the profound revulsion of many Israelis toward talking with the P.L.O. by denying it dominance and prominence in the peace process. Yet the dialogue idea respects the integrity of the Palestinian people by including a small number of those living presently outside the territories together in a delegation made primarily from those inside.
Egypt is dealing with the P.L.O. as an organization so that Israel will have to deal only with the Palestinians as a people. The Palestinians will get the opportunity to represent themselves directly in official dialogue with the Israeli Government under Egyptian auspices, but only as long as they put their ideas forward and keep their organization in the background.
The Mubarak plan also allows the Likud-Labor coalition to maintain the Israeli refusal to deal with the P.L.O., by creating the first legitimate representative of the Palestinian people that does not formally assert the P.L.O. imprimatur.
Nonetheless, peace is possible only if Israel does not insist on dividing the Palestinian people, inside and outside the territories, and, only if the Palestinians can respect Israeli divisions and not try to exploit and intensify Israeli fears. Egypt and the U.S. must build the bridges with much energy, perseverance and boldness equal to that of those who drive the wedges.

HEADLINE: NORIEGA OFFICERS TRY COUP AND FAIL; U.S. KNEW OF PLOT

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Dissident Panamanian officers tried to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega today but failed when troops loyal to the Panamanian leader recaptured a central military headquarters the rebels had seized.
In a day of heavy fighting in the Panamanian capital, the rebels also managed to briefly seize control of the national radio and television, but did not expand their control much beyond military headquarters, according to officials here and reports from Panama City.
After a day of reports that General Noriega had been deposed, wounded and captured, the general appeared on television at the end of the day and said the coup had been crushed. He added: ''The incident this morning corresponds to the permanent aggression and penetration by the forces of the United States against the tranquillity of our country.''
 
Setback for Anti-Noriega Effort
President Bush denied accusations by Noriega loyalists that the United States engineered the rebellion, the second attempt in 18 months by dissident members of the armed forces to remove the military leader. ''There were rumors around that this was some American operation and I can tell you that is not true,'' Mr. Bush said. 
But Administration officials said the United States had learned of the planned uprising in the last two days and had not tried to discourage it. One official said the United States had advance information about the coup from the dissident officers and that the United States, in what amounted to tacit approval of a rebellion, had agreed to take custody of General Noriega if the rebels captured him.
 
Day of Attack and Counterattack
Another official said that early today, before it became clear that General Noriega had not been captured, the United States had asked to have him turned over, and the rebels refused. [Page A11.] Tonight, a former Commerce Minister under General Noriega, Mario Rognoni, asserted in an American television interview that during the coup attempt, United States troops had blocked access roads to the capital in an effort to keep reinforcements from reaching loyalist troops.
Mr. Rognoni, appearing on the ABC News program ''Nightline,'' said that the Panamanian Government had photographic evidence, as well as witness testimony, that American troops had set up roadblocks in the early hours of the coup attempt, but had withdrawn them after radio reports suggested that General Noriega had been captured or wounded and that the uprising was a success.
There were also reports tonight from witnesses in the Panamanian capital that earlier in the day, American troops had briefly sealed off the Bridge of the Americas, the key link between Panama City and Panamanian military bases like Rio Hato, from where a large portion of the loyalist reinforcements were ultimately drawn.
There was no immediate response from the Pentagon to Mr. Rognoni's assertion.
In general, reports from Panama were sketchy late today. But news accounts,, the testimony of residents reached by telephone, and information from Administration officials formed the outlines of a day of attack and counterattack that produced heavy artillery, automatic-weapons and mortar fire. [In putting down the rebellion, about 65 rebels were said to have been detained, The Associated Press reported.] The failed coup was the latest setback to Administration efforts to remove General Noriega, who has survived economic sanctions imposed by Washington and defied demands by Latin American countries and the United States to install a democratically elected government.
For months, Mr. Bush has been openly urging the Panamanian Defense Forces, the country's military establishment, to overthrow General Noriega. Today, before news reached Washington that the coup had failed, Mr. Bush again seemed to be encouraging a military rebellion.
 
U.S. Troops on Alert
''I would repeat in the hopes that it be conveyed instantly to Panama: we have no argument with the Panamanian Defense Forces,'' Mr. Bush said. ''Our argument has been, as has many other countries, with Mr. Noriega, who aborted the democratic will of the people of Panama.''
Mr. Bush did not soften the stance he expressed in a stronger statement in May, when he told reporters that he ''would love to see them get him out.''
Throughout the day of fighting, American forces stationed in Panama were on the highest degree of noncombat alert. Some American soldiers took up positions about 600 yards from the military headquarters, between the fighting and American installations, but the rest were held at their bases, and the Americans did not move to support the rebellion, Administration officials said. Accounts from the scene of the fighting said that United States military helicopters hovered over the area.
There were no reliable reports about the extent of casualties. Witnesses quoted in news dispatches said ambulances were seen leaving the area of headquarters compound.
At one point, heavy smoke and flames came out of the fortified military compound, which is surrounded by the Chorrillo, a densely populated slum on the banks of the Panama Canal that forms the bulk of the downtown area.
The coup attempt began at 7 A.M., when about 200 to 300 soldiers seized control of the headquarters, expecting to find General Noriega there, Administration officials said. Some of the rebellious forces were already inside the compound, they said, and others stormed the building.
At first, reports from the scene indicated that the rebellion had been successful. The dissident officers, having seized the broadcast facilities, issued a statement saying they had taken over the military command and were forcing General Noriega and several other top officers into retirement. Others named with General Noriega were the chief of the joint military staff, Col. Marco Justines, and the head of the secret police, Col. Julio Ow Young.
 
'We Heard Shooting and Fighting'
''This is strictly a military movement; there is no politics involved,'' said the rebel statement, which was signed by Maj. Moises Giraldi Vega, commander of the Urraca battalion, which is stationed in the military headquarters.
Major Giraldi helped General Noriega crush a coup attempt in March 1988 and is reported to have personally led the detachment that arrested its leader, Col. Leonidas Macias, the Chief of Police.
The statement, broadcast at 11:30 A.M., said Major Giraldi was supported by at least three key young officers, including Capt. Javier Licona, commander of the Panamanian cavalry, Capt. Jesus Balma, chief of the special forces, and Capt. Edgardo Sandoval, chief of the company charged with maintaining public order.
''We heard shooting and fighting in the streets, tanks and bombs and mortars exploding,'' said a resident of Panama City who was reached by telephone and who asked not to be identified by name. ''Suddenly, on three radio stations and one television channel, we heard the communique and then just as suddenly, all of the broadcasts were cut off and the shooting started again,'' she said.
By early afternoon, General Noriega's forces, many of whom had been out of the city on an exercise, were laying siege to the military command post. Loyal soldiers climbed onto the roofs of surrounding buildings, throwing hand grenades, firing mortars and shooting at the compound, according to news reports from Panama.
About an hour after the first statement from the rebels, Panamanian television's Channel 2, controlled by General Noriega, carried a bizarre broadcast showing a clock on a wall while the voice of a man identifying himself as Lieut. Col. Arnulfo Castrejon, an aide to General Noriega, said the rebellious officers ''are penetrated by the U.S. and sell themselves for a few dollars more.''
 
Noriega's Location Unclear
The state radio also was retaken by the Noriega forces and Maj. Edgardo Lopez Grimaldo, the general's spokesman, broadcast an appeal for the country not to support the uprising.
Gradually, the fighting subsided, and it became apparent that General Noriega was in control. The Government later declared an overnight curfew.
Administration officials said American intelligence indicated that General Noriega was at the headquarters on Monday. But one official said the general customarily changed his location at night and it was not clear whether he was there when the rebellion began.
An official said the United States sent word to the rebellious officers that Washington would like to take General Noriega into custody. The military leader was indicted on drug-related charges in February 1988 by two Federal grand juries in Florida.
''The rebels said they were not willing to give him up,'' the official said.

HEADLINE: Once Again, A Survivor;
Ruthlessness Keeps Noriega in Command

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Over the last two years, two American Administrations have elevated the leader of Panama, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, to the top of the list of world figures they wanted to see removed from action. Only Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya came as close to getting under Washington's political skin.
As described by the Reagan and Bush Administrations, General Noriega stood for everything repugnant in a political leader. He was accused of taking part in election fraud, drug trafficking, money laundering, espionage against the United States and even murder. 
But General Noriega has survived Washington's intense economic pressure and diplomatic censure, resisted pleas that he give up power, sneered at threats of military intervention and defied indictments on drug-trafficking charges in American courts.
 
A Basic History Lesson
In part, he has been able to stay in power because, despite much anti-Noriega language, Washington was reluctant to take the kind of brutal military action that would have overthrown him.
General Noriega left the Reagan Administration twisting in the wind last year when he abruptly changed his mind after hinting that he would accept a deal to leave the country - along with his millions - if he was not prosecuted in American courts.
Instead, he dug in his heels and taught the world a basic history lesson: that a seemingly insignificant dictator can sometimes thwart the efforts of the rest of the world to get rid of him if those efforts are made without any meaningful pressure behind them.
When dissident officers seized the country's military headquarters today and claimed to have toppled their Commander in Chief, there was a brief hope in Washington that perhaps General Noriega had finally been ousted.
But the general, who has ruled Panama since 1983 largely through intimidation, has crushed a coup attempt by his own troops before, and today was apparently no different.
 
Genghis Khan as Mentor
In a little-known manual on psychological warfare written in 1975 when he was a lieutenant colonel in charge of Panama's military intelligence, General Noriega revealed the political philosophy that has served him over the years: use ''astuteness before threats or violence,'' but be prepared to ''exterminate'' enemies in a ''cold and calculating'' way whenever necessary. In that book, the lieutenant colonel said his spiritual mentor was Genghis Khan.
Already officials in his Government have attributed the coup attempt today to American meddling, and if history is any guide, General Noriega will do what he did after a much less serious uprising in March 1988: move ruthlessly against those officers who betrayed him. Shortly after that coup attempt, General Noriega articulated that theory, saying, ''Virility is proved by remaining in power.''
General Noriega's 1952 high school yearbook noted that his goal in life was to become either a psychiatrist or President. Instead, he used a combination of guile and political shrewdness to pull himself out of a poor Panama City barrio and up the military ranks.
Trained by the United States military at the School of the Americas and serving as the head of army intelligence for more than a decade, he simultaneously cultivated relationships with the United States Drug Enforcement Administration and Colombian drug cartel leaders, with Israel, Libya and Nicaragua.
 
Lucrative Sidelines
Last year, as part of a campaign of ''psychological warfare'' against George Bush during the American Presidential race, General Noriega spread the word that he had ''something on Bush'' that would prevent the United States from moving against him, perhaps nothing more than a bit of disinformation at the time, but one that disheartened the opposition at home.
As early as the 1950's, Panama's military was involved in corrupt activities, in part because of its control of prostitution and gambling, which have long been legal in Panama. Over the years, General Noriega expanded those practices while also consolidating control over the air force, navy and police and strengthening the feared anti-riot force known as the Dobermans.
He essentially took over the country's traffic, customs, immigration and airport operations, and helped set up other private interests under military control. These proved to be lucrative sinecures for senior military officers under his command.
Few Panamanians were surprised when General Noriega engineered a fraudulent election in May and then sent paramilitary forces into the streets of Panama City to beat up opposition candidates. Already in 1984 he had rigged the presidential vote in favor of a candidate he assumed he could control. When that did not work out, the President was ousted.
 
Turning a Blind Eye
The United States was willing to turn a blind eye to General Noriega's excesses, largely because of his cooperation on matters of intelligence and combating drug trafficking . In 1985, when Dr. Hugo Spadafora was killed after he publicly accused General Noriega of drug trafficking, United States policy remained unchanged, despite reports by American intelligence that connected the slaying to Panama's Defense Forces.
The current crisis dates from the summer of 1987, when Col. Roberto Diaz Herrera, who had been dismissed as General Noriega's second-in-command, detailed the 1984 vote fraud and accused the general of drug-trafficking.
After violent street demonstrations, General Noriega declared a state of emergency, suspended the Constitution, banned public demonstrations, closed newspapers and radio stations and detained or drove into exile opposition leaders. The United States began to hint that Panama would be better off without its leader, a campaign that accelerated after General Noriega was indicted by two Federal grand juries.
But thus far he has shown no willingness to end the two-year crisis that has gripped his country.
''Today's mutiny was by far the most serious challenge to his rule,'' a senior Latin American diplomat said. ''And each time there is a disruption, it gets more expensive for him. But he's a street fighter, cunning and clever. He always has been, and he seems to have won this round.''

HEADLINE: MEXICAN-U.S. PACT REACHED ON TRADE AND INVESTMENTS

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
In the latest sign of closer ties between the United States and Mexico, Presidents Bush and Carlos Salinas de Gortari signed an agreement today intended to enlarge trade and investment between the two nations.
The accord, the highlight of a five-day visit here by Mr. Salinas, is the broadest economic agreement ever reached by the two countries.
At a White House ceremony, President Bush spoke of benefits for ''both sides of our border'' and Mr. Salinas said the initiative ''opens up additional sources of employment in Mexico for Mexicans.''
 
'Concrete Results' Cited
Mr. Salinas, who arrived in the United States on Sunday for his second visit since he took office in December, said the trade accord and an environmental agreement signed during the same ceremony showed that the two countries' friendship ''leads to concrete results.'' 
The environmental accord calls for the Governments to deal with air and other pollution problems in Mexico City and in urban areas at the border.
Mexico is the third-largest market for American goods, after Canada and Japan, while Mexico sends about three-quarters of its exports to the United States. Trade between the two countries totaled $44 billion last year.
 
Rebuffed Until Recently
For years the United States had sought closer trade and consultative links with Mexico, but until recently had been rebuffed by Mexico's political leadership, which was entrenched in policies of trade nationalism.
Under President Salinas and his predecessor, Miguel de la Madrid, Mexico slowly began developing policies of greater openness in trade and investment. Mr. Salinas, who has a doctorate in political economy from Harvard, served as the minister of budget and planning in the de la Madrid administration.
The first sign of the shift was Mexico's signature in August 1986 on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world's free-trade charter, to which nearly 100 other nations subscribe. Since then Mexico has announced a number of measures to cut tariffs and to dismantle other trade controls. Earlier this year, it removed large parts of foreign investment from official oversight by declaring that acquisitions under $100 million would not need preliminary approval.
Under the new trade and investment agreement, Mexico and the United States are to decide by November on specific industrial sectors that could benefit from lower tariffs. These might include autos and auto parts, telecommunications, petrochemicals, computers and related equipment and processed foods, an American official said.
By July, negotiators are to complete a first round of talks on such provisions.
 
Beneficiary of Brady Plan
In the American view, Mexico is not only more cooperative in trade matters, it is also a model of how a developing country can through market-oriented policies begin to ease its foreign debt burden.
Its programs to convert state-owned companies to private ownership and its deregulatory policies and lower tariffs have made it a principal beneficiary of a debt-slashing plan put forward by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
''I look forward to continued progress and additional proof of how Mexico and the United States can work together toward common ends, toward positive results,'' Mr. Bush told his guest today. On Sunday, Mr. Salinas was his guest at an informal dinner at Camp David.
 
No Free-Trade Pact Seen
Still, American officials said they did not expect the trade agreement, formally known as the Understanding Between the Government of the United Mexican States and the Government of the United States of America Regarding Trade and Investment Facilitation Talks, to produce anything so far reaching as the free-trade agreement with Canada signed last year.
''What we have is a series of negotiations in specific product sectors, which, of course, could develop their own momentum, but any free-trade agreement between the two countries is a long way off, if ever,'' an Administration trade official commented.
A free-trade agreement might well arouse more opposition in both countries than the accord with Canada. In Mexico distrust of the United States has been pronounced over the years, and American labor and business are both sensitive to competition arising from cheap Mexican labor.
 
A 'Significant Evolution'
Nevertheless, today's agreement, which broadens a 1987 accord providing for consultative talks on trade disputes, is a ''significant evolution'' in the two countries' trading relationship, American officials said.
The Governments also reached agreements today on steel and textiles and declared that their negotiators had found ''an improved and constructive atmosphere on matters concerning the protection of intellectual property rights to promote technological innovation and investment in Mexico.'' Protection for patents, copyrights and other intellectual property in Mexico has been a matter of dispute between the two nations for many years.
On steel, Mexico signed an agreement to limit its shipments to the United States at an undisclosed level over the next two and a half years and to work toward eliminating trade-distorting practices in the sector.
Mexico is one of 29 countries that have reached new restraint agreements with the United States. Although no specifics of the Mexican pact were available, it was expected that Mexico would be permitted to ship more steel here than it has under its past quotas.
On textiles, the United States committed itself to ''review and improve'' an import restraint agreement by the two nations. According to a joint communique, the textile agreement provides for ''continued expansion of trade in textiles and apparel in an orderly and nondisruptive manner.''

HEADLINE: Palestinian Militants Urge Wider Revolt

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 3

 BODY:
The underground leadership of the Palestinian revolt in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip sought today to broaden the protest, calling for a five-day general strike and ''rebellion'' in the streets.
Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip said they believed the call to intensified activity reflected growing frustration with the slow pace of peace efforts.
The appeal was designed to inject urgency into diplomatic efforts under way between Egypt, Israel and the United States to unlock the stalemated diplomatic process, the Palestinians said, requesting anonymity.
Shortly after the leaflet was distributed in the territories, the Israeli authorities took the unusual step of closing off an entire section of East Jerusalem to prevent Palestinian leaders from holding a news conference. 
 
Closed Military Area
Streets around the National Palace Hotel were declared a closed military area. Such action is frequently taken in the occupied territories at scenes of unrest where reporters are present, but are rare in the city.
Faisal el-Husseini, a Palestinian nationalist who was to appear at the news conference, spoke to reporters at a police barricade before members of the paramilitary border police threatened to break up the gathering.
''What you are seeing now is the signs of the beginning of the end of the occupation,'' he said.
The new appeals in the uprising were made in one of the leaflets the shadowy leadership frequently distributes in the occupied territories. It followed a tightening of Israeli efforts to impose economic constraints on the revolt, now in its 22d month.
 
Resistance Is Urged
The leaflet called on the territories' 1.75 million inhabitants to resist what it called new Israeli attempts to divide them.
''On strike days, people should go out after 5 P.M. to the streets and start a rebellion,'' it said, without making clear how Palestinians should intensify their rebellion, fought thus far largely with rocks and gasoline bombs. Campaigners said they did not believe it implied a switch to armed protest.
The leaflet urged Palestinians to stay away from jobs in Israel and close businesses in the occupied territories on Thursday, Friday, Sunday, Monday and Tuesday.
President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met in Washington with President Bush on Monday, and Israel's inner Cabinet of senior ministers is to meet on Thursday to discuss the Egyptian proposals and other peace efforts.
 
Proposals From Egypt
In response to an Israeli plan to hold elections among Palestinians in the occupied territories to choose negotiators to discuss limited self-rule, Egypt has offered 10 proposals. Cairo has also proposed direct Palestinian-Israeli discussions, but the debate has reached stalemate largely because of two key questions: whether Israel will accept a negotiation that involves the P.L.O., however indirectly; and whether Israel is ready for a negotiation that could lead to exchanging land for peace.
Palestinians have also expressed strong reservations about the Egyptian initiative because it mentions neither the P.L.O. nor Palestinian statehood. In the West Bank, Palestinians said the new leaflet may have been issued primarily at the behest of the P.L.O. outside the territories as the organization sought to strengthen its position in the current diplomacy.
Some West Bank Palestinians said they believed a secondary purpose of the new call to revolt was to demonstrate the leadership's continued influence.
In the West Bank town of Beit Sahur, the authorities have been locked in a battle of wills with residents over the nonpayment of taxes and have raided homes to confiscate goods instead of payments.
The authorities now plan to auction the Palestinians' belongings if they do not come forward and pay taxes.
In the Gaza Strip, where residents depend on jobs in Israel, the Israelis seem to have had some success in imposing their economic will with magnetic identity cards.
