HEADLINE: Godollo Journal;
How to Disarm Hungary (Hamburgers? Tennis?)

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GODOLLO, Hungary, Sept. 29

 BODY:
A large American flag covered a window by the entrance to the House of Culture in this college town 20 miles northeast of Budapest. Pinned to it was a photograph of a boyish-looking man with a bow tie, whose smile has become familiar throughout Hungary.
A notice under the portrait announced a meeting of the Godollo Opposition Club, which the man in the bow tie would address this evening. A Louis Armstrong tape resounded over the public-address system to make him feel at home. 
Not all the people milling about before the meeting were members of the opposition. ''Heaven forbid!'' Istvan Safrany said. ''We're Reds.''
''Speak for yourself,'' rebuked a man standing next to him. ''I'm no Communist. I prefer Mr. Palmer.''
 
Both Sides of the Street
But Ambassador Mark Palmer is popular not only with the opposition.
Mr. Safrany, too, said he preferred the American envoy. ''We expect more from that side,'' he said with nonideological pragmatism. ''Those over there fooled us.'' There was no doubt about which country he meant by the vague allusion.
It is difficult these days not to find Mr. Palmer somewhere in the public eye.
He has been observed marching with the opposition, taking to lunch at the local McDonald's the general secretary of the Communist Party, Karoly Grosz, and on another occasion his friend, the Soviet Ambassador, an event the Hungarian press christened ''the hamburger summit.''
''There may be different views about what is diplomacy,'' the 48-year-old Mr. Palmer said in a conversation in his office. ''Whether it's sitting behind the desk and going to cocktail parties or whether it's important to be visible, it's important to be the United States in another country, to speak out about our values and about the fate of the nation that you're sent to.''
 
Friends in the Party
Mr. Palmer, former speechwriter to Secretaries of State, Deputy Assistant Secretary for European Affairs and one of the department's specialists on Soviet-American relations, has left Hungarians in no doubt which school he adheres to. He had hoped to be named Assistant Secretary of State in the Bush Administration, but when he did not get that post, he returned here as enthusiastic as ever for his job.
And at a time of transition, when Hungary seeks to show in many ways that it wants no longer to be seen as a satellite in the Soviet orbit, when a whole nation appears to ''expect more from that side,'' the Ambassador's style is attuned to its policy.
''I think probably it's fair to say that next to the Soviet Ambassador I have the best contacts with the party leadership of anybody in this city,'' the Ambassador said. ''I'm very close to Pozsgay, I'm close to Nemeth, with Nyers I play tennis.''
Together with Mr. Grosz, the three men constitute the party's Presidium. Imre Pozsgay is likely to be elected President of the republic before the year is out, Miklos Nemeth is Prime Minister, and Rezso Nyers presides over the Presidium.
 
The No. 2 Ambassador
''I've worked hard with him also,'' Mr. Palmer said of his Soviet colleague, Boris I. Stukalin. ''When I called on him initially I said to him: 'You know you're the most important ambassador in this city, but I'm the second-most important ambassador. We can either fight or work together.' So we have a good, strong relationship. He does occasionally joke with me about how active I am.''
The Ambassador emphasized the view that the United States had no interest in creating problems between Hungary and the Soviet Union or ''to push them out of the Warsaw Pact.''
Mr. Palmer is aware that he works close to the line that separates active diplomacy from interference. Asked about it in a lively question session after his speech here, he replied, to roars of laughter followed by applause from the standing-room-only audience, ''Other ambassadors had much more involvement with Hungarian politics before.''
In his office, Mr. Palmer noted that he had associated openly with the opposition since he arrived in 1986. Dissidents in those days lived on the margin of society.
 
An Opening Gesture
''The very first thing I did was to invite Janos Kis and Laszlo Rajk, two very visible figures of the democratic movement, for dinner in the Gellert Hotel dining room,'' Mr. Palmer recalled. ''I wanted to announce that this was my greeting card, my way of arriving in Hungary.''
The Ambassador said that he avoided endorsing any single group and met with all. But, he said, ''I have tried to show in a variety of ways that Americans side with the democratic forces in this country.''
''I'm open about supporting the opposition parties, including getting money for them from the National Endowment for Democracy,'' he continued. ''I think we should be proud of it.''
He said that marching in the opposition demonstration on March 15, the anniversary of the 1848 uprising suppressed by Austria and Russia, was his high point.
 
A Nutritionist at His Side
While preaching democracy in politics, Mr. Palmer has been equally outspoken in praising free enterprise and urging the privatization of Hungary's economy. He said he considered his active role in creating an American-style management training institute his second most important achievement.
The Ambassador is joined in achievement by his wife, Dr. Sushma Palmer. She spent a sabbatical year here from her directorship of the food and nutrition board of the National Academy of Sciences instructing postgraduate physicians in Budapest in her specialty, the relationship between nutrition and cancer, heart illness and chronic diseases. She has just returned here and is working on several projects.
Among those in the opposition club office in the House of Culture, enthusiasm was high over Mr. Palmer's coming. They said they had no plan to invite other ambassadors. So why Mr. Palmer?
''Oh, everybody knows him,'' a man replied. ''On March 15 he paraded with the opposition. A very good thing.''

HEADLINE: SOVIET AIM UPHELD BY SHEVARDNADZE

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

 BODY:
Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze ended his annual trip to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday and flew off to visit Nicaragua. And he left Americans to ponder a history lesson.
Addressing the American Foreign Policy Institute in midtown Manhattan on Monday night, Mr. Shevardnadze acknowledged that his country's economic troubles are worsening as perestroika takes hold. But he said the Soviet Union's difficulties resemble those that the United States experienced in the Depression, when ''a powerful and confident state took an economic nose dive.'' 
''There were bread lines in New York's Times Square and the tents of the jobless huddled along Riverside Drive,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said. By 1931 more than 100,000 Americans had applied to emigrate to the Soviet Union in search of work.
Many people, the Soviet official went on, drew the false conclusion that capitalism was finished and the world stood on the brink of revolution. The unspoken implication was obvious: don't assume that the Soviet Union's present troubles mark the end of Communism.
''I'm sure that in a few years from now, recalling perestroika's arduous path, people will be saying that 'toward the end of 1989 serious misgivings arose about its future,' '' he said, adding that he would return in three years to explain how the Soviets overcame them.
''So long as there is the will, the understanding of the situation and the determination to change things for the better - and we certainly have them -the economy can remedy its ills,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said.
A lasting consequence of this failure to understand the Depression, he went on, was the belief that World War II rescued America from revolution and that capitalism ''could only prolong its existence through militarization.''
This, in turn, encouraged the Soviet Union to arm itself against an expansionist West, which then concluded that ''Communism could only survive through militarization and aggression.'' The result, he said, was the arms race and the cold war.
 
Arrives in Nicaragua
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 3 (Special to The New York Times) - Mr. Shevardnadze arrived here today for a one-day working visit in which he is widely expected to negotiate new reductions in Soviet assistance to the Sandinista Government.
Mr. Shevardnadze, the highest-ranking Soviet official to visit Nicaragua in the 10 years of Sandinista rule, was met at the Managua airport by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, and laid a wreath at the tomb of Carlos Fonseca Amador, a Sandinista martyr, before beginning an intense schedule.
On his brief stay, Mr. Shevardnadze has planned three lengthy working sessions with Mr. Ortega, as well as other meetings with the entire nine-member Sandinista National Directorate and the diplomatic corps.
Diplomats and Government officials said they expected Mr. Shevardnadze to cut Soviet aid to Nicaragua, in keeping with a general trend of cutbacks in Soviet aid commitments.
Western diplomats also said that they expected the Soviet and Nicaraguan officials to hold lengthy discussions on the flow of Soviet-bloc arms to Nicaragua. Soviet officials have told American leaders that they have halted their country's military aid to Nicaragua, which has in the past been estimated at as much as $5 million a year. But non-American diplomats said the flow of arms has continued through Cuba and other Soviet bloc countries.
In an internal study completed this year, the Sandinista Government reported that, after reaching a high of $1.04 billion in 1987, Soviet bloc donations and credits to Nicaragua, excluding military aid, fell to $266 million in 1987, and have continued to decline.

HEADLINE: U.S. Created Coup Conditions, Panamanian Asserts at U.N.

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 3

 BODY:
The President of the Panamanian Government, who is loyal to General Manuel Antonio Noriega, blamed the United States today for creating conditions that led to the coup attempt in his country.
In an address to the United Nations General Assembly, the official, Francisco A. Rodriguez, said: ''The Government has had today to control a new attempt at subversion, frustrated by the will of our people and the armed forces.'' The mention of the coup came in a departure from the printed text of his speech, which was, like the other speeches at the General Assembly, a catalogue of the world's problems from his country's point of view. 
 
Comment by U.S. Ambassador
Immediately after Mr. Rodriguez spoke, the United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering, said the United States understands ''the frustrations of the Panama Defense Forces that apparently caused them to take action today against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.'' ''We believe the Panamanian military has seen the limitations for the future of Panama as long as General Noriega is in control,'' he said, and described the appearance of Mr. Rodriguez at the General Assembly as ''a jolting reminder to the international community of the election stolen from the Panama people last May.''
After Mr. Rodriguez was sworn in on Sept. 1, President Bush said the United States would have no diplomatic contact with him.
Mr. Rodriguez's address today was unusual because it occurred as delegates were avidly following news reports of the coup attempt from Panama City. But he was able to speak because no delegation challenged his claim to represent Panama.
Mr. Rodriguez denounced the United States, asserting it was violating the Panama Canal Treaty and seeking to overthrow his Government through economic sanctions and other forms of pressure.
''Panama is today living evidence that the Government of the United States means to impose on Latin America and the Caribbean a new model of colonialism by establishing weak and dependent governments, coerced by economic crisis and provoked by financial terrorism,'' he said.
The Panamanian Government was also attacked at the session today by President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica. Mr. Arias called Panama's Government ''an authoritarian regime,'' and he said that in Panama, ''the path of oppression has also become the road to impoverishment.''
 
Panamanians Demonstrate
Outside the United Nations, meanwhile, about 20 Panamanians protested against General Noriega and Mr. Rodriguez and hailed ''the legitimate leaders'' of Panama, the opposition presidential candidate Guillermo Endara and his chief running mate, Guillermo (Billy) Ford.
Other speakers who addressed the General Assembly today were Foreign Ministers Luis Barrios Tassano of Uruguay; Farouk al-Sharaa of Syria; Petar Mladenov of Bulgaria; Abdelhamid Escheikh of Tunisia; Mesut Yilmaz of Turkey; Tserenpiliin Gombosuren of Mongolia; Hernan Felipe Errazuriz of Chile; Pascoal Manuel Mocumbi of Mozambique and Dawa Tsering of Bhutan and Deputy Foreign Minister Soubanh Srithirath of Laos.

HEADLINE: Struggle Within the Military Appears to Be a Major Cause

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
A bitter power struggle between rebellious junior officers and older members of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's inner circle appears to have been a major catalyst in the fighting that erupted in Panama yesterday, experts on Panamanian military affairs say.
''The sense all around is that this was something led by the middle-level ranks, that it was a battle between the old guys and the enlisted personnel,'' said Mercedes K. Morris, a spokeswoman for the United States Southern Command in Panama.
The apparent leader of the revolt, Maj. Moises Giraldi Vega, is a middle-level officer who commands the Urraca battalion, a crack unit known for its role in crushing an attempted coup against General Noriega last year.
The battalion is in charge of security at Panamanian military headquarters in the capital, the scene of the abortive coup in March 1988 as well as of yesterday's fighting. 
''These guys are very junior - a major, a few captains,'' said Prof. Richard Millett, a lecturer in Latin American studies at the University of Southern Illinois in Edwardsville, Ill.
Professor Millett and others said that many junior officers have become increasingly restive in recent months, with Panama's economy reeling and their own positions in the military hierarchy increasingly unclear because of the determination of General Noriega and his top commanders to hang on to power at any cost.
''One thing we've got to remember is that these officers have all got extended families, and they're all hurting bad because the economy is collapsing,'' the professor said.
A communique, broadcast shortly before loyalist troops began a furious counterattack in the Panamanian capital, described the rebellion as ''an internal coup'' whose chief aim was ending corruption in the military, a goal it said would be furthered by the forcible retirement of the general and his aides.
The general and his inner circle, the communique said, were violating Panamanian law by remaining in the military beyond a 20-year limit.
Although the communique called for new elections, it did not ask for popular support. Nor did it mention the possibility of ending military control of the country or of repealing any of the repressive decrees promulgated under General Noriega.
The communique was broadcast over Exitosa, a Government radio station, and Channel 4, an official television station. It said the revolt was an internal Panamanian matter and had no United States connection.
''This appears to have been entirely a barracks movement, without any civilian politicking,'' said Richard Koster, a longtime resident of Panama whose home is some five miles from the scene of the fighting yesterday. ''They said nothing about restoring democracy, nothing about human rights. What they clearly meant to do was replace one military group with another group.''
The leadership of the uprising ''cuts across several different units, including the Panamanian special forces, which is a small but very good unit,'' Professor Millett said. At least three captains appear to have helped lead the uprising, including the special forces commander, Capt. Jesus Balma, and Capt. Javier Licona of the cavalry. The objects of their revolt, besides General Noriega, included Colonels Marco Justines, Angel Mina, Julio Ow Young and Lorenzo Purcell, all top commanders close to the general who are widely believed to have close ties to Colombian drug traffickers.
The counterattack against the rebels appears to have been led by a combat unit known as Battalion 2000 and other troops that were rushed to the capital from Rio Hato, a nearby military base.
There were reports that the loyalist troops were also assisted by members of a militia known as the Dignity Brigades. The head of the Brigades, a civilian, is also president of the Panamanian electric workers' union, a pro-Government group. There were reports that the rebels lost their radio and television link to the public after the electrical workers were ordered to cut off the power to the two stations.
''My private opinion,'' a Panamanian analyst said, ''is that this uprising is a sign that the National Guard is finally beginning to break up from pressure on the institution from within. They're all trying to chew on a piece of the same cow.''
There was widespread agreement that the aftermath would include a major crackdown on the civilian opposition and a purge of the military.
Late last night, Panamanians reached by telephone said the streets of the capital were empty not only of troops, but of police, indicating that General Noriega had ordered the armed forces to remain in their barracks as a precaution.
''They normally do that - it happened last year after the coup attempt,'' he said. ''They need time to put everybody in one place until they decide who's reliable and who's not.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Tells East Germany: Reform or Lose Citizens

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
The Bush Administration publicly called on East Germany today to undertake political and economic reforms as a way to halt the flood of its citizens to the West.
At the same time, a senior Bush Administration official warned that if the East German Government does not liberalize its political system, the system might explode from within.
In a departure from the Administration's normally reserved approach to Eastern Europe, the State Department's spokesman declared today, ''We believe that in order to remove the conditions which caused so many people to flee to the West, the German Democratic Republic leadership should institute reforms which will lead to a political and economic system responsive to the population.''
 
Political Eruption Called Possible
Alluding to the East Germans seeking refuge in West German embassies in Czechoslovakia and Poland, the spokesman, Richard Boucher, added:
''The root cause of the situation is that these people don't want to live in East Germany, and if you are going to have a way of resolving the situation in the long run there are going to have to be political and economic reforms in East Germany that will make it a more livable place.'' 
That message was echoed on Capitol Hill, where the Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, Raymond G. H. Seitz, told the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Europe that he ''could not rule out'' a volcanic political eruption in East Germany if its aging leadership does not move to open its rigid political and economic systems.
''I noticed just this morning that there was a demonstration in Leipzig of some 10,000 people yesterday,'' Mr. Seitz said, when asked what might happen if the East German Government, once the anchor of the Warsaw Pact, continues to resist change.
The Seitz and Boucher statements, after several months in which the Administration has adopted a very muted approach, reflect the degree to which both Washington and Moscow seem to understand each other's interests and intentions in Eastern Europe.
 
'We Are Not Out to Exploit'
''The Soviets understand that we are not out to exploit any signs of trouble or weakness in Eastern Europe, so they are comfortable in granting these countries a certain degree of freedom, provided they show sensitivity to the Soviet Union's security concerns,'' a top Administration policy maker said.
A State Department European expert said, ''The Soviets are increasingly looking at the situation like us -that reform is required for stability in Eastern Europe. As that happens we feel emboldened to encourage the reform process.''
There is ''obvious Soviet acquiescence to what is happening with the East German refugees,'' the official added. ''They are trying to send the East Germans a message that the hemorrhaging of East Germany's population underscores that the Government needs to get on the reform bandwagon.''
 
Democrats Propose Aid Increase
As Administration officials discussed the East German situation, House Democratic leaders, dismissing President Bush's $244 million in new assistance for Poland and Hungary as a woefully ''inadequate'' response to the historic changes underway in Eastern Europe, today introduced their own aid program. It would spend $887.5 million over three years in food aid, private funds, Peace Corps programs, trade credits, insurance loan guarantees and technical training. About $415 million would be allocated in fiscal 1990, which began Sunday.
This House aid package is expected to be merged with a similar bill introduced by Senate Democrats and approved last month by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
In addition, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, and the Senate Majority Leader, George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, invited Lech Walesa, the leader of Solidarity, to address a joint meeting of Congress on Nov. 15. Mr. Walesa, who had already announced plans to visit the United States, is expected to accept.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: EUROPE (96%); UNITED STATES (96%); GERMANY (93%); EASTERN EUROPE (90%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (79%); POLAND (79%);

HEADLINE: Boeing Machinists Reject Wage Package

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Perhaps no company in America has been so successful in surviving the manufacturing downturn of the 1980's as the Boeing Company, but its current prosperity has made it a prime target for organized labor's attempts to make up for years of stagnant wages and other concessions.
Boeing plants here and elsewhere around the country are working overtime to fill billions of dollars in new orders for commercial airliners. With skilled labor in short supply, the International Association of Machinists, which represents virtually all of Boeing's 58,000 production workers, expected this year to extract substantial wage increases and healthy bonuses. But the company has insisted on holding raises and bonuses to a level the union considers inadequate, and today the union members voted to strike at midnight. 
Boeing, which has more than $80 billion in unfilled plane orders, is the single biggest exporter in the United States. The company sells more than 30 percent of its aircraft abroad, and a prolonged strike could swell the nation's trade deficit.
Noting that the machinists union had the power to shut down Boeing, Justin Ostro, a vice president of the union, urged its members to approve a strike. #30,000 Workers at Rally ''You'll never be in a better position than you are now,'' he told more than 30,000 Boeing workers at a rally in the Kingdome, Seattle's indoor stadium, just before the workers voted this morning to reject the offer and to approve the strike. ''If you turn tail and run now, don't come back in three years begging for more.''
The key issue was an inadequate wage and bonus package, said Thomas Baker, president of District 751, the machinists' unit in Seattle, where Boeing has its headquarters. He said other provisions of the proposed contract would have been acceptable.
More than any other labor dispute this year, a strike at Boeing would challenge the prevailing pattern of wage settlements in the United States.
Two other major contracts, involving steelworkers and telephone workers, were settled for wage and bonus packages that were less than the Boeing offer. But in both cases, either the companies were not as prosperous as Boeing or the unions lacked the leverage of the machinists to close operations.
The strike, which began at midnight at Boeing's Wichita, Kan., plant, was the first at Boeing since 1977. #10% Pay Rise Offered In negotiations that were closed to the public, Boeing offered a 10 percent wage increase over three years, or an average of 3.3 percent a year. That amount is below the inflation rate, which is now 4 to 5 percent, but it is equal to the average union wage settlement in the first half of this year, according to the Labor Department.
But the machinists' leadership, noting Boeing's record profits and nearly 10-year backlog of orders, insisted on a ''substantial'' wage increase.
Mr. Ostro said Boeing's refusal to offer better compensation reflected the company's ''greedy'' desire to keep its profits. ''They've gotten used to them,'' he said.
Russell Young, a company spokesman, said the Boeing proposals offered ''substantial growth in compensaton and benefits.'' Boeing now pays its workers an average of about $13.50 an hour, putting them at the upper end of the blue-collar wage scale in the United States.
 
Bonus Payments at Christmas
But the proposed wage increase would be the first for Boeing production workers in six years. The company had obtained concessions in 1983 and 1986, contending that it needed the concessions to compete profitably in world markets. The concessions involved one-time bonus payments, reaching 12 percent of gross pay in 1986 and 5 percent in each of the last two years.
They were paid just before Christmas, and many workers counted on them to pay off credit card debt, take vacations or make a down payment on a car or home. But the bonuses were not wrapped into base wages and thus did not count toward pensions, vacation, overtime and sick pay - a huge savings for Boeing and for many other companies that have substituted bonuses for wages in hard times and now want to continue them.
Boeing sought in the current negotiations for a new three-year contract to keep the wage element to a minimum, offering bonuses instead. Some executives argued, for example, that wage increases could make labor costs unbearably high in the next downturn in airplane orders. They also counted on the often-stated preference of many Boeing workers for another round of Christmas bonuses, this time above 10 percent a year.
''I like the bonus; it's a form of forced savings and I used it last year for a trip to California,'' said Cheryl Loomis, a 40-year-old materials inspector. ''If they could make the raise big enough that would be better of course, but that won't happen. If it did, Boeing could price itself out of the market.''
In the weeks before the current contract expired the union conducted an intensive campaign to educate workers about the bonus, even issuing a videotape showing how wage increases, through compounding, produce more income for workers than bonuses do.
Boeing offered a bonus of 8 percent the first year and only 3 percent the second year, in addition to the wage increase. Mr. Baker suggested that either a better bonus or a better wage increase, or a combination of the two, would have avoided a strike vote.

HEADLINE: ENFORCEMENT LAX, U.S. AUDITORS SAY

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
The internal inspectors of three Federal agencies told Congress today about serious weaknesses in the agencies' enforcement of Federal law.
Still, two of the inspectors general, from the Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Health and Human Services, praised the Bush Administration's commitment to addressing emerging problems and to improving enforcement. The third is the acting inspector general from the Labor Department.
Some problems the three men described relate to poor management, while others stem from a recent Justice Department ruling that raised concern about the legal status of the inspectors general. The inspectors general, under a 1978 law, enjoy much independence to investigate fraud and waste in their agencies or departments. But because they report both to the President and Congress, they work in a constitutionally ambivalent environment. 
 
Jurisdiction Limited
In March the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel limited the investigative jurisdiction of the Labor Department inspector general's agents to Government-financed programs or Federal employees.
John C. Martin, inspector general of the E.P.A., said the ruling was ''unnecessarily restrictive.''
The implications of that ruling were a focus of the hearing today by the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee. The testimony included these disclosures:
* Mr. Martin said the E.P.A. had become a ''paper tiger'' in enforcing laws against polluters. He said its ''pervasive problem'' concerned large reductions in penalties, which, in effect, make it cheaper for polluters to pay a fine than to clean up a hazard.
* Richard P. Kusserow, the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services, said Medicare was being cheated out of $400 million to $900 million annually by insurance companies, but the Justice Department's strict interpetation of inspector general duties clouded his auditors' ability to investigate it. Mr. Kusserow said a similar situation existed at other agencies, like the Interior Department office that collects billions of dollars in royalties from oil and gas leases.
* Raymond Maria, the acting inspector general of the Labor Department, said the department historically had a ''visceral aversion to criminal enforcement'' that was exacerbated by the Justice Department ruling. He also said the ruling, which Labor Department lawyers first requested in September 1988 because of conflicts between them and the inspector general's office, had caused his office to suspend 1,200 criminal investigations in areas like unemployment insurance fraud.
The hearing is part of an inquiry by the Senate committee into the activities of the inspectors general and Administration efforts to improve management of the Government. The panel's chairman, Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, has said he hopes the hearings will help prevent a recurrence of the management problems of the Reagan Administration, including those in the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Energy Department's nuclear weapons program.
 
Questions Over Applicability
David Runkel, a Justice Department spokesman, said that Justice officials and a representative of the inspectors general were discussing the March ruling and that it should be applied only to the Labor Department. But Mr. Maria said his office was not part of those discussions and was concerned that the original request by Labor Department lawyers included ''distortions and inaccuracies.''
Mr. Martin of the E.P.A. said that while the ''new Administration has a serious commitment to enforce programs,'' audits by his office of many enforcement programs showed penalties were routinely reduced.
He spoke of an instance in which the E.P.A. assessed a $3.5 million fine against the city of Arcadia, Fla., but later settled for $36,000 or about one cent on the dollar. He said this was ''not an isolated example.''
Mr. Kusserow praised the management efforts of senior officials at his department, as well as those of Richard G. Darman, the budget director. But he also said there was a ''general reluctance on the part of program managers to admit'' to weaknesses in their programs.

HEADLINE: PTL FRAUD CASE GOES TO THE JURY

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 3

 BODY:
Jim Bakker was described by prosecutors as a con man and by his defense lawyers as a victim of Government interference today at his trial on conspiracy and fraud charges.
In closing arguments on the 23d day of Mr. Bakker's often-tumultuous trial, the lawyers presented pictures of Mr. Bakker that were as varied as the defrocked evangelist's boom and bust career. The judge gave the case to jurors after later in the day.
Prosecutors portrayed Mr. Bakker's PTL ministry, which collapsed amid sexual and financial scandals in 1987, as an overextended marketing scheme, dependent on fresh pitches to keep the money coming in. 
''What you have is a pyramid on the brink of collapse, a house of cards ready to fall,'' the prosecutor, Deborah Smith, told jurors. ''PTL could not have gone on for more than a few months than it did.''
But defense attorneys said the case against Mr. Bakker depended more on innuendo than on evidence and that the prosecution had not proved that Mr. Bakker committed any crimes.
 
Defendant Faces 24 Counts
''Just think how much circumstantial evidence there is in this case,'' Mr. Bakker's chief lawyer, George T. Davis, told jurors. ''It's just reeking with it. It is replete with it.''
Mr. Bakker is charged with 24 counts of fraud and conspiracy in connection with vacation inducements called lifetime partnerships that the government says were fraudulently offered to supporters of the evangelist.
Federal District Judge Robert Potter gave his instructions to jurors late this afternoon and they are scheduled to begin their deliberations Wednesday morning. The charges against Mr. Bakker carry a maximum penalty of 120 years in prison and $5 million in fines.
Ms. Smith, whose stern demeanor never wavered throughout the trial, characterized the case as ''a tale of corruption, of immense corruption.''
 
'Master of Using Half Truths'
She said Mr. Bakker had built an empire on false inducements and half truths and she quoted Alfred Lord Tennyson: ''A lie which is half a truth is ever the blackest of lies.''
''Mr. Bakker is a world class master of using half truths,'' she said.
She said Mr. Bakker's half truths included efforts to keep the financial status of his PTL empire from his board members and his promotion of lifetime yearly vacations at his Heritage USA Christian theme park and resort that he could not provide.
Instead of building the lodgings he promised, the funds were mostly used to meet operating expenses as well as for bonuses for himself and his wife Tammy Faye, said the prosecutor.
Using charts of PTL's activities, Ms. Smith portrayed the government's version of how Mr. Bakker parterships operated: The first program, the Grand Hotel partnership, was billed as limited to 25,000 followers who sent in $1,000 each. That was supposed to guarantee them yearly four-day vacations at the Heritage USA for the rest of their lives.
Instead, the prosecutor said Mr. Bakker sold 66,683 partnerships without telling his viewers. She said only 53 percent of the money went for the hotel. In his next two vacation partnership plans, for which the lodgings were never completed, only 15 percent and 5 percent of the money raised was used for construction, she said.
Ms. Smith, an attorney with the Justice Department in Washington, said the result was a classic pyramid scheme built on lies presented in the guise of religious broadcasting.
''It's gone on too long,'' Ms. Smith told jurors. ''It's your job and your time to let the world and the victims know what went on.''
The closing arguments for the defense got off to a rocky start.
 
Defense Stresses Doubts
Mr. Davis, Mr. Bakker's 82-year-old attorney, began with a rambling remarks about the history of the American legal system that had jurors looking bored and confused.
Several times Mr. Davis, in what seemed to be a thinly veiled reference to the chances of a a mistrial, stressed the importance of jurors with doubts about guilt holding out, ''even if it's one versus 11,'' he said.
Mr. Davis said that with its superior resources the government had built a case that intruded unfairly into church activities. ''I don't recall ever hearing anything about how much the Pope of Rome got for bonuses or housing allowances,'' he said.
He said the government had never proved Mr. Bakker had any intention of committing fraud or conspiracy. He said at least 95 percent of the government's case was based on circumstantial evidence.
''He's being tried because it's alleged he had a criminal mind,'' Mr. Davis said. ''You didn't hear one person in this case say that. You didn't hear it because it isn't true.''
His co-counsel, Harold Bender, followed with a fervent defense of Mr. Bakker. Speaking in almost evangelical tones, he asked jurors to imagine their own preacher under a similar microscope, portrayed in videotapes taken out of context.
''He doesn't expect you to give him pity,'' he said. ''He doesn't expect sympathy. But he does have the right to expect justice under the law.''

HEADLINE: Capital Gains Break - Wrong!

 BODY:
Last Thursday the House approved a two-year cut in the tax rate on capital gains - increases in the value of stocks, bonds and real estate - to less than 20 percent. The decision was wrong. Profoundly wrong. It's now up to the Senate to preserve some semblance of conscience and reason, and reverse the House vote. 
Proponents of the bill say it will increase Federal tax revenues and revive long-term productive investment. The evidence says otherwise. Studies show that tax revenues will fall after an initial orgy of selling appreciated assets to beat the 1991 deadline. To control the growing deficit, Congress would then be forced to raise other taxes or cut Federal programs. The victims of these changes will not be the rich, who stand to gain most from favorable capital gains treatment.
Nor will the temporary tax cut spur productive investment. Instead it gives an impetus to quick selling. When John sells his shares of General Motors stock to Mary, the corporation doesn't gain a dime. The tax cut applies to old and new assets alike. It would take magic, not logic, to link a windfall gain from past investments to an investor's decision about the future. The proponents' case is further weakened by the fact that the bulk of the money for new technological investment comes from pension funds and other tax-exempt investor groups; their decisions are immune to tax rates.
Especially galling is the claim that the House bill will encourage investors to make long-term financial commitments. Such commitments require confidence that the investment climate will not change at Congressional whim. The sorry vote in the House last week proves otherwise.
In one stroke, Congress reversed two solemn pledges that it made as part of the 1986 tax reform. First, capital gains and ordinary income were to be taxed the same. Second, tax shelters were to be abolished. Yet last week's vote reinstates the right of timber investors to offset ordinary income with ''passive losses''; in other words, they got their tax shelter back. Will pig farmers and real estate investors be far behind?
It's O.K. to exclude from taxation the part of capital gains due to inflation. The House bill would do this after 1991. But such indexation ought to be reserved for future investments and only for corporate equity. Other assets already receive tax breaks and require no additional subsidy. Otherwise, capital gains taxes need to be left alone.
Odds are that the Senate will pass some capital gains tax cut. But senators would go far to restore faith in government if they looked the plain facts of the capital gains tax in the face, and then left the tax reform of 1986 essentially intact.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Frankly Nice to China

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, told the United Nations that relations with the U.S. were ''at a crossroads,'' but could improve if America stopped criticizing China.
That seems to be the reward to President George Bush for keeping almost mum after Tiananmen Square and during the continuing crackdown. Despite the angry distress of Congress and the American public, he limited official reaction to suspending military deliveries and high-level contacts. Both measures have already been breached. 
So it shouldn't be surprising that Beijing considers it reasonable to try to censor American opinion, as well as stifling all domestic critics. For well over a decade, starting almost immediately after ''Ping-Pong diplomacy'' in 1971 in the midst of the vicious Cultural Revolution, China has benefited from a special indulgence in U.S. human rights attitudes.
There was an excessive, almost hysterical view of China from the 1949 revolution until then, but afterward there was a switch to a double standard. After Deng Xiaoping launched his ''four modernizations'' in the late 1970's, there came extravagant expectations that China was ''going capitalist'' and would inevitably move on toward democracy. The U.S. was prepared to be patiently encouraging. No doubt this illusion contributed to the shock of this June.
But it isn't a reason to let Beijing think America doesn't care what it does at home as long as China accepts dollar investments and credits. Chinese leaders keep repeating they will maintain ''reform and opening to the outside world'' because ''the policies have injected vitality and energy into China's socialist cause and reinforced state economic power.''
Indeed they have. ''China is not afraid of sanctions,'' Chairman Deng recently told Japanese visitors. But he doesn't seem to realize that no foreign penalties could set back his ambition of assuring ''China's rightful place as one of the most advanced industrial countries in the world in the next century'' as much as his own power gluttony and brutality.
Even if the leaders wanted to, no doubt they couldn't reimpose the isolation of the Cultural Revolution, which cost millions of deaths and probably decades of development.
Still, there is nostalgia for that kind of self-exaltation. Two years ago, when there was rapid advance, a young woman who had been a Red Guard told me that perhaps it was better when the country was cut off because ''The U.S. was more polite then.'' It didn't occur to her that she hadn't a clue what the rest of the world was saying while China lacerated itself in self-imposed quarantine.
But the leaders, who are old enough to remember all their country's tremendous upheavals in this century, do know it can have weight in the world only if it stays in the world as an active partner. They forget that partnership takes more than one, and it is China's own behavior that makes it more or less appealing, more or less reliable for cooperation.
It does China no service for the U.S., and the rest of the West, to be ''polite'' and hide what we think, our reasons for loss of confidence in China's future and loss of sympathy.
An article in the current World Policy Journal points out that U.S. policy ''has only encouraged further irresponsible behavior on the part of China,'' as well as discouraging reformers who seek democracy, and making it harder to develop business relations.
Washington is ''driven by outdated sentiments and questionable assumptions,'' the writer Marie Gottschalk says. She sums them up as the appeal of anti-Soviet strategy, a vast market but in the distant future, and the illusion of stability.
Although ''stability'' is the main excuse Chairman Deng gives for repression, in fact post-revolutionary China has followed the most unstable policies imaginable, lurching from the Great Leap Forward and vast ''people's communes'' (which brought a famine that killed 20 million) to the Hundred Flowers to the Cultural Revolution to ''modernization'' to reasserting class war. In between, there were zigzags of tolerance (Democracy Wall) and campaigns against ''intellectual deviation.''
These unsteady 40 years, which Beijing has just celebrated, the advances of the last decade and the Chinese people's energetic talents make it likely this phase won't last long either. As former U.S. Ambassador Winston Lord says in the journal Foreign Affairs, ''For the Chinese people above all, we must hope that the Big Chill is soon lifted.''
But as Beijing says, it depends on China, not on us.

HEADLINE: Florio Runs With Method to His Meekness

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Representative James J. Florio, a candidate once derided as stiff if not robotic, is campaigning for governor these days with the fluid ease and growing self-confidence of a man who feels he is finally in synch with his times.
In 1981, Mr. Florio lost the governorship running against the anti-government policies and personal appeal of Ronald Reagan. This year the Democrat praises New Jersey's seven years of economic growth under the Republican who beat him, Thomas H. Kean, but says good times in suburbia have brought worries about overdevelopment and pollution that now require an active government to solve.
In addition, Mr. Florio says, prosperity has eased concern over inflation and the economy, giving voters the peace of mind to choose this year on the basis of social issues like abortion, on which his stands are distinct from those of his conservative opponent, Representative Jim Courter.
But just as he embraces the economic growth of the Reagan years, Mr. Florio has also copied the tactics that brought Republicans success in New Jersey and elsewhere in the 1980's. Mr. Florio is appearing likable in person while using television to launch harsh assaults against Mr. Courter. 
''Florio has taken a page right out of the Republican game book,'' said Jay Severin, a Republican political consultant. ''The candidate can be a nice guy on the ground while the air war inflicts the damage.''
The Florio campaign's sharply negative television attacks on Mr. Courter follow the success of a similarly harsh campaign by another New Jersey Democrat, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg. in his defeat of Pete Dawkins last year.
And the outcome of the New Jersey race is of particular interest to both national parties because it was here, in a state whose voters were loyal to the Democratic Party since the New Deal, that the Republicans scored five victories in the 1980's, starting with Ronald Reagan's defeat of President Jimmy Carter in 1980 and Mr. Kean's victory over Mr. Florio by 1,797 votes in 1981. Mr. Reagan and Mr. Kean won lopsided re-election victories here, and Mr. Bush carried the state last year with 57 percent of the vote.
In 1981 Mr. Florio ran as a defender of government and Democratic social policies, just months after Mr. Reagan's anti-government rhetoric brought a Republican Administration back to the White House.
While Mr. Kean and Mr. Reagan campaigned in the state as avuncular leaders of a party reborn, Mr. Florio, his supporters later conceded, often appeared as a frosty technocrat who seemed to prefer long love affairs with policies and curt conversations with people.
But this year television cameras frequently find Mr. Florio crouching to ask a tiny child her name and to tell her about his own baby granddaughter. When he stands, there is his wife, Lucinda, by his side, her gaze riveted to the candidate's face and radiating affection and respect.
Across the state, he repeats the theme that he believes will win the governorship: a faith that with hard work and revitalized government, America can keep a promise of a better life for its children.
''I want to make sure there is opportunity for the next generation,'' Mr. Florio said at a recent campaign stop, referring to his granddaughter. ''I have an involvement in the year 2020. I have a little piece of me that will be here, even if I am not.''
 
Auto Insurance and Environment
In his speeches to unions, Mr. Florio portrays his pledges for more action on the environment and insurance not as a promise of more government but as a covenant between a son of a shipbuilder and ''average, God-fearing, hard-working people'' who deserve better from their leaders.
Mr. Florio has proposed reducing the state's rising automobile insurance rates, now the highest in the nation, by stricter regulation of the insurance industry. Amid rising concern over the environment, Mr. Florio, the author of the Federal Superfund law, has promised to create a new office of environmental prosecutor.
''My husband is the only man I know who can talk passionately about sludge,'' Mrs. Florio said recently, deflating with a smile what from an opponent would be an attack on her husband's personality.
Resting in his shirt-sleeves in his living room in Blackwood, Mr. Florio chuckled over what others have described as a new ease with voters. This year, he said, he is just being himself, while his Republican opponent, Mr. Courter, has struggled to find his identity.
 
Mr. Nice Guy, Mr. Mean Guy
''My mother always told me it is better to be what you are than make yourself over into something else,'' Mr. Florio said.
But critics point out that there is method to his meekness. Like Mr. Lautenberg in his race for re-election last year, Mr. Florio tempers personal criticism of his opponent in his speeches while a battery of commercials does the really nasty work, accusing Mr. Courter of many misdeeds.
A new Florio commercial features a drawing of Pinocchio and a caricature of Mr. Courter. The Republican candidate's nose grows as the commercial accuses Mr. Courter of leaving hazardous waste on his property, changing his position on abortion and falsely claiming credit for sponsoring a bill to make the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday a national holiday.
The advertisement says flatly that Mr. Courter has lied and that environmentalists have compared him to Pinocchio.
''Poor Pinocchio,'' the narrator says. ''Jim Courter's giving you a bad name.''
 
Courter Sees Distortion
A Courter spokesman, Donald Sico, disputed the advertisement's claims, particularly the accusation that Mr. Courter is a polluter. Mr. Courter says the waste was illegally dumped on his land and was cleaned up.
''Jim Florio has been extremely effective in distorting the record of Mr. Courter,'' Mr. Sico said.
Three independent polls conducted in the state showed that among voters who made up their minds or were leaning toward a candidate in mid-September, Mr. Florio was favored by margins of between 14 and 23 percentage points.
One poll, conducted by The Record of Hackensack, found that Mr. Courter had lost support among Republicans for his conservative stand on the right to abortion and for his proposal to ban homosexuals from jobs as teachers, camp counselors and foster parents.
The poll indicated that three in five New Jersey voters opposed new laws that would make it harder to obtain abortions and that nearly the same proportion opposed any consideration of someone's sexual preference in applications for a teaching job.
The Record's poll sampled the opinions of 983 likely voters in telephone interviews from Sept. 16 to 23 and had a statistical margin of error of 3 percentage points.
 
Florio Aiming at Social Issues
Mr. Courter strongly opposed abortion and in August called for a ban on homosexuals in jobs that involved contact with children. He has modified those positions, however, saying that he would not impose his beliefs about abortion on others and that he no longer supported a job ban on homosexuals.
Since much of the Reagan coalition was made up of voters who agreed with Republicans on economic policies but disagreed with conservative social stands, Mr. Florio said, social issues could prove an increasingly useful tool to Democrats in regaining voters who strayed in the 1980's.
A number of Republican leaders in the state attribute Mr. Florio's advantage in the polls less to philosophical shifts among the electorate than to tactical errors in the Courter campaign during the summer and early fall. They say that if Mr. Courter campaigns effectively and his television commercials take hold among the voters, what polls show as a Florio lead will quickly shrink.
Mr. Sico said the Democrat's weaknesses in the state might be exposed in the coming weeks as Mr. Courter begins to stress the messages that worked for Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush. He said Mr. Courter would repeatedly ask voters to judge who is tougher on crime and drugs and who is likelier to raise their taxes.

HEADLINE: Four Hospitals Break Ranks And Set Pacts

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

 BODY:
With a strike deadline hours away, four New York City area hospitals, including Beth Israel Medical Center, broke ranks with industry negotiators and reached separate union agreements late last night, officials involved in the negotiations said.
Yesterday's agreements came after hospital negotiators made their first new contract offer in weeks, only to see it rejected by union leaders as ''insulting.''
Officials in the negotiations said the rejection spurred several hospitals, including Beth Israel, one of the city's largest, to reach separate agreements with Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Workers to avoid a strike set for 5 A.M. today.
As of 1 A.M. last night, the other hospitals said to have settled were Jamaica Hospital, the New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital and the South Oaks Hospital in Amityville, L.I.
Other major Manhattan teaching hospitals, including St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, were reportedly discussing similar separate agreements. 
 
Patterned on Presbyterian Pact
Both union and hospital sources said the new agreements were patterned on an agreement reached Monday between the union and Presbyterian Hospital.
Public health experts and hospital officials said the new agreements, coming on the heels of the dramatic departure of Presbyterian from the position of the industry's negotiating arm, the League of Voluntary Hospitals, would make it exceptionally difficult for the more than 40 remaining hospitals and nursing homes to hold out for less expensive contract terms.
Hospital and union officials said that the president and chief executive of Beth Israel, Dr. Robert G. Newman, reached the agreement with the union at the Hilton Hotel at 54th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, then drove to the Carlyle Hotel on Madison Avenue to meet with members of the league's executive committee in an apparently unsuccessful attempt to convince them to reach similiar terms.
Dennis Rivera, president of the union, said: ''We are hopeful that the growing number of institutions which are settling with Local 1199 will send a very powerful signal to the League that it is time to end the conflict between employers and workers and that it is time to go back to taking care of our patients.''
A spokesman for Beth Israel confirmed the hospital's agreement with the union, saying: ''We are extremely pleased that we were able to reach an agreement with our employees. We look forward to continuing to work without interruption with our employees tomorrow to provide the best possible care for our patients. We are hopeful there will be an industry-wide settlement.''
Union officials said they were remaining in contact with field organizers throughout the night to inform them of late-breaking hospital settlements. ''We have also asked all our members to listen to the radio for reports,'' said Bill Batson, a spokesman.
The League's offer had been made yesterday afternoon to create movement in negotiations and stem defections from hospital ranks, but was immediately called ''outrageous, insulting and provocative'' by a union official. The proposal called for a three-year pact with raises of 6 percent in the first two years and 5 percent in the final year, along with signing bonuses totaling $600.
 
Talks Dramatically Affected
Both sides agreed that the Presbyterian's surprise departure from the league's bargaining position had dramatically affected the negotiations. Presbyterian, which employs more than 3,100 of Local 1199's 50,000 members, completed its agreement with the union yesterday afternoon.
The agreement called for a three-year contract that includes annual wage increases of 8 percent in the first year, 7 percent in the second and 5.5 percent in the final year. The workers covered include nurses aides, pharmacists, X-ray and blood technicians, orderlies, clerks and messengers.
The union had been asking for similar terms to the two-year pact with annual raises of 8.5 percent agreed to in June by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, which runs four hospitals. Before yesterday's offer, the league had proposed a three-year contract with a raise of 4 percent the first year and 4.5 percent thereafter, along with annual signing bonuses of $500. Most of Local 1199's members make between $300 and $400 a week.
The officials and observers said the Presbyterian agreement placed severe pressure on league negotiators to reach a settlement.
''A strike is in no one's interest,'' said Dr. Spencer Forman, president of the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. ''Anyone who thinks that anyone is spoiling for a strike is mistaken. The problem in New York is how to balance equity against the financial situation of the hospitals.''
One public health administrator, who asked not to be identified, said yesterday afternoon: ''Everything suggests to me they are going to settle by the morning. There are too many people who will back away from the league if they don't.''
The new offer was announced by its president and chief negotiator, William J. Abelow, at a somber news conference at the Omni Hotel.
 
'On the Brink Financially'
Mr. Abelow said that the offer ''far exceeds what the hospitals can expect to receive from the state and Federal governments,'' and that it ''will place us right on the brink financially.''
Minutes later, in a scene that revealed both the talks' substantive and emotional gulfs, the union countered with a news conference of its own.
With dozens of union negotiating committee members behind him jeering every mention of the league, Gerry Hudson, executive vice president of Local 1199 said, ''At this late hour, the league sent the Federal mediator to give us what we consider a provocative and insulting offer.''
''Instead of bringing us closer to a settlement,'' he added, ''this offer brings us closer to a strike.''
Mr. Hudson told reporters that, ''it is our expectation that other hospitals will ultimately accept the terms of Columbia-Presbyterian.''
A chief executive of another academic medical center, who asked to remain anonymous, called Presbyterian, part of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in upper Manhattan, ''one of the real jewels in the crown of the city's medical establishment.'' But, he added, ''from an operational basis, they have been losing their shirt for some time.''
Comparing Presbyterian with the remainder of the private hospital industry, the executive said: ''Their economic situation caused them to make a deal. Our situations are somewhat different. We are not prepared to cave on the strength of the Presbyterian deal.''
But several observers said that the Presbyterian settlement, precisely because the hospital's financial condition is so precarious, makes it all but impossible for the holdouts, led by other large, prestigious academic medical centers, to claim that they cannot afford a similar agreement.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Lessons

BYLINE: By Edward B. Fiske

 BODY:
President Bush may or may not be able to create a ''kinder, gentler'' nation, but he has already created a kinder, gentler Federal education policy.
Both the rhetoric and the decisions that emerged last week from the education conference at the University of Virginia indicate that Mr. Bush has quietly repudiated the central education policies of the Reagan Administration. Under William J. Bennett, the education secretary at the time, the Administration mounted strident attacks on teachers unions and maintained that better curriculums will cure most educational ills.
Mr. Bennett, now director of National Drug Control Policy, seemed to sense the shift when he characterized a discussion from which he had just emerged as ''pap.'' This drew a knuckle rap from John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, who said the President believes that the governors ''have a strong grasp about what's going on in the country.'' 
The shift was foreshadowed in January when, 10 days before the inauguration, the White House held a conference that focused on the idea of giving parents and students a greater choice of which school to attend.
For eight years the Reagan Administration sought tuition vouchers or some alternative that would help students who wished to go to private or parochial schools. These plans were vigorously opposed by Democrats, who feared a weakening of public schools.
But at the White House conference, Mr. Bush and other speakers pulled their punches, limiting talk on choice to public schools. As a result, the Administration now has bipartisan support in its push for choice.
Mr. Bennett frequently attacked the leaders of teachers unions and other education organizations, describing them as a ''blob.'' By contrast, Lauro F. Cavazos, his successor, has met frequently with such leaders, and at Charlottesville Mr. Bush seemed to cheer him on.
''Our teachers already are giving their heart and soul to their jobs,'' Mr. Bush said. ''But we have never before worked together - President and principal, governor and teacher - to achieve results in education.''
One of Mr. Bennett's major accomplishments was a series of booklets titled ''What Works.'' They were an effort, generally well received among educators, to put research findings at the disposal of teachers, principals and others.
Implicit in ''What Works'' was the message that the solutions to the important educational problems of the day are already known - at least to the Department of Education; all that is needed is to apply them.
But in his speech at Charlottesville, Mr. Bush looked not to the certainty of school days past but to the promises of the future. There is no ''quick and easy solution,'' he said; for many schools ''experimentation is preferable to the status quo.''
Perhaps the most striking change between the administrations, though, can be found in their analyses of the causes of the country's educational woes and what is needed to cure them. Mr. Bennett spoke often of the three ''C's'' - content, character and choice. Two of the three dealt with curriculum, and in his speeches he plugged relentlessly for more teaching of ethical and religious ideals and a better grounding in the classics of Western civilization.
But the ''social compact'' forged between Mr. Bush and the governors last week was built on the assumption that American schools face a structural and environmental crisis, not a curricular one. The best curriculum will go unlearned, they argued, if students arrive at kindergarten undernourished, if red tape keeps school officials from making the most efficient use of Federal resources or if school systems are too top heavy and rigid to respond to diverse student needs.
''Business-as-usual is not getting us where we need to go,'' Mr. Bush said. ''The American people are ready for radical reforms. We must not disappoint them.''
Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, suggested that the vision enunciated by Mr. Bush in his address seemed to come right out of John Dewey -tolerant of diversity, child centered, interested in empowering teachers and others. ''Maybe George Bush is a closet Progressive,'' he said.
In fact, what Mr. Bush did was embrace an approach to school reform that began developing in the mid-1980's around groups like the Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy and that has won wide support from corporate leaders and the National Governors Association. Last winter, John Scully, the chairman of Apple Computer, met with the President to argue for this approach. It has also been embraced by Secretary Cavazos.
A kinder and gentler Federal education policy may or may not turn out to be effective in solving the country's educational woes. But there is no doubt that it is new.

HEADLINE: EATING WELL;
Cholesterol Matters, But How Much?

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
''MY friends are saying: 'Oh, thank heavens. I don't have to worry about that any more.' ''
Prof. Marion Nestle, chairwoman of the department of home economics and nutrition at New York University, was speaking about her friends' new attitude toward cholesterol. Suddenly, after America's collective nutrition consciousness had grown used to being told that cholesterol is practically synonymous with arsenic, experts appear to be having second thoughts.
Perhaps, some of them are saying, the relation between a high cholesterol level and the incidence of heart disease is not so clear after all. Perhaps, some people are beginning to think, there is no reason to reduce fat consumption; perhaps this means that eating a Dove Bar after every dinner is no better or worse than eating a bowl of raspberries. 
Such a conclusion would, of course, thrill people who reluctantly order a bowl of bran cereal for breakfast when what they really want is three strips of crisp bacon, a cheese omelet and a piece of Danish pastry.
In the last two months several experts have suggested that high cholesterol has been greatly overrated as a factor in heart disease. Almost simultaneously two books and two articles, one in The New England Journal of Medicine and the other, based on one of the books, in The Atlantic magazine, have made such an argument.
No question, the debate has muddied the waters. Nonetheless, most experts still agree that Americans need to reduce their consumption of fat, cholesterol and calories, and that the reduction of the risk of heart attack is just one of the benefits of such a diet.
What has drawn most of the fire in the recent publications is the National Cholesterol Education Program, a Federal effort to persuade Americans to reduce their cholesterol levels by whatever means necessary, even drugs, to what the experts consider a safe range. (They recommend 200 milligrams or less in a tenth of a liter of blood.) In ''Heart Failure'' by Thomas J. Moore (Random House, 1989) and ''Balanced Nutrition'' by Dr. Frederick J. Stare, Dr. Robert E. Olson and Dr. Elizabeth M. Whelan (Bob Adams Inc., 1989) the authors argue that the evidence against cholesterol is not strong enough to warrant such drastic measures as cholesterol-reducing drugs, which can have serious side effects.
If cholesterol is a risk factor for heart disease at all, they say, it is only one of several, including heredity, smoking and obesity. And they are concerned that most of the evidence showing that the risk of heart attack can be reduced by lowering cholesterol comes from studies done on middle-aged men.
Dr. Marvin Lipman, an internist in Scarsdale, N.Y., and the medical adviser to Consumers Union, is among those who think too much emphasis based on too little evidence has been placed on cholesterol. The results of studies on cholesterol, he said, ''may not apply to women or seniors or children, and we can't extrapolate from the studies.''
''I think it's hard to fly in the face of the National Academy of Sciences or the American Heart Association,'' he said, ''but by and large I think they tend to overdo it by extrapolating scientific data from one segment of the population to all segments of the population.''
What especially concerns those who agree with Dr. Lipman's view is the emphasis the National Cholesterol Education Program puts on lowering cholesterol by any means, including drugs if diet doesn't work.
Dr. Nestle, who was the managing editor of the 1988 Surgeon General's Report on Nutrition and Health, which also advised Americans to reduce their consumption of fat and cholesterol, is sympathetic to that view.
''I was concerned there was not enough emphasis on nutrition in the National Cholesterol Education Program,'' she said. ''Diet is given lip service in the program, and an awful lot of attention is paid to drugs. That the drugs have not been adequately tested is correct.''
But she emphasized that the diet component of the program should not be tainted by the questions about the use of drugs. ''There is nothing harmful about it,'' she said.
If people are confused it is not surprising. But the fact is that not a single reputable expert, including those who believe too much emphasis has been placed on cholesterol as the cause of heart disease, is suggesting that Americans should feel free to substitute Dove Bars for raspberries.
Speaking of the current controversy, Dr. Lipman said, ''I don't think the backlash should be so hard and fierce that people who should reduce elevated cholesterol levels should be told not to do so.''
The debate over cholesterol has arisen, in part, because science is made up of uncertainties. Data can be interpreted in more than one way, and not every study has indicated a link between high cholesterol levels and risk of heart attack.
''You are never going to get incontrovertible evidence in nutrition,'' Dr. Nestle said. The kind of epidemiological studies required for such proof are enormous and costly, and may never be done.
But an overall reduction of fat in the diet is a good idea, not just because of any benefit for the heart, but also because high-fat diets are associated with increased levels of certain types of cancer, diabetes, obesity, high blood pressure and gallbladder disease.
Those who defend the basing of cholesterol recommendations for the general population on studies of middle-aged men point to 1960's studies of male smokers that tied lung cancer to cigarettes.
''We looked for the effects of cigarette smoking in men before we looked for the effects in women,'' said Dr. Howard Hiatt, professor of medicine at Harvard University and former dean of the Harvard School of Public Health. ''And we saw a tremendous increase in lung cancer and coronary heart disease in men. And now that women are smoking as much as men we can see the increase in lung cancer and coronary heart disease in women. Common sense says if women stop smoking there will be a reduction.''
Dr. Hiatt said the analogy was apt for diet and heart disease as well: ''I don't think we have to wait 20 years to tell women to stop eating so much fat. The likelihood is very, very strong that the result will be the same.''
Dr. Art Ulene, author of ''Count Out Cholesterol,'' an official publication of the American Medical Association, said: ''It is ridiculous to assume that the studies are not applicable to younger people since we know the process of atherosclerosis starts early. Women are clearly at less risk than men prior to menopause, but rapidly catch up after they lose estrogen. I think women should make the same effort to keep cholesterol low, but obviously they have less to fear when they are younger.'' Dr. Ulene is a clinical associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Southern California and the ''family doctor'' on the ''Today'' show. ''
Dr. Ulene said some people are ''born lucky'' and can eat anything they want. ''There are people who are born with hereditary tendency to have very low cholesterol, and it is indeed foolish for them to be preoccupied with this issue,'' he said.
There are also people born with extremely high cholesterol levels and a tendency to premature death. But most people, he said, ''are in the middle and the risk of heart attack is going to be affected by whether or not we smoke, how much we weigh and the amount of saturated fat in our food.''
Dr. Ulene said it was not surprising that some short-term studies of cholesterol and heart attack do not show any relationship, adding, ''I believe that the real benefits from a cholesterol-lowering program are long term, really making a difference in 5, 10 or 15 years of adherence.''
Moderation, rather than hysteria, however, is the key. Dr. Hiatt said, ''If you have parents who died in their 90's in an auto accident, and you aren't smoking two packs a day, and you aren't violating any kind of code that will lead to your death, and if eating ice cream twice a week brings you an enormous amount of satisfaction, I don't see that there is any harm stopping at the nearest Haagen-Dazs.''
For those described by Dr. Ulene as in the middle, being prudent does not mean giving up everything you love to eat. Rather it means eating less of it.
''If you eat intelligently,'' Dr. Ulene said, ''you can enjoy a rich and varied diet and still have an occasional ice cream. There are no forbidden foods but there are foods you have to be very careful about.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
The U.S. and Mexico signed an agreement intended to enlarge trade and investment between the nations. Under the agreement, the broadest economic agreement ever reached by the countries, the nations are to decide by November on specific industrial sectors that could benefit from lower tariffs. [Page A1.] 
The European Community adopted a compromise plan of nonbinding rules that urge European television stations to devote a majority of their air time to shows made in Europe. [A1.]
 
Economy
The Senate Finance Committee approved a Democratic plan that would restore tax deductions for contributions to I.R.A.'s for all taxpayers, after rejecting a Republican plan to reduce the capital gains tax rate for individual and corporate taxpayers. [D1.]
U.S. factory orders for manufactured goods rose 2.9 percent in August. [D6.] New home sales fell 0.4 percent in August. [D6.]
The S.E.C. might get a greatly expanded budget should the House's budget reconciliation bill becomes law. [D8.]
 
 
 
Companies
McCaw Cellular agreed to acquire Metromedia's stake in the New York cellular market for $1.9 billion in cash, opening a new front in its battle to acquire Lin Broadcasting. [D1.]
Gillette wants to take razors a step further. The company has introduced a razor blade welded together by lasers and meant to be used in its new permanent razors. [D1.]
Investigators in Tokyo searched the offices of a Canon subsidiary and Apple Computer Japan, seeking evidence that importers selling Macintosh computers at discounts were being driven out of the market. [D1.]
Sony's deal to buy Columbia Pictures Entertainment has made the company a lightning rod for unaccustomed criticism. [D5.]
Crazy Eddie will liquidate its remaining assets to satisfy its creditors. [D1.]
Production workers at Boeing voted to strike, rejecting an offer comparable to what many unions have accepted this year. [A18.]
MGM Grand will spend nearly $700 million to create a movie theme park and 5,000-room hotel on the Strip in Las Vegas. [D4.]
The merger of Bristol-Myers and Squibb was approved by shareholders. [D4.]
 
 
 
Markets
The stock market soared to another historic high, as the Dow rose 40.84 points, or 1.5 percent, to 2,754.56, surpassing the record of 2,752.09 set on Sept. 1. [D1.]
Prices of Treasury securities rose, helped by the dollar's strength overseas. [D17.] Yields on C.D.'s and money market accounts were generally higher. [D7.]
The dollar rose against most major currencies despite continued dollar-selling by central banks. [D16.] World coffee prices dropped after Brazil said it saw no chance of reviving an international agreement to support prices. [D16.]
 
Technology
Using mirrors to gather solar energy is being expanded in the California desert northeast of Los Angeles. [D9.]
Twelve vendors have formed a consortium to set standards for testing work stations. [D9.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
The potential harm of leveraged buyouts in the airline industry may be exaggerated. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Stocks of independent banks in California are gaining attention after long going unnoticed. Market Place. [D10.]
Creation of another television network is being studied by large marketing companies. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D20.]
