HEADLINE: Senate Unit Approves I.R.A. Plan

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The Senate Finance Committee approved early today a Democratic plan that would restore tax deductions for contributions to individual retirement accounts for all taxpayers, after a Republican measure to reduce the capital gains tax rate for individual and corporate taxpayers lost on a tie vote.
Ten Democrats opposed the tax cut. Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma was the only Democrat to join the panel's nine Republicans in supporting it.
But the vote does end the Senate's debate on taxes, which will now shift to the Senate floor. There, Republicans and a substantial number of Democrats who favor a capital gains rate cut, will have to muster 60 votes, rather than a simple majority, to put their proposals before the full Senate. 
 
House Backing Last Week
Last week, the House approved a two-year reduction in the capital gains tax rate. But Senators of both parties object to the temporary cut, saying it was economically unsound.
Earlier in its session, the panel agreed on Tuesday afternoon to a 50 percent increase in the amount that 15 million Social Security recipients ages 65 to 70 could earn without having their benefits reduced.
On the capital gains issue, Republicans on the Finance Committee had hoped to amend the bill to include a permanent reduction rate for individual and corporate taxpayers. Their plan would also reward investors and companies that hold their assets for a long period.
After a day of scrambling, the Republican leaders acknowledged before the vote that they remained one shy of the 11 needed for passage in the committee. Throughout the day, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, and the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, met with Republican leaders to plot strategy.
 
Plans to Continue Battle
They laid plans to carry their fight to the Senate floor later this week. The proponents of the tax cut were optimistic that if they could get their plan on the Senate floor, they could prevail.
A reduction in the capital gains tax rate enjoys strong support among most Republicans and many Democrats, and its proponents said they believed they would succeed on the Senate floor. That plan depends on assurances from Democratic leaders that the full Senate will have a chance to vote on reducing the gains tax.
Because the tax legislation is part of a larger deficit-reduction package, special parliamentary rules and procedures apply and may require proponents of a tax cut to gather 60 votes rather than a simple majority to have their plan considered on the floor.
But the debate on tax policy was the focus of the session. The Republican plan, which evolved into a search for support among conservative Democrats, would reduce the individual capital gains tax rate to 19.6 percent, from the current 28 percent or 33 percent, for investors who hold their assets at least six years. Investors who hold their assets for less time would receive proportionally smaller capital gains reductions. The reductions would apply to assets sold after Oct. 1.
For corporations, the plan would permit the computation of capital gains tax using an alternative rate of 27.9 percent for assets owned 8 to 10 years, amounting to what sponsors said was an 18 percent reduction from the current level.
To attract Democratic support, the Republican plan, sponsored by Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the committee, would permit tax-free withdrawals from I.R.A.'s after age 59 1/2.
The Democratic plan adopted by the committee tonight was drafted by Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the chairman, to forestall an outright cut in the capital gains rate.
Mr. Bentsen's plan would allow a 50 percent deduction for contributions to an I.R.A., beginning on Jan. 1, 1991, and permit penalty-free withdrawals for first-time home purchases and higher educaton expenses beginning on Jan. 1, 1990.
 
Plan to Raise Revenue
The I.R.A. proposal was part of a $5.4 billion revenue-raising package that the Finance Committee vote on. The package would also extend several popular tax breaks scheduled to expire at the end of this year. These include preferential tax treatment for employer-paid education benefits, research and development tax credits and tax breaks for mortgage revenue bonds.
Other provisions in the package would expand existing tax credits to help parents pay for child care, repeal a 1986 tax law provision that bars discrimination against lower-wage workers in employer-sponsored health benefit plans, and limit existing tax breaks for certain employee stock ownership plans as well as limiting tax refunds corporations can receive as a result as levereged buyouts or buybacks.
The panel's plan would allow Social Security recipients between 65 and 70 to earn up to $11,700 a year in 1990 without having their Social Security benefits reduced, and up to $14,520 in 1991 without a benefit reduction. Under current law, retirees in this age group can earn up to $9,360 in 1990 without loss of benefits; for each $3 in earnings above that cap, they lose $1 of benefits.
 
Reduction in 1991
Under the Finance Committee measure, benefits would be similarly reduced in 1990, but in 1991 retirees who earn between $14,520 and $19,520 would have their benefits reduced by $1 for each $4 in excess earnings. Retirees over the age of 70 receive full benefits regardless of their earnings, and this would not be changed.
In another important change, the Finance Committee agreed to make the Social Security Administration an independent agency that would be headed by a Presidentially appointed administrator and advised by a board.
The Social Security Administration is now part of the Department of Health and Human Services, but a growing number of lawmakers contend that the agency would be more accountable and more attentive to the needs of the elderly if it was independent. Others contend that the Social Security trust fund should not be a part of the unified Federal budget, because its large surplus is used to mask the size of the Federal deficit.
 
'A Betrayal of the Trust'
''The Social Security trust fund surplus is rising at a rate of $1 billion a week, and it is being spent for general purposes, which is a betrayal of the trust,'' said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is pushing for such a change. ''We will now have a person whose job it is to account for that surplus.''
The House of Representatives has also approved a measure increasing the Social Security earnings limit and making the Social Security Administration an independent agency, but its earnings limit is less generous than that in the Senate Finance Committee's plan, and if the full Senate approves the Finance Committee plan, the two measures will have to be reconciled in a conference committee. The Administration opposes making the Social Security Administration an independent agency.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Airline Leverage: Who Loses?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
CAUGHT off guard by the airline industry's frenzied financial restructuring, Washington is scrambling to put on the brakes. Last week Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner succeeded in putting pressure on Northwest Airlines to rewrite its leveraged buyout agreement with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, halving KLM's equity stake and denying the foreign carrier a place on its board.
The United Airlines buyout, which is more dependent on capital from a foreign investor - British Airways - is under similar attack. Federal law prohibits foreign control of domestic airlines, and Secretary Skinner is asserting broad discretion in deciding what constitutes control. 
But while most of the tough talk has been about foreign influence, few analysts are worried that Europeans would substitute frogs' legs for chicken and peas on dinner trays or install bidets in lavatories. Nor is there much concern that such international alliances would diminish competition. To the contrary: opening the domestic market would dilute the power of the giant carriers, which have made American skies so unfriendly to start-ups.
Mr. Skinner's real worry, say many who sympathize with the Secretary's campaign, is financial leverage - the mountain of debt that managers must assume to pay off their stockholders.
Other industries may be able to cope with the problems created by debt. But airlines, it is argued, are different. Adding billions to the industry's interest costs will lead carriers to skimp on safety and slow spending on modernization. A deep recession might even drive some into bankruptcy, threatening the viability of the nation's transportation network.
But the closer one looks at the case against leverage, the less meets the eye. Perhaps airlines with little spare cash would be tempted to cut corners on maintenance or pilot training. However, it was American Airlines, the carrier with the deepest pockets, that suffered the most notable maintenance-related crash in Chicago in 1979. And it is Delta, a profitable, financially conservative carrier, that has had to live down well-publicized instances of pilot error, most recently in a crash in Dallas last year.
All major carriers, concludes Dan Kasper, an airline consultant at Harbridge House in Cambridge, are very safe. And there is simply no measurable relationship between money and safety.
A related concern, one reportedly much on Mr. Skinner's mind, is that cash-short airlines will fight to delay the retirement of noisy aircraft and lobby harder against new taxes needed to finance local airport expansion.
Airlines may well fight expensive infrastructure improvements, especially the sort that give competitors easier access to their turf. But it is not clear that leverage would influence their determination to resist. After all, costs that affect all airlines should be relatively easy to pass on to travelers in the form of higher ticket prices.
The bankruptcy issue is similarly murky. Airlines with big debts would certainly be more likely to run out of cash in a recession. But it probably would not affect travelers very much. Airlines are companies with high fixed costs that generally have little difficulty covering their operating costs. And since the liquidation value of their assets -planes, plus airport gates - would be depressed during a recession, creditors would have every incentive to keep the carriers flying.
These arguments suggest that the potential harm of leverage has been exaggerated. There may also be reason to believe there are benefits to be had from buyouts.
The reason the airline business is under the leverage gun, Mr. Kasper points out, is that airline stock prices have not reflected the explosive growth in the value of airline assets. Leveraged buyouts have proved the one way stockholders have to realize those values.
But perhaps the most persuasive point in favor of leveraged buyouts is their potential impact on competition. Over the last few years the major airlines have developed a variety of effective defenses against smaller carriers. Not least among those defenses is predatory pricing - the willingness to lose money on selected routes to drive out the small fry or deter their entry.
One likely effect of leverage is to make airlines think twice before going into the red to defend market share. The leveraged buyout at United might, for example, make it easier for upstarts America West and Alaska Airlines to challenge its West Coast dominance. And the mere threat of a leveraged buyout may help explain why Delta is not prepared to sacrifice short-term profits to drive weakling Eastern from Delta's fortress hub at Atlanta.
Secretary Skinner has declared war on leverage in order to preserve healthy competition in the airline industry. The result, ironically, may be to make the business safer for would-be monopolists.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 5, 1989, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
The Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday misstated part of a consent agreement between the Department of Transportation and Wings Holdings, the new owner of Northwest Airlines. Under its terms, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines will retain a seat on Northwest's board, not relinquish it. But that director must abstain from decisions involving ''sensitive competitive and international aviation matters.''

HEADLINE: COMPANY BRIEFS

 BODY:
* Airgas Inc., Radnor, Pa., a maker of gases, completed the sale of its Jackson Products Inc. unit to Jackson Acquisition Corp. for $70 million.
* British Aerospace Commercial Aircraft, a unit of British Aerospace P.L.C., said it had received seven orders for its new mid-sized, twin-engine business jet. Each jet is worth $54 million. 
* Businessland Inc.'s stock plunged $1.75 a share, to $10.125, yesterday on news that the San Jose, Calif., computer retailer had a worse-than-expected earnings outlook.
* Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., London, said it would buy certain soft-drink brands and assets in Spain and Portugal for 45.25 million, or about $73 million.
* Control Data Corp., Minneapolis, completed the sale of its data-storage products unit, Imprimis Technology Inc., to Seagate Technology Inc., Scotts Valley, Calif., which makes disk drives for computer systems.
* EG & G Inc., Wellesley, Mass., a maker of laboratory and test instruments, said it received a six-year, $250 million contract from the National Science Foundation in a venture with a unit of Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky.
* First Financial Management Corp., Atlanta, said it would acquire the Microbilt Corp., Atlanta, a maker of computer hardware and software, through a stock swap.
* Hicks, Muse & Co., Dallas, an investment group, said it had reached an agreement to acquire five insurance companies from I.C.H. Corp., Louisville, Ky., for $495 million.
* Intel Corp., Santa Clara, Calif., said it planned to build a $825 million electronics plant in Ireland.
* Laidlaw Transportation Ltd., Burlington, Ontario, said it had acquired 12 companies in the waste service area and three school bus concerns and was awarded two transit contracts.
* Merck & Co., Rahway, N.J., offered to buy all shares of Britcair Ltd., a British medical products concern, for undisclosed terms.
* Neoax Inc., Stamford, Conn., said it sold its Superior Air Parts Inc. unit for $30 million to S P Acquisition Corp., a unit of HMA Investments.
* Outboard Marine Corp., Waukegan, Ill., agreed to sell its Lawn-Boy mower business to Toro Co. for $85 million.
* PWA Corp., Calgary, Alberta, an airline, said it would combine the operations of its Canadian Airlines International and Wardair Canada units into one unit.
* Unisys Corp., Blue Bell, Pa., said it planned to cut up to $500 million in costs, leading to a charge against third-quarter earnings.
* United International Holdings exercised an option from United Artists Communications Inc., Englewood, Colo., which owns movie theaters and cable television systems, to acquire certain assets. Terms were not disclosed.
* Warner-Lambert Co., Morris Plains, N.J., said it acquired the Italian pharmaceutical firm Pagni, which specializes in oral-care products. Terms were not disclosed.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Advanced 2.9% in August

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Orders to American factories for manufactured goods rose 2.9 percent in August, the Government said today. But analysts said a one-month increase from automobile orders belied weakness in the industrial sector.
The Commerce Department reported that orders for both durable and nondurable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $237.2 billion after declining 2 percent in July, to $230.5 billion, the lowest level since last November. Orders rose six-tenths of 1 percent in June. 
The August gain was driven by the transportation sector, which rose 6.9 percent despite a decline in the aircraft component. Orders for automobiles posted a big increase because of end-of-the-model-year sales incentives.
 
'Temporary Phenomenon'
''But the auto sales were a temporary phenomenon,'' said Bruce Steinberg, senior economist at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York.
''Basically, the industrial sector has slowed down,'' he said. ''American consumers are spending less. Exports are still strong, but they are falling down, too. Domestic capital spending is beginning to evaporate.''
He added the factory sector would continue to be ''quite sluggish'' for the rest of the year and into 1990.
John Hagens, an economist at the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., also sees the industrial sector continuing to slow, ''flip flopping'' from one month to the next.
The Commerce Department report showed orders for durable goods -''big ticket'' items expected to last more than three years - rose 3.9 percent in August, up from the 3.8 percent initially reported last week. Nondurable goods orders were up 1.8 percent.
In addition to transportation, the non-electrical machinery durable goods component, which includes computers, registered a gain, up 9.3 percent. But orders for electrical machinery fell 2.1 percent, mostly as a result of military communications equipment, while primary metals were off 1.8 percent.
In the influential category of non-military capital goods, a barometer of business investment plans, orders fell 10.1 percent in August after rising 5.9 percent in July.
Shipments of manufactured goods rose 5.6 percent, the sharpest increase in the current economic expansion, which began in 1982. Shipments had fallen 2.3 percent in July, the sharpest drop since March 1986.
Inventories rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the smallest increase in the last two years, but Mr. Steinberg attributed this more to recently improved inventory control than to increased demand.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Slip 0.4% After Surge in July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
New-home sales fell four-tenths of 1 percent in August but remained above 750,000 for the second consecutive month, as buyers took advantage of lower interest rates, the Government reported today.
Analysts had forecast a steeper slide in August sales from a double-digit gain in July, the largest advance in three years. They said the pace could not be sustained but would remain healthy for the rest of the year. 
The Commerce Department said that new single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted rate of 755,000 in August, a relatively small drop from July's revised rate of 758,000, which was up 16.1 percent from June.
The report indicated that new-home sales were stronger throughout the summer than previously thought. Not only was the July figure revised upward but so were the figures for May and June, both of which totaled 653,000 units.
''It appears that the new-home market is steaming along,'' said John A. Tuccillo, an economist at the National Association of Realtors. ''What is noteworthy about the August numbers is not that they have gone down, but that sales remained at an extremely high level.''
 
Lower Mortgage Rates Cited
The sales improvement was attributed by analysts to fixed-rate mortgages that dropped from an 11.22 percent peak in March to 9.81 percent at the end of August.
The lower rates also improved sales of existing homes, which, according to the realtors association, rose 3.3 percent in August, to 3.44 million units.
Mortgage rates, however, had climbed back up to 10.16 percent by last Friday, according to a survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, and analysts said the increase would affect future sales.
Despite the recent surge, sales for the first eight months were down 2.7 percent from the comparable period in 1988 because of higher interest rates earlier in the year as the Federal Reserve tightened credit to slow inflation.
The Commerce Department report said the median price of a new home was $122,900 in August, up 5.9 percent from $116,000 in July. The median is the point where half of the homes sold for more and half for less. The average price of a new home rose 14.6 percent, to $162,300.
Sales of new homes in the Northeast, which jumped 50 percent, to 108,000 units, in July, slipped nine-tenths of 1 percent in August to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 107,000 units.
Sales in the Midwest were down 27.9 percent, to 93,000 units, after rising 26.7 percent, to 129,00 units, in July. Sales in the South rose 6.2 percent, to 310,000 units, and were up 6.6 percent in the West, to 244,000 units.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
A Cheaper Road to Solar Power: It's Done With Mirrors

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
For years the quest for economical solar power has centered on photovoltaic cells that turn sunlight directly into electricity. The cost of the cells is so high, however, that their use has been limited.
But a more prosaic and less costly method of harnessing the sun, using mirrors to gather energy, is being expanded in the California desert northeast of Los Angeles. It now feeds 194 megawatts of power into Southern California Edison's distribution system, which is enough to serve 270,000 people.
With tax breaks those ''solar thermal'' plants make electricity at a price that competes with that of power made from oil or gas, and the cost appears likely to be competitive soon even without a subsidy. 
The system, commercialized by Luz International Ltd., makes large quantities of steam by using miles of curved, movable mirrors that focus the sun's heat on pipes filled with a liquid. The liquid is heated by the sun and then pumped through pipes immersed in water. That water is boiled into steam, which is fed through a turbine that turns a generator.
Only the method of generating the steam is different; the rest of the system is the same as an electric plant that gets its energy from burning oil, coal or gas or from splitting uranium atoms.
But making electricity from the sun's rays has several advantages over conventional means. The use of expensive, nonrenewable fossil fuels is greatly reduced, although a backup system is required for periods without sun. And emissions of toxic gases and gases contributing to the greenhouse effect are cut back.
Luz is an American company, based in Los Angeles, that has an Israeli subsidiary that makes the mirrors. It is named for the spot where Jacob dreamed he saw the angels ascending and descending a ladder. The company is already the largest generator of solar electricity in the United States.
Last year the company added 60 megawatts of solar thermal capacity, compared with world shipments of photovoltaic cells with a capacity of about 35 megawatts. Both numbers are modest - a large nuclear plant can generate 1,000 megawatts - but executives at Luz think their technology is much closer than photovoltaic cells to becoming popular in the electric-utility market.
The electric-utility grid is the prime use, in fact, for solar thermal stations. By contrast, photovoltaic cells are so costly that they are now practical only where grid power is not available. They were initially developed for the space program and are most familiar in pocket calculators. They have already established an important market niche at remote sites, for use in navigation buoys and mountaintop telecommunications repeater stations, for example.
While photovoltaic cells are still not cost-competitive with conventional power sources for bulk power generation, engineers and scientists at laboratories around the world are trying new ingredients to lower costs.
Larry L. Sherwood, director of the American Solar Energy Society, said: ''Photovoltaics clearly has the potential to come down in price. Semiconductor-type technology, just by its nature, tends to come down.''
Luz officials say their solar thermal installations are already cost-competitive with the expensive sources of electricity used at peak hours, producing power for about 8 cents a kilowatt-hour. Energy analysts say both solar technologies will have applications in replacing fossil fuels.
Luz has built its operations with the help of Federal and state tax credits, the last of which are scheduled to expire this year. But the company says the system will become commercially viable without subsidies. It has raised more than $750 million in capital from investors like Potomac Electric Power, Baltimore Gas and Electric and Prudential Insurance.
The Luz energy collection system is based on curved mirrors about six feet high, which concentrate the sun's rays to make them 80 times more powerful. These rays are focused on a black steel pipe filled with a heat-transfer fluid.
''It's no different from what you tried as a child, when you burned holes in a piece of paper with a lens,'' said Michael Lotker, a vice president of the company. It is considerably hotter, though. The heat-transfer fluid reaches 735 degrees Fahrenheit, which is about 200 degrees hotter than the water used to make steam in most nuclear plants. To hold in the heat, the pipe is surrounded in thermos bottle fashion by a glass tube and a vacuum.
The plant heats up less than an hour after dawn. As the sun moves across the sky, the motorized, shaft-mounted mirrors rotate to follow, keeping within a tenth of a degree of the sun's position.
Sunshine, even in the desert, is variable, but so is demand for electricity. In fact, in most of the United States the sun's heat is what determines the peak in electricity demand, because of the air-conditioning load. This allows Luz to provide power almost exactly when it is needed most.
Luz has added a refinement to cope with demand on cloudy days and after nightfall. It supplements the solar heat supply with a boiler fueled by natural gas.
To qualify for favorable power purchase terms under Federal law, a solar plant built by an independent power producer must get 75 percent of its heat from the sun. Luz uses natural gas for up to 25 percent, to assure steady output, but a utility that owned such a plant outright could use the natural gas portion without constraint, the company noted.
In this solar-fossil hybrid, the solar collectors could be thought of as a system for saving natural gas, or fuel oil, the other fossil fuel most often used for small plants that provide electricity to meet peak demand. Each square meter of solar collector will save about a barrel of oil, or 6,000 cubic feet of gas, each year for its 30-year life, Mr. Lotker said.
The fuel savings from a square meter of mirror would be about $600 over 30 years, assuming current oil prices of about $20 a barrel. One square meter gathers enough energy to light two lightbulbs of 100 watts each; an 80-megawatt plant requires 464,000 square meters, so the total fuel savings could be $278 million.
Whether such an investment compares favorably with other investments depends on the future price of oil and the price of money. Many analysts are predicting increases in gas prices soon, and over time, oil prices are also likely to rise.
The value of the technology may also be measured by how much importance society puts on reducing the output of carbon dioxide, the gas most linked to global warming.
When the system operates in only its solar mode, no carbon dioxide is emitted. Luz officials say the hybrid system produces 0.27 pound of carbon dioxide for every kilowatt generated, compared with 1.1 pounds for plants fueled solely with natural gas, 1.7 pounds for oil and 2 pounds for coal.
Nitrogen oxides, another pollutant, are 20 times lower than in a conventional gas-fired plant, the company says, and almost three times lower than in a gas plant with advanced pollution-control equipment.
Luz officials say the cost of land is not a big factor in solar economics. In the desert northeast of Los Angeles where Luz has 194 megawatts in operation and 80 under construction, ''there are thousands of square kilometers serving no useful purpose,'' Mr. Lotker said.
 
Following the Sun
 
Luz solar collectors track the sun's daily path across the sky. The collectors focus sunlight onto steel pipes mounted inside vacuum tubes. The pipes contain a heat-transfer fluid that is heated to 735 degrees Fahrenheit. This fluid is pumped through a conventional heat-exchange system to create steam to generate electricity.

GRAPHIC: Diagram; photo of miles of curved, movable mirrors at Kramer Junction, Calif which focus' the sun's heat on liquid-filled pipes to make steam to spin a power-generating turbine.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Banking 'Frenzy' Seizes California

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
STOCKS of independent California banks that have previously gone without much notice are being bid up. The recent acquisition of four banks anticipates a shift in California state law that will allow banks in other states to enter California banking, beginning Jan. 1, 1991, either through acquisition or by opening offices, if that bank's home state has a reciprocal law.
Comerica Inc., an $11.5 billion Detroit-based bank holding company made the first move on Sept. 20, when it acquired the Plaza Commerce Bancorp of San Jose, Calif., for $117 million, or $16.50 a share. While this was the first out-of-state acquisition, Wells Fargo, California's third-largest bank, after Security Pacific and BankAmerica, has also been an active buyer of smaller institutions, including the Valley National Bank of Glendale, the Central Pacific Corporation of Bakersfield and the Torrey Pines Group of San Diego. 
These deals, all at premium prices, have not gone unnoticed, and virtually every remaining independent California bank is now trading at or near a 52-week high. Accordingly, some analysts recommend approaching the group with caution. But others say some of the small banks still represent buying opportunities because they will probably all be acquired within the next two years.
''Recent events appear to have touched off a feeding frenzy'' in independent California bank stocks, said Dan B. Williams, an analyst with Sutro & Company in San Francisco.
He notes that until recently, nearly all merger and acquisition activity involving California banks had been intrastate, ''either to strengthen the defenses of smaller banks, or alternately, to dress them up for future wooing by incoming banks, and in the cases of large banks headquartered here, to add to market share while opportunities exist.'' Most of these deals have had price-to-book value ratios in the 1.6 or 1.7 times range, he said.
But the Comerica and Wells purchases were at substantially higher valuations, Mr. Williams said. Plaza Commerce went for 3 times book; Valley National for 2.1 times; Central Pacific for 2.9 times, and Torrey Pines for 2.4, an average of just under 2.6 times book. While the remaining banks are priced high, there may be some good buys, Mr. Williams said, but he is making no specific recommendations.
Mr. Williams lists 11 independent California banks that could be acquisition candidates: City National, in Beverly Hills, with assets of $4.24 billion; Imperial Bancorp, in Los Angeles, with assets of $2.52 billion; WestAmerica Bancorp, in San Rafael, with assets of $1.29 billion; Pacific Western Bancshares, in San Jose, with assets of $1.06 billion; Metrobank, in Los Angeles, with assets of $835 million; First National, in San Diego, with assets of $506 million; La Jolla Bancorp, with assets of $487 million; Lincoln Bancorp, in Encino, with assets of $396 million; Napa Valley Bancorp, in Napa, with assets of $465 million; Silicon Valley Bancorp, in San Jose, with assets of $322 million, and Mission Valley Bancorp, in Mission Viejo, with assets of $254 million.
Michael Abrahams, a banking analyst with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards in Los Angeles, said only five publicly held independents of any size were yet to be acquired. ''The Japanese, Wells Fargo and Security Pacific have bought them all in anticipation of the state opening up,'' he said. Of the independents remaining, ''there is a wide discrepancy in quality,'' he said.
But ''as long as the economy holds up, these are all going to get taken out,'' Mr. Abrahams added. He said the United States has 14,000 banks to England's six, and California alone has 450, so ''we are going to see a big shrinkage.'' As investments, he favors Pacific Western Bancshares, which closed yesterday off 25 cents, at $11.875, or about 2.14 times book, and the Imperial Bancorp, which closed yesterday up 25 cents, at $25.25, or about 1.76 times book.
Among those advising caution is Donald K. Crowley of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in San Francisco, although he said that the valuation of the banks acquired so far clearly left room for growth in the prices of those remaining.
''There's no question but that the medium-sized California banks have benefited tremendously -particularly in the last few months - from potential acquisition activity,'' Mr. Crowley said. But, he added that ''someone looking at this group should probably go into it with the idea that they like the company, the individual bank and its management, so that if it doesn't get acquired, they are still comfortable with the stock.''
Since the most active buyers have been ''California banks doing fill-in acquisitions or pre-emptive strikes,'' Mr. Crowley said, it ''helps to know where the holes are in existing California banks.''
For example, Wells Fargo is strong in Northern California, so it is primarily looking in Southern California; Security Pacific is in Southern California, so it needs to expand in the San Francisco Bay area and Sacramento. ''In San Diego, the savings and loans are much stronger than the commercial banks, so they have to be looked at as acquisition candidates as well,'' Mr. Crowley said.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Aztar Sweetens 'Junk' Offer To Attract Wary Investors

BYLINE: By ANISE C. WALLACE

 BODY:
Two weeks after the sharpest sell-off in its short history, the ''junk bond'' market continues to show signs of skittishness. Yesterday, investment bankers for the Aztar Corporation, the successor company to the Ramada Corporation, postponed and restructured the company's $400 million offering of new securities.
The move indicated that investors in the high-yield, high-risk market are growing unwilling to invest in new securities of highly leveraged companies unless the future stream of payments is a virtual certainty, analysts and dealers said.
''The market only appears willing to accept deals with current adequate cash flow,'' said Anne K. Lorsung, a junk bond analyst at McCarthy Crisanti & Maffei, a bond research firm in Montpelier, Vt. 
Yesterday morning, Aztar's investment bankers, Salomon Brothers Inc., announced that they were postponing the company's offering of mortgage bonds and notes to Friday or even next week. The bankers also altered the offering to give bond investors warrants that can be exchanged for 10 percent of the equity in the gaming company in the future.
''It's right that they give bond holders some of the upside,'' said Margaret Eagle, portfolio manager of the Fidelity High Income Fund, one of the largest junk bond mutual funds. Ms. Eagle declined to say whether she planned to buy any of the notes as a result of the change.
But some investors - nervous about the economic viability of these issuers - said they still were not attracted by the warrants, stock or other equity-like features being offered. They said that unless a company had the cash flow on hand to meet future debt payments - like Petrolane Inc. or Johnson Coca-Cola, both of which were considered successful ''blowout deals'' - investors may balk at buying some new issues.
Indeed, some investors like Wayne F. Wong, a managing director of the $3 billion bond department at Marinvest, the investment subsidiary of the Marine Midland Bank, said he believed prices in the junk market could drop even lower before becoming attractive enough to compensate for the risks.
Aside from the new issue market, secondary trading of most outstanding junk bonds continues to be light, said portfolio managers and dealers. ''Nobody's hitting a lot of bids,'' said Robert S. Dow, portfolio manager of the Lord Abbett Bond Debenture Fund in New York.
Bonds of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. continued to fall after it announced last week that it had sold its Sea World theme parks to the Anheuser-Busch Companies for $1.1 billion instead of the $1.7 billion expected by some analysts.
New junk bond issues that are coming on the market next week include a refinancing package of $500 million of securities of the Turner Broadcasting Company. Most analysts and portfolio managers said they expect the deal to be a success.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose in lethargic trading yesterday, helped by a rise in the dollar in overseas markets. The move in the dollar prompted some overseas buying, but dealers in New York said most domestic customers showed little interest once trading shifted to the United States.
''We have been at these price levels since early this morning,'' said David Green, manager of government bond trading at Chemical Bank. ''The last two days have been as slow as the worst days of summer. I don't know what it will take to get retail investors off the fence, but they show no signs of moving right now.'' 
 
Employment Numbers Awaited
Roberta D. Olsen, a fixed-income portfolio manager at the Banc One Asset Management Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, with $650 million under management, said, ''Nobody is going to want to get back into the Treasury market until after the employment numbers are released on Friday.'' He added that now people are doing business in specific sectors like municipals or mortgage-backed bonds, and are trading those until they get a clearer picture of where the economy is going.
Still, prices of some Treasury securities moved up by more than half a point, and gains were spread across the maturity spectrum.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 99 19/32, up more than half a point, or more than $5 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.16 percent.
Secondary Treasury note issues also posted solid gains.
In late trading, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 21/32, up 14/32, to yield 8.20 percent. And the 8 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 2/32, up 6/32, to yield 8.34 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates fell sharply.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.74 percent late yesterday, down 11 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by 5 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.83 percent. And one-year bills fell by 10 basis points, to an offered rate of 7.76 percent.
Yesterday's activity came as members of the Federal Reserve Board's policy-making Open Market Committee began two days of meetings in Washington.
Such sessions inevitably spark interest among credit market participants, but the consensus is widespread among analysts that for the time being the Fed governors will leave monetary policy unchanged.
 
No Change in Fed Policy
''The expectation of no change in Fed policy is so widespread that it's not worth talking about,'' said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist and managing director at Midland Montagu Economics. ''The economic data is so mixed that the Fed itself is probably unsure about what to do.''
Mr. Fabbri said interest rates were likely to move lower, but not until data covering economic activity in the fourth quarter begin to come out later this year and early in 1990.
''Growth in the third quarter looks like it was about 3 percent,'' he said. ''You can make a good assumption that growth in the fourth quarter will be much less - around 1.5 percent. But we won't know that for sure for another three to six months.''
In other developments, underwriters from Shearson Lehman Hutton, a unit of the American Express, priced a $145 million high-yield offering from the Illinois Central Railroad.
The offering came on a day when Salomon Brothers once again postponed a $400 million offering from the Aztar Corporation, the successor company to the Ramada Corporation.
The 14 1/8 percent Illinois Central senior subordinated debentures were priced at $98.57, to yield 14 3/8 percent.
The issue, which is noncallable for five years, has a final maturity date of Oct. 1, 2001. It is rated B-2 by Moody's Investors Service and B-minus by the Standard & Poor's.
 
Secondary Market Issues
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate issues, dealers said prices of intermediate-term securities rose by a quarter to three-eighths of a point, while long-term bonds were up half a point.
''This is the first really good day we have had in a month or so,'' one corporate bond trader said.
In the secondary tax-exempt municipal bond market, traders said prices of most issues rose by about a quarter of a point in light trading.
Among the new municipal issues offered yesterday was a $90 million issue of New York State certificates of participation.
A bid from an investor group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets won the issue, which consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1990 to 1996. Coupons on the certificates range from 6.30 percent on securities maturing in 1990 to 7 percent in 1996.
The issue is rated A by both Moody's and S.&P.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
In Midtown South, Space Eases a Bit

BYLINE: By Shawn G. Kennedy

 BODY:
THE effects of New York City's glut of office space and the economic slowdown may be catching up with the midtown south office district.
According to the Williams Real Estate Company, a brokerage and management company that tracks conditions in the office market, the percentage of space available increased to 12.33 percent from 11.77 percent in the first half of this year. This modest softening, the Williams statistics showed, had followed more than a year of steady tightening.
According to the company, 13.12 percent of the 68 million square feet of office space in the district was available during the first quarter of 1988. Midway through the year, that figure dropped to 12.49 percent, and it fell again, to 11.77 percent, by the end of the year. Williams defines midtown south as the area from 38th Street south to Astor Place and from Third Avenue west to Seventh Avenue. 
But even as the amount of space available climbed this year, so did rents. Williams's figures also show that owners were asking on average about 5 percent more in rents in the first half of 1989 than in 1988.
''The price gap between midtown south and other office areas, which propelled migration to the area, and in turn fueled absorption, is narrowing.'' Michael T. Cohen, managing director of Williams Real Estate, said. ''Some midtown tenants can realize substantial savings by coming to midtown south, but tenants relocating from downtown will find only a 2 or 3 percent difference in asking rents in prewar buildings now.''
When advertising agencies, accounting firms, architects and design companies started leaving midtown 10 years ago for the cheaper rents below 38th Street, some found space in the buildings along Madison, Park and Fifth Avenues for less than half the cost of new or renewal leases in midtown. In the early 1980's, for example, the cost of space in midtown ranged from $25 to $45 a square foot in prime locations, compared with the $15 to $20 a square foot owners were asking for space in renovated buildings in midtown south.
According to Williams, the average asking rent in midtown south is now $26.58 a square foot for all types of space, and $24.52 a foot for space in prewar buildings.
Norman Sturner, a principal of Murray Hill Properties, a real estate investment company that owns close to a million square feet in buildings below 34th Street, said that typically his company is renting space at $24 to $26 a foot today and the tenant ususally gets a $25-a-foot allowance for interior space construction and six months of free rent.
Mr. Cohen and other real estate professionals say the increase in asking rents in midtown south reflects, in part, the higher prices being paid for commercial properties in the district. Buildings that sold for $80 to $100 a square foot five or six years ago, Mr. Cohen said, have been resold recently for $125 to $150 a square foot.
''For the prices now being paid,'' he added, ''certain rents have to be achieved.''
Joseph P. McCluskey Jr., senior vice president wtih Helmsley Spear Inc., who is in charge of the company's Gramercy Park office, said that higher rents were also an indication of increased operating costs and additional renovation projects.
''Some buildings are going through second renovations in less than 10 years,'' he said. ''When rents in the area were in the high teens, landlords were spending about $15 a foot to improve the space. Now they are spending $25 a foot for things like replacing window air-conditioning units with central systems and building more stylish lobbies.''
Mr. McCloskey said that the firmness of the district's rents also reflected changes that had taken place in such midtown south neighborhoods as the Flatiron district and Park Avenue South. They have acquired a downtown chic, which makes them more desirable.
''There are more shops, restauants and services now,'' Mr. McCloskey said. ''Tenants are willing to pay more to be in these areas.''
Mr. Sturner of Murray Hill Properties said that while his company was still signing leases with companies moving from midtown, it was also making deals with tenants that were growing and relocating within the midtown south district.
An example is David Feldman & Associates, a freelance court reporting agency, which recently moved from 800 square feet on the 79th floor in the Empire State Building at 34th Street and Fifth Avenue to 5,500 square feet in a building owned by Murray Hill Properties at 240 Madison Avenue between 37th and 38th Streets. Mitchell Silvermintz, general manager of the firm, said it had taken space in the Madison Avenue building because of the neighborhood.
''We run a 24-hour office,'' he said. ''Fifth Avenue in the 30's can be fairly deserted at night.''

HEADLINE: U.S., IN DRUG DRIVE, TO REGULATE SHIFT OF FUNDS ABROAD

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
In an attempt to halt the extensive laundering of drug profits earned illegally in this country and sent abroad, the Bush Administration has decided to regulate international money transfers by American banks, the Treasury Department announced today.
Such transfers, mostly to Latin America, are not regulated now, but Treasury officials estimate that as much as $110 billion is laundered, or disguised, each year in the American banking system.
The Government also said it would open a financial crimes center next month in Arlington, Va., with computers to monitor information on money laundering to be supplied by more than half a dozen Federal agencies.
 
Getting Data Into Computers
At a Senate hearing today, the Administration said it would for the first time mandate record-keeping on international electronic transfers and require American banks to share that information with the Government. 
To reduce paper flow and get large amounts of data into Government computers quickly, new rules will also require large banks to use magnetic tapes when they file reports. The banks and other financial institutions are already required to file written reports to the Government on all domestic deposits of more than $10,000. But officials of the Drug Enforcement Administration say there are so many such deposits that the drug money goes undetected, buried in huge paper backlogs.
''It represents a substantial stride in the area of money laundering both domestically and internationally,'' said Salvatore R. Martoche, Assistant Treasury Secretary for enforcement, who is leading the regulation drive.
 
Seen as Step Forward
John F. Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's Subcommittee on Terrorism, Narcotics and International Operations, agreed that the Treasury decision represented an important step forward, but he said much remained to be done to fight laundering effectively. Mr. Kerry is conducting the hearings on regulating banks.
The move came after Administration officials found that under current bank regulations the increasing volume of computerized electronic money transfers through American banks - now more than $1 trillion a day - had made it virtually impossible to trace narcotics profits.
And last week officials at the Office of National Drug Control Policy said the true dimensions of the problems were only now beginning to emerge. Among the laundering operations that have come to light in recent weeks are the thousands of small, unregulated money-transmitting businesses that take in drug money in the nation's inner cities, deposit it in legitimate banks and then order it transferred abroad electronically.
 
'Working With the Industry'
Treasury officials said the precise reporting provisions on international transfers had yet to be worked out. But one high official confirmed in an interview that the banks and clearing houses were now going to have to keep good records on the transfers and were going to have to share this information with the Government. ''We're working with the industry to get them to figure out ways'' to carry this out efficiently, he said.
And John Lee, chief executive of one of the nation's largest clearinghouses, Clearing House Interbank Payments System, said, ''We're happy to work with them.''
But some bank executives expressed concern that the regulations might become excessively burdensome. It has not been determined how much detail on each transfer will have to be recorded and filed with the Government.
 
'Totally Unproductive'
''If it turns out to be a wholesale blanket rule on filing, it would be totally unproductive,'' said Donald J. Reid, senior compliance officer at Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco. ''To the extent the rules would require us to target certain areas or banks, then it would enable authorities to make some conclusions which are meaningful.''
But the fact that the records must be kept and be available to the Government, at least in necessary cases, is regarded by law-enforcement officials as vital to solving the money laundering problem.
In the type of modern electronic money transfer, or wire transfer, that has become so difficult to monitor, a customer may instruct his personal computer to tell his bank's computer to take funds out of his account and send them to another account in a foreign bank. In most of these foreign transfers, no person talks to another, regardless of the amount.
The bank's computer then tells a banking clearinghouse - a kind of automated middleman that assists banks in switching funds from one to another - to send the customer's funds to the account abroad. $700 Billion a Day The clearinghouse acts as a middleman for about $700 billion in transfers each day, up by about 40 percent in the last two years.
Senator Kerry said the effectiveness of the new regulations ''remains to be seen,'' and he criticized the Administration for not pursuing negotiations with other countries as well as domestic banks to gain their cooperation in sharing information.
The Administration is required by law to report by next month on the progress of those negotiations, and officials said today that no one was working full time on the talks.
Mr. Kerry also said the Treasury Department's planned financial center ''was a good idea, but not broad enough in scope.''
Known as the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, the $15 million center will be under the auspices of the Treasury Department. It is expected to open on Nov. 1, and its staff is planned to grow by the end of the year to include about 200 economists, analysts and law-enforcement personnel as well as representatives from more than half a dozen other agencies.
 
Enormous Data Bases
The center will integrate the enormous data bases that have been compiled by Customs, the Internal Revenue Service, the drug agency, the Federal Reserve and the State Department. It is also asking for computer data bases that have been compiled by states, and will share with state officials the Federal information it has stored.
In addition to studying patterns of illegal money flows and helping to develop enforcement stategies, the center is expected to create software and artificial intelligence programs. When combined with the huge amount of bank filings of customer transactions, these programs can be used to detect patterns of suspicious activity.
The creation of the center comes amid repeated charges that the enforcement of money laundering laws has been marred in recent years by battles among all the agencies and departments that have some authority in the area. Indeed, officials at the office of National Drug Control Policy concede that one of their big tasks is to coordinate the disorganized approach taken by the agencies.
In large part, those fights have been caused by the nature of the crime of money laundering. Big cases typically involve narcotics trafficking, banking violations, tax evasion and criminal prosecutions across national boundaries.
As a result, jurisdiction is shared by several agencies, like the drug agency, Customs, the I.R.S., the F.B.I., the Justice, State and Treasury departments, the Secret Service and the C.I.A. There is also considerable tension between Federal and state law-enforcement authorities.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Senators Threaten Fight Over Gains Tax

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct 4

 BODY:
Senate Republicans threatened today to bring the Senate to a halt if Democrats invoked parliamentary rules to prevent the full Senate from voting on a proposal to reduce the capital gains tax rate.
''If we don't get it, then we're not going to be cooperating around here on anything,'' the Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, told reporters today.
Late Tuesday night, the Senate Finance Committee defeated, in a tie vote, a Republican plan for a permanent cut in the capital gains tax rate for individuals and corporations. Republicans had anticipated their defeat in the Finance Committee but believe they can win enough support from Democrats who favor a lower capital gains rate to prevail on the Senate floor.
 
Temporary Cut Called Unsound
Last week, the House approved a two-year reduction in the capital gains tax rate. But senators of both parties object to the temporary cut, saying it is economically unsound. 
As the Finance Committee session carried over into the early hours of this morning, the panel approved hundreds of millions of dollars in special tax incentives that would benefit cattle breeders, farmers, oil well drillers, petrochemical companies and tuxedo rental companies, among others.
The tax incentives, proposed by various senators in both parties, would cost the Treasury $435 million in 1990 and an estimated $3.5 billion in the next five years.
In rejecting the proposal to reduce the gains tax, the Finance Committee opted instead for a Democratic plan that would restore tax deductions for contributions to individual retirement accounts. That proposal is part of a $5.4 billion revenue-raising measure that will, in turn, become part of a larger Congressional package aimed at cutting the Federal budget deficit and avoiding automatic, across-the-board spending cuts. The package is expected to come before the Senate on Friday or Saturday.
Unlike other measures that come before the Senate, the deficit-reduction package is subject to special rules intended to limit amendments. If the rules are strictly enforced, proponents of reducing the gains tax rate would have to muster 60 votes, rather than a simple majority, to be able to amend the measure.
As he prepared to press for a full Senate vote on the gains tax, Mr. Dole said he would meet with Administration officials including the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and the budget director, Richard G. Darman, to work out a strategy.
 
Amused by Complaints
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, predicted a tough floor battle over the capital gains issue. He said he was amused by Republican complaints about the procedural difficulties of bringing a tax cut bill to the floor.
''You can't just use the rules when they work in your favor,'' he said, adding that Mr. Dole was a master at using the rules to his party's advantage when Republicans controlled the Senate, from 1982 to 1986.
To complicate matters, the capital gains fight has become intertwined with a movement to repeal last year's catastrophic health insurance law. The combination of these two volatile issues and a crush of urgent budget legislation that must move through Congress in the next month has left some lawmakers fearful.
''What I'm afraid we have here is basically a free-for-all,'' said Senator David Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat who favors capital gains reduction but voted against the Republican plan in the Finance Committee in the hope that like-minded Democrats will come up with a better one. ''I don't see how we get around the need for 60 votes.'' He said a bidding war might emerge for votes, with special provisions offered to senators in return for votes.
 
Pet Provision Included
Mr. Pryor, whose committee vote was crucial to Mr. Bentsen in blocking the Republican capital gains cut plan, was successful in getting a pet provision into the panel's tax package. The provision would allow farmers to income average when calculating their tax liability. It would cost the Treasury $5 million in 1990 and $295 million over five years.
Senator Bentsen, who sponsored the I.R.A. proposal, has argued that his plan would provide greater benefits to the economy and to middle-income taxpayers than the capital gains tax cut. But a new Treasury study indicates that more than 80 percent of the total reduction in tax liability resulting from the I.R.A. plan would be for taxpayers who earn $50,000 a year or more. The Treasury study has not yet been made public.
The tax provisions adopted by the committee would raise $37.5 billion in revenues between 1990 and 1994. But only $9.5 billion of that amount would go toward deficit reduction in the next five years. The remaining $28 billion would be used to pay for the special tax incentives the panel adopted this morning, extensions of a variety of other tax incentives due to expire at the end of this year, a new program to assist parents with child-care expenses, expansion of Medicaid coverage and Mr. Bentsen's proposal to restore deductions for contributions to retirement accounts.
 
Measures Adopted
The provisions adopted by the Finance Committee include these:
* An amendment by Senator Thomas A. Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, that would allow an ethanol derivative known as ETBE to qualify for an existing tax credit on alcohol fuels. The revenue loss from this tax change would be $18 million in 1990 and $172 million over three years, when the tax incentive would expire. The benefit would go to a handful of small companies, primarily in the Middle West, that blend ETBE with ethanol. The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, the country's largest producer of ethanol, lobbied heavily for the provision.
* An amendment by Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma and the lone member of his party to support the capital gains tax cut in the committee, that would allow farm cooperatives to choose how to categorize sales of their assets for tax purposes. The tax change, which would apply retroactively, would lose an estimated $40 million in revenue over five years.
* An amendment by Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, that would allow a generous formula for calculating the minimum tax on gifts. The provision would be effective for one year only and would cost the Treasury $13 million.
* An amendment by Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, that would change the method for computing a proposed excise tax on ozone-depleting chemicals. The proposed tax is a revenue-raising measure in both the Senate Finance Committee bill and a companion measure approved by the House Ways and Means Committee last month. The Du Pont Company, which is based in Delaware, is one of four major producers the chemicals affected by the tax. Finance Committee aides said the change sought by Mr. Roth appeared to be revenue neutral.
* An amendment by Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, that would allow corporations using the minimum tax formula to compute their tax liability to get the same dividends-received deduction that is available to corporations who use the regular tax formula. The change would benefit companies that own 20 percent to 80 percent of another company, and the revenue loss to the Treasury would be $15 million in 1990 and $90 million over five years.
* An amendment by Senators Dole and Boren that would allow cattle feeders to choose the most advantageous accounting method for tax treatment of deferred income. The change would cost the Treasury $18 million in 1990 and $80 million over five years.
* Another Dole-Boren amendment would allow owners of marginally producing oil and gas wells to take full deductions for their losses rather than the 50 percent available under current law. The change would cost the Treasury $20 million a year.
* An amendment by Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, and Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, that would remove income restrictions on investors who want to claim a tax credit for passive losses on low-income housing rehablitation. The change would benefit investors with income of more than $250,000 a year. No immediate figures were available from the Finance Committee on the amendment's impact on revenue.
An amendment sought by the tuxedo rental industry and endorsed by the Treasury Department would allow companies that rent tuxedos to depreciate the clothing over two years rather than five. The change would cost the Treasury $29 million over five years.

HEADLINE: White House Adds $200 Million to Polish Aid Plan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Under pressure from Democratic lawmakers to respond more aggressively to the changes in Eastern Europe, the White House announced today that President Bush would ask Congress for an additional $200 million in economic aid for Poland.
But the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said Poland must reach an understanding with the International Monetary Fund on a series of steps to revise its debt-ridden economy before it can get the additional aid. Warsaw is now negotiating an economic-stabilization package with the I.M.F., and an accord is expected by the end of the year.
''We, like the Polish Government, think that Poland's best chance for recovery rests with a sound I.M.F. program that will restore its credit worthiness and open the way for billions of dollars of new loans and credits,'' Mr. Fitzwater said of Poland's economy, which is reeling under about $40 billion in foreign debt and suffering from an inflation rate of nearly 1,000 percent. 
Saying that ''the dramatic changes in Poland over the past two months have lent new urgency'' to the Administration's commitment to assist Warsaw in its transition from Communism to a more pluralistic system, Mr. Fitzwater also announced that Mr. Bush had invited Poland's President, Wojciech Jaruzelski, a Communist, and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a Roman Catholic independent who supports Solidarity, to meet him in Washington.
The Administration's latest increase in Polish aid comes after a proposal for a $1.2 billion three-year assistance program for Poland and Hungary put forward by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and an $887.5 million three-year program put forward Tuesday by House Democrats. The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, said the initiatives were needed because the Administration's offer of $219 million in various kinds of aid ''plainly fails to meet the challenge of supporting the Solidarity-led Government's efforts to make meaningful economic and political freedom available to all Polish citizens.''
It now appears that the Warsaw Government is increasingly benefiting from the fact that American policy toward Eastern Europe is becoming a highly partisan political issue, with a Democratically run Congress and a Republican White House engaged in something of a competition to see who can respond most effectively to the changes in Poland and Hungary.
On Tuesday, Senate Democratic leaders announced that they were inviting Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, to address a joint session of Congress.
Today, the White House invited the Polish President and Prime Minister.
On the Polish aid plan, Joseph S. Nye, professor of international relations at Harvard University, said the Democrats were saying to Mr. Bush that he ''cannot say 'Read my lips: No new taxes,' 'We cannot afford to do these things'' and at the same time pose as a leader.'' ''That's claiming leadership on the cheap, and the Democrats want to expose that,'' he said.
On his trip to Poland in July, Mr. Bush outlined a $119 million package of economic, technical and environmental assistance to Warsaw, which was then introducing liberalizing changes but was still a Communist Government.
In August, after the non-Communist Solidarity movement took a share of power, the White House announced that it would send Poland an additional $50 million in emergency food aid and, on Sept. 14, in the face of mounting pressure from Congress for more assistance, the Administration added another $50 million in food aid.
The $200 grant proposed today would be in addition to all of those measures.
Asked where the money would come from, Mr. Fitzwater said, ''Direct appropriations.''
Mr. Fitzwater said the $200 million the Administration was proposing for the fiscal year 1990, which began Sunday, would be in the form of an outright grant for Poland ''which would be the U.S. contribution to the $1 billion in assistance the Poles have requested'' from the 24 leading Western industrialized countries.

HEADLINE: Account of Plot: Close Call for Noriega

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Conspirators who tried to overthrow Gen. Antonio Manuel Noriega on Tuesday planned to trap him in his office and turn him over to United States authorities, a businessman with close ties to the Panamanian armed forces said today.
But the plot was foiled by bodyguards who opened fired with submachine guns when one of several soldiers waiting at the entrance of the general's office in army headquarters pulled a gun.
General Noriega's personal guards threw him to the floor and shielded him with their bodies, the businessman said, then shoved him down a corridor away from the shooting.
''It was very close,'' the businessman said, ''very, very close.'' 
The failed kidnapping set off a raging gunbattle between a force of about 200 anti-Noriega soldiers and hundreds of loyal forces that ended eight hours later.
The Government announced on television tonight that 10 soldiers were killed, 21 were wounded and 37 others taken prisoner. Five rebels, the Government said, took refuge on American bases. Telephones at the headquarters of the American military command here went unanswered this evening.
The Government said all the dead were rebels. Five civilians were reported among the wounded.
After the initial skirmish at General's Noriega's office, the general took cover in a bunker in the headquarters, according to American officials and Noriega supporters, and directed a counterattack that led to his freedom.
The Associated Press reported assertions by a Noriega aide, Lieut. Col. Arnulfo Castrejon, that the rebels captured the general and held him for hours but released him after loyal forces warned them that they would ''face the consequences'' if he was harmed.
Two opposition members who said they talked with soldiers who had been engaged in the battle said the rebels decided not to attack the bunker and lost the initiative.
 
Opposition Leaders in Hiding
Guillermo Endara and Ricardo Arias Calderon, leaders of the opposition to General Noriega, went into hiding shortly before the fighting started, according to their supporters and Noriega loyalists.
Mr. Endara, who had obtained the largest number of votes in the presidential election last May before the results were annulled by General Noriega, had been on a hunger strike for two weeks, protesting the appointment of Francisco Rodriguez as President by the Noriega-dominated National Assembly on Sept. 1. Mr. Arias, who was the candidate for first vice president on Mr. Endara's slate, had been leading a campaign to encourage Panamanians to withhold taxes and payment for electricity and water.
There were reports that two of the insurrectionists had taken refuge at Fort Clayton, a United States Army base on the edge of the capital.
Officials at the United States Southern Command headquarters in Panama as well as officials at the United States Embassy refused to discuss the attempt against General Noriega.
''We cannot let any press on the base,'' said a secretary at the Southern Command press office this morning, ''and we do not have anyone who can speak about the current crisis.''
 
Noriega Supporters Celebrate
The capital was quiet today, except for motorcades of what appeared to Government employees, blasting horns and waving flags.
Early this afternoon, as a motorcade rolled noisily past the army headquarters where soldiers were plastering bullet holes and applying fresh paint, General Noreiga, wearing a camouflage uniform, appeared at a barred window for a few minutes, grinning and alternately thrusting his right fist into the air and waving.
Later, with a band playing salsa music in the courtyard of the headquarters, he climbed up on an iron fence to shake hands with well-wishers who crowded the sidewalk during a tropical downpour.
The sprawling city of gleaming, oceanfront skyscrapers and small wood and brick houses ticked along as it does most days, with restaurants and shopping centers bustling, until early evening when an 8 P.M. curfew imposed on Tuesday went into effect. The American bases here remained on alert and military people and civilians were advised to avoid travel into the capital.
United States officials in Washington have acknowledged that they knew two days in advance that the move against General Noriega was coming, but they have insisted that they had nothing to do with it.
American officials here confirmed Panamanian charges that American troops blocked key roads between the besieged headquarters and other loyal Noriega units. But the Americans said the intention was not to interfere with troop movements but to protect ''United States lives and property'' at installations along the blocked roads.
The Americans also confirmed reports that American combat helicopters had circled over the army headquarters during the fighting, but they said they were merely observing the action. Every few minutes this afternoon, American Blackhawk helicopters swept over the warehouses and rickety houses flanking the army headquarters, but took care to avoid flying over the installation itself.
 
U.S. Inaction Is Criticized
Americans and Panamanians said in interviews that they were surprised that the United States did not send troops to help the rebels as the battle dragged on and it became clear that they might fail.
''The Panamanians expected a lot from the United States,'' a Panamanian office secretary said. ''We want to get rid of Noriega. But now people are starting to believe that we are never going to get any help from the U.S.''
There is widespread dissatisfaction with General Noriega's authoritarian rule and the sharp decline in the economy resulting from American sanctions against Panama. But during the fighting Panamanians refrained from going into the streets to demonstrate support for the rebels.
''We were waiting to see what happened,'' one woman said. ''We were all afraid we would get beaten and go to jail. There's no justice in this place.''
Some Americans who say they would like to see General Noriega ousted say they oppose risking American soldiers' lives while Panamanians remain safely on the sidelines.
''Why should Americans sacrifice, when the Panamanians are not pouring into the streets?'' one American official asked.
 
No Clear-Cut Choice
Ramon Franco, a lawyer and opposition figure, said he and many others did not rally in support of the rebels because they represented a faction of the military that was dissatisfied with General Noriega but did not hold the promise of restoring democracy.
If the rebels had won, Mr. Franco asked, ''What was I going to celebrate?''
In statements issued Tuesday while they briefly held the Government radio and television stations, the rebels variously said that they favored early elections and that they backed the recently appointed president, Mr. Rodriguez.
The businessman with close military ties, who said he had spoken to several officers who had been inside the headquarters defending General Noriega, said most of the rebels had been soldiers who were unhappy because they had been passed over for promotion. Their leaders, he said, had been driven mainly by personal ambition.
One American official said the plotters, members of the headquarters security force, apparently pinned their hopes solely on the capture of General Noriega and had not lined up support among other units, assuming that the General's backers would fall into step behind the victors.
''It was very badly planned,'' said an opposition supporter. ''You cannot have a coup d'etat against one military compound.''

HEADLINE: STRAINED U.S. TIES REPORTED IN CHINA

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 4

 BODY:
A secret analysis prepared for the Chinese leadership says that China's relationship with the United States has deteriorated sharply and will continue to be rocked by new conflicts, but that President Bush is quietly trying to limit the damage.
The authors suggest that the United States has little leverage over China because Washington is afraid of driving China toward the Soviet Union or back into isolation. Those concerns, the analysis indicates, leave Beijing in a strong position and put the burden on Washington to repair the harm to Chinese-American relations.
The report also suggests that the White House is subordinating human rights to its friendship with Beijing. 
The analysis appears in the Sept. 13 issue of a weekly bulletin called Neican Xuanpian, or Internal Reference Selections. The 32-page publication, recent issues of which were obtained from a Chinese official, includes briefing materials about the domestic and international situation.
 
Analysis in Blunt Language
Unlike other internal publications, such as Reference News and the higher-level Reference Materials, the bulletin includes analyses that have not been published elsewhere. It is marked secret and is circulated only at very senior levels of the Communist Party and Government.
An article in the Sept. 20 issue of Internal Reference Selections discusses the attitudes of American business executives toward China, asserting that ''China remains attractive to American investors.''
Those analyses are written for the leaders, rather than by them, and so it is impossible to determine to what extent they reflect the present thinking of the Chinese leadership. But Chinese officials have long experience in telling their superiors what they would like to hear, and the essays do correspond -though in language far blunter than that used publicly - to the known positions of the Chinese Government.
The Sept. 13 article warns that China must be vigilant for any American policy changes on Taiwan and cautions that ''the two countries will confront each other frequently on human-rights controversies, which will be a major obstacle to the development of Sino-American relations.''
 
'Both Sides Have Lost Trust'
''Recent interference and criticism by the United States, especially one-sided sanctions, certainly have caused damage unprecedented since 1972, when Nixon came on his first visit,'' the authors contend. ''Politically, both sides have lost trust and become more suspicious of the other, which inevitably will lead to frequent conflicts and trouble.''
But the overall tone of the articles is positive, suggesting that the Chinese leadership may be basing its policy on a more optimistic view about China's international position than prevails in the West. Though most Westerners believe that international condemnation, economic sanctions and investor alarm after the violent suppression of the democracy movement in June have left China in a very difficult diplomatic and economic situation, the articles advise the leadership that it is the United States that is being forced to modify its position and repair the relationship with China.
The bulletin quotes the Bush Administration as saying it will balance its wish to help the democracy movement with the need to protect the Chinese-American relationship.
''However, more profound observation reveals that the Bush Administration is not putting absolutely equal weight on both stances but in fact tips toward the protection of Sino-American relations,'' the article says. ''The slant does not reflect any special affection for China; rather it is decided by the best interests of the American nation. To be specific, the United States has five fears in its relation to China:
U.S. Fears, as China Sees Them ''First, that China will be forced into isolationism and hostility toward the West. Second, that China will be pushed into the embrace of the Soviet Union, thus costing the United States the use of an important political and military power to check the Russians. Third, China might back away from its reform and open policies, thus destroying American efforts to encourage China to evolve peacefully to capitalism.
''Fourth, if China and the United States quarrel, then Japan, West Germany and South Korea will jump into China's huge market on an unprecedented scale and cause colossal damage to American businesses. Fifth, a divided and weak China would not have the power to check Japan economically and militarily, and that might complicate the process of maintaining peace and stability in the Asian-Pacific region.''
The article also said the United States was likely to resume military ties soon ''because the United States is anxious to retain cooperation on electronic monitoring stations that are of great value for military intelligence.'' The reference was to secret listening posts on Chinese territory - which both sides refuse to acknowledge -that intercept Soviet communications signals and process them.
President Bush, former President Richard M. Nixon and former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger all were portrayed as working to repair Chinese-American relations.
That favorable perception of Mr. Bush and his Administration may in part explain why China has toned down its criticisms of the United States in the last couple of months.
