HEADLINE: When Work Means Bring the Kids

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SYRACUSE, Sept. 29

 BODY:
It is 10 P.M. and the lights are low. The toys, the high chairs, the diapers, the bottles, the crayons and the face paint have been stored for the night. Danny Ross, 3 years old, Ryan Moulton, 5, and Ryan's brother Jake, 3, are relaxing on canvas cots watching ''Sesame Street'' on videotape. Kristyna Jaquin, 2, is sound asleep beside them.
They are denizens of the Little Eagles Child Care Center in the regional postal center in Syracuse. Little Eagles, which opened a year ago this month, is a new departure in the efforts of parents, employers and organized labor to meet the needs of two-earner families, particularly parents who work when others sleep. 
Little Eagles is always open by 6 A.M. and for three months last year, it was open for 24 hours. It will stay open round the clock as demand requires. While many centers are open 12 hours, Robert Lurie, the president of Resources for Child Care Management in Berkeley Heights, N.J., and other child care consultants said they knew of no other that is open 24 hours.
 
Two Cities Plan Similar Centers
Similar centers are planned for Buffalo and Phoenix.
The center is a warren of rooms including a nursery, a kitchen and two bathrooms, and it has play areas both indoors and outdoors. By midmorning every day except Sunday, it is usually filled with its maximum of 33 children and the six workers who care for them.
Many employers are open at odd hours: the Postal Service, police and fire departments, hospitals, supermarkets, service stations, factories that run two and three shifts, and casinos in Las Vegas and Atlantic City.
These employers have suffered more than others from the nationwide shortage of qualified workers.
Although millions of young mothers have already entered the work force, many others do not work regularly and constitute a pool of workers for the employers who can accommodate their needs. Audrey Freedman, a labor economist at the Conference Board in New York, says 81 percent of all people 20 to 64 years old work at least part of the year. About 53 percent of those who do not work are women at home with their children. To attract these women, 1,200 employers sponsor day care centers.
 
Digging Deeper for Workers
In Syracuse, the unemployment rate is 4 percent, a little more than a percentage point below the national average, and employers are feeling a need to dig deeper for workers. John W. Duchesne, the postmaster, says the day care center is important for recruiting new people and keeping those he has.
''I'm competing with the telephone company, the banks, Blue Cross, the state,'' he said. ''All those employers are going after the same employee. If you come to me for a job, I will pay you more, but you're going to come in at 5:30 or 10:30 with Tuesday and Thursday off. You'll work those odd hours, but you've got a good child care place.''
Of the 1,500 postal employees in the Syracuse area, 68 families who work here and at other nearby post offices use the center. The Postal Service and the American Postal Workers Union provided about $20,000 to help start the center. A board of 11 parents formally oversees it and contracts management to Kevin and Kathleen La Grow, who own a child care concern that runs three other centers with daytime hours.
 
Fee Is Low for the Area
The La Grows charge $68 a week for infants and $65 for older children, a fee that is low for Syracuse because the Postal Service provides the space and pays for utilities. Irregular users pay $3.75 an hour or $9 for five hours.
Ryan and Jake Moulton's mother, Gail, and Danny Ross's mother, Lauri, are machine clerks who start work at 5:30 P.M. and finish at 2 A.M. They bring their boys in with them, and their husbands pick the children up when they get out of work, usually around 10 P.M. Kristyna, whose mother works the same shift, usually leaves about midnight when her father comes.
Mrs. Ross said her mother had lived with the family and taken care of Danny for a while, but she left about the time the center opened.
The center's hours allowed Rick Moulton, who works at a drugstore warehouse, to move to the night shift. ''By working nights,'' Mrs. Moulton said, ''he could get a pay increase.''
No one has tried to quantify the benefits the center gives the Postal Service. ''I think it's definitely improved morale,'' said the director of human resources, Michael L. Brick, whose daughter also works at the post office and uses the center. Officials said absenteeism seemed to be down among employees who use the center, along with tardiness, sick leave and requests for schedule changes.
 
'Employees Are Happier'
Howard Evans, the president of the Postal Workers Union local, helped to persuade Washington to approve the center as a pilot project. ''The employees are happier, and it's made them a little bit more productive,'' he said.
When the center opened, it was not clear if the children of night workers would keep the same schedules as their parents, asleep by day and alert by night. The parents, it turned out, discourage this, in part to keep their children on their playmates' schedules.
But they are using the center in an unexpected way. Charlotte Tarwacki, the superintendent of the 10:30 P.M. to 7 A.M. shift, said: ''Some of the night moms were trying to deal with their kids at home during the day while trying to get some sleep. They'd call in and they'd be off sick.'' Since the center has opened, Mrs. Tarwacki said the mothers were leaving the children at the center for the day while they sleep.

HEADLINE: Boeing Strike Halts Work on $80 Billion in Planes

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The people who weld, rivet and fasten together airplanes for the Boeing Company, the maker of nearly 60 percent of the world's commercial jets, went on strike today, virtually shutting down production of $80 billion worth of aircraft.
The strike by 57,000 machinists, most of whom work at plants in the Seattle area, comes as Boeing is under pressure to turn out one new commercial jet every day, four times the pace of two years ago. Many workers, who have complained of exhaustion from seven-day work weeks and mandatory overtime, welcomed the strike as a needed rest.
With no new talks scheduled between management and leaders of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, the strike could last several weeks, or even months, according to company and union officials and independent analysts. A long strike would further delay delivery of new planes to airlines anxious to restock an aging fleet. It would also swell the nation's trade deficit, since Boeing is the country's single biggest exporter and sells 30 percent of its aircraft abroad. 
Boeing has firm orders to build 1,603 planes, worth about $80 billion, in the next four to five years. To meet the production schedule, the company has been hiring new employees at a rate of 400 a month and working some trained machinists up to 200 hours of overtime every three months.
 
Gaps Can't Be Filled
The Boeing boom, 20 years after a bust led to layoffs of two-thirds of the company's work force, has fueled a job market economists say is the fastest-growing, by percentage, of any city in the nation. Last year, the Seattle area added 60,000 jobs, half linked to Boeing.
While Boeing officials said today that they were trying to continue production by using supervisors, they said most of the jobs done by machinists, some of which require Federal Aviation Administration certification, could not be done without the strikers.
''The supervisors alone cannot keep Boeing production going,'' said Bill Whitlow, an aerospace analyst with Dain Bosworth in Seattle. He said Boeing, which has promised to deliver 93 passenger planes to airliners by the end of the year, will only be able to work on a few planes, those which are nearly completed, during the strike.
The machinists make up less than half of Boeing's nationwide work force of 145,000, but they are the ones who actually assemble the airplanes, including the jumbo-sized 747 and the smaller 737. About 27,000 engineers, whose contract expires in two months, reported to work today, but they were not asked to do any assembly work, according to Boeing and union officials. Engineers generally do designing and testing and are not involved in production.
 
Record Profits Cited
Already among the highest paid industrial workers in the nation with average pay of $35,000 annually counting overtime, the Boeing machinists voted by an 85-to-15 percent margin Tuesday to reject a wage and bonus offer that would have given the typical worker $13,800 in additional income over three years.
Labor leaders pointed to the company's record profits of $614 million last year on sales of $17 billion and said the workers deserved a bigger share of the Boeing pie. While they received cost-of-living increases and annual bonuses, Boeing machinists have not had a general wage increase for six years.
The company offered 4 percent wage increase in the first year of a new contract, and 3 percent for the remaining two years, plus an 8 percent bonus in the first year and 3 percent in the next. They offered to bring the overtime down from a mandatory 200 hours a quarter to 160 hours a quarter. The standard work week is 40 hours.
The package, said a Boeing spokesman, Paul Binder, is ''substantial and generous.''
Although Boeing has experienced several years of record orders, the company has been under pressure from some shareholders to increase its profit margin.
 
Voted in Kingdome
Mr. Binder said Boeing would not suffer financially if the strike is short. Although production delays brought by the huge backlog of orders have reportedly cost Boeing millions of dollars in late penalties to airplane buyers, there are contract clauses which exempt the company from paying late fees because of a strike.
Mr. Binder also denied assertions by some analysts that Boeing welcomes a short strike because it gives the company ''a breather'' on supplying aircraft to its buyers.
Boeing workers who packed the Seattle Kingdome Tuesday for the strike vote, roundly booed any talk of settlement. They cheered when Justin Ostro, vice president of the machinists union, said, ''There is no good time to strike; only a right time to strike.''
The walkout began at 12:01 A.M. today with the start of the night shift at plants around Seattle, in Wichita, Kan., where Boeing employs 12,000 machinists, and in Portland, Ore., where the company has 1,700 workers.
 
Time With the Family
Workers who walked the picket line here in a cold drizzle seemed upbeat about the prospects of a successful strike. They said overtime pay has allowed many machinists to build up their savings. Others said they needed the time off, no matter what the issue.
''When my kids found out about the strike, they said, 'Oh, boy, we get to see Daddy,' '' said Bob Junka, a machinist who was walking a line at the plant in Renton, south of Seattle. ''I'm not so worried about what sort of paycheck I get at this point as I am about being able be spend any time with my family.''
Boeing officials have been recruiting workers from different parts of the country, running advertisements which promote the Puget Sound life style. At one point in the last year, the company brought in several hundred workers on loan from Lockheed.
Barbara Simkins, a machinist who voted in favor of the contract, said a strike of more than a month would hurt her and other workers who have saved money in preparation for a long layoff. The union has promised its members strike benefits of $100 a week. Each worker is expected to walk the picket line for about 4 hours every three weeks.

HEADLINE: Sensible Restraint on Panama

 BODY:
Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military strongman for the last six years, had his closest call yet on Tuesday. While rival elements of his Panamanian Defense Forces shot it out, more than 10,000 U.S. military personnel stood minutes away, on full alert, but apparently ordered to stay out of the fight.
For what possible reasons could George Bush have passed up this chance to take decisive action to end the humiliating Noriega problem, this standing affront to his policies of combating drug lords and encouraging democratic rule? 
One answer is that it may not have been all that easy to topple the general even with direct U.S. military intervention. Another is that even if intervention had worked smoothly, there would have been serious complications and costs.
General Noriega's regime colludes with drug barons, lacks legitimacy and rules as a result of electoral fraud. The Panamanian military offers the best hope of ousting it, and the Bush Administration has sensibly encouraged officers to act.
But throwing U.S. forces directly into the revolt would have brought major risks. The operation could have run into damaging complications, like prolonged fighting with heavy civilian and military casualties. Such concerns led the Senate Intelligence Committee last year to question a C.I.A. plan for sponsoring just such a Panamanian coup.
It's not clear that Tuesday's coup leaders, including former loyalists of the regime, would necessarily have been a big improvement. Success could have left the U.S. committed to an unknown new strongman. Given the culture of the Panamanian military, he could have proved as dictatorial and drug-tainted as General Noriega, himself once a U.S. protege.
And make no mistake, the outcry from Latin America would have been substantial and negative. Latin American allies, some more vital to U.S. interests than Panama, would have been swept by the anti-Yanqui hysteria that invariably accompanies unilateral use of U.S. military force against any Latin republic.
General Noriega is a remarkable survivor who has withstood two attempted coups, electoral repudiation, U.S. drug indictments, prolonged American economic pressure and multilateral efforts to negotiate him out of power. Each time he seems to come back stronger.
Yet the challenges keep coming, with growing frequency. Tuesday's coup attempt was reportedly led by a major who rescued General Noriega from the previous military uprising 19 months ago.
The general cannot rest easy. He has done great damage to his own country, once a regional oasis of relative prosperity and peaceable politics and now an economic pariah and a police state. A dictator who tramples his people's interests for selfish and criminal reasons is permanently insecure.
General Noriega has firepower, money and Machiavellian skills. His ability to manipulate less sophisticated opponents has won him many victories. Now he's won another, but he's not home free. There may come a time when it makes sense to use U.S. troops in Panama, as Secretary of State Baker noted yesterday. But that ought to be a deliberate American decision, not a precipitous response to a problematic opportunity. Superpower armies aren't frontier posses. Critics, disappointed at being denied instant gratification, are wrong to attack the President for understanding the value of restraint.

HEADLINE: Thrifts Bailout Law Has Regulatory Teeth

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to ''Insure Deposits, Not Fear'' (editorial, Sept. 10), the recently passed savings and loan legislation is filled with sharply improved regulatory and oversight provisions.
Long before the Administration sent up its legislation last spring, I made it clear that the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee would not move a bill without enhanced regulatory enforcement and new disclosure and reporting on insured institutions. That pledge was kept. 
One entire title of the bill was devoted to reworking enforcement powers for the regulatory agencies -including improved cease and desist authority, easier removal of officers, public disclosure of enforcement actions, imposition of stiff penalties for false reports of an institution's condition, mandatory submission of condition reports to auditors, protections and rewards for whistle blowers who reveal violations of banking laws, increased civil and money penalties, establishment of a special regional office of the Justice Department to pursue financial fraud and increased funds to investigate and prosecute banking crimes.
Other titles of the bill are honeycombed with audit, reporting and specific oversight efforts by both the executive and legislative branches. The General Accounting Office is given major new oversight authority.
When you describe enhancement of oversight and enforcement as ''distressingly absent from the new thrift bailout law,'' you are woefully short of the facts.
You also take issue with my suggestion that the $100,000 per account insurance be reviewed and possibly reduced. I have always supported adequate deposit insurance and will continue to do so.
With the average account insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation substantially under $10,000, there is room to debate the public purpose served by insurance limits of $100,000. Those with $100,000 in liquid assets are not ordinary depositors. The $100,000 insurance has been misused and abused. Money brokers and others have used deposit insurance to churn money throughout the financial system. In search of the highest interest rates, they have fueled many of the corrupt and worst-run institutions, knowing that the Federal Government would pay them off if anything went wrong. Breaking deposits into $100,000 units - with full Government protection - provides no barrier in this day of computers and wire transfers.
This brokering of volatile funds raised the cost of the savings and loan rescue and adds greatly to the future liability of the Federal Government in other financial institution failures.
The insurance limit was raised from $40,000 to $100,000 under mysterious circumstances in a 1980 House-Senate conference. The House Banking Committee did not hold one minute of hearings, nor did the matter come before the full House for a vote before the conference.
There is certainly no economic or public policy rationale for treating the $100,000 figure as some immutable magical level for deposit insurance.
 
(Rep.) HENRY B. GONZALEZ
Chairman, House Committee on
Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs
 Washington, Sept. 12, 1989

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Baltics Report

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: RIGA, Soviet-Occupied Latvia

 BODY:
This weekend the congress of the Latvian Popular Front will meet to assert its intent to bring about a fully independent nation. No more veiled talk about ''economic sovereignty'' or confederation with the Soviet Union - the magic word is independence, the state of nationhood stolen from the Latvians 50 years ago in a pact between Stalin and Hitler.
Five weeks ago, Moscow's Central Committee issued an ominous warning to the Baltic States to stop all talk of separation lest their ''viability'' be destroyed. The Latvian Popular Front interpreted this as ''a readiness of the Soviet Government to resort to force and even to genocide.'' The Latvians called for the protective publicity of United Nations concern, but Secretary General Perez de Cuellar, in craven and unprincipled League of Nations tradition, ignored the plea. The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, followed up in a blast at ''revanchism,'' meaning ''a call for a return of territory taken by force.'' 
The Soviet intimidation has served to unify the bickering Baltic factions and steel their resolve. Most Latvian leaders profess no fear of the likelihood of Soviet tanks in their streets; moreover, they claim to hear mixed signals. Mikhail Gorbachev, meeting with Baltic representatives soon after the Central Committee warning, is reported to have assured them privately that it might be interesting to see if independence could serve as a model for Soviet perestroika.
Such talk may be whistling in the dark, but evidence exists that a Soviet hard line is far from unanimous. In Leningrad a few days ago, Aleksandr Fursenko, vice chairman of the Academy of Sciences and an outspoken Gorbachevite, at first told me that ''independence is not on the agenda,'' but added, ''if the Baltic States decide for political independence, they have earned that right.'' At least some Soviet reformers would rather have a string of small allies, similar to Finland, acting as a bridge to the West than face the need to repress sullenly resistant provinces.
But even granting that the Baltics are a special case, long recognized by the West as captive nations, won't this agitation for separation weaken Mr. Gorbachev and undermine his reforms? I put that squarely to Dainis Ivans, chairman of the Popular Front and an elected Latvian deputy in the Supreme Soviet: Won't the independence of the Baltics fan nationalist sentiment within the original dozen Soviet republics and lead to a crisis in the Ukraine? The 34-year-old editor, a soft-spoken man with a good chance of being the next president of a free Latvia, replied matter-of-factly: ''The Ukraine will rise no matter what happens in the Baltics.''
If his movement wins in national elections next spring, Mr. Ivans sees real, if not formal, independence in the Baltics within five years, achieved through parliamentarian means. Nothing inflammatory or provocative about that. What about the recent Central Committee warning from Moscow? ''There was panic in Moscow because the movement here is so peaceful and disciplined.''
What if hard-liners in the Kremlin insist that Mr. Gorbachev put on an economic squeeze? ''We have more free farmers than exist in all Russia,'' says the Latvian leader, ''and we put bread on Russian tables. All their electric trains and wagons are produced in Riga. If they boycott us, we will manage somehow, but they would hurt themselves. Gorbachev knows that in a super-controlled state, if you lose one economic part, you could cause a catastrophe.''
The people of the Baltics are reaching for the brass ring of freedom at their own gathering speed and in their own way. They know they can expect no military help from the West if Soviet tanks roll, but they count on the U.S. to make clear to Moscow the economic and political consequences to the Soviet Union if force is applied.
That's what we have told the Balts we are doing. An American diplomat called in Baltic supporters in Washington last week to tell them this: ''We have made it clear that if the Soviets crack down, it will be an end to everything - including arms talks and trade negotiations.'' Our diplomat added that ''the Soviets understand this at the highest level.''
At this critical moment, with the lives of thousands and the freedom of millions at stake, it is vital that the U.S. not waffle or mislead or treat Baltic freedom as a Soviet internal affair.
We support Baltic independence; we applaud the present peaceful approach; and we would consider any coercion by Moscow of these illegally subjugated people to be tantamount to a Soviet declaration of cold war III.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
The Savimbi Smear

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
If you can't win a political argument on the merits, attack your opponent as a Communist. It is an old Washington tactic. But I have not seen it used as crudely in years as it has just been by Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah.
On Monday Senator Hatch wrote Attorney General Dick Thornburgh urging him to investigate Randall Robinson, director of the organization TransAfrica. Why? Because Mr. Robinson opposes American aid to Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan guerrilla leader, and favors U.S. recognition of the Government of Angola. 
''Mr. Robinson, by his own admission, is actively working to change a stated U.S. foreign policy,'' Senator Hatch said.
Senator Hatch emphasized that the Angolan Government is Marxist. He told the Attorney General: ''Mr. Robinson should not be permitted to propagate Marxist propaganda under the cover of academic independence.''
Mr. Robinson and TransAfrica led the 1986 campaign for U.S. economic sanctions against South Africa. Congress passed the legislation over President Reagan's veto.
Last week Mr. Robinson went to Angola. He gave President Jose Eduardo dos Santos an invitation from 36 members of Congress - 28 Democrats and 8 Republicans - to visit the United States.
''It is known that the Marxist regime financed Mr. Robinson's trip to Luanda,'' Senator Hatch wrote. In fact, the United Church of Christ paid for the trip. I have seen a copy of its check to TransAfrica, for ''transportation to Angola.''
A number of senators have agreed to host a coffee party or other meeting for President dos Santos, if he comes. They include Democrats Paul Simon of Illinois, Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts, and Republican Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas.
''I don't understand the objection'' to a dos Santos visit, Senator Bradley said yesterday. ''We have this other guy [Savimbi] traipsing around here all the time. How about hearing the other side?
''If people are going to be investigated because they express their views, then we're in trouble.''
Senator Hatch or his staff evidently distributed copies of his letter soon after it was sent to the Attorney General. The next day someone from Human Events, a right-wing magazine, asked Mr. Robinson about it. His troubled reaction was, ''I certainly do not want to be painted as some kind of Communist.''
Even by the standards of extremist politics in this country, the Hatch letter is remarkable. I do not recall a senator charging that it is a criminal offense for an American to try to ''change a stated U.S. foreign policy.'' James Madison and the other Framers of the Constitution thought they were creating a system in which citizens would do exactly that.
Why would Orrin Hatch go so far? I think the real answer is that he and the right are desperately worried about loss of support for Jonas Savimbi.
In March a longtime admirer and biographer of Mr. Savimbi, Fred Bridgland, wrote a critical article for The Sunday Telegraph of London, a conservative paper. He raised serious charges of torture and other abuses.
In August an even more critical piece appeared in National Review, the American conservative magazine. Radek Sikorski, who had just visited Savimbi-held territory in Angola, spoke of Mr. Savimbi's ''despotic instincts'' and ''Leninist'' methods, and said: ''He is no more a democrat than Mao or Castro.''
The situation in southwestern Africa is ripe for peace. Cuban forces are leaving Angola, and South Africa is letting Namibia become independent, under terms brokered by the United States.
The Bush Administration is supporting efforts by 18 African heads of state to end the Angolan civil war. With President Mobutu of Zaire as mediator, they seemed to have arranged a cease-fire last June. But Mr. Savimbi denied that he had agreed to the terms they announced.
Mr. Savimbi is just starting another visit. He remains the darling of the right. But there are growing doubts about his attitude toward a negotiated settlement in Angola - and about the wisdom of an American policy that keeps sending arms to fuel a terrible war.
All that may explain Senator Hatch's mood, but it cannot excuse his letter. He is a smooth man, not suited for the mask of Joe McCarthy.

HEADLINE: Use Force Against Noriega

BYLINE: By Elliott Abrams; Elliott Abrams was Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs in the Reagan Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For nearly two years, the United States has been locked into confrontation with Gen. Manuel Noriega. Panama's dictator was indicted by two U.S. grand juries and dismissed by Panama's President in early 1988. He is intensely unpopular in Panama, where his party lost the recent elections 3 to 1, and throughout Latin America, where his drug trafficking and human rights abuses have left him isolated and condemned by the region's democracies.
Twice in two years, groups in his own Panama Defense Forces have rebelled against him. The disparity in power between those backing General Noriega and those opposing him, including the U.S. Government, is enormous. 
Why has he survived? Largely, because he is willing to use his power while the U.S. has been unwilling to bring its power to bear against him.
During the Carter Administration, the abuses of Gen. Omar Torrijos and his then No. 2, Colonel Noriega, were overlooked, for the sole goal of Panama policy was to get the canal treaties ratified.
General Noriega came to power during the Reagan Administration. His increasingly unacceptable behavior led to distancing, pressure, indictment and then consideration of a variety of proposals for more vigorous action against him.
All these were dismissed under adamant pressure from the Joint Chiefs of Staff and its then Chairman, Adm. William J. Crowe Jr. The Joint Chiefs resisted any confrontation with General Noriega's troops, grossly exaggerating the military threat from a small force that was more adept at cowing unarmed demonstrators than facing real soldiers.
It was at this period, the spring of 1988, that discussions on policy options at sensitive White House meetings were leaked, and Panamanian harassment and abuse of U.S. soldiers was downplayed and sometimes covered up as part of the Pentagon's efforts to fight off U.S. military action.
Instead, President Reagan undertook rhetorical onslaughts against General Noriega. Now President Bush has done so, virtually inviting a coup in some of his public remarks.
In addition to speeches, both Administrations have maintained economic sanctions against Panama, which have badly hurt its economy. Both have sustained large and increasingly successful diplomatic efforts to isolate the regime.
The problem is that speeches, sanctions and votes by the Organization of American States do not interest General Noriega: Raw power does. He watches what we do, not what we or other hemispheric democracies say. He notes that we have been willing to do next to nothing to topple him. When power seemed to hang in the balance on Tuesday, we did not act.
From the facts thus far known publicly - and, judging from the reactions of the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Senator David Boren, the classified information as well - the U.S. missed an opportunity to topple General Noriega.
If it is the case that there was a standoff until he could summon reinforcements to combat dissident officers who tried to overthrow him, one wonders how difficult it might have been to block their arrival.
In recent months, there have been confrontations between U.S. troops and Panamanian soldiers. Not surprisingly, the Panamanians backed down each time in the face of superior U.S. training and firepower. Why would it have been different Tuesday?
The real issue is not the details of the attempted coup; perhaps it was doomed from the start, although this does not appear to be the case. The real question is one of policy.
Is it U.S. policy to act to remove General Noriega? Or is our policy limited to speeches and sanctions? Are we more concerned about the supposed problem of ''U.S. interventionism'' and the Latin reaction to it than about our interests in Panama?
As for drugs, consider the electric effect in Colombia if today General Noriega were in a U.S. prison awaiting trial on his two indictments. The Colombian Government is struggling against drug traffickers who consider themselves above the law and beyond reach, and have long worked hand in glove with General Noriega. His departure would hurt them; his defiant survival can only embolden them.
And what would the impact be on drug trafficking in Panama, if today Panama's Government were in the hands of honest officials? What would the reaction be in Nicaragua, where the Sandinistas face elections soon, if General Noriega's election fraud were followed by his political demise? How can the canal's future be guaranteed when Panama is in the hands of a drug-trafficking thug?
Who rules Panama ought to be a constitutional question; General Noriega's criminal regime, however, has made it a matter of raw power. The Panamanians want him out, but will need our help to achieve that goal. They've had our sanctions and our speeches, but never our assistance. To borrow a slogan from Theodore Roosevelt, who was profoundly involved in Panamanian affairs, it's time for the U.S. to speak more softly, but carry - and contemplate using -a bigger stick.

HEADLINE: Plan to Let Builder Buy Part of 61st St. Is Blocked

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Facing almost certain rejection by the New York City Planning Commission, the developers of a proposed luxury apartment tower on Amsterdam Avenue yesterday withdrew their request to buy part of West 61st Street to gain extra development rights for their skyscraper.
The effect of the withdrawal, which was announced at a hearing of the Planning Commission, would be to reduce the tower's size to 220,000 square feet from 370,000. If an average apartment were 1,000 square feet, that would mean a loss of about 150 units. 
At issue is the northwest corner of Fordham University's Lincoln Center campus, a site bounded by Amsterdam Avenue, 62d Street and the stub end of 61st Street, a public cul-de-sac that cuts into the campus. Fordham wants to sell the site to Carol Management, a Kaskel family development concern, which would build the apartment building, to be called Alfred Court.
 
'Demapping' Action Opposed
The original proposal was for a structure 49 stories high. That size would have been made possible by the city's closing part of 61st Street - an action known as ''demapping'' - and selling the street to Fordham University, which in turn would have sold it to Carol Management. The company would have used the air rights but kept the cul-de-sac in use as a private way.
''I took a very dim view of that kind of action,'' Sylvia Deutsch, chairwoman of the Planning Commission, said yesterday. ''It would be very unfortunate and send the wrong signal. To demap a street to generate additional development rights and then continue to use it as a street - I was very doubtful that I could support that.''
A lawyer for Fordham and Carol Management, Victor Marrero of Brown & Wood, said the demapping request had been withdrawn ''in view of the lack of support'' among planning commissioners and staff members.
Even with the reduction in the tower's size, the proposal still faces strong opposition from neighborhood leaders on the Upper West Side. They said construction of a luxury apartment tower was never contemplated when the site was cleared in the 1950's as part of the urban renewal of Lincoln Square and then set aside for educational or charitable use until the 21st century.
 
University Sees Benefits
But officials of Fordham said the $16.5 million they would realize from the sale of the site would subsidize the cost of a new dormitory on the Lincoln Center campus.
''Through the sale,'' said the Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, president of Fordham, ''we will be able to finance the dormitory at a cost that will make it significantly more affordable. That is a very wise use of the resources available to the university.''
Opponents of the project include Community Board 7, the Coalition for a Livable West Side and several local elected officials - Representative Ted Weiss, State Senators Manfred Ohrenstein and Franz S. Leichter and Assemblyman Jerrold Nadler, all Democrats.
''It would be ironic,'' Mr. Weiss said in a statement read by an aide, ''if urban renewal swept away a high-density, low-income neighborhood with the promise of using the land for educational or charitable purposes, and instead succeeded in creating another high-density edifice providing no educational or charitable services.''
Dr. Brian J. Byrne, a vice president of Fordham, said that the university had informally explored selling the site to another educational institution but that no institution could afford to pay what a private developer would offer.
To accept anything less, he said, would not serve the students.

HEADLINE: Seidman Admission On Bailout

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
A top Federal regulator confirmed today what private economists had been saying for some time: The $50 billion that Congress approved in August to liquidate and sell off hundreds of ailing savings and loan associations over three years could be inadequate to cover the losses at the institutions.
The testimony of L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, before the Senate Banking Committee raised the question of whether the Bush Administration would have to come back to Congress for a second bailout package.
''It is possible that $50 billion will prove to be an insufficient amount to deal with potential failures,'' Mr. Seidman said in testimony. He appeared with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady to discuss the status of the bailout effort. 
 
A Glum Response
Mr. Seidman's admission provoked little surprise from at least one private financial consultant.
''So what else is new?'' asked Bert Ely of Alexandria, Va., who has predicted that as much as $70 billion would be needed for the effort.
At the same time today, other regulators acknowledged that last Friday night the Treasury Department blocked a transaction that would have injected $8 billion into five large savings institutions that the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created to resolve the problems of ailing financial institutions, was preparing to sell to investors before the 1989 fiscal year ended on Sept. 30.
Because of the Treasury's action, they said, Resolution Trust, which operates under the F.D.I.C., was unable to spend $20 billion by the end of its fiscal year, as mandated by the rescue legislation passed in August. Mr. Seidman testified today that he expected the deals to be completed by next week.
 
Shift in Budget Deficits
The regulators said that because of the delay, the Federal Government's budget deficit in 1990 would be $8 billion more, while its 1989 deficit would be $8 billion less. They added, however, that the change would not spur any automatic spending cuts under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law.
Government officials have been slow to agree that the money approved in August for the bailout is insufficient, primarily because it would be embarrassing, as well as politically risky, for the White House to have to return to the Congress in two years for more money.
Mr. Brady has maintained that $50 billion would be enough, and told the Senate Banking Committee today, ''I know of nothing that would change my view.''
The $50 billion is part of a $159 billion package budgeted for the bailout over 10 years, including $61 billion for agreements reached last year, $34 billion for institutions that become insolvent after 1992 and $24 billion in interest costs.
In his testimony today, Mr. Seidman seemed wary about creating new anxiety over the problem, but said that his projection of possible higher costs was based primarily Resolution Trust being likely to have to deal with more insolvent institutions than previously expected.
The agency now controls more than 280 savings institutions, with $112 billion in assets. But it could end up, he said, with as many as 600, with assets greater than $300 billion.
''The projections raise questions about the adequacy of the $50 billion in R.T.C. funding,'' Mr. Seidman told the committee. ''But it is really much too early to make a reliable new prediction of loss.''
 
Minimizing Tensions
Meanwhile, Mr. Seidman and Mr. Brady, who heads a Cabinet-level oversight board that sets policy for Resolution Trust, tried to assuage fears in Congress that tensions between the F.D.I.C. and the trust agency's oversight board were rising.
''No joint enterprise of any magnitude is without its healthy frictions, and ours is no exception,'' Mr. Brady said in his testimony. ''But over all, we have gotten off to an excellent start.''
Though the transaction that was blocked by the Treasury last Friday will have little budgetary effect, Government officials said today that it underscored the difficulty the F.D.I.C., an independent banking regulator, was having in obeying an oversight board controlled by the White House.
In preparing the five savings institutions for sale last week, Resolution Trust had wanted to lend them $8 billion and require them to invest the money in Government securities that the agency would hold as security.
But the Treasury's lawyers contended that such a transaction, in effect, took taxpayer money and invested it in Government securities, which is prohibited by law.
 
Lawyers in Disagreement
In his testimony today, Mr. Seidman said he was not told until late on Monday that the transactions had not been consummated and that the F.D.I.C.'s lawyers disagreed with the Treasury's about their illegality.
''How do you feel? Do you feel fully independent?'' Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat from Michigan, asked Mr. Seidman.
''We're not as independent as we used to be,'' Mr. Seidman responded. ''I keep telling my people, 'Remember the good old days.' ''
Mr. Seidman added, for example, that the Office of Management and Budget had asked to review his testimony, that Resolution Trust's operations had to be audited by six different agencies, and that, under the new regulatory structure, the F.D.I.C. did not feel as free to make judgment calls.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INDUSTRY: NAICS524128 OTHER DIRECT INSURANCE (EXCEPT LIFE, HEALTH & MEDICAL) CARRIERS (83%); SIC6399 INSURANCE CARRIERS, NEC (83%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: VIRGINIA, USA (79%); 

COMPANY: FEDERAL DEPOSIT INSURANCE CORP (83%); RESOLUTION TRUST CORP (73%); RESOLUTION TRUST CORP (73%);

HEADLINE: Dow Up 16.53, to New Peak, Paced by I.B.M.

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Led by the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose to yet another historic high.
I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., rose by 2 1/4, to 108 1/4. The company's chairman, John F. Akers, said yesterday that the company's recent announcement of lower-than-expected earnings would not affect I.B.M.'s long-term growth. More than three million I.B.M. shares changed hands, making it the New York Stock Exchange's second-most-active issue. 
That helped push the Dow up by 16.53 points, to 2,771.09. But the broader market did not show as much enthusiasm, as advancing issues on the Big Board outnumbered declining ones by 831 to 656.
By late afternoon, the Dow had risen by nearly 20 points beyond the 2,754.56 mark it set on Tuesday, when the average jumped by 40.84 points.
In the last hour, however, a wave of selling pushed the Dow down to about a 2-point gain for the day. But in the final 45 minutes, the buying of stocks and selling of futures bolstered it anew.
So far this week, the Dow has risen 78.08 points, its best three-day gain since Aug. 22-24, when it rose by 87.64 points.
Volume on the Big Board yesterday swelled to 194.6 million shares, from 182.6 million shares on Tuesday.
 
Surprising Investors
''Sell programs are seesawing the market, but the overall trend is towards buy programs,'' said Gene Jay Seagle, the chief technical analyst at Gruntal & Company. ''The breakout to new highs to close near the 2,800 level has caught most investors by surprise.''
In the broader markets yesterday, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose by 2.23 points, to 356.94, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 1.14 points, to 197.98.
USX jumped by 2 1/2, to 38 3/4, on speculation that Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor who owns 11.4 percent of the company, was increasing his stake in the former United Steel Corporation. The stock of the company, based in Pittsburgh, was the New York Stock Exchange's most active, on an exceptionally heavy volume of 12.7 million shares. In many ways, one trader said ''USX was the story of the day.''
GTE climbed by 1 1/2, to 65 3/8, after analysts at Salomon Brothers Inc. reiterated their ''buy'' recommendations on the stock.
Among the active glamour stocks, General Electric rose by 3/8, to 58 7/8; Bristol-Myers edged up by 1/4, to 53 3/4, and American Telephone and Telegraph slipped by 1/4, to 44 3/4.
Hitachi fell by 3 1/2, to 105 1/4. The Japan-based company said it had filed a new lawsuit against Motorola Inc., charging the company, based in Schaumburg, Ill., with patent infringement on a semiconductor.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market-value index added 1.34 points, to 394.36, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index moved up by 2.04 points, to 479.32.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed as Traders Await Move by Bundesbank

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against major currencies in fairly quiet trading yesterday with traders cautious ahead of today's meeting of West Germany's central bank.
Many economists and foreign currency dealers predicted that the Bundesbank would raise its discount rate, now 5 percent, and its Lombard rate, now 7 percent, at its regular biweekly meeting. The rate increase, expected to be at least a half-point, would be aimed at pushing the dollar lower or keeping it at its current level. 
''All eyes are watching the Bundesbank,'' said Ronald Holzer, chief currency broker for Harris Trust and Company in Chicago.
A rate increase by West Germany would be the latest step in a concerted effort by the Group of Seven nations to keep the dollar in check since their finance ministers met more than a week ago.
Until now, the Group of Seven, composed of the United States, West Germany, Japan, Britain, France, Canada and Italy, has limited its actions to the selling of dollars and buying of other currencies in the foreign-exchange market.
Higher West German interest rates would make mark-denominated assets more attractive than dollar holdings and would strengthen the mark against the dollar. If the Bundesbank decides to raise interest rates, other central banks will probably follow, analysts said.
In New York, the dollar traded at 141.48, up from 141.20 late Tuesday. And the pound was at $1.6020, down from $1.6045 late Tuesday.
 
Late New York Rates
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.8815 West German marks, down from 1.8865; 1.6290 Swiss francs, down from 1.6350; 1.17475 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17495; 6.3825 French francs, down from 6.4000, and 1,376.75 Italian lire, down from 1,379.65.
Gold prices were up sligthly. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery closed at $367 an ounce, up from $366.30 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Inch Down in Slow Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched lower in slow, featureless trading yesterday.
Traders said they were encouraged that prices remained fairly firm in spite of a drop in the dollar.
''One of the surprising elements of the day was that the dollar went down a little bit but the market didn't skip a beat,'' one government bond trader said. ''That is a pretty constructive sign about how investors view the market.'' 
Credit market participants said that conditions might become more volatile today, particularly if West Germany's central bank does not raise interest rates, as many economists and market participants expect. It is thought that an increase in interest rates by the Bundesbank would help hold the dollar at its current level or push it lower.
 
'Trading Off the Dollar'
''Our market has been trading off the dollar, and if the Bundesbank doesn't do anything the dollar will go up quite a bit, even if central banks intervene to push it down,'' the trader said.
Nicholas Sargen, director of bond market research at Salomon Brothers Inc., said, ''The Bundesbank has surprised the market in the past by the timing of their moves, but I would be very surprised if they didn't raise the Lombard and discount rates by at least half a percentage point on Thursday.''
A move of that magnitude, which would push the Lombard rate to 7 1/2 percent, is already reflected in bond prices here, Mr. Sargen said.
But ''if they raised the rate by a full percentage point, that could trigger a selloff in the dollar'' and put upward pressure on interest rates in the United States, he added. 30-Year Issue at 8.16% Trading in the secondary market for Treasury securities remained light. By late in the day, the closely watched 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 99 18/32, down 2/32, to yield 8.16 percent.
Among secondary note issues, the 8 percent 10-year Treasury notes were offered at 98 5/8, down 1/32, to yield 8.20 percent. And the 8 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100, down 2/32, to yield 8 3/8 percent.
Late yesterday, the Treasury announced it will sell $7.5 billion of new seven-year notes on Oct. 11.
In when-issued trading after the announcement, the notes were offered at a price to yield 8.24 percent.
 
Modest Rise in Short-Term Rates
Meanwhile, short-term Treasury bill rates rose modestly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.77 percent, up 3 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month rates rose 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.86 percent. And one-year bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.84 percent, up 2 basis points.
In other developments, concerns were voiced in Washington yesterday that more than the $50 billion Congress has already appropriated might be needed to rescue the nation's crippled savings and loan industry.
In testimony before Congress, L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said that ''it is possible'' that the $50 billion would prove an ''insufficient amount to deal with the potential failures.''
There was little market reaction to Mr. Seidman's comments, but analysts viewed his statement as potentially ominous.
 
Cost Put at $150 Billion
''Keeping in mind that this is the first hearing since Congress passed the thrift legislation in early August, officials are already predicting the need for more money,'' said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, a managing director at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ''It's not too hard to read between the lines that it will take at least three times that amount, or $150 billion, before all is said and done.''
Market participants are still waiting for the Resolution Funding Corporation, the entity set up to finance the savings and loan bailout, to announce its financing intentions. Several billion dollars worth of Refcorp bonds are expected to be sold at some point in the current quarter.
Elsewhere, activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was very light yesterday, with little or no change in prices, dealers said.
 
Joy Technologies' 'Junk Bonds'
In the high-yield market for ''junk bonds,'' Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for a $120 million offering of resettable senior secured notes for Joy Technologies Inc.
The 13 percent notes, which mature May 15, 1996, were priced at par, or 100. The issue is rated Ba-2 by Moody's Investors Service and B by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most issues rose by a quarter-point in light trading.

HEADLINE: Goals of Fed Called Fulfilled

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Martha R. Seger, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, said yesterday that the central bank had achieved a hoped-for ''soft landing'' in the nation's economy and that inflation was not a significant threat.
''Inflation should continue to be reasonably well contained through 1990 - barring any dramatic developments in food and energy markets or sharp moves in the dollar,'' she said in remarks prepared for delivery in New York yesterday. 
''There are many reasons to be pleased with our economic performance over the past year.''
 
She spoke at the 29th annual
Business Outlook Conference, sponsored by the Conference Board, a private business research group.
A ''soft landing'' is a term describing a condition where economic growth slows just enough to keep inflation in check but not enough to draw the country into a recession.

HEADLINE: Many Elderly Fear Loss of Program That Helps Pays Cost of Long Illness

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4

 BODY:
As the House voted to kill a program intended to protect the elderly from ruinous medical bills, residents of several retirement homes here continued to express the fears that inspired the plan in the first place.
While few of these people were aware of particulars of the legislation, or indeed of the debate about it that has raged so loudly around the country for the last few months, nearly all said they would regret the demise of any measure that might help them weather an expensive illness.
And while some said they worried about the income tax surcharge that provoked furious opposition from some beneficiaries and led to the repeal movement, most focused on the even greater costs that medical emergencies would bring.
''None of us know what will happen to us tomorrow,'' said Alice Roland, a 79-year-old former teacher of psychiatric nursing. ''Expenses keep going up and we can't afford them.'' 
 
Too Much and Too Little
Many retired people said they did not have a clear understanding of the complicated law, and some of those who did said it would cost them too much and deliver too little. But advancing age and failing health seemed to have brought a shared sense of the need for health services and insurance that cut across economic and class lines.
Marion Dwyer, 83, a retired New York City policewoman who once greeted visitors on behalf of Mayor Fiorello La Guardia, said she could barely pay her day-to-day bills. With a program to protect the elderly from catastrophically high medical bills, she said, ''We would all feel a lot more secure about our futures.''
Lesley Keller, 85, a retired businessman who described himself as ''one of the more wealthy'' and who pays $4,200 a month for his penthouse room at the Ocean House retirement home here, said, ''I would be in favor of it because it would be a means of providing extra care for the needy.''
But the law, which was passed in June, drew a storm of protest from many elderly people because of the graduated tax that would place a greater burden on the better-off beneficiaries and because it did not satisfy all their health care needs.
 
'Our Incomes Are Fixed'
''I'm against it,'' said Charles Jacobsen, 84, a retired liquor distributor. ''Why should costs keep going up? They keep on raising everything, and our incomes are fixed.''
Reached by telephone in Dallas, Lina Mae Maddox, 65, a retired telephone company administrator, said she was one of those who had joined a letter-writing campaign against the law. Her name was provided by the National Committee to Preserve Social Security and Medicare, which has been active in lobbying for repeal.
''It's most unfair for them to tax us that much money for not so much benefits,'' Mrs. Maddox said. ''If they had put long-term health care like nursing homes in, there would not have been so much reaction. But we don't feel we would get anything from it.''
She said many retired people like herself who already have private insurance as well as Medicare would end up subsidizing care for people on Medicaid and a growing number of people with AIDS who will consume a large part of the nation's health services.
 
'People Are Living Too Long'
But Bertha Lemel, an 88-year-old dancer and singer with an informal troupe called the Dancing Dolls, said repeal of the law would be a disgrace. ''We're the richest country in the world,'' she said. ''It's a joke that we can't care for our elderly.''
Cynthia Evans, 83, another member of the Dancing Dolls, said: ''The trouble is that people are living too long. The whole country is getting filled up with old people.''
Then, getting up to dance, she added, ''When you get to a certain age you don't really bother about things because there is nothing you can do about them.''
Joseph Levinson, 80, a former buyer for a department store, seemed to echo this sentiment when he said, ''I think younger and wiser people ought to tell us how to live and what to do.''
 
High Cost of Long Illnesses
Sylvia Rosenthal, a widow who is a neighbor of Mr. Levinson's, said: ''I'm going to be 90 in November, so how much longer do I have to go? Another year or two and I'll be gone.''
June Gatewood, the administrator at Ocean House, said, ''The big fear is cancer.''
Leonard Fox, 82, who ran a department store in Youngstown, Ohio, for 42 years, said older people feared ''getting hit hard with catastrophic illnesses that can break them for all they've got.''
At the Goergian, a nursing home where residents can watch the Pacific sunset from their front porch, Beulah Levine, 83, said she had sold a house she owned for 45 years to be able to afford retirement care. ''The little bit we do have, this nursing home deal will clean us all out,'' she said. ''Then if something happens, what we do have we won't have.''
 
Of Dignity and Changes
In the Westwood Plaza retirement home, where petitions opposing the law have been circulated, Morris Shapiro's golf clubs stand by the head of his bed, although it is some time since he has used them.
''All I know is, something ought to be done about people in this age bracket that really need it,'' he said. ''Why not help people to exit like gentlemen?''
Betty Hertz, who lives just down the hall from him, also talked of dignity and of the changes that come over people after they go into a retirement home to live out the rest of their lives.
''You spend a few months in here and you're a changed person,'' she said, looking out the window at the sunshine. ''What do you do? You watch TV and you take a walk. You lose your interest in life and you just wait for meals.
''A year ago I was younger. I looked younger. I acted younger. I drove a car. I wouldn't be sitting here at this time of the morning. I'd be doing something or I'd be getting ready to go out.''

HEADLINE: Soviets Said to Double Cambodia Aid

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The Soviet Union has sharply increased its military aid to the Cambodian Government in Phnom Penh this year, roughly doubling deliveries of arms and ammunition over 1988 levels, Asian diplomats and Cambodian rebel leaders say.
Between January and July, these officials say, 11 Soviet cargo ships delivered some 14,000 tons of military supplies to the Cambodian port of Kampong Saom, including 100 T-54 tanks, armored vehicles and heavy artillery. The Soviet Union also sent 16 MIG-21 fighters to bolster the air force of Prime Minister Hun Sen.
These officials, commenting as the debate continued in the General Assembly for the ninth day, say there was also a substantial delivery of small arms in September, adding that their information comes from the United States and their own intelligence efforts inside Cambodia. 
Some Asian diplomats say the Soviet effort appears intended to insure that Mr. Hun Sen retains control of Cambodia after last month's Vietnamese military withdrawal and is strong enough to resist the Khmer Rouge and the non-Communist opposition groups loyal to Prince Norodom Sihanouk.
 
An 'Afghan Solution'
This suggests, they argue, that Moscow may now foresee an ''Afghan solution'' in Cambodia, with Mr. Hun Sen following the example of President Najibullah of Afghanistan, and retaining power by force instead of seeking a compromise with the opposition.
According to this view, Hanoi and Moscow are now relying on worldwide mistrust of the Khmer Rouge, whose brutal regime caused the death of at least a million Cambodians before its overthrow by Vietnam in January 1979, to build support for a solution that would keep Mr. Hun Sen in effective control of Cambodia, perhaps in loose partnership with Prince Sihanouk.
Addressing the General Assembly, Vietnam's Deputy Foreign Minister, Nguyen Dy Nien, attacked the Khmer Rouge saying the key issue facing Cambodia today is to ''prevent the genocidal Pol Pot clique from kindling a civil war and re-establishing their genocidal rule in Cambodia.''
He assured the General Assembly that Vietnam has removed all its armed forces from Cambodia, saying ''from this rostrum I solemnly declare that from Sept. 27, 1989, there does not remain a single Vietnamese volunteer soldier in Cambodia - either armyman, adviser or military employee.''
 
Assertion Is Challenged
The Cambodian opposition groups and many southeast Asian nations challenge this assertion, accusing Vietnam of leaving thousands of soldiers disguised as militiamen and settlers.
This week the six-member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations introduced a draft resolution in the General Assembly that says the United Nations must verify the Vietnamese withdrawal before the international community can accept it.
The Indian Foreign Minister, Shri P. V. Narashima Rao, addressing the Assembly, also warned against a return to power of the Khmer Rouge, saying Cambodia must not fall victim again ''to the universally condemned genocidal policies and practices.''
 
Military Operations on Rise
Since Vietnam announced its withdrawal from Cambodia last month, rebel officials say the three loosely allied rebel forces, which are all armed by China, have stepped up their military operations in the northwest.
Concerning another tense region, the Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, painted a bleak picture of the prospects for further progress toward a lasting peace in the Persian Gulf. In his address, Mr. Aziz accused Iran of sabotaging Red Cross efforts to organize an exchange of the roughly 100,000 prisoners of war.
Other speakers who addressed the Assembly today were the Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister, Abdul Ghafar Baba; the head of the Dominican Republic delegation, Franklin Andrew Baron; and Foreign Ministers Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania, Sid'Ahmen Ould Baba of Mauritania, Gareth Evans of Australia, Abdul Aziz al-Dali of Southern Yemen, Antoine Ndinga Oba of the Congo, Pedro de Castro Van Dunem of Angola and Shailendra Kumar Upadhyay of Nepal.

HEADLINE: Nairobi Journal;
In a Land of the Censor, a Bold Magazine Endures

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 5

 BODY:
After the second issue of Gitobu Imanyara's monthly magazine appeared on the newsstands, with a bold title about human rights and a chilling graphic of barbed wire splashed across the cover, some friends in the security forces got in touch with the editor. Not a good idea, they warned. Dangerous copy, they said. ''I said I would try and find out what was dangerous in the magazine,'' Mr. Imanyara recalled, only slightly facetiously. ''But no one quite knew.'' In the meantime, the security people ferreted out the printer, who happened to be Asian, and told him he would be expelled from Kenya if he handled any more issues.
Fourteen issues and some sharp covers later, The Nairobi Law Monthly survives, an outspoken magazine in a political milieu where the press has become increasingly restricted. Mr. Imanyara, a lawyer turned journalist, manages to tell his readers - not only lawyers, diplomats and businessmen but ordinary Kenyans curious about their society - what others can't, or won't. 
In a nation that once boasted the most unfettered press in Africa, the retinue of press closings and restrictions has been long lately.
 
Church Magazine Banned
The magazine of the National Council of Churches in Kenya, was banned last year. More than five months ago, a lively weekly, The Financial Review, was shut down when its coverage of the economy and political issues irritated the Government. A rather innocuous magazine, Development Agenda, was prohibited in August after two issues, apparently because of its political connections.
Perhaps most ominous of all, The Nation, the largest selling and most comprehensive daily newspaper, established 28 years ago by the Aga Khan, was stopped in June by Parliament from covering Parliament. Legislators complained about ''subversive elements'' at the paper and how its training program with The St. Petersburg Times, in Florida, was tainting the paper.
Editors at The Nation used to resist calls from the office of President Daniel arap Moi requesting that articles be suppressed.
Since the banishment from the press gallery, the editors acquiesce, fearful that a consequence of publishing displeasing articles will mean a shutdown.
A free press is a rare species in most of Africa. In the neighboring Sudan, for example, a flourishing press -about a dozen dailies - was shut down after the military coup in June. The broadest points of view on Africa can often be found in magazines and newsletters printed in Europe, out of the way of the censors. But the recent crackdown in Kenya has disappointed people here because the country regards itself as a democracy.
 
A Pocket-Sized Office
Mr. Imanyara, a lithe, mild-mannered 36-year-old graduate of Nairobi University's law school, who puts out his magazine from a pocket-sized office with the help of only three others, has experienced his own problems.
The third issue of The Monthly featured a cover article on the release of a jailed human rights lawyer, Gibson Kamau Kuria (winner of the Robert F. Kennedy human rights award), and a prominent letter to the editor suggesting the Commissioner of Police should resign because of reported deaths of people in police custody.
''I was arrested and then released,'' Mr. Imanyara said. ''They said the magazine was spreading 'alarm and despondency among the wananchi' and giving a lot of prominence to dissidents and their sympathizers. I wrote a statement saying I was a lawyer and wouldn't accept being told what to print.'' Wananchi is Swahili for ''the people.''
Before turning to journalism, Mr. Imanyara attracted attention as a lawyer. He defended the employee accused of killing the conservationist Joy Adamson. He lost the case, but as he puts it now, won ''a lot of exposure.'' Several years later, he defended 120 members of the air force charged with treason in connection with a failed coup of 1982. Not surprisingly, he lost that case, too.
 
Jailed for 5 Years
By that time, his political activities, viewed as courageous by some but threatening by others, had earned him the ire of the Attorney General. He charged Mr. Imanyara on the basis of a complaint that a client of the lawyer's had filed with the Law Society but the society had dismissed as groundless.
Mr. Imanyara was jailed for five years - he spent two years in solitary after which he was released - in what was widely seen as a vendetta for having dared to defend the air force officers. In jail he laid plans for starting his law magazine.
While he has many criticisms of what he sees as abuses by and of the Kenyan judicial system, he also believes in its strengths. Each month he goes out of his way to point these out.
''Our bias is covering civil rights and human rights, but by selecting cases for publication we are able to educate people so they know there are judges who've acted favorably,'' he said, as he took a break from writing an assessment of the new Chief Justice for the next issue.
 
On Western Foundations
Mr. Imanyara's magazine, with its push for human rights, is just the kind of effort that Western foundations and agencies line up to endow. The calling cards of potential donors lie on top of his desk.
''I would not accept money from a U.S. foundation,'' he said. ''It would encourage us to be dependent. A lot of Kenyans leave too much to outsiders. I'd rather have 50,000 subscribers in the United States than $50,000 that might help us only in the short term.''
A case against Mr. Imanyara dealing with his second arrest over an issue of the magazine is still pending. In the meantime Mr. Imanyara's eye-catching, sell-out publication - 3,000 to 5,000 issues depending on the print run - has not been shuttered.
''They still haven't closed it and they can't,'' he said. ''They want to show the world we have a judiciary that functions.''
There is another reason, too, Mr. Imanyara said. He is well aware of the possibility that the Government may find the magazine useful. ''The Government can say: 'How can you say we have no freedom of the press when you are reading this magazine?' It's a contradiction, of course, to say we have freedom of the press, because we don't.''

HEADLINE: Panama Opposition Figures Seized in Crackdown

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Armed men attacked opposition party headquarters tonight hours after Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega called for a crackdown on his opponents and urged Government employees to root out traitors in their ranks.
Anel Beliz, a spokesman for the opposition coalition, said that about a dozen members of the Liberal Party, including a doctor and a nurse, were seized shortly after 9 P.M. after a day of harassment by Government and paramilitary forces wearing civilian clothes.
''They were attacked with tear gas and a lot of violence,'' Mr. Beliz said in a telephone interview. ''They were taken away. We don't know where they are. They destroyed the facilities.'' 
 
Endara Reported Safe
There were unconfirmed reports that Guillermo Endara, the apparent winner of presidential elections last May that were annulled by General Noriega, was arrested in the assault and later released.
Journalists who went to the party headquarters to investigate reports of the attack were chased by men armed with clubs. A car rented by a group of photographers was seized along with their film.
Earlier today, General Noriega called for a crackdown against what he called disloyal Government employees and others. In an emotional speech in Santiago, a city 140 miles southwest of Panama City, the general also accused the United States of hypocricy in denying a role in the attempted coup against him on Tuesday and held Washington responsible for the death eight years ago of the Panamanian leader Gen. Omar Torrijos, who was killed in a mysterious plane crash.
As General Noriega spoke in the steamy auditorium of a teachers' college in the heart of Panama's rice-growing region, security forces in the capital began to take action against political opposition leaders, first arresting a chief of security for the Liberal Party and a party photographer.
This afternoon a dozen men dressed in civilian clothes and carrying clubs, rubber hoses and shotguns forced their way into the offices of the civilian opposition coalition shortly after a press conference involving the opposition leaders Ricardo Arias Calderon and Mr. Endara, who is on a hunger strike to protest Government policies. The men took away three civilians, including one of Mr. Endara's bodyguards, and surrounded the building for more than an hour before leaving.
In the afternoon incident at the opposition offices, the man who appeared to be leading the group refused to identify himself or show his authorization to conduct such a raid, but said that he had been told to prevent anyone from entering or leaving the building.
''We have orders from high up,'' said the man, who brandished a steel rod with a homemade handgrip.
General Noriega, in his speech in Santiago, apparently referring to the radio and television stations that broadcast rebel communiques during the attempted coup, said broadcast organizations that ''have been suborned have to be shut down.'' Both stations are run by the Government.
Drenched in sweat and wearing a floppy red-and-blue striped straw hat, he portrayed Panama as a country under siege by the United States and threatened by internal tensions that were revealed by the participation of some of his closest allies in the attempted coup.
 
Under Fire for 4 Hours
General Noriega said he spent nearly four hours under fire in army headquarters during the coup attempt.
He suggested that not only military officers but civilian Government employees as well had been involved in the rebellion.
''In the name of those functionaries who acted with dignity,'' he said, ''we have to throw out those who did not. We have to throw them out to create a vacancy for those who do not have jobs.'' He described his Panamanian enemies both in and out of the Government as traitors and told the audience of several hundred cheering Government workers: ''The functionary who does not turn in a traitor is himself a traitor.''
Though General Noriega thoroughly dominates Panama, he said he was presenting to his hand-picked President, Francisco Rodriguez, a ''proposal that certain laws that protect enemies of the Government be knocked down.''
The general declared that ''those who are privileged and involved in traitorism cannot get away with it.''
''We have to have a new package of war laws,'' he said. ''We have to defend ourselves.''
He drew attention to the United States economic blockade of Panama and the country's declining commerce and Governmental revenues as further evidence for harsh actions. ''The laws for old times do not serve anymore,'' he said.
The crowd underscored points in the speech with slogans like ''Hit the Yankees hard!''
 
Canal Accords in Peril
General Noriega, who is under indictment in the United States on drug trafficking charges, has tried to picture his troubles with Washington as a result of a campaign not against him but against Panama. He suggested again today that the United States agreement to turn over control of the Panama Canal to Panama in 1999 was in great jeopardy, and he cited the failed coup attempt as proof.
He insisted that after the coup attempt he had discovered ''written proof'' that the United States had encouraged the rebels and that part of the plan was to replace President Rodriguez with Mr. Endara, who had appeared to be winning the elections for president in May when the Government stopped the vote-counting and annulled the election.
Referring to General Torrijos, General Noriega said that ''with the most sophisticated technology,'' the United States ''brought down his plane.''
General Noriega said the Americans had made a mistake in believing that by removing him, it could prevent ''the people from receiving their canal on Dec. 31, 1999.''
''It is not a question of the death of one man,'' he continued angrily, ''but of a generation of people struggling for national dignity.''
