HEADLINE: For Boeing Strikers, Walkout Is Welcome Respite

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EVERETT, Wash, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Across the street from the cavernous building where the Boeing Company builds 747 jets is an old cafe called the Overtime Inn.
The name is apt, for it dramatizes a chief complaint of many workers in the two-day-old strike by 57,000 machinists against the world's largest airplane manufacturer.
''People are worn out,'' said Ed Elliott, who has worked on an assembly line building the midsection of the jumbo jets 12 hours a day, every day, for the last five weeks.
Tired machinists, many of whom have been working 30-day stretches without a day off, are common on the picket lines in front of the plant here, the largest building in the world. Their work schedules have emerged as one of the most emotional issues in the strike. 
 
'We're Just Dog-Tired'
To meet the largest production order in its history - more than 1,600 airplanes worth $80 billion - Boeing has made overtime work mandatory at some plants. Many machinists appreciate the extra money and have no qualms working 12-hour days for four weeks at a stretch. But others express concerns about their family lives and even about the quality of their workmanship.
''You walk around the plant like a zombie,'' said Craig Huse, who has been a machinist at Boeing for less than a year. ''We're out here building most of the world's airplanes, trying to make sure Grandma doesn't fall out of the sky someday, and we're just dog-tired. I don't mind the overtime that much, but I think we should have a choice.''
Aside from one highly publicized complaint last year by Japan Air Lines, one of Boeing's biggest customers, the aerospace company has received few public complaints about workmanship. The planes are inspected by the Federal Aviation Administration and by independent airline engineers as they are put together.
Boeing officials say they recognize that the people who assemble the airplanes are overworked. For the last year, they have been bringing new people onto the assembly line as fast as they can hire and train them. In the company's latest contract offer, which was overwhelmingly rejected by the International Association of Machinists on Tuesday, Boeing offered to reduce the mandatory overtime from 200 hours every three months to 160 hours.
 
'I Used to Be a Fisherman'
But many workers walking picket lines here in Everett, 30 miles north of Seattle, say they want a choice.
The fresh-cleared land around the plant is stuffed with new apartment buildings housing thousands of workers who have flocked to the Puget Sound area for the economic good times. But they say they are working so hard that the blessings of the Pacific Northwest - the fishing, hiking, hunting, skiing and boating in the nearby mountains and waterways - are passing them by.
''I used to be a fisherman - that was my hobby,'' said Don Hubble, a striking machinist. ''I haven't caught a salmon or a steelhead in a long time. I have two kids, little ones. Once, I wanted to go to a baby pageant, and not work overtime. They treated me like I was a pansy.''
Mr. Hubble, a native of the Northwest, has never made so much money as now. With overtime, the average Boeing machinist makes $35,000 a year, state labor officials say. But Mr. Hubble said he would gladly give up some of his big checks in return for a normal weekend - that is, more than one day off every 35 days.
''This job cost me my marriage and my little girl,'' said Rick Gauthier, who moved to Everett this year from Fort Worth. The move, plus spending virtually every waking hour away from home, he said, led to the breakup of his family. #80 Hours of Overtime Like other Boeing workers on the picket line here, Mr. Gauthier said that all he wants to do is sleep when he comes home from work. His last paycheck, for two weeks, included money for 80 hours of overtime, he said.
For others, the mandatory overtime is doubly vexatious because it doesn't even pay the bills.
''I'm considered an unskilled factory worker,'' said Tim Rizan, who moved to the Seattle area this year from South Carolina, where he worked at Lockheed. ''We're supposed to be a bunch of dumb blue-collar workers. I'm no financial wizard but I can read the paper. And it says that Boeing made $600 million in profit last year. Well, if they want us to work this hard, why not give us a choice or pay us what we're worth.''
Mr. Rizan said he supports his wife and two kids on a base salary of $11.76 an hour. The pay is 20 percent more than earned in South Carolina. But he cannot afford to buy a house in the soaring Seattle market, where home prices are going up 30 percent a year in many neighborhoods.
Although Boeing has said it will try to continue limited production during the strike by using supervisors, striking workers scoff at the idea.
''What those supervisors are trying to do to those airplanes right now is a sin,'' Mr. Gauthier said. ''Most of those guys haven't turned a wrench in years. One of my bosses was a fisherman before he came to Boeing. What does he know about being a mechanic?''
Paul Binder, a spokesman for Boeing, said supervisors would not be asked to do jobs which they are not qualified or certified by the Federal Aviation Administration.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
The Monument to '88 Lives in Politics of '89

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
A year ago, many politicians and analysts said the 1988 Presidential campaign would have little to do with governing, little to do with the issues and problems that would shape the years that followed. To the Democrats' despair and the Republicans' delight, they were wrong. If you seek the monument of the 1988 campaign, look around.
It is apparent in the politics of patriotism, in large ways and small. Each day, the House of Representatives convenes with the Pledge of Allegiance, a ritual adopted when George Bush was hammering Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for blocking a Massachusetts law that required schoolchildren to recite it. Today the Senate, following the lead of the House, passed the 1989 Flag Protection Act, aimed at outlawing flag burning in the aftermath of the Supreme Court decision protecting such acts of political expression. 
With a critical budget deadline just 11 days away, carrying the threat of automatic spending cuts, and a host of fiscal and public policy issues pressing in, the Senate spent the entire day and much of the night on Wednesday making speeches about the importance of protecting the flag. Many of the speeches came from Democrats, who in 1988 saw their party outmaneuvered on traditional values.
''George Bush campaigns at a flag factory and everybody says, 'What does that have to do with the problems of the country?' '' said one aide to the House Democratic leadership. One year later, he said ruefully, ''We've spent four months trying to perfect an anti-flag burning statute.''
Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, sees the flag-burning bill as the triumph of the mainstream values that President Bush championed in 1988. ''I think it proves that candidate George Bush was on to something when he talked about that in the campaign,'' said Mr. Atwater, who managed the Bush organization.
The 1988 campaign has framed the economic struggles now consuming the Democratic Congress and the White House. Mr. Bush's ''no new taxes'' pledge, made in the heat of the campaign, has echoed through the autumn of 1989, even as pressure grows because of the deficit and the law requiring its reduction.
Given their political vulnerabilities on the issue, Democrats are wary of making the first move on taxes. The Democratic leadership of the House, for example, was roundly criticized last week when it proposed higher taxes only on the 600,000 richest taxpayers. ''I do think the single best issue the Republican Party has over the Democrats today is the tax issue,'' said Mr. Atwater.
In general, Democrats have waited for Mr. Bush to blink first; some were convinced that the moment would come as part of a grand budget compromise. He has not blinked yet. ''The dirty little secret of Democrats' displeasure is they didn't believe George Bush was serious when he talked about not raising taxes,'' asserted John Buckley, spokesman for the National Republican Congressional Committee.
In fact, Republicans argue, President Bush is doing exactly what candidate George Bush promised to do: forswear new taxes and cut the taxes on capital gains.
Some Congressional Democrats say that is exactly the problem. The 1988 campaign finessed the hard questions of the deficit and left the country in a state of drift that plagues it today, they argue. ''That campaign took us nowhere,'' said Representative Vic Fazio of California, vice chairman of the House Democratic Caucus. ''It took us to four more years of fudging.''
There is another echo of the 1988 campaign in Washington today. The fierce tactical thrust and parry that marked the Presidential campaign has carried over, in some ways, to the style of governing. The battle over the capital gains cut last week, for example, had many of the trappings of a campaign, with competing sound bites and slogans, press releases and commercials. Much of the public dialogue between Congress and the White House is reminsicent of the dialogue a year ago.
Some lawmakers worry about blurring the line between tactics and policy, campaign and governance. ''The amount of governing that is substance is less and less and less,'' says Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn. ''On Monday, the guys in the White House say, What image can we convey? And on the Hill, on Tuesday, Democrats say, How can we counter that image?''

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Speaker Holds Off Insurance Ban

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The Massachusetts House voted Wednesday to delay for a year the key provision of the state's universal health insurance law after turning back an attempt to repeal it.
The Speaker of the House, George Keverian, a Democrat, quit the rostrum Wednesday and took the floor to offer an amendment to preserve the program, a centerpiece of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's Presidential campaign last year.
Mr. Keverian postponed the effective date of the legislation until 1993, so as to save its key provision, that businesses with six or more employees provide health insurance worth $1,680 to each worker. 
The bill goes next to the Senate. where it has strong backing and is expected to be passed.
 
Study of Law's Financing Due
State Representative Peter Forman, a Republican, had won preliminary House approval in July to repeal the key provision, arguing that the plan would cost $400 million to $1 billion and the added burden could harm businesses.
Under the plan, the state would subsidize health insurance for workers whose employers chose not to buy coverage for their employees. It would also help provide insurance to the self-employed and to businesses with fewer than six employees.
Mr. Keverian argued against repeal and pleaded instead for a delay to study the law's financing. The Democratic-controlled House agreed, 96-53.
 
Insurance for the Jobless
The Keverian amendment would also keep in place a provision that would take effect next year, providing insurance to jobless workers collecting unemployment compensation. That plan would be financed by a $16.80-a-year fee that businesses with six or more workers would pay for each employee.
The plan has already provided health insurance to about 77,000 of the estimated 600,000 people who did not have insurance when the plan was made law last year.
Of the 77,000, 17,000 are people moving off welfare into jobs that do not provide health insurance, as well as disabled adults and some children with serious disabilities. The 60,000 others are college students who were required this school year to have health insurance either through their parents or group plans through schools.

HEADLINE: How to Slow the East German Exodus

 BODY:
East Germans keep heading west. And Bush Administration officials now say they would like the flow of refugees to slow, but that it's up to East Germany to do so by reforming itself economically and politically. Preferring East Germans to stay home sounds harsh, but it's sound policy. And only a country worth living in, not a socialist workhouse, will keep them there. 
Thousands of East Germans tried this week to send the same message. They took to the streets in Leipzig to chant for reform - ''We want to stay,'' and ''Gorby, Gorby.'' But the Honecker regime, still hoping that perestroika collapses before it does, grimly clamps down. Repression and the continuing emigration risk a popular explosion, which could chill warming relations between East and West, not just in Germany.
The U.S. and West Germany have always welcomed refugees from tyranny, and it's right to extend that hospitality. But the rush to exit in recent weeks has its complications. The arrival of skilled young workers may benefit Bonn economically by spurring growth, but it creates political strains. Some West Germans resent the newcomers. Others worry that the exodus will cause border closings, impeding contact with their relatives in the East.
These concerns give the U.S. and West Germany an interest in encouraging reform without disorder throughout Eastern Europe. The Soviets share this interest. But the goal may not be achievable in East Germany, almost certainly not with Erich Honecker and his henchmen in charge. That's why Washington, Bonn and Moscow want more pragmatic East German leaders to surface soon.
In this context, the Bush Administration's policy rightly addresses the question at hand, the future of East Germany, not the future of a united Germany. That's a useful counterpoint to siren calls on the right in Bonn for German reunification.
West German Governments have long relegated reunification to an indeterminate future in favor of Ostpolitik now. That's the series of small steps Bonn has taken to improve relations between the two Germanys and make life more bearable for Germans in both. To jettison that policy now would disrupt the process of change in the East and improvement in East-West relations. That's why Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher wisely takes issue with reunification, calling instead for ''a European federalism and a German federalism.''
Orderly democratic reform may be a contradiction in terms for Mr. Honecker. But for Washington, Moscow and for all Germans, it represents the best hope for a permanent end to the cold war.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Freight Access Program for New York city Remains Essential;
Switch to Night Shift

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Neither David Dinkins nor Rudolph Giuliani should spend a moment to address the nonissue expressed by John F. McHugh, a lawyer with railroad clients (Op-Ed, Sept. 16).
True, most freight for New York City is delivered on small trucks -possibly 10 for each highway trailer - after unloading of trailers and redistribution of freight to city delivery routes. This is true of trailer loads as well as freight-car loads, as Mr. McHugh should know. He should also know that loads destined for one delivery point are not unloaded and then reloaded to 10 small trucks.
These small trucks are less of a burden to cross-Hudson routes than they would be to the impassible Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.
The freight-handling system can be improved upon by acknowledging that the congestion is a function of the tremendous volume - for which there is only one sane solution: reorganization of the 24-hour day for general freight delivery and pickup.
Copy the meat, produce and fish distribution night operation. Prohibit pickup or delivery for less than truckload lots from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. It may require businesses to hire employees willing to work at night, thus easing unemployment. It will also require major convulsions within teamster union contracts, but there is no other rational or sane solution to a problem that grows worse as prosperity grows.
 
BERT NEUMAN
Passaic Park, N.J., Sept. 21, 1989

HEADLINE: LAW;
Law Schools Seeking to Limit Students' Part-Time Work

 BODY:
Using letters and moral persuasion, law school deans in the nation's largest metropolitan areas are urging law firms to discourage students from spending too much time in part-time jobs at their firms.
The most recent plea came last month when a letter signed by the deans of all 15 laws schools in New York was sent to about 2,000 firms in the state.
The letter stated that the schools shared a concern that ''excessive part-time work'' during the academic year can detract significantly from studying and reduce participation in extracurricular programs like moot court, the law review and legal research. 
''The lure of a $40-an-hour job is very difficult for a young professional to resist,'' said John E. Sexton, dean of New York University Law School who was an organizer of the letter. ''But the three years of law school is the only extended amount of time students have with experts committed to teaching the fundamental issues of the law. That's not the role of a law partner.''
New York, like Washington and other major cities, has a high concentration of law offices and Federal agencies offering part-time work to law students as researchers. The pay ranges from $10 an hour at a government agency to $45 an hour at a blue-chip firm. #20-Hour Suggested Maximum Legal educators say the American Bar Association's guideline suggesting that full-time students work no more than 20 hours a week outside of school is often flouted by law firms, corporations and government agencies. Others say even that suggested limit is too high.
''Recently we have heard stories of law firms requiring students to work more than 45 hours a week,'' said Betsy Levin, executive director of the Association of American Law Schools in Washington. ''We've been very concerned by students' being encouraged by law firms to violate the standard.''
Professor Levin said that at some schools, second- and third-year students were deserting the libraries and moot courts so they could earn money at law firms. Professors have reported that some working students frequently miss class or come ill-prepared.
Last August, a joint committee composed of officials from the Association of American Law Schools and the National Association of Law Professors was formed to examine the extent of the problem.
In Dallas, where Southern Methodist University's Law School is the only one in the city to provide part-time legal labor, Dean Paul Rogers says the problem of student overwork is serious. ''We have a lot of students who work more than we would like,'' he said. ''But on the other hand we are a private law school with a fairly steep tuition so our concern has to be tempered by students' economic necessities.''
Law students say the money they earn as part-time workers fulfills the work-study requirements of their scholarships and often leaves extra money to pay rent and other expenses.
Natalie Frazier, a 23-year-old second-year student at George Washington Law School, says the experience will help her find permanent employment. ''It gives you leverage and marketability,'' said Ms. Frazier, who is to become a clerk in the spring at Arent, Fox & Kitner in Washington. ''It's practical experience that will follow you the rest of your career.''
But Professor Levin says the value of the legal education diminishes when students spend an inordinate amount of time working. ''The difficulty is they only have three years to prepare themselves for a lifetime in the law,'' she said. ''They shouldn't waste it.''

HEADLINE: LAW: At the Bar;
In defense of ambulance chasing: Will more competition keep lawyers' fees down?

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
No stereotype of lawyers is more common or more unflattering than that of pin-striped locusts descending on tragedies in quest of clients long before the smoke has cleared or the black box has been found.
But Prof. Lester Brickman of New York's Cardozo Law School says solicitation need not be bad. Or, to paraphrase Gordon Gekko, the Michael Douglas character in ''Wall Street,'' ambulance chasing can be good - for clients.
''What is ambulance chasing?'' Professor Brickman asked. ''It is lawyers openly competing with each other for business. And when lawyers greedily compete, prices go down.'' 
Professor Brickman is also a disciple of Milton Friedman, the apostle of free enterprise. And, as the professor puts it in an article in the current issue of The U.C.L.A. Law Review, some more free enterprise is what's really needed in personal injury law.
Historically, personal injury lawyers charge clients nothing up front but collect up to half of whatever their clients receive through a verdict or a settlement. So, with recoveries skyrocketing, the hourly rate can exceed those of the fanciest Wall Street lawyers. What ostensibly justifies these fees is the risk that the victims, and their lawyers, may win nothing at all.
But Mr. Brickman contends that this justification is no longer valid and that the system remains simply because it serves lawyers. ''The contingent fee area presents a blatant example of routine price-gouging by lawyers,'' he said. ''The bar's indifference to this situation is stunning.''
America has long been ambivalent about contingency fees, which are prohibited in most countries. In many places they were equated with champerty, or selling a piece of litigation speculatively, and were prohibited. Laws against them date at least to 1658, when Peter Stuyvesant specified just how much lawyers in New Amsterdam could charge.
Such bans gradually fell, mainly because contingent fees were well-suited to the Industrial Revolution, when ever-larger numbers of workers without funds to hire lawyers were hurt. But for several reasons, including broadened rules of discovery and transformation of the tort system into a kind of social insurance program in which the deepest pocket pays regardless of fault, today's personal injury plaintiffs collect far more predictably than they once did.
Airplane crashes, hotel fires, medical malpractice - all are, in a way, like the classic case of an Englishman named Byrne, who was crushed by a flour barrel that rolled out of a warehouse window in 1863. All are open-and-shut cases in which liability is certain. In cases like this, there is nothing ''contingent'' about the contingent fee.
Professor Brickman noted one case in which a Kansas doctor removing a woman's thyroid gland cut off a piece of her esophagus in the process. The case produced a $2 million verdict, half of which went to the lawyer - a fee that worked out to $3,000 an hour. Such remuneration, Mr. Brickman said, violates injunctions against ''illegal or clearly excessive'' fees. But such charges, he added, ''are so much a part of the culture that people have stopped questioning them.''
Go to any bar convention, and the American flag is amply on display. The star-spangled spectacles of the American Bar Association are filled with patriotic homilies, pledges of allegiance and color guards. But historically, the bar has protected itself from all-American free enterprise, usually under the guise of maintaining high ethical standards. It was in precisely this way that innovations like legal clinics and lawyer advertising were blocked.
''When it comes to economics, lawyers, like every group in America, put their interests first and claim those interests are in society's interests,'' Mr. Brickman said. But bans on solicitation remain on the books, at least officially. As a practical matter it is allowed, but only when done discreetly and unthreateningly - that is, by lawyers adhering to the usual contingent rates rather than underbidding one another.
In Mr. Brickman's ideal world, lawyers would not only descend on a Gramercy Park or a Bhopal but also bid against one another once they got there. Where risks were minimal, percentages would drop proportionately; conversely, where recovery was unlikely, lawyers would raise their rates.
The spectacle, while unsavory, would also be efficient. Mr. Brickman notes how, in air crashes, competition between lawyers has already cut the usual contingency fee in half.
''So pervasive are these abuses that one may legitimately describe the current regulatory scheme as 'rotten.' '' he writes. Until the problem is fixed, he says, ''we should at least change the term 'contingent fee' to 'percentage fee' or 'joint venture fee' or 'access toll.' After all, would we still call it 'Hamlet' if it lacked the Prince of Denmark?''

HEADLINE: LAW;
Law Firms Tighten Belt on Recruiting Students

BYLINE: By SHARMAN STEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Law students who are packing suitcases for job interviews at firms around the country are likely to find only an interview, not an all-expenses-paid vacation. Troubled by the escalating costs of recruitment, law firms are putting limits on accommodations and expenses for prospective associates.
''Why should we compete with each other to put students up at the next most ridiculously expensive hotel?'' said Francis Carling, the hiring partner at Winthrop, Stimson in Manhattan.
Several years ago, firms in San Francisco, Atlanta, Cleveland and Los Angeles got together to establish guidelines on how much students may spend while in town for an interview. Firms in New York City, which includes some of the country's largest partnerships and the most active recruiters, have lagged behind, possibly because of the greater amount of national recruiting. 
The guidelines used in San Francisco, and now being considered by New York firms, set forth recommendations like suggesting that students obtain economy-class airline tickets and take a shuttle bus from the airport instead of a taxi. Firms are advised to inform students that they will pay no more than $15 for breakfast, $15 for lunch and $30 for dinner.
 
Watchword Is 'Reasonable'
Los Angeles firms are following similar monetary limits. Many firms in other cities are simply advising students they will be reimbursed only for ''reasonable'' costs.
While many firms report a few cases of overspending and fraudulent bills, recruiting officers like Mr. Carling say this abuse was not the impetus for such a change. Last year Winthrop, Stimson conducted 167 in-office interviews, Mr. Carling said, emphasizing that he is interested in saving money while providing students with first-rate accommodations.
Large New York firms spend $300,000 to $500,000 each on the annual recruitment process. The firms collectively bring from 3,000 to 5,000 students to the city each year, said Paul Kurland, a lawyer at Snow Becker Krauss who is spearheading the ad hoc New York City Law Firms Office Interviewing Procedures and Guidelines Committee, representing about 50 firms.
''The guidelines would let people know that it is not appropriate to go to The Four Seasons or Lutece for dinner, or to order a $100 bottle of wine, or caviar,'' said Mr. Kurland, who estimated it costs $1,140 to bring a student from Chicago to New York for a day of interviewing, which includes a $600 plane fare, $220 hotel room, $70 in cabs to and from the airport and meals.
 
Collaboration Studied
The New York firms are considering a move to arrange airline tickets and hotel rooms through one travel agency to obtain bulk rates. The agency would also handle the laborious administrative task of dividing each student's expenses among each of the firms visited.
''We could get big blocks of rooms at a hotel and save a lot of money,'' Mr. Carling said. ''The firms who want to be more lavish don't have to join the system.''
Because of antitrust questions raised by some firms, the matter is still under debate. But many partners said the guidelines and the travel agency proposal would eventually be adopted.
Michael Delikat, the hiring partner at Baer, Marks & Upham in Manhattan, said setting such limits would help to set a better tone for the entire profession.
''There's a feeling that we should start fostering the right attitudes in students from the beginning by keeping expenses reasonable, whether or not the firm or the client picks it up,'' Mr. Delikat said. ''This would bring back a sense of reason to the process, and it's a good way of having all the firms in New York play on a level playing field.''
 
Cutback on School Interviews
In addition to paring travel costs, firms are also reducing the number of partners each student sees in a visit to the firm, saving costly time. The firms are also reducing the number of law schools where preliminary interviews are conducted.
''We found that we were interviewing at several schools where we don't do well, possibly because of geography or a lack of interest in the Midwest,'' said Diana Goebel, director of legal recruiting for Arter & Hadden in Cleveland. ''We cut out some of those schools. During the past three years, our costs have dropped, but we're doing better because we're not aiming to hire anything that walks by.''
Jamienne Studley, executive director of the National Association for Law Placement, an organization of 700 legal employers and law schools, said, ''The message many firms are trying to communicate is, 'Let's concentrate on the work you'd do here, and the people you're working with, and not what kind of hotel we put you up at.' ''
Some students have apparently reached the same conclusion by themselves. Students at the 14 top law schools, including Harvard, Yale and Michigan, are participating in a program in which they ask law firms to book hotel rooms and patronize restaurants that are less expensive than the norm, and to give the difference in cost to an organization serving the homeless.
 
Still a Seller's Market
Nevertheless, lawyers note that it is still a seller's market for top law students, and firms will make sure that accommodations are pleasing.
''Costs are obscene, and they have gotten out of hand,'' said Tim Baetz, the hiring partner at McDermott, Will, Emery, which is based in Chicago. ''But firms will do what it takes because all of us are expanding at such a significant rate.''
Mr. Baetz, whose 470-lawyer firm plans to hire about 80 lawyers this year in its seven offices, said the manpower needs of the top 200 largest firms are almost twice what the top half of the graduating classes can provide.
''We're all vying for the same people, and nobody wants to go second-tier,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Sounds Around Town

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS

 BODY:

From Africa and Asia
''We Came Before Columbus,''
Davis Hall, Convent Avenue and 134th Street (307-7420). An impressive collection of groups will celebrate African and Asian pre-Columbian influences in the Americas with traditional drumming, dance and singing, to open the Caribbean Cultural Center's fall season. Included is a rare appearance by the Allegheny River Indian Dancers, who will sing traditional Seneca social songs, as well as dance and drum. Soh Daiko will perform pieces on the taido, a Japanese drum, and Luis Bauzo and Patakin, along with Roots of Brazil, will perform Cuban and Brazilian versions, respectively, of West African religious ceremonies. Babatunde Olatunji, the master Nigerian drummer, will headline the show. The tickets for tomorrow's concert, at 8 P.M., are $12 in advance and $14 at the door. 
 
Tommy Flanagan
Tommy Flanagan, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Tommy Flanagan has consistently led one of the great piano trios of the 1980's. Along with the bassist George Mraz and the drummer Kenny Washington, he has made extraordinary interplay an essential part of his performances. Mr. Flanagan can not only rummage around an extensive catalogue of standards, but he's also an expert on the tunes of Bud Powell and Thelonious Monk and other be-bop composers. One set of his is never the same as the next, and each one always offers surprises. Sets today and tomorrow at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight, and Sunday at 8 and 10 P.M.; the cover is $12.50 and the minimum $7.50.
 
Dorothy Donegan
Dorothy Donegan, Village Vanguard, Seventh Avenue South at 11th Street (255-4037). Dorothy Donegan is an American eccentric, a pianist who can invest an Ellingtonian melody with a primal stillness, then rock it with boogie-woogie or stride piano. Though she was often overlooked in her youth, she's finally beginning to reap some of the recognition she deserves. Mixing styles with real glee, she deflates pretension. And as an entertainer, she's just as liable to whack a note, turn around on the piano bench, look at the audience so they understand, then get back to the business of originality. Sets tonight through Sunday are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. The cover is $12 and there is a $7.50 minimum.
 
'Majestic Zouk'
Zouk Album of the Week: Kassav': ''Majestik Zouk'' (Columbia FC 45353). Technology and economic success have allowed Kassav', the most popular of the zouk bands from Guadeloupe, the liberty to record albums that have all the glitter of typical pop albums. On the deficit side, this means that the recordings don't document the players' boiling live shows. It does allow them to layer chorus over chorus, electric and acoustic drums and synthesizer lines into a big danceable mess. On ''Majestik Zouk,'' the band's second album on a major label, Kassav' lets complicated rhythms stutter, stop and start. Horn lines charge and dart while the vocals, in Creole, float over the dancing synthesizer figures.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
The Pottery of George Ohr At American Craft Museum

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
The times have almost caught up with George Ohr, the turn-of-the-century American potter who always knew that he was a genius and that the pots he produced were unprecedented as both art and craft. The exhibition of 91 examples of Ohr's work that has just opened at the American Craft Museum could be larger and more complete. Ohr's achievement merits more than one floor of this small museum; it certainly deserves better company than the display of umbrellas that fills the museum lobby.
Nonetheless, if small, this exhibition is all muscle. It outlines in certain, often irresistible terms many of the facets of Ohr's originality, introducing an achievement that deserves a place among the artist's greatest contemporaries - Thomas Eakins, Albert Pinkham Ryder, Louis Sullivan, Marsden Hartley, Alfred Stieglitz and perhaps even Frank Lloyd Wright.
The son of an Alsatian blacksmith, Ohr was born in 1857 in Biloxi, Miss., where he would spend most of his life. His education did not extend beyond the elementary years and he trained as a blacksmith and worked as a tinker, a dock chandler and a sailor before a childhood friend offered to teach him the pottery trade. The first time he sat at a potter's wheel, Ohr knew he had found his life's calling. 
Yet, despite Ohr's unwavering self-confidence and relentless, often obnoxious flair for self-promotion, his talent went largely unrecognized in his lifetime. In 1910, eight years before his death, ''the mad dauber of Biloxi,'' as he called himself, converted his Biloxi pottery (or ''Pot-Ohr-E,'') into an auto repair shop. His beloved pots were packed away in wooden crates that remained stored in the garage's rafters until 1972, when they were rediscovered by an antiques dealer.
It's hard to encapsulate Ohr's sensibility and his drive to set free color and form. It's equally hard to do justice to the sense of artistic intelligence (and humor) and the extreme improvisational flair that his work exudes. The innate technical virtuosity he brought to the potter's wheel enabled him to create pots whose walls are among the thinnest known. In his mature years, which date from 1894 to 1910, his inventiveness led him to deform these thin-walled vessels with ruffles and dents, nips and tucks that turned each into a unique formal event.
Handles alone occasioned great originality, their linear profiles variously drooped, coiled or flairing, spilling down or up the sides of vases. Some handles are so full of personality they turn Ohr's more thin-waisted vases into abstracted female figurines.
On top of this, Ohr's feeling for mixing colors and glazes yielded an astounding array of hues, surfaces and application techniques. The vases, pitchers and teapots that grace this show are often splattered, dripped and dappled in patterns as free form as the pots themselves. But visitors shouldn't let the brighter colors outshine the artist's subtler greenish browns and his countless shades of black - shiny and matte, rough and smooth.
Basically Ohr invented his own brand of beauty, one so innately modern that it's easy to understand why he wasn't more appreciated in his own time. His liberations of color and form move beyond Art Nouveau and the Arts and Crafts Movement - with which his work has obvious links - and points toward the present. In particular, his exquisite, constantly shifting balances of randomness and control convey a kind of three-dimensional Automatism that presages ideas basic to Surrealism and Abstract Expressionism. And in a way that seems both modern and close to the experience of painting, Ohr invites the viewer to rehearse the pleasure and release he felt in making his pots.
In some instances we can see where he stopped the wheel's spin to pull a pot's mouth into a delicate four-cornered box; frequently we feel that he reversed the wheel to create bands of repeating ruffles or that he simply tapped the vessel's top to introduce the suggestion of collapse into an otherwise perfect shape. All these devices dramatize the pots' thinness and their feeling of spontaneity, but they also introduce complex emotions - gentleness or violence, irreverence or awe - that convey an undiluted sense of Ohr's presence and personality.
If we are lucky, this exhibition will lead to a full-blown survey of Ohr's work, one that would feature some of the more modest, often quite tiny (shot-glass-sized) bowls and vases, as well as the erotica that he produced. But in the meantime, this show holds its own in a moment when New York, playing host to Picasso and Braque and Velazquez, is blessed with museum exhibitions of almost overwhelming greatness. It manages this by revealing an artist who focused absolutely on his chosen medium, who believed that its possibilities were limitless and who proved them to be so.
''George Ohr: Modern Potter'' remains on view at the American Craft Museum, 40 West 53d Street, through Jan. 7.
 
'Bruce Nauman: Prints 1970-1989'
Castelli Graphics and Lorence
Monk Gallery
578 Broadway (near Prince Street)
Through Oct. 14
This two-gallery exhibition features nearly all the prints that Bruce Nauman has made. It is an impressive display and also an especially personal one, in part because the artist's prints stress his use of language and his language forces a not-always-comfortable intimacy with the viewer. These surfaces are rife with the word plays, word reversals, verbal challenges and imperatives with which Mr. Nauman admonishes himself, his audience and fate in general.
In prints, Mr. Nauman works most often in drypoint etching or lithography, media that accommodate aggressive marks, gouges and retracings that make his words and images jangle and jump. In some prints, he calls us names, in another he spells ''Clear Vision'' backward and in a third he equates violins with violence. In a work whose image spells out ''Normal Desires,'' the routine suddenly seems oxymoronic, while the seemingly nonsensical ''Oiled Dead'' suggests business as usual, especially in these post-Valdez times.
These are insistent, often hostile works that seem bent on startling our consciousness upward a notch or two. They are ultimately more touching than aggravating and often quite beautiful to look at.
 
Jeff Wall
Marian Goodman Gallery
24 West 57th Street
Through tomorrow
In Jeff Wall's photographs, a picture is worth at least a thousand words, words that for the most part would combine social and esthetic critique. Mr. Wall's photographs are actually gigantic Cibachrome transparencies - measuring up to 10 feet in width and installed on equally large light boxes - that pull together a number of representational traditions. They combine the lustrous, idealizing glow of commercial art with the scale, formal complexity and psychological suggestiveness of great painting and the neutrality of the news photograph - and invite the viewer to write their captions. Almost large enough to step into, they are initially enticing, yet prolonged examination reveals subtle tales of desperation and man's inhumanity to both man and nature.
These five images constitute the first solo show in New York City for Mr. Wall, a Canadian artist whose work was seen in last year's Carnegie International exhibition in Pittsburgh, and who is well known both here and abroad. The simplest and most obvious of them shows a grand landscape of river, hills and mountain range with an industrial park festering at its center. The most convincing works take racial and economic inequity as their subject.
In ''Tran Duc Van,'' named after its central character, an Asian man in filthy clothing, seemingly homeless, leans against the trunk of a lushly-leafed tree while two people stroll by, oblivious. He looks upward as if asking succor of the tree, which is as isolated and out of place as he is, but his pose also suggests a Renaissance flagellation scene.
In ''The Goat,'' a scene that is straight out of Goya, four boys, each seeming to represent a different racial or ethnic group, taunt a fifth. The leader, a white youth, wields a bamboo stick as if it were a riding crop, assuming a stance that takes superiority for granted and seems to sum up generations of colonialism.
Yet as another work, ''Outburst,'' suggests, prejudice is not necessarily interracial: this Caravaggio-like sweatshop drama - complete with protruding tabletop - shows an Asian boss about to strike an Asian employee, while other workers look on in frozen horror.
It is hard to separate the strengths from the weaknesses of Mr. Wall's art. At times, his images seem too ambiguous and deadpan - and too dependent upon the viewer's knowledge of art history. In other instances, he gives just enough clues to pull us into his narratives, withholding final judgments so that we see all the participants as victims, knowing or not.

GRAPHIC: Pitcher, circa 1895-1900, by George Ohr, part of an exhibition at the American Craft Museum. (John White)

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

 
Companies
Donald J. Trump offered $7.5 billion for AMR, the parent of American Airlines. The company is expected to reject the $120-a-share bid. [Page A1.] Robert L. Crandall, American's hard-driving boss, wants to run his own show and is unlikely to agree to any friendly takeover. [D4.] Mr. Trump has a strong staff and a solid record of repaying bank debts, but he suffers from an image as a corporate raider. [D4.] 
A G.M.-Chrysler joint venture will make manual transmissions and other components. The deal is the first joint venture among the nation's Big Three auto companies. [D1.]
Carl C. Icahn has increased his stake in USX and will continue to acquire more stock, according to filings with the S.E.C. [D3.]
Boeing's handling of its machinists' strike indicates that the company will favor a longterm strategy - seeking to put the brakes on wage increases - over immediate production needs. [A12.] Work schedules have become an emotional issue in the strike. [A12.]
An agreement to buy American Medical International was canceled by investors who offered at least $260 million less. [D3.]
L. J. Hooker will speed up the sale of B. Altman because of its inability to provide financing to modernize the stores. [D3.]
 
The Economy
Senate Republicans said they might strike a deal with Democrats to keep extraneous spending and tax measures, including a capital gains tax cut, out of the pending deficit-reduction package. [D1.]
Big retailers reported generally strong sales for last month. But a lag in purchases of household durable goods continued to hurt results at chains like Sears and Montgomery Ward. [D6.]
Prudential-Bache was censured by the S.E.C. for numerous violations of securities laws governing accounting procedures and operational controls. [D3.]
 
International
The Transportation Department proposed a liberalizaton of the U.S. air market, in a plan that would allow foreign airlines access to any city if they do not compete with existing service. The access would be restricted to airlines from nations with liberal rules on air traffic. [D1.]
The European Community was criticized by Commerce Secretary Mosbacher and the U.S. trade representative, Carla A. Hills, for what they said were protectionist trade measures on television programming and computer chips. [D2.]
 
Markets
The dollar closed higher, despite West Germany's increase in interest rates. Some other nations followed suit on the increase of one percentage point. Traders said a Japanese increase and a U.S. decline would be needed to tame the buoyant dollar. [D1.]
The Dow Jones industrials rose modestly to another record, closing at 2773.56. The broader market was less strong, and declining stocks outnumbered advances on the Big Board. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in fairly active trading, pushed higher by a jump in the dollar. [D12.]
Precious metals futures slumped in a disappointed reaction to the dollar's late surge. Energy and coffee prices also fell. [D14.]
 
Today's Columns
Young & Rubicam expects to be indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges related to the purported bribing of Jamaican officials in order to obtain a tourism advertising account in 1981. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D1.]
The Bush Administration appears to have ended its ''benign neglect'' toward the dollar. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Dividends may be on the decline, after years of increase in the long-lasting bull market, says the editor of Standard & Poor's Outlook, an advisory newsletter. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Europe Lifts Key Rates, But the Dollar Still Rises

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
In a coordinated effort to weaken the buoyant dollar, the West Germans and other European countries increased key interest rates today, but the dollar closed higher anyway.
The rally against the interest rate move, which was larger than expected, surprised traders. But they said it showed that the United States economy was attractive enough to create strong demand for dollar-denominated securities and the currency to buy them.
Other interest rate changes will be needed, they said, including an increase in Japanese rates and a decline in rates in the United States, to tame the dollar. A summer rally sent the dollar well over the ceilings of 1.90 marks and 140 yen believed to have been set by the Group of Seven, which consists of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada. 
But most economists do not expect the United States or Japan to act in the near future, which means that the Group of Seven will have to continue its largescale selling of the dollar to keep it from rising sharply again.
 
Fed Waiting
The Federal Reserve Board does not want American interest rates to ease until it sees sure signs that the economy is slowing. Analysts do not expect such signals until the end of the year. In Japan, officials have said they would not follow European increases. They are worried that by raising rates and slowing their economy, they would increase their trade surplus with the United States, which would aggravate political relations.
By the end of trading in New York, despite Fed sales, the dollar, after falling on the initial announcement of the interest rate rise, had risen against most major currencies. The dollar ended at 142.40 yen, up from 141.48 on Wednesday, and 1.8845 marks, up from 1.8815. The rise against the yen was stronger because the Japanese did not change interest rates.
While the Bundesbank was expected to raise its interest rates, the 1 percent increase was larger than expected, as were the following moves by Britain, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, and the Netherlands, which also went up a point. The French raised their key rate by three-quarters of a percentage point and the Swiss by half a percentage point.
The coordinated move was another step in the effort by the Group of Seven and their allies to bring the dollar back into line with the group's ceilings.
 
Moves Began Last Month
That group's effort began late last month with a communique saying the dollar was too high. This was followed by repeated and coordinated dollar selling by the Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan and European central banks that has already driven the dollar down significantly. The dollar was at 1.95 marks and 146 yen before the communique.
The West Germans raised their discount rate to 6 percent from 5 percent and their Lombard rate to 8 percent from 7 percent. The Lombard rate governs short-term rates and the discount rate is charged on medium-term borrowings. In a statement, the Bundesbank said the increase, the fourth this year, was intended to ''combat continued inflationary danger.''
Nicholas Sargen, director of bond research at Salomon Brothers in New York, suggested that the dollar may have rebounded after falling on the announcements because the West Gemrans later set a 7.3 percent interest rate on an offering, which was lower than the new 8 percent Lombard rate. ''The movement in official rates was bigger than the movement in money rates,'' he said, which diluted the impact somewhat.
 
Dollar Opens Higher
TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 6 (AP) - The dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen in morning trading today,, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange declined.
The dollar ended morning trading at 142.65 yen, up 1.60 yen from Thursday's close of 141.05 yen. After opening at 141.95 yen, the currency ranged from 141.80 to 142.75 yen.
The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, a 140.19-point gainer Thursday, shed 416.46 points, or 1.17 percent, closing the morning session at 35,106.53.

HEADLINE: U.S. Cautions Europe On Protectionist Moves

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The Bush Administration warned today that it might have to re-examine its support for European Community efforts to forge a single market by the end of 1992 if Europeans continued taking actions that discriminated against the United States. Officials cited a recent television directive calling for majority European content in programming and policies that favor European computer chips.
Two Cabinet officers, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, addressing separate Congressional forums, took the occasion to voice the strongest Administration reservations to date to the European plan to remove internal trade barriers by 1992. 
Mr. Mosbacher told a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee that ''European integration can be a great thing,'' but ''if they continue to hammer away at local content as they have with these guidelines on TV, and as they are doing in the semiconductor and other areas, we will have to take a whole new look at it and think about it differently.''
 
First Wavering in Support
It is the first time that any senior official of the United States, which has been an enthusiastic backer of European integration, has publicly suggested American support could waver.
Spurring Washington's wrath are tariff and other proposed regulations that favor European-made computer chips, telecommunications equipment and other products over imports from the United States, Japan or other regions.
The Europeans are also proposing local content rules covering municipal and public procurement, and as a result, American, Japanese and other companies are being induced to build European plants to retain European market shares.
This was reflected in a decision announced earlier this week by the Intel Corporation of Silicon Valley, one of the world's leading manufacturers of advanced computer chips, which is investing up to $400 million in a semiconductor plant near Dublin to meet demands for ''European content'' in chips used in the European automobile, telecommunications and other industries.
Mrs. Hills, addressing the Congressional Competitiveness Caucus, termed ''outrageous'' a European decision taken Tuesday by the European Council of Ministers, the community's highest decision-making authority, and served notice that the United States would retaliate.
The council set nonbinding rules urging European television stations to devote a majority of their air time to shows made in Europe. The United States contends that even the nonbinding rules will discriminate against American programs.
Mrs. Hills said the United States would ask the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to declare the action a violation of the charter of the 96-nation fair-trade agency. Should a GATT panel find against the community, the Europeans could come under pressure to rescind the ruling. However, GATT panel decisions are not binding.
Asked by Representative Don Ritter, Republican of Pennsylvania, ''Are we being caught with our pants down?'' Mrs. Hills, like Mr. Mosbacher, insisted that the Administration had a strategy of bringing maximum pressure to bear on the European rule-making procedures.
But Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee's Subcommittee on International Economic Policy and Trade, elicited from Mr. Mosbacher that the Commerce Department was still unable to field a single specialist in Brussels to follow the Europe 1992 developments.
''They'll be dealing in European Currency Units before we have Commerce people represented in Brussels,'' Mr. Gejdenson said.
Referring to a proposal from the Transportation Department, also made today, to open additional American cities to flights by foreign airlines, both Mr. Mosbacher and Mrs. Hills stressed that the Administration continued to back open trade policies and welcomed fair foreign competition in the domestic market.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Dollar Anxiety At White House

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE Bush Administration, concerned about the rising dollar, appears to have ended its ''benign neglect'' for the time being and is working with other governments to push the currency down.
Yesterday, help came from abroad when the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, raised its key discount and Lombard rates a full percentage point and sold a lot of dollars. Other European central banks followed and the dollar fell - but briefly, and then went up again. The foreign-exchange markets had expected the move and had already factored it in. The markets remain uncertain, however, over how committed the United States and its partners in the Group of Seven, most importantly West Germany and Japan, are to pushing the dollar down, and holding it down, against market forces that have been pushing it up. 
The Bush Administration lacks credibility on its dollar policy. From the time it took office until just before last week's meetings in Washington of the International Monetary Fund and the Group of Seven, the Bush Administration had reverted to the benign neglect of the dollar followed by President Reagan's first Treasury Secretary, Donald T. Regan. In the second Reagan term, James A. Baker 3d moved to the Treasury and set the dollar on a downward course, fearful at last that the soaring dollar, once hailed as a mark of strength, was ruining the nation's trade position.
Similarly, the Bush Administration started out by passively watching the dollar climb from 123 to 145 Japanese yen and from 1.7 to 1.95 against the German mark - until shortly before last week's Group of Seven meeting. Does that constitute a ''Plaza II'' commitment, in the phrase of C. Fred Bergsten of the Institute of International Economics? Or is it only a temporary convenience?
If market forces - and psychology - continued to drive the dollar up, it could again undermine American exports, suck in a rising tide of imports, aggravate protectionist pressures and drag the United States into recession.
The White House, apart from its dollar anxieties, also wanted lower interest rates for domestic reasons, to ward off recession and spur economic growth, and had been leaning on the Fed to deliver lower rates. The Germans, for their part, were worried that a rising dollar - and falling mark -would intensify inflationary pressures in their country and throughout Europe. But the Japanese are not yet ready to go along.
And the markets don't believe this is Plaza II. Shafiqul Islam, the senior fellow for international finance on the Council on Foreign Relations, said, ''The markets are confused - they see the United States only half-committed to stabilizing exchange rates, acting in a sense of crisis, but unsure what the real problem is.'' The European and Japanese governments also continue to doubt that the United States is yet prepared to take the hard, fundamental steps needed to restore strength to the dollar. Mr. Islam says, ''They are asking, 'If the United States doesn't fix its own policy, why should others support the U.S.?' ''
More important than rhetoric to talk the dollar down, central bank intervention or even coordinated manipulation of rates is whether the United States is prepared to deal with the budget deficit. It lies at the root of the trade deficit, the savings shortage, the dependence on foreign capital and the high interest rates that push the dollar up.
As Ronald McKinnon of Stanford University observes, in a highly open economy only fiscal policy, which operates directly on the balance between savings and investment, can reduce a deficit in trade and the balance of payments. In the 1980's, he says, the American fiscal deficit created a savings deficiency, which has not been repaired.
The now-widening United States budget deficit, partly disguised by putting the savings and loan bailout and other items ''off budget'' while putting the Social Security trust-fund surplus on budget, threatens to keep the American trade position weak and increases the ultimate risk of future dollar devaluation.
With that risk of devaluation - and the fear that it will result in higher inflation - investors demand higher yields on dollar assets than on those denominated in yen or marks. The high-risk premiums built into United States interest rates shorten the time horizons of American business.
Thus, the chronic United States budget deficits, low savings rates, and high costs of capital are forces that underlie what Budget Director Richard G. Darman calls ''now-now-ism,'' the fevered search of Americans for deals with immediate payoffs. Dollar depreciation may be the unavoidable consequence of fiscal deficits, payments deficits, high interest rates and a loss of national competitiveness, but cannot provide a lasting cure for those ills, as the poor experiences of other debt-ridden countries have amply demonstrated.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
3-Year Talks Pay Off For Chief of Pyramid

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
Shortly after joining the Pyramid Technology Corporation as chairman, president and chief executive three years ago, Richard H. Lussier began conversations with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company about possible collaborations. This week, the two companies said they would jointly develop a new series of minicomputer systems.
Pyramid, based in Mountain View, Calif., was a pioneer in the technology of reduced instruction set computing, or RISC, which allows a computer processor to operate faster by limiting nonessential tasks. With revenues of about $79.8 million in its 1988 fiscal year, Pyramid has grown 30 to 35 percent a year during Mr. Lussier's tenure. While healthy by most corporate standards, such results are lackluster compared with the 100 percent growth over the same period of other RISC manufacturers like Sun Microsystems Inc. 
Mr. Lussier, who is 51 years old, said this week's announcement marks a turning point for the company. ''The A.T.& T. deal is the opportunity to move out of the 30 percent growth mold and into a whole other level,'' he said. ''It tells everyone we've arrived. We are obviously ecstatic about it.''
AT& T's endorsement of and investment in Sun have been major factors in that company's success, analysts say. Pyramid's machines, which typically sell for $200,000 to $350,000, are larger than Sun's and more powerful than A.T.& T.'s own minicomputers, the 3B series, which will continue in production, Mr. Lussier said. A.T.& T. will sell both Pyramid's existing line, based on Pyramid's proprietary RISC processors, as well as the new jointly developed systems, which will use an industry-standard microprocessor.
Before joining Pyramid in November 1986, Mr. Lussier was president and chief executive of Verticom Inc., which he joined in May 1984. Before that, he was executive vice president and a director of the Masstor Systems Corporation. He was previously executive vice president and a director of the Itel Corporation, and has also held sales management and director positions at Honeywell Inc.'s electronic data processing division.
Mr. Lussier received his B.S. in economics from the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, Mass., in 1960, and his M.B.A. from Boston College in 1967. He and his wife, Suzanne, have two sons: Mark, 21 and Kyle, 16.

HEADLINE: Record on Borrowing Can Help Trump's Bid

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump brings a strong staff and a solid record of repaying bank debts to his $7.1 billion bid for the AMR Corporation, but he suffers from an image as a corporate raider who may not be seriously interested in completing a transaction.
The billionaire developer has large real estate holdings that would be easy to borrow against, a long record for repaying his debts, and warm relations with his bankers that together allow him to borrow large sums at low interest rates. He has also assembled one of the best staffs in the property development industry and recently hired a veteran airline executive to run the Trump Shuttle, which was recently acquired from Eastern Airlines and quickly renamed. And Mr. Trump may be able to borrow more than AMR's assets alone would permit because the combination of American and the shuttle probably make the shuttle far more profitable. 
Yet professional traders and analysts note that Mr. Trump has in the past expressed interest in many public companies - including MCA, Pillsbury, Golden Nugget, Caesars World and Resorts International -without ever buying an entire publicly traded company. Mr. Trump's pledge to put up $1 billion of his money for the deal may strain even Mr. Trump's fortune, which has been estimated at about $1.7 billion.
 
Seen as 'Publicity Hound'
''I've always looked at him as a publicity hound,'' said J. Michael Short, an analyst with Wealth Monitors Inc., a stock research firm that watches the investments of prominent raiders to glean stock tips.
''Maybe the motive for him is that Marvin Davis and Al Checchi have had their name in lights recently and he hasn't,'' Mr. Short added, referring respectively to the billionaire bidder for the parent of United Airlines and to the new owner of Northwest Airlines.
In a letter to AMR's chairman and president, Robert L. Crandall, Mr. Trump said yesterday that he was ''prepared to commit at least $1 billion of equity to the transaction'' and that he believed he could raise the rest of the money needed to complete a $120-a-share deal.
''I've never been on a Trump job where there were financial troubles,'' said Irving R. Fischer, the chairman of HRH Construction, which has done a lot of work both for Mr. Trump and his father, Fred Trump, who is also a wealthy developer.
 
He Pays Well
Mr. Trump has gathered some of the best real estate executives in the country, Mr. Fischer said. ''He pays well and he's got an in-depth organization.
The AMR proposal itself was the work of only a handful of Mr. Trump's top aides, headed by Harvey I. Freeman, who led the Trump Organization negotiators in the purchase of the Eastern Shuttle, said Norma Foerderer, Mr. Trump's executive assistant. Also involved in the proposal was Susan M. Heilbron, who, like Mr. Freeman, is an executive vice president of the Trump Organization.
Robert Trump, Donald Trump's brother and also top adviser, was less involved in the work, Ms. Foerderer said. ''It happens to be the baby of Harvey Freeman.''
Donald Trump oversaw the proposal and should receive the credit, she said, declining to set up interviews with any senior managers.
 
More Lawyers Expected
Gerald N. Schrager, a partner at the law firm of Dreyer & Traub, advised Mr. Trump on the proposal. Mr. Schrager said that he had begun working with Mr. Trump's father 15 years ago and that he expected lawyers with more background in the airline industry to be brought in as the AMR proposal advances.
Mr. Trump brings competence as well as style, guts and foresight, to the airline industry, Mr. Schrager said, declining to elaborate.
Bear, Stearns & Company, a New York investment bank, has advised Mr. Trump on previous financial dealings and is said by traders to have been actively buying shares on his behalf in the last two weeks. Alan C. Greenberg, the firm's chairman, declined to address questions concerning Bear, Stearns's role in Mr. Trump's pursuit of AMR.
A professional trader said that the Federal Reserve might also cast a disapproving eye on bank lending to another highly leveraged airline. A spokesman for the Fed said the Government agency had cautioned banks on Feb. 16 about their lending to leveraged buyouts. He declined to comment on current airline takeovers.
 
No Pressure From Fed
But an official at a leading money center bank who asked not to be identified said the Fed had not expressed concern directly or indirectly about lending to airline deals.
Banking analysts differed on how easy it would be for Mr. Trump to raise several billion dollars. ''It's more difficult than it used to be'' said Edward T. Thompson, a vice president of Thomson Bankwatch, a bank credit rating and consulting firm.
Mr. Thompson cited recent limitations on the purchase of risky bonds by savings and loan institutions, and to the possible nervousness of foreign banks to lend after the Department of Transportation's expressions of concern about the participation of foreign airlines in acquisitions of United States carriers.
But James J. McDermott, Jr., a banking industry analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, was more optimistic. ''I think this is a deal the banks would want,'' he said.
In addition to the Trump Shuttle, Mr. Trump owns hotels in New York, casinos and hotels in Atlantic City and 27.2 percent of Alexander's, the department store chain.

HEADLINE: Stocks End Day Mixed; Dow Up 2.47

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks ended narrowly mixed yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose modestly to yet another high.
After a seesaw session, the Dow ended 2.47 points higher, at 2,773.56. But declines on the New York Stock Exchange edged advances, 743 to 741. 
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added a scant 0.03, to 356.97, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index tacked on 0.07, to 198.05.
Volume on the Big Board dropped to 177.9 million shares, from 194.6 million shares on Wednesday.
Initially, stocks fell narrowly and broadly as investors took profits after the Dow Jones industrial average's more-than-80-point rise over the last four days.
A round of European interest rate rises, led by the Bundesbank of West Germany, also depressed domestic equities by making European currencies more attractive to investors.
In the end, however, the market showed amazing resiliency, analysts said.
''The West German central bank increasing interest rates was so widely anticipated that currency markets reacted well in advance of today's reality,'' said Bernard S. Spilko, a senior vice president at Zurich-based Bank Julius Baer in New York. ''In fact, after the rate rise news, the U.S. dollar increased in value as compared to other currencies.
He said the confidence of investors in the United States economic system, especially from foreign sources, should continue to have a positive effect and continue the rally in the stock market.
Among individual stocks, the story of the day was AMR, the parent of American Airlines. The issue soared 16 7/8 points, to 99 7/8, and was by far the most active stock on the Big Board on a volume of 8.4 million shares. Donald J. Trump proposed to pay $120 a share cash, or $7 billion, for the approximately 58.9 million outstanding shares of the airline, if AMR's management would cooperate in a friendly deal.
The sharp advance by AMR propelled the Dow Jones transportation average 31.65 points higher, to 1,498.76, one of its biggest daily gains in history. The record for the indicator is 1,532.01 set on Sept. 5 of this year. The biggest rise for the transports was on Aug. 7, when the average rose 94.06 points, or 7.52 percent, when the UAL Corporation soared 46 1/4 points, the first day of Marvin Davis's bid for the parent of United Airlines.
Yesterday, UAL dropped 1 1/4, to 281 1/2, on worry that Mr. Trump's bid for AMR would intensify the Government's scrutiny of leveraged buyouts in the airline industry.
Among other individual issues, Sears, Roebuck dropped 7/8, to 43 1/8. Analysts said the stock's price was depressed by a lower outlook for third-quarter earnings.
Active glamour stocks included USX, off 3/8, to 38 3/8; Paramount Communications, down 3 3/4, to 62; Chevron up 1 7/8, to 64 3/4; A.T.&T., up 1/4, to 45; Citicorp, off 1/2, to 33 7/8, and I.B.M., off 3/4, to 107 1/2.
Gold stocks fell across a broad front on the surge by the dollar. Homestake Mining slipped 1/8, to 15 3/4; ASA Ltd. was off 5/8, to 44 3/8, and Hecla Mining was off 1/4, to 13 3/4.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index added 0.07, to 394.43, while in over-the-counter trading the Nasdaq composite index rose 1.34 points, to 480.66.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metal Prices Fall After Late Surge in Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of precious metals futures slumped yesterday in a disappointed reaction to the dollar's late surge in value against other leading currencies. Energy futures retreated, coffee futures fell again and grains and soybeans were mixed. Livestock and meat futures were also mixed. 
Gold futures settled $3.60 lower across the board on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in October at $363.40 an ounce. It was the biggest daily move in gold prices since Sept. 25, but the market did not fall out of its recent trading range. Silver was 8.2 cents to 9.3 cents lower, with December delivery at $5.243 an ounce.
The precious metals closely followed the action of foreign currencies, which rallied against the dollar early in the day only to end lower as the dollar advanced.
The early rally was set off by the decision of West Germany's central bank to raise two important interest rates a full percentage point, forcing other European countries to follow.
 
Crude Supplies Reported Ample
Heating-oil futures fell sharply and most other energy futures declined on the New York Mercantile Exchange, partly in reaction to reports indicating ample supplies of crude oil and refined products.
The Department of Energy's weekly inventory report showed larger-than-expected increases in American stocks of crude oil and gasoline. In addition, a monthly report from the International Energy Agency indicated that OPEC nations were producing crude oil at levels substantially higher than the 20.5-million-barrel ceiling set last month.
Coffee futures dropped to 14-year lows on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, but losses were limited by signs that negotiators of the International Coffee Organization were making some progress toward a new price-support agreement. After the market had closed, the group's governing council passed a resolution to negotiate a new pact.
Corn futures prices rose moderately in active trading on the Chicago Board of Trade amid rumors of new Soviet purchases of American corn. Soybean futures retreated and wheat futures finished mixed, with no fresh export sales seen.
Hog futures rose sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on expectations for higher cash prices. The rally lifted pork-belly futures and near-month live cattle futures, but feeder cattle prices retreated.

HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE EDGES UP TO 5.2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Factory employment took its biggest drop in nearly seven years in September as the nation's unemployment rate edged up one-tenth of a percentage point, to 5.2 percent, the Labor Department reported today.
Although analysts said the latest figures may overstate the decline in manufacturing, there was widespread agreement that the industrial sector is nearly stagnant.
The Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Dr. Janet L. Norwood, said the decline of 105,000 in factory jobs last month was most disturbing and noted that the weakness was widespread, with 16 of the 20 principal manufacturing industries reducing jobs.The loss of factory jobs since March, when growth halted, now totals 135,000. 
 
Big Fluctuation in Auto Industry
About one-third of the decline in factory jobs in September came in the automobile industry, where employment has fluctuated widely in recent months as producers sought to hold down inventories. That drop of 33,000 jobs at auto plants led to a 1.2-point jump in the unemployment rate in Michigan, where many of the plants are, to 8.1 percent from 6.9 percent.
In all, 119,158,000 Americans were employed last month - 117,456,000 civilians and 1,702,000 members of the armed forces stationed in the United States. The Labor Department's survey of households found that the total number of people employed fell by 127,000 last month while the labor force increased by 36,000. The ranks of the jobless thus swelled by 163,000, to 6,584,000, for an unemployment rate of 5.2 percent.
The unemployment rate for civilians only also edged up one-tenth of a point last month, to 5.3 percent.
 
New York's Rate Rises
In New York State, the unemployment rate rose sharply last month, going up four-tenths of one percentage point, to 5.4 percent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. New Jersey's unemployment rate was essentially unchanged, at 4.6 percent.
Over all, there was a rise of 209,000 in jobs as measured by the Labor Department's separate survey of business payrolls. That increase included the return of 75,000 workers, most of them at telephone companies, who had been on strike in August. The August gain, meanwhile, was adjusted downward to 88,000 from the 110,000 first reported, with manufacturing accounting for two-thirds of the revision.
 
Easing of Credit Is Possible
The employment growth was on the lower end of what had been expected, a weakness that many analysts thought would be likely to nudge the Federal Reserve toward an additional easing of credit. But there were enough pluses in the report to allow the Federal Reserve to hold off on such a move, to await new data, like the producer price index to be reported next Friday.
A typical view was that of James D. Blumenthal, a director of BNY Securities, who suggested that any immediate cut in interest rates would reflect efforts to hold down the dollar in world currency markets rather than to head off any looming recession.
''It does give them the window if they wanted to cut rates for dollar reasons,'' he said.
Practically all of the rise in unemployment was among people seeking to re-enter the labor force after seasonal idleness or other absence.
 
Companies Not Adding Workers
''A lot of companies made a decision not to add workers as they usually do'' in September, said Thomas J. Plewes, a senior Labor Department official. There were five weeks between the August and September surveys instead of the usual four. Some analysts said the extra week might make the job data look a bit stronger, but Mr. Plewes said he could see no effect.
While the percentage of manufacturing companies adding workers was less than 35 percent last month, the lowest since November 1982, the news was not entirely grim. The length of the factory workweek edged up six minutes, to 41 hours, just short of the record for that measurement, and factory overtime climbed the same amount to 3.8 hours.
Continued long workweeks and large amounts of overtime are generally regarded as signs of eventual job gains.
Jobs in business services increased by 45,000 last month, the biggest jump in a year and a half, and health services posted a similar increase. There was a rise of 95,000 in government employment, mainly because of an increase of teachers at the beginning of the school year that was greater than usual. Construction jobs were unchanged, and employment slipped a bit in the mining industry.
The New York State rate of 5.4 percent was the the second highest this year. The highest was 5.8 percent in May.
''At the three-quarter mark, 1989 is shaping up as a year of significantly higher unemployment in New York,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics. ''The New York economy is shifting to a considerably slower track than earlier in the 1980's.''
''Finance, trade and construction industries are either growing more slowly or not all this year,'' he added. ''Service-related industries are the only areas where there is growth last month.''
There were 8,182,000 people employed in the state in September, while 467,000 were unemployed, In New Jersey, the unemployment rate of 4.6 percent was virtually unchanged from the August rate of 4.5 percent, and the total number of people holding jobs remained constant at about 3,800,000. There were 186,000 people without jobs last month.
Slight gains in the service and financial industries have been offset by declines in the wholesale and retail trade in New Jersey, leading to the steady unemployment rate, Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
Today's report also showed these trends:
* A further decline, to 815,000 from 869,000, in the quarterly tabulation of discouraged workers who have given up looking for work because they think they cannot find it.
* Increases of five-tenths of 1 percent, after declines in August, in the average hourly and weekly earnings of production workers.
* A further climb, to 37.3 percent, in the unemployment rate for black teen-agers after it fell to 27.4 percent in July.
Of the 11 biggest states, nine had increases in their jobless rates, but the only one of statistical significance was Michigan's rise to 8.1 percent from 6.9 percent. The only significant improvement was the 1.2-point decline, to 6.3 percent, posted by Texas.
The Northeast, Midwest and West had modest increases in unemployment, while the South, where the level remains the highest, had a modest decline. Unlike the national figures, these are not adjusted for seasonal variation.
