HEADLINE: ISRAELIS REJECT CAIRO'S PROPOSAL ON MIDEAST TALKS

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 6

 BODY:
The Israeli Government today rejected an Egyptian proposal to convene preliminary Palestinian-Israeli talks in Cairo as a way of breaking the deadlock in stalled efforts toward peace.
Officials from the Labor Party, the junior partner in Israel's governing coalition, said the move thwarted the diplomacy of peace and could lead to a Government crisis in Israel. They said the United States must overcome its reluctance to intervene formally in peace efforts with new proposals acceptable to Labor and the dominant Likud party.
In Washington, Bush Administration officials said they saw the rejection as a temporary setback in efforts to organize a dialogue. They said the Israeli deliberations were marked by confusion over an Administration proposal for talks involving Israel, Egypt and the United States to break the present impasse. [Page 4.] 'Rejection of Mubarak's Proposal' 
''I believe that the decision today by the Cabinet is a great missing of an opportunity to allow the peace process to go ahead,'' Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of the Labor party said in an interview in Tel Aviv after the Cabinet meeting.
''For all practical purposes, it is a rejection of Mubarak's proposal to bring about a meeting between an Israeli and a Palestinian delegation,'' he said, referring to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. Asked if the dispute between Labor and Likud could bring down the coalition, he said, ''It's one of the possibilities.''
Since Thursday, the inner Cabinet of 12 senior ministers, six from Likud and six from Labor, has been meeting to consider President Mubarak's invitation to Israelis and Palestinians to meet for discussions on elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
 
Dispute on Palestinian Delegation
At Thursday's session, Labor proposed that the invitation be accepted, but a vote at today's meeting produced a tie, meaning under Cabinet rules that it was rejected.
One of the central points of dispute within the Cabinet is the makeup of a Palestinian delegation, which Egypt proposes to name. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud leader, says a delegation appointed by Cairo would be no more than a surrogate of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Israel outlaws all contact with the P.L.O., which it deems a terrorist group, and refuses to negotiate with it.
On Thursday, Likud officials said Mr. Shamir was ready to consider a compromise proposal that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was said to have made when he met Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of the Likud party in New York on Sept. 27. According to the Likud account, Mr. Baker suggested that the makeup of a Palestinian delegation be negotiated in a three-way discussion involving Israel, the United States and Egypt.
Labor Party officials said Mr. Arens was challenged on Thursday to produce the Baker proposal in writing and did not do so today.
 
U.S. Role Sought by Israelis
Mr. Arens told reporters that Labor had refused to wait for the American proposal to arrive. ''Instead of waiting for the proposal, they insisted on holding a vote when they knew beforehand they couldn't carry their proposal and I can only explain it on narrow party interests, not out of concern for peace or Israel's interests,'' he said.
Describing how events unfolded, Mr. Rabin said: ''We asked him to bring the American proposal of Secretary Baker and today we were told that he had not succeeded in bringing it about. And the Prime Minister said we have to continue the discussion on the basis that there is only one proposal.''
Labor thus faced a choice ''either to take back or to ask not to make the voting, or to vote,'' he said.
Mr. Arens said, ''I think if the proposal is presented as Mr. Baker presented it to me, it will be carried in the Cabinet.''
Labor has also indicated readiness to accept the American proposal, reinforcing the view that Labor and Likud want the United States to be drawn directly into the peace effort to overcome an impasse in Israeli politics that is compounded by divisions within Likud.
A factor in Likud's opposition to the Egyptian plan is the reality that Labor would probably face a difficult time at the polls if it chose to bolt the coalition now and force new elections. The poor state of the economy, and not the peace process, would likely be the dominant issue in elections, and Labor is seen as vulnerable because its leader, Shimon Peres, holds the Finance Ministry.
 
Revolt and Election Proposal
In the interview, Mr. Rabin drew parallels between the close involvement of the Carter Administration in negotiating peace between Egypt and Israel in the late 1970's and the absence of new Middle East initiatives from the Bush Administration.
The last major American initiative in the region took place 18 months ago, when George P. Shultz, who was then Secretary of State, toured the region.
There was no immediate reaction to the Israeli decision from Palestinian leaders here, who said earlier this week that they viewed the Egyptian proposal for negotiations in Cairo as a possible way of unlocking the peace effort.
For the last 22 months, Palestinians in the occupied territories have challenged Israeli dominance with an uprising that has claimed more than 700 lives, most of them Palestinian.
The revolt prompted a general Israeli proposal in May for elections in the occupied territories to choose Palestinians to negotiate limited self-rule, and the Egyptian proposal that Palestinians and Israelis hold direct talks to work out terms for holding the elections.
 
Cairo Plan's Unresolved Issues
The P.L.O. and many Arabs have dismissed the Israeli proposal because it offers too few potential political gains. Now Israel has rejected the Egyptian proposal because Likud sees it as a cover for talks with the P.L.O.
The Egyptian invitation left several issues unresolved. It did not, for example, insist that the Palestinian-Israeli talks be held on the basis of a 10-point list of principles that Cairo has offered as a blueprint for holding elections and negotiations on a peace settlement, Government officials said.
Those include demands that Mr. Shamir rejects, notably the idea that Israel trade occupied territory for a peace settlement.
The Israeli Government has not formally responded to the 10-point Egyptian list and sees the points only as a statement of Cairo's position, the officials said.

HEADLINE: We Need Many More Computer Scientists

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Bush Plan Would Aid Computing,'' (Business Day, Sept. 8) offers a useful discussion of ''The Federal High Performance Computing Program'' report and of the related Gore-Jeffords bill.
But, while only about 250 Ph.D.'s in computer science were awarded in 1985, and this number was little higher in the preceding decade, studies conducted by the Computing Research Board show that since 1985, this figure, and the figure for computer engineering, have been increasing, not decreasing. For example, Computing Research Board data show more than 500 Ph.D.'s in computer science awarded in 1988.
Yet, despite the 1985-88 increase, current Ph.D. production does not meet current needs, much less projected needs. For example, the computing report calls for more than 1,000 Ph.D.'s in computer science by the mid-1990's. The information industry even now accounts for more than 10 percent of our gross national product. At the same time, very few faculty members in computer science and engineering programs in four-year colleges have Ph.D.-level training in computer science or engineering.
Thus, even the target of 1,000 Ph.D.'s is probably too low to meet the needs of industry and academia.
The increase in Ph.D.'s in computer science and engineering in the mid-1980's grew out of improvements in the universities' computing research infrastructure. Rapid development and modernization of our computing research infrastructure is essential if we are to attract and train the students, at all levels, that this country needs to maintain its primacy in computing.
 
PAUL YOUNG
Chmn., Computing Research Board
 Washington, Sept. 14, 1989

HEADLINE: To Be Young and in China: A Colloquy

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
The poem seemed to express an individual yearning, a personal agony only tenuously related to the pro-democracy slogans recently heard in China. But Wuer Kaixi, the 21-year-old exiled student leader who read his short verse at a public meeting in lower Manhattan on Wednesday night, said it reflected the inner life of the student uprising, its wellsprings in alienation and thwarted idealism. The verse goes: I pour my heart out to the white cloud, I, the homeless wanderer. O, float back to my native land And drop the tears I shed for my mother.
Mr. Wuer was among several Chinese student leaders, writers, poets and American scholars at the meeting sponsored by American PEN, the organization of writers that promotes free expression. The ostensible subject was the struggle for human rights in China. But many simply spoke of China's contemporary youth culture, using it to explain the forces that pushed thousands of young Chinese to risk their lives confronting troops during the recent upheaval in Beijing. 
Several themes emerged. One, discussed by Mr. Wuer and other student leaders, was that the students who occupied Tiananmen Square in Beijing in May and June were very different from their elders; they are of a generation, influenced by Western ideas, that is restive under the weight of China's tradition of obedience and insistent on sexuality and feelings.
 
The Favorite Word Is No
Mr. Wuer compared traditional Chinese culture and what he called its complete negation of the individual and patterns of well-defined hierarchical personal relationships with the emerging youth culture of China, with its stress on immediacy, sensation and the self.
''In recent years Chinese college students have been rebellious against all sorts of authority,'' he said. ''The favorite word among the youth in China is No.''
''You might find it strange, but I do not,'' he said, ''that one aspect of our movement was the student who stood naked on top of a university building shouting, 'I am what I am.' '' But because the preoccupation with who they are is ''totally contradictory to the reality of our system,'' Mr. Wuer continued, young people are ''lost and disoriented.'' They seek identity and consolation in part from the songs and poems that Mr. Wuer described as the cultural accompaniments to the political movement.
Among the most popular songs is one that begins ''I am a wolf from the north'' and then describes a kind of lonely wandering through a desolate land, a wandering full of longing and nostalgia for ''that beautiful prairie'' that is, it seems, a land of unfulfilled dreams.
Mr. Wuer said volumes could be written to explain the sensibility behind the words of that song and why it appealed so strongly to young Chinese. The image of the wolf, a lonely, isolated creature, is an uncomfortable one in the context of Chinese culture, with its stress on the family and the group. The song, which could be heard playing on hundreds of little tape recorders during the students' two-month occupation of Tiananmen Square, was an expression, he said, both of the students' despair and of their idealism. The students found meaning in the image of the lonely wanderer trapped in a bitter, empty landscape. They dreamed at the same time of something better.
 
Greater Sexual Freedom
Mr. Wuer's remarks and those of other student leaders now in exile in this country led a Western participant, Robin Munro, a reasearcher on China for Asia Watch, to talk of a ''political economy of libido moving from a primitive to a more advanced stage'' among China's young people.
Mr. Munro was speaking of remarks by some student leaders that the experience of greater sexual freedom was an important part of the democracy movement. The students gave no details, but they seemed to be describing an element in Mr. Wuer's notion of increased attention to the self, one not all that different from the sexual liberation experienced by students in the United States during the protests of the 1960's.
In the past, Mr. Munro said, the sexual energy of Chinese students had been channeled by Chairman Mao Zedong into a frenzied, proto-fascist worship of himself, particularly during the Cultural Revolution of the late 1960's and early 70's. This time, he said, the youthful libido found an entirely different expression, in both a new exaltation of selfhood and in political outrage at the conservative gerontocracy bent on imposing its values and its will on its children.
And that, in turn, was related to another issue arising at the colloquium: whether China's hostility toward greater freedom is embedded in the nation's traditional culture or whether it is something that comes from 40 years of Communist rule.
 
The Effect of Tradition
Jonathan Spence, a historian of China who teaches at Yale, enumerated aspects of the Chinese tradition that seemed to explain the country's modern-day dictatorial nature and the violent suppression of the democracy movement in June. Specifically, he said, there has long been a tradition of protests by intellectuals against immoral leaders and an even stronger tradition of repression, all of which was played out in Beijing this year.
''China has never been able to come up with a concept of a loyal opposition,'' he said. ''For 3,000 years, the authorities have tried to keep people from getting together and speaking freely.''
A different view was offered by Su Wei, a writer and critic who escaped from China in June. Mr. Su said that the last 40 years had imposed on China a ''Communist Party culture,'' which, he said, is similar to the culture of underground organizations. Each person, he said, has to answer to the Communist Party, or, more specifically, to one of the Communist Party warlords, since the party itself is divided into factions.
''That's where you get your culture, your identity,'' Mr. Su said. ''It's very similar to the society of the Mafia.''
Thus, in Mr. Su's view, China's present circumstances are more a product of this ''Communist culture'' than they are of tradition. One result of the Communist culture, he said, has been ''the systematic destruction of the most brilliant in China.'' The ''best and the brightest,'' those who show independence of spirit, are crushed, leaving behind ''the most retarded, the most dictatorial, and the most moronic.''
Moreover, the methods used by the cultural authorities have given rise to new and malevolent cultural traditions, Mr. Su said. He identified these as the tradition of lying, the tradition of threat and the suppression of memory.
''This is what we have to fight against,'' he said. ''It is a culture dominated by the party that has suppressed free thought and is sustained by lies, by threats and by a requirement to forget.''

HEADLINE: Panama Opposition Chief in Refuge in Vatican Mission

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Oct. 6

 BODY:
The leader of Panama's democratic opposition has taken refuge in the Vatican diplomatic mission here, diplomats and supporters said today.
The opposition leader, Guillermo Endara, sought temporary asylum on Thursday night after soldiers ransacked his offices and briefly detained him and a dozen associates.
Several times earlier in the day, Government agents in civilian clothes fired in the air and prevented visitors from entering the political headquarters.
While the soldiers were tossing furniture, files and telephones around the storefront headquarters, thugs with clubs chased journalists away, stealing cars, equipment and money from several of them and beating a photographer for The Associated Press. 
 
Crackdown by Noriega
Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, outlined a campaign against his enemies in a speech Thursday, apparently in reaction to a failed coup attempt on Tuesday and to an effort by the opposition to further cripple him economically. He assailed the United States for supporting the coup attempt and asked, ''How can we have a democracy when we're under such pressure?''
Opposition leaders said they believed that General Noriega moved against Mr. Endara, who was the apparent winner of the presidential election in May, to force an end to a hunger strike that he started on Sept. 20. The opposition leader was trying to dramatize opposition calls to Panamanians to delay paying taxes and utility bills and to stop spending money in Government-run casinos and the national lottery.
It was not clear whether Mr. Endara had interrupted his strike, but General Noriega succeeded, at least, in preventing him from continuing the protest in public view on a hospital bed behind the plate glass windows of the downtown headquarters.
As the United States has been trying to bring down the general with political and economic pressure, it has been lauding the opposition.
 
Visited by Bush Aide
Last Saturday, Everett Briggs, a former Ambassador to Panama and now a special assistant to President Bush for national security, flew here to visit Mr. Endara.
''I came here to greet a great person,'' Mr. Briggs told reporters later, ''the president-elect, the person who should be president of the country, the person who will be president of the country. He is a person that we Americans and the entire democratic world recognize as the real representative of the great people of Panama.''
Some Western diplomats said they believed General Noriega was trying to drive Mr. Endara out of the country. But many of Mr. Endara's backers said they did not expect a great increase in pressure against the democratic opposition. Instead, they said they expected him to direct his ire mainly at soldiers and Government employees he regards as disloyal.
Some of General Noriega's closest military aides turned against him in the coup attempt. While the gun battle for control of the Government was under way neither Francisco Rodriguez, the general's hand-picked President, nor any other senior Government official demonstrated support for their leader.
In fact, at midday, when the rebels announced that they had toppled the general, parties reportedly broke out in some Government ministries, and in some offices, official portraits of the general were gleefully ripped down.
 
Planning to Lie Low
Guillermo Cochez, a former member of the House of Representatives and now a prominent opposition figure, said the opposition was planning to withdraw into the background as General Noriega carried out his purge and to concentrate mainly on rallying international pressure against the regime.
''We have to wait until this action plays itself out,'' he said. ''To provoke them now would be a stupidity. The main obligation of the political opposition now is not to be arrested, to keep a low profile.''
Mr. Endara was freed from custody Thursday night through the intercession of Tomas Lozano, the Spanish Ambassador, according to a spokesman for the Spanish Embassy.
The spokesman said that the Ambassador had telephoned President Rodriguez to request Mr. Endara's release and that within an hour the opposition leader was handed over to Msgr. Jose Sebastian Lavoa, the Vatican's senior diplomat in Panama.

HEADLINE: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
While cocaine has dominated public concern about drug use, alcohol remains the drug of choice among suburban teen-agers, like those in Westchester County.
Drinking remains more prevalent among high-school seniors than among adults, national surveys show, and many experts believe alcohol has become a cornerstone of high-school life.
Mention crack, and Kim Bulger, an animated 17-year-old from Rye Brook, N.Y., frowns disapproval. Mention beer, and she brightens. ''Everyone drinks,'' she said. ''We drink to get drunk. It's fun.'' Substance-abuse experts say that many teen-agers appear to have embraced alcohol as the one safe drug, and that their drinking comes almost as a relief to parents terrified of crack. 
 
'Given Up the Battle'
''It's unfortunate, but to some extent we have, as a society, given up the battle to get students not to drink,'' said Abby Hirsch, a guidance counselor at Hastings High School in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and adviser to the high school's chapter of Students Against Driving Drunk, known as SADD.
''In fact,'' she said, ''one of the problems with SADD is the implicit admission that students do drink.'' The group has chapters in 15,000 high schools and 4,000 junior high schools across the nation.
The concern about alcohol has risen despite surveys showing that the percentage of students who drink has fallen, in line with a decline in the general population. This decline comes after years of school anti-drinking programs, and after the last state with a drinking age of 18 returned it to 21. New York did so in 1985.
But those who work with young people now are concerned that alcohol is so rooted in the lives of teen-agers - as it is in the lives of many of their parents and society at large - that complacency about teen-agers' drinking will only grow as people become more intolerant of deadlier drugs.
''This has taken a backseat to hard drugs, but in our community and in the suburbs generally, teen-age drinking is by far our biggest problem,'' said William Shuluk, a police officer who monitors the activities of minors in Dobbs Ferry, on the Hudson River.
The street drugs common across the border in sections of New York City do have a grip on the few urban pockets in Westchester, but educators, law-enforcement officials and young people say crack and most other narcotics are rarely seen in the suburbs, whether modest or wealthy.
''Beer is the way you get high,'' said Dr. Robert Mackin, the principal of Fox Lane High School in Bedford, an affluent town in northern Westchester. ''If you see any peer pressure among the kids as it relates to drugs and alcohol, it is against using hard drugs.''
Weekends for many teen-agers revolve around drinking beer - whether from kegs or bottles, in parks or kitchens, with or without parents present. And today, it is not uncommon for elementary-school students to begin experimenting with alcohol.
Westchester is not unusual. Across the United States, alcohol eclipses all other drugs tried by high school students. According to a survey by the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan, 64 percent of 16,300 high school seniors surveyed in 1988 had drunk alcohol in the last month, compared with 18 percent who had smoked marijuana and 1.6 percent who had smoked crack.
Westchester, a county of 890,000 people, has, like many large suburbs, long waged a campaign against underage drinking.
 
'To Rebel, to Defy - to Drink'
Yet there is a growing sense among the campaigners that, while they may be able to prevent drunk students from climbing behind the wheel of a car, they cannot prevent them from becoming drunk in the first place.
''What's part of the adolescent stage of development is the need to rebel, to defy authority - to drink,'' said Larry Posner, a supervisor of Student Assistance Services, a nonprofit Westchester organization fighting student substance abuse. ''So I don't think we can eliminate it. That would be a fantasy. But we can try to control it.'' The county's greatest effort in recent years has centered on reducing drunken driving by teen-agers. About half of the 35 school districts have ''Safe Rides'' programs in which sober students drive intoxicated ones home from parties on weekend nights. Two thirds of the high schools have SADD chapters, and a course emphasizing the dangers of drunken driving has reached 20,000 students.
The efforts have not been restricted to Westchester's high schools. This year, a county-financed program on substance abuse for all sixth-graders was extended to the fifth grade. And in its third year is a mini-course for parents called ''Talking to Your Kids About Alcohol.'' Student Assistance Services furnishes 36 high schools and 17 middle schools with counselors specializing in drug and alcohol abuse.
 
'Current Drinkers' Decline'
In cities and towns across the country, anti-drinking campaigns may be producing positive results. Drug experts are buoyed by the steady decline in the last decade in students who say they are ''current drinkers'' - meaning they have had at least one drink in the last month. Surveys by the Institute for Social Research of high school students in their senior year show that alcohol consumption among them peaked in 1980, when 72 percent of students were ''current drinkers,'' compared with 64 percent last year.
But those same experts caution that 64 percent is still a lot. Furthermore, high school seniors are out-drinking the general adult population. Of 4,214 adults ages 26 and over surveyed last year by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, 55 percent said they had had at least one drink in the last month.
Surveys show that seniors have been out-drinking the population as a whole at least since 1972, the year the Institute began surveying them.
Excessive ''binge'' drinking is an even greater concern: more than a third of the high school seniors said that in the last two weeks, they had had had five or more drinks in a row.
 
'Who Can Pass Out First?'
''For some people, the idea is to see who can pass out first, or who is left standing,'' said Leonard Lombardi, a senior at Byram Hills High in Armonk, who said he goes to parties but rarely drinks. ''Everybody huddles around the keg and watches each other. It sounds stupid, but that's the half of it.''
''You just have a better time in general if you're drunk,'' said Karen Pellicone, 16, a junior at Port Chester High School. ''But it's really not true,'' she added, laughing, ''because half the time, the next morning, you can't even remember all the fun you had.''
Why do students drink? Teen-agers and adults point to a number of reasons: peer pressure, alcohol's general availability but alluring illegality to them, and its glamorous portrayal in advertisements. Some students say it relieves boredom, helps them relax, makes them feel sexy and gives them confidence in social situations.
 
'One or Two a Total Mess'
Some students interviewed scoffed at the legal drinking age, noting that most European countries let teen-agers drink and contending that most students they knew were able to handle alcohol. ''The laws are absolutely ludicrous,'' said Jordan Copeland, 16, of Hastings-on-Hudson, who said he drank in moderation at parties.
''There's always one or two people at parties who are a total mess,'' he said. ''But the majority are in complete control. And they watch out for those one or two and drive them home at the end of the night.''
By and large, students do not drink during the school week, and with the legal drinking age at 21, bars are out of bounds. But come the weekend, practically every town has at least one underage party, indoors or out.
''Each town has its place - the park in Dobbs Ferry, the woods in Hastings, the beach in Rye,'' said Ellen R. Morehouse, the executive director of Student Assistance Services, adding that fake identification cards, older siblings, friends and even parents all help teen-agers obtain beer, wine coolers and, to a much lesser extent, hard liquor.
 
'From Rye to Yonkers'
Unlike crack, which is confined mainly to poor urban neighborhoods, alcohol seems to cut across Westchester's socio-economic lines. ''The problems of alcohol abuse exist across the board, whether it's rural North Salem, suburban Rye or inner-city Yonkers,'' said Larry Posner, a supervisor of Student Assistance Services.
Drug experts and students say that in middle-class towns marijuana seldom circulates at parties now, and cocaine may be reserved for special occasions, like birthdays and graduation. LSD has made a minor comeback recently, but harder drugs, especially crack, are generally shunned.
''Drugs is nowhere near as popular as beer,'' said a 15-year-old Hastings High School junior and member of the SADD club and varsity soccer team, who requested anonymity. ''I don't think anybody in the school uses crack. Students joke around about it. But look at the effects of crack - you take it once and you're addicted. That's one good reason not to take it.''
Substance-abuse specialists say that the lack of compelling social choices for teen-agers is in some measure to blame for teen-agers' drinking. ''It's not as easy as saying, 'Okay, let's play Parcheesi,' '' Mr. Posner said. ''And it's partly the responsibility of adults to come up with alternatives, to acknowledge the fact that their children are bored and lonely and going through the hell of adolescence.''
 
Some Ground Children, Some Buy
Educators say parents play a vital role in shaping their child's attitude toward drinking. But in Westchester, parental response covers the spectrum. There are parents who ground their teen-agers caught with beer and object to Safe Rides because they feel it encourages drinking. Then there are parents who provide alcohol.
''I know parents who actually go out and buy a keg or beer-ball for their kids, set it up and just leave,'' said Mr. Lombardi, the high school senior.
Laws in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and many other states hold parents liable if a minor has a car accident after drinking in their home. It is also against the law in those states for an adult to sell or give alcohol to minors who are not their children.
But for many parents, drug experts say, there is sometimes a sense of relief that their children are dabbling in beer and nothing harder. ''When confronted, parents often say, 'Well, at least my child's not using crack,' '' said Ms. Morehouse.
''The attitude seems to be, 'So what if my kids drink on weekends so long as they get A's in school?' '' she said. ''But what's really important in life is not whether they get an A in physics, but that they learn to flirt, handle boredom, be intimate and socialize without the crutch of alcohol.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Five Exchanges Weighing Move To Jersey City

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The five commodity exchanges in New York, outgrowing their space in the World Trade Center, are considering moving to Jersey City and are talking to municipal officials on both sides of the Hudson River to see which could provide a better package of tax breaks and other inducements.
The exchanges, now in cramped quarters at 4 World Trade Center, provide jobs for 5,000 people, with 15,000 more indirectly involved. The exchanges pay tens of millions of dollars annually to the city and state, directly or through employees' taxes, exchange officials said. 
Z. Lou Guttman, chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the largest of the five, told reporters visiting the exchange yesterday, ''There's a premium we're willing to spend to stay in New York, but it's not a big premium.'' The reporters had gathered for a lunch to introduce the new president of the exchange, R. Patrick Thompson.
 
'Very Concrete Proposals'
Mr. Guttman said that the exchanges had considered seven sites and now had one prime site in lower Manhattan, a secondary site in that area and a prime site in New Jersey, which, he said, was less than 10 minutes from Manhattan by mass transit. Without naming Jersey City, said, ''The New Jersey entity is starting to make very concrete proposals.''
Officials in New York and Jersey City confirmed that they were discussing inducements with the exchanges. New York has programs to provide property-tax breaks, low-interest construction loans and other benefits. A spokesman for Jersey City, Roger Jones, said his city would stress a lower cost of doing business and the availability of land and workers.
The other exchanges are the Commodity Exchange Inc., the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, the Cotton Exchange and the New York Futures Exchange, which is affiliated with the New York Stock Exchange.
The Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Stanley E. Grayson, said that New York had discussed offering inducements to the exchanges, but that they had not agreed among themselves exactly what they wanted to build or what kind of partnership they would form to do that. The five are independent, but have formed an organization to lease the space they occupy and handle housekeeping.
 
Collapse of 1985 Plan
The exchanges are scheduled to vote next month on how to proceed.
In 1985, the exchanges and the city agreed on the construction of a $500 million 56-story office building and adjacent 11-story trading space at the ramp of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. But after the stock market crashed, the Mercantile Exchange withdrew, and the deal fell through.
Mr. Guttman said the exchanges would like to build a $175 million to $225 million structure, with a trading floor of 55,000 to 60,000 square feet, unencumbered by columns, and a second area of equal size on a different floor, for future expansion. The exchanges would like to break ground next year and move by 1993, he said.
The exchanges' trading floor now is 25,000 square feet.
Robert W. McGrath, a spokesman for the Commodity Exchange who is designated to speak for the five exchanges, said the group was having ''discussions with the appropriate entities'' and was analyzing which sites would work financially and functionally.
''Before you can get to specifics of who can make the best offer, you have to look generically at what's there,'' Mr. McGrath said. The exchanges, he added, were considering what was needed for construction and what help was available.

The Economy
 The Senate worked toward a deal that may give President Bush the permanent reduction in the capital gains tax that he promised in the 1988 campaign. The deal would provide for a vote in both houses within weeks. In exchange for the scheduled vote, Senate Republicans offered to end their efforts to attach a capital gains tax cut to a deficit-reduction package. [Page 1.] The nation's jobless rate edged up one-tenth of a percentage point, to 5.2 percent, in September. Factory employment took its biggest tumble in nearly seven years, a drop the Commissioner of Labor Statistics called ''most disturbing.'' Analysts said the latest figures may overstate the decline in manufacturing, but there was widespread agreement that the industrial sector has slipped into near stagnation. Bond prices rose in response to the unemployment news, because it raised the possibility of lower interest rates, and stock prices rose. [1.] Some companies, individuals and a Government agency are crafting a new breed of what have been called anti-viruses to hunt down disruptive software in computer systems. But the anti-viruses may themselves cause problems. [1.] The campaign for pay equity for women may be sputtering to a halt in the courts after a decade of defeats. But the movement has brought workers in several states multimillion-dollar pay upgrades at the bargaining table. HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Resilient Dollar Up Slightly Despite Efforts to Rein It In

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar rose slightly yesterday, despite efforts once again by the United States and its economic allies to rein the currency in.
The resilient dollar also shook off the September unemployment report, which showed a rise in joblessness to 5.2 percent, indicating that the economy is weaker than had been thought.
Despite this rally - and the rise Thursday in the face of European interest rate increases - some traders and economists said the United States and its allies in the Group of Seven are doing better in controlling the dollar than may be apparent from day-to-day movements.
This view contends that the policy makers' goal is to keep the dollar below 2 marks and 150 yen until the Federal Reserve decides it can lower interest rates - a move that would be expected to push the dollar lower. 
''They are trying to keep the dollar from exploding to a much higher level,'' said Peter Rona, president of the IBJ Shroder Bank and Trust Company in New York. ''But they are not trying to prevent it from rising.''
Traders said they would have expected the combination of widespread dollar selling and the jobs report to push the dollar lower. The Federal Reserve, the Bundesbank and the Bank of Japan sold dollars in Asia overnight. Other central banks joined the intervention in Europe, and the Fed sold dollars in New York.
Some analysts said the employment report could mean the Federal Reserve might ease interest rates before the end of the year, which would be sooner than generally expected. A decline in interest rates here, most traders said, is needed to knock the dollar lower.
After dropping initially on the report, the dollar rose through the day. It briefly passed the important 1.90 level against the mark but fell back in the face of intervention. By the end the day it had lost some of its steam as traders in New York sold dollars to square up their books ahead of the three-day Columbus Day weekend.
But the dollar still ended higher, at 1.8883, up from 1.8845 Thursday. The 1.90 level is believed to be the ceiling that the United States and its economic allies in the Group of Seven have set for the dollar. The ceiling for the yen is 140, and while the dollar moved further above that yesterday, ending at 142.43, up from 142.40, it was down from the day's high of 143.61.
Nicholas Sargen, director of bond research at Salomon Brothers in New York, said the dollar managed to rise after the unemployment report ''because the foreign exchange market is expecting that the Fed will be cautious'' and not move to lower interest rates until it has more proof that the economy has slowed down.
He said that the market's general expectation was that next week's inflation report would show that the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, which declined four-tenths of 1 percent in August, would rise five-tenths of 1 percent. Such an increase would make the Fed, which is very worried about inflation, cautious about lowering interest rates, he said.
The dollar rose on Thursday after a coordinated round of interest rate increases in Europe, which normally would have knocked it down. This move was the lastest step in the effort to push the dollar lower. Two weeks ago the Group of Seven issued a communique in Washington saying the dollar was too high. Since then, the central banks of the leading industrialized democracies have used coordinated intervention to push the dollar down from 1.95 marks and 146 yen.
Mr. Rona said that he did not believe that the underlying economic support for the dollar was enough to push it above 2 marks and 150 yen, where it was earlier this summer.
Mr. Sargen said part of the demand for the dollar now was a result of the G-7's effort to knock it down. He said the aggressive intervention had also driven down bond prices. This meant that foreigners had seen both attractive prices for bonds and a lower dollar. But he expects that the G-7 can keep a cap on the dollar and prevent it from hitting new highs.

HEADLINE: AMR Likely to Rely on Stake for Workers

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The AMR Corporation's most likely response to a $7.5 billion takeover bid by Donald J. Trump would be to move about a fifth of its stock into an employee stock ownership plan, investment bankers and lawyers said yesterday.
Such a move would make it difficult for Mr. Trump or anyone else to complete a hostile takeover, because AMR, the parent of American Airlines, is incorporated in Delaware, where the law makes it difficult to finance an acquisition unless at least 85 percent of the target company's stock is obtained.
An authority on employee stock ownership plans, known as ESOP's, Mario Baeza of the law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton in New York, spent yesterday at AMR's headquarters in Fort Worth. Mr. Baeza, who did not return telephone calls seeking comment, has been helping AMR prepare its takeover defense for the last few weeks. In late August, Mr. Trump filed a Hart-Scott-Rodino report of his intention to buy more AMR stock. 
 
Some Defensive Buying
AMR shares climbed $3.875 yesterday to close at $103.75 on the New York Stock Exchange, on trading volume of 3.9 million shares. Although some speculators were buying, some institutions were making defensive purchases, said an arbitrager who asked not to be identified.
''Aggressive money managers can't run the risk of not having this in their portfolios in case it turns out to be good,'' he said. Such sentiment is especially strong because many money managers were skeptical about Marvin Davis's bid for the UAL Corporation in August and were slow to buy shares in the target company, the arbitrager said. The board of UAL, the parent of United Airlines, ended up approving a lucrative $300-a-share bid from the company's management and employees, a price nearly double the stock's level before the Davis bid.
The arbitrager added, however, that he was doubtful that Mr. Trump's interest would lead to a similar buyout of AMR.
If AMR does not adopt an ESOP, an investment banker with experience in airline deals said, alternative takeover defenses include selling a stake of 15 to 25 percent in the company to a foreign airline, selling or refinancing assets and subsequently declaring a special dividend and issuing special securities that would multiply and be hard to buy in a hostile tender offer. But others said all of these moves would have drawbacks for Robert L. Crandall, AMR's highly regarded chairman and chief executive.
Selling a large stake to a foreign airline would create an influence to rival Mr. Crandall's on the board and could be stalled by the Department of Transportation, they said. Asset sales and payment of a dividend would impair the ability of Mr. Crandall, who is fiercely competitive, to expand his airline at the expense of other carriers. And the issuance of special securities might antagonize the money managers whose support Mr. Crandall needs if Mr. Trump seeks to have Mr. Crandall replaced by using the ''consent solicitation'' clause in AMR's charter.
Mr. Trump could take advantage of the terms of that clause, which provides for the replacement of management by a majority vote of stockholders, if AMR puts 20 percent of its stock in the presumably friendly hands of its employees. But Mr. Trump is initially seeking a friendly transaction, said Jack H. Nusbaum, a partner of Willkie, Farr & Gallagher who is advising Mr. Trump.
''You would never start out with a consent solicitation,'' Mr. Nusbaum said. ''That's an option down the road.''
 
Bar to Self-Interest
Delaware's anti-takeover legislation bars a buyer of less than 85 percent of a company's shares from carrying out ''self-interested'' actions for three years. These include merging the acquired company with his own so that the acquired company's earnings can pay off debt incurred in the acquisition.
''He can replace the board, but he's still disabled from using the assets,'' said a lawyer who asked not to be identified. ''That's the way the Delaware statute really gets someone like Trump.''
A consent solicitation effort would require Mr. Trump to obtain a list of AMR's shareholders, which could mean a lengthy lawsuit, and then to wage an intensive telephone and mail campaign to persuade them that Mr. Trump could put in place a better management team than the current one. That might be difficult given investors' high regard for Mr. Crandall, two money managers said.
 
'We're Very Impressed'
''We're very impressed with what Robert Crandall has done with that organization,'' said Dale M. Hanson, chief executive of the California Public Employee Retirement System, which holds nearly 1 percent of AMR's stock.
Among the managers that Mr. Trump could propose might be the five executives who recently said they would leave Northwest Airlines, effective Oct. 15. Steven G. Rothmeier, the chairman and chief executive, and John F. Horn, the president and chief operating officer, both declined to comment yesterday, as did the other three executives.
A long takeover battle could turn into a test of wills that might go badly for Mr. Trump, several Wall Street executives said. ''Crandall is a beast,'' a money manager said. ''Crandall's going to have him for breakfast.''
 
Investment Bankers Line Up
Mr. Crandall appears to be well prepared. He retained two investment banks, Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers, in August to draft takeover defenses. He spent much of August and September lobbying in Washington to curb highly leveraged transactions in the airline industry and he has just returned from a two-week trip to Europe that included conversations with executives at European airlines, people close to Mr. Crandall said.
There is much at American Airlines to attract Mr. Trump. The airline is growing fast, has many strong hubs, little debt and would fit well with the Trump Shuttle, which Mr. Trump purchased from Eastern Airlines in June.
Combining the shuttle with American's international route structure would substantially increase business and profits on both, said L. John Eichner, an airline economics consultant who became head of strategic planning at American in 1961, right after Eastern started its shuttle. ''My very first assignment was how do we compete with the shuttle,'' he said. ''And we never did figure that out.''
 
UNION SEEKS TO HELP
 FORT WORTH, Oct. 6 (AP) - The head of American Airlines' second-largest union met with legal and labor advisers today to discuss possible ways to help management fend off the buyout proposal from developer Donald J. Trump.
Michael Kelleher, president of the 16,000-member Association of Professional Flight Attendants, was notified of the offer by management early Thursday. He talked with the advisers today in New York ''to prepare contingency plans in light of any events that may transpire,'' said Alan Fahringer, a spokesman for the independent union.
Officials of the other unions at American were not available to discuss the matter. Labor relations at the airline are widely considered to be good.

HEADLINE: Borrowing Rate Up 6% For August

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Americans took out $3.48 billion more in consumer debt than they retired in August, the Government reported today.
In July, Americans had reduced their debt for the first time in two and a half years, but analysts had said they did not expect that situation to continue. July's decline was the first since January 1987, when consumer debt fell $1.63 billion, or 3.4 percent. 
''We really haven't become a nation of big savers,'' said Sandra Shaber, an economist at the Futures Group in Washington. ''People aren't tearing up their credit cards.''
The Federal Reserve Board said that consumer credit in August increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6 percent, compared with July's revised decreased rate of nine-tenths of a percent. The initial July report said consumer credit had fallen five-tenths of a percent.
The August debt rebound was expected because of strong sales of 1989 automobile models brought on by incentives and by price increases for the 1990 models. Auto loans, which fell 6.9 percent in July and 2.3 percent in June, grew by $400 million in August, or 1.7 percent at an annual rate.
The debt category that includes credit cards rose by $3.57 billion in August, resuming a 22.5 percent annual rate of increase. It had risen only 8.9 percent, to $1.41 billion, in July, down from a 20.1 percent increase in June.
Consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of all economic activity, is watched closely as a sign of economic health, particularly in light of efforts by the Federal Reserve to contain inflation by slowing the economy.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose by $158 million, a 1 percent annual rate of growth. That compared with a 1.1 percent decline in July.
Mobile home debts fell $656 million, to a 33.3 percent annual rate of decline. This category has fallen for seven consecutive months, including a July drop of $56 million, or 2.8 percent.
The various changes left total consumer debt in August at a seasonally adjusted $703.8 billion.

HEADLINE: Fed Left Rates Unchanged At August Policy Meeting

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Policy makers at the Federal Reserve decided to leave interest rates unchanged in late August, after a period earlier in the summer when they were nudging rates lower, according to minutes of the meeting released today.
The Federal Open Market Committee voted, 10 to 1, at its Aug. 22 meeting to make no changes in interest rates although it issued a directive that leaned toward easing credit if the economy weakened.
''For the period ahead, a steady course was desirable in light of the latest evidence suggesting that price pressures were not intensifying'' and the economy was continuing to grow at a moderate pace, the committee said. 
The Federal funds rate - the interest rate most closely watched for signals of Fed policy decisions - fell to 9 percent by late July from 9.75 percent in early June as the central bank eased credit amid signs of widespread weakness in the economy.
 
 Funds Rate Hovers Near 9%
 Since then, however, various indicators show the economy was not so weak as previously feared, and the Fed has made no further moves to ease credit conditions. The funds rate, the interest banks charge each other to make overnight loans, has hovered near 9 percent for the last two months.
The Open Market Committee, composed of Fed governors in Washington and five of the 12 Fed regional bank presidents, met again on Tuesday. The minutes of that meeting will not be released until after the next Open Market Committee meeting on Nov. 14, but private economists said they believed that the central bank had again decided to leave its credit policy intact.
The Labor Department reported today that the unemployment rate rose to 5.2 percent in September as manufacturing employment took the biggest one-month nosedive since the end of the last recession. But Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company, said he believed that it would take more signs of weakness than one month's unemployment report to convince the Fed to loosen credit further.
Roger Guffey, president of the Kansas City regional Fed bank, cast the only dissenting vote at the Aug. 22 meeting, arguing that inflation remained at unacceptably high levels.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 11.96, to 2,785.52, on Job Data

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Buoyed by an unexpected increase in unemployment for September and a sharp decline in factory jobs, blue-chip stocks rose to another record yesterday.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 11.96 points, to 2,785.52, as advances on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded declines by 780 to 667. Volume on the Big Board fell to 172.5 million shares, from 177.9 million shares Thursday. 
For the week, the Dow rose 92.70 points. The rise was the Dow's best weekly advance since it soared 114.86 points in the May 31-June 3 span in 1988.
Traders said fixed-income Treasury issues also advanced sharply on the belief that the information on jobs - unemployment rose one-tenth of 1 percent, to 5.2 percent, in September - would prompt the Federal Reserve Board to ease credit soon.
 
S.&P. 500 Up 1.81, to 358.78
 In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.81 points, to 358.78, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index edged up 0.89, to 198.94.
''For the week, the market gained more than 90 points, which hasn't happened more than a few times in the last decade,'' said Joseph H. Barthel, senior vice president and director of investment strategy at Hopper Soliday & Company in Philadelphia.
''Both the dollar and bonds have staged a rather remarkable rally in the face of what appeared to be negative news,'' Mr. Barthel said, such as the financial problems of the Campeau Corporation, the raising of German interest rates and the strong intervention of central banks to curb the strength of the dollar.
He said that although Wall Street was braced to buy on expected weakness, the market's failure to respond to bad news had caused cash-rich institutions to ''chase strength.''
Paramount Communications, which rose 3 3/4 Thursday amid speculation that it was considering a merger with a Japanese concern or that it might be acquired by Metromedia Inc., rose 5/8 yesterday, to 62 5/8.
 
Oil Stocks Strong
 Oil stocks rose broadly on the strength of Chevron's 1 1/4-point advance, to 66. Analysts said the company's stock was lifted by continued speculation that it might be restructuring. Elsewhere in the group, Kerr-McGee climbed 2 1/8, to 51 1/8; Phillips Petroleum 7/8, to 27 1/4; Texaco 1 5/8, to 53 1/4; Mobil 2, to 59 3/4, and Exxon 5/8, to 45 3/8.
AMR jumped 3 7/8, to 103 3/4, in response to Donald J. Trump's offer, announced Thursday to buy the company.
Among active issues, General Electric rose 1/2, to 58 7/8, and Bristol-Myers gained 1/4, to 54.
USX led the active list, up 1/8 to 38 1/2, on a volume of nearly 4.9 million shares. Late Thursday, the investor Carl C. Icahn said he had raised his stake in the company, apparently confirming recent rumors that he was increasing pressure on the company.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index rose 1.50 points, to 395.93, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index rose 2.98 points, to 483.64.

HEADLINE: For Airline Industry and Public, Tars Signal a Major Change

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Takeover fever has gripped the airline industry, bringing major changes in ownership, giving employees new power and attracting outsiders with new visions of how carriers should be run.
But the trend, which intensified last week with Donald J. Trump's $7.5 billion bid to gain control of American Airlines, is loading carriers with debt and giving foreign airlines a chance to gain a foothold in the domestic market. It is also leaving some major airlines much more vulnerable to an economic downturn, which could lead to reductions in service and raise concerns about safety.
With Mr. Trump's offer for the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, three of the nation's largest carriers - American, United Airlines and Northwest Airlines - have become embroiled in takeover attempts or buyouts since last spring. The three represent almost half of the nation's airline seats. And industry analysts say Delta and USAir, which are profitable and dominant in their markets, could also become targets. 
''It's incredible,'' Paul Karos, a longtime airline analyst, said last week after hearing of the Trump bid. ''When is it going to slow down?''
The recent activity reflects a new attractiveness of the airlines, which have long been considered a glamour industry. Investors see a chance for a quick killing on undervalued assets and stocks, while visionaries want to redefine air travel and exploit its potential.
Mr. Trump, for example, is attracted to American, as he has been to acquisitions like the Plaza Hotel and the Eastern Shuttle, not only by the potential to make a lot of money but also by the prestige of the industry and owning what is considered a premier carrier.
 
No Spinoff Is Planned
''I would not spin off anything,'' Mr. Trump said in discussing his bid. ''I wouldn't want to do anything to change it. I would just continue what's been happening.''
On the other hand, Alfred Checchi, a former Marriott executive who led a group of investors in a buyout of the NWA Corporation, parent of Northwest, last month, said he planned to find new ways to keep people occupied while they are in airplanes.
''Air travel is going to be redefined,'' Mr. Checchi said in a recent interview, explaining that technology has opened up all kinds of new ways to entertain and inform fliers and to get them to try new products.
The airline industry has not always been so attractive. Deregulation in 1979 led many investors to shun the industry because the resulting uncertainty and change made it appear too risky.
This turmoil, which has still not ended for some carriers, was exemplified by financial troubles at carriers like Eastern Airlines and Braniff Inc., labor turmoil at Continental Airlines and mergers that disrupted carriers like Northwest. In addition, the low-cost carriers, like People Express, were unable to become viable forces.
But this upheaval has left a smaller number of larger, more powerful carriers, and as a result, the industry has been able to raise fares and make it more difficult for business travelers to use discount fares. Industry profitability has jumped and caught Wall Street's attention.
''There is a perception that the industry will be more stable and that it has created a better pricing discipline than has existed in the past,'' Mr. Karos said.
 
Concern in Washington
A central issue raised by the takeover wave is whether the industry, which at first resisted deregulation but has adjusted to many of the new freedoms, may find itself being put under more Government control.
The takeovers have also left some carriers, like Northwest, heavily indebted, under top managers who have little experience in the airline business and with a big portion of their stock owned by foreign airlines. Both the Bush Administration and Congress have expressed concern about the carriers' financial condition and the extent of foreign investment.
The Trump bid for American prompted members of Congress to renew calls for the speedy passage of legislation to require prior approval of such deals.
On Thursday, the Senate Commerce Committee approved its version of legislation that would require the Transportation Department to review airline takeovers in advance. And on Friday, a bill was introduced in the Senate that would increase competition among the nation's air carriers by forcing them to sell their computer reservation systems and give small airlines more flights at big airports.
In the case of Northwest, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner has gotten Mr. Checchi to agree to cut back the amount of equity put up by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines in the takeover. The Secretary said he was concerned that foreign carriers could begin to exert too much control over major domestic airlines.
Curbs on investment by foreign airlines would also affect the acquisition of United's parent, the UAL Corporation, by the airline's pilot union and management, with the help of British Airways P.L.C. The deal would give employees 75 percent ownership of the airline and a major role in long-term decisions.
 
Marvin Davis's Role
One catalyst for the recent takeover activity was Marvin Davis, the California investor who bid for Northwest and United.
Mr. Davis said he was attracted by hidden values at the two airlines. Both had placed large orders for new planes, which could then be leased at much higher prices, greatly aiding repayments to banks that were asked to put up billions of dollars in financing for the takeover effort.
Another catalyst is jockeying by European carriers to form alliances with American carriers to help the Europeans compete when many of the European Community's restrictions on airlines are lifted by 1992. In the UAL deal, British Airways put up $750 million of the $1 billion in equity. Thus the investors had to risk a relatively small amount of their own money.
But the takeover wave is only part of a major change facing the airline industry.
Frank A. Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, has put Continental up for sale, and Eastern, another Texas Air unit, could face liquidation if it fails to revive under protection of Federal Bankruptcy Court.
Thus the remaining large, strong carriers could end up with major pieces of Mr. Lorenzo's empire, which represents about 15 percent of the industry's carrying ability.
 
Mixed Results for Consumer
And just last week, Braniff filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code for the second time in seven years, reflecting the hazards for smaller airlines that try to grow too quickly to stay competitive.
For the consumer, the trends could lead to mixed results.
''It can cut both ways,'' said Alfred E. Kahn, one of the main founders of deregulation and now a professor at Cornell University.
Alliances between foreign and domestic carriers, he said, could result in increased competition on domestic routes that will keep fares lower.
But alliances like the British Airways-United one could reduce competition on international routes, since they could inhibit domestic and foreign companies from challenging each other in markets like the trans-Atlantic one.
The need to repay the banks for the expense of takeovers could also put much greater pressure on the industry to raise fares.
 
Fares and Fringe Benefits
Lee Howard, an airline industry consultant in Washington, said that since the industry has shrunk to about six major carriers that control more than 90 percent of the traffic, it is in a much better position to control prices.
He said he expected major carriers to continue their efforts to limit business travelers' use of lower discount fares. He also expected the industry to further tighten restrictions on discount fares, like making some low fares nonrefundable if the buyer does not use the ticket for the flight he has booked.
On the other hand, Mr. Howard said, as fares rise, airlines will again have to provide more amenities and better service, like more convenient flights, to attract customers.
Mr. Kahn expressed another worry: If a sustained recession occurs, the airlines that have heavy debt and high interest costs will face great pressure to cut back on service and maintenance.
''They will be so heavily leveraged that even a mild recession could start to cause them to cut down on all sorts of operations,'' he said. ''This could end up in a major curtailment of service.''

HEADLINE: Forest Project Called Peril to New Jersey

BYLINE: By RICHARD SEVERO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TUXEDO, N.Y., Oct. 2

 BODY:
Two members of Congress from New Jersey and a water delivery expert warned today that the proposed development of 19,000 acres of Sterling Forest in southeastern Orange County could imperil the drinking water for two million residents of northern New Jersey and make them more vulnerable to floods.
The warnings were issued by Representatives Margaret S. Roukema, a Republican, and Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, and by Dr. Ella F. Fillipone, executive administrator of the Passaic River Coalition, an association of organizations that manage water supplies in North Jersey. They delivered their testimony at a daylong hearing conducted in Tuxedo Town Hall by Representative Peter H. Kostmayer, Democrat of Pennsylvania, who is chairman of the oversight subcommittee of the House Interior and Insular Affairs Committee.
The hearings were held because the forest's owner, the Ambase Corporation of Manhattan, wants to develop the pristine area, which has long been prized for its trails and wildlife. 
Robert E. Thomson, chairman of the Sterling Forest Corporation, a part of Ambase, told the hearing that development by his company would not transform the whole forest into a suburban development, but said the details have not been decided. His company is preparing a master plan for n the forest which it plans to make public next spring.
 
Peril to Reservoirs
The New Jerseyans said that their state's two most critical water supply reservoirs, Wanaque and Monksville, are fed by waters that drain from Sterling Forest. ''We cannot afford to have massive amounts of siltation, lead, chlorides, pesticides and fertilizers pollute the rivers, streams and creeks which enter New Jersey from New York State,'' said Dr. Fillipone.
Dr. Fillipone also warned that overdevelopment in Sterling Forest might increase the risk of floods in the central Passaic River Basin. Sterling Forest contains some 21,000 acres of land in all, 2,000 acres of which are in New Jersey and already in the control of Passaic County.
Mr. Torricelli warned that New York State should not permit Orange County to repeat the mistakes made in the massive development of North Jersey. In recent years, Orange County has been the fastest-growing in the state and one of the fastest-growing in the nation. Mr. Toricelli said that because New Jersey permitted overdevelopment years ago, $1 billion is now being spent to correct flooding problems that development in the forest could make worse.
 
Debate on Taxes
Michael J. DiTullo, president of Orange County Partnership, an economic planning organization, said that proper development of Sterling Forest would help the county's tax base. In the last five years, he said, 30,000 new jobs had been created in the county. ''As we begin the last decade of the century,'' Mr. DiTullo said, ''Orange County must strive to be a world-class competitor.''
But other environmentalists said they feel that the competition to lure business sought by Mr. DiTullo would destroy the rural qualities that made the county attractive to newcomers in the first place. They also disagreed with his assertion that more development would lead to lower taxes.
John A. Humbach, who is a dean at Pace University and chairman of the Sterling Forest Coalition, an environmental group, cited a recent study conducted by the Cornell Cooperative Extension of Dutchess County and the American Farmland Trust. The study showed that for every dollar in taxes generated by farmland a town must spend 21 cents in services, while residential properties require $1.36 in services for every tax dollar they generate.
''Open space uses of land actually subsidize the local tax base,'' he said, ''and urban sprawl is literally killing the geese which lay the golden eggs.''
 
A National Problem
Christopher J. Dunleavy, executive director of the Orange County Chamber of Commerce, acknowledged that he did not want to see the region go the way of North Jersey or Nassau County, but said that careful development could satisfy both economic interests and those who would prefer to see the land remain open.
Town officials from Tuxedo and Warwick, which also contains a portion of the forest, said that they would be in favor of very selective development, but would oppose any massive projects that would cause congestion.
Mr. Kostmayer said the fight over Sterling Forest was symptomatic of a national problem. He said that between 70 million and 100 million acres of open space have been developed nationwide since the end of World War II and that''we are still losing open space at the rate of about 5,500 acres a day.''
During the hearing, officials from New York State said that they lacked money to buy the forest. Mr. Kostmayer later suggested a possible Federal role, and said he planned to ask the National Forest Service to conduct a study on the effect of development of the forest.

HEADLINE: HOME OWNERSHIP FOUND TO DECLINE

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Home ownership declined in the 1980's for the first time since World War II, Senator Lloyd Bentsen said today, citing high prices and high interest rates.
''In the decades following World War II you saw home ownership continue to climb, but in the 80's it headed downhill,'' said Mr. Bentsen, Democrat of Texas. The reasons, he said, included higher housing costs and higher interest rates. 
Mr. Bentsen introduced a study by George Tyler, a senior economist for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, finding that home ownership peaked at 65.6 percent of the population in 1980 and then began falling, to 63.9 percent last year.
The study found home ownership had fallen dramatically in the youngest age groups. In 1973, 23.4 percent of people under the age of 25 owned a home. In 1988 the rate was 15.5 percent.
Among other groups of the relatively young, the situation was similar: 43.6 percent of 25- to-29-year-olds were homeowners in 1973, falling to 36.2 percent in 1988. For the 30- to-34-year-old group, 60.2 percent owned homes in 1973, dropping to 52.6 percent in 1988. And in the 35-to-39 bracket, the rate fell from 68.5 percent in 1973 to 63.2 percent in 1988.
 
Using I.R.A.'s for a Home
The study was performed at the request of Mr. Bentsen, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, who is pushing for Congress to extend tax deductions for contributions to individual retirement accounts. Those deductions were sharply restricted in the tax overhaul voted by Congress three years ago.
Under Mr. Bentsen's proposal, I.R.A. contributions could be withdrawn without penalty for the purchase of a first home or for education expenses, in addition to retirement purposes.
Mr. Tyler's study found that housing affordability is determined by several factors, including tax policy, income growth and housing prices.
Rising house prices are reflected particularly in down payment requirements, the study said. In this decade alone, the average down payment for first-time home buyers has risen more than 50 percent, from $8,600 in 1981 to $13,000 in 1988.
The other major hurdle to home ownership is interest rates, the study said.
The interest cost alone for a 30-year mortgage for $100,000 at a fixed-rate of 6 percent, the prevailing rate in the 1960's, would have been $115,841, with a monthly house payment of $600. At 9 percent, the prevailing rate of the mid-1970's, the total interest cost would have been $188,810, with the monthly payments $802.
But at 10.5 percent, the prevailing mortgage rate today, that interest cost would be $229,306 - nearly double the interest cost off a 6 percent mortgage, and monthly house payments would be $915.

HEADLINE: Senators See Some Progress On Cut in Capital Gains Tax

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
White House negotiators and the Senate Republican leadership bargained with Senate Democrats today, seeking a firm date for a vote that could give President Bush a permanent cut in the capital gains tax.
''The major sticking point is giving us a fair shot on capital gains,'' the Senate minority leader leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, told reporters as negotiations on a complex budget and tax deal entered their second day.
The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, said, ''There is no agreement, but we are making some progress.'' He and Mr. Dole said late in the day that they were encouraged enough to resume discussions Sunday.
 
It Seemed Close Friday
When negotiations ended Friday evening, senators in both parties said they were close to a deal. As the senators met in a rare Saturday session today, Democrats and Republicans were jockeying for tactical advantage. Republicans, who lost a vote on a capital gains cut in the Senate Finance this week, would like to bring that measure to the floor without having to overcome parliamentary and procedural obstacles. 
Mr. Mitchell said that he was not prepared to relax Senate rules to accommodate them. ''I am not going to participate in a process that exempts certain measures from the procedures from the Senate,'' he told reporters.
The deal, first proposed by the Senate Democratic leadership Thursday night, would strip extraneous spending and tax measures from a $13 billion deficit reduction package that is awaiting action in the Senate. Democrats want to pass the budget by Oct. 16 to avoid automatic cuts in most Government programs provided under the budget-balancing law.
In exchange, Republicans would agree to drop their efforts to attach a permanent capital gains tax cut proposal to the package, and Democrats would agree to allow such a tax cut proposal to be offered on other legislation.
 
Futile 'Arm-Twisting'
Under special parliamentary rules that apply to the deficit package, Republicans have to muster 60 votes rather than a simple majority to attach their capital gains cut plan. Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Finance Committee, told reporters he was ''two to three votes'' shy of that number despite what he described as ''lots of arm-twisting'' by Mr. Bush.
 
The Magic Number Is 51
But Republicans would need only 51 votes to attach the capital gains cut measure to other legislation, a number they say they think could be reached easily with help from at least some of the dozen Democrats who favor reducing the capital gains tax. But Republicans risk the possibility that Democratic opponents of a capital gains tax cut would mount a filibuster, in which case 60 votes would again be needed to shut off debate.
Today's negotiations centered on Republican efforts to minimize that risk. The Republicans would like to offer their capital gains cut proposal as an amendment to a bill that temporarily extends the ceiling on the national debt, and they would like that measure to be put before the Senate next week.
Republican leaders are wagering that senators who might be willing to filibuster an ordinary piece of legislation, or even the deficit reduction package, would be unwilling to filibuster essential legislation like a debt ceiling bill. The current debt ceiling is expected to be reached by the end of the month.
 
Democrat For Long-Term Way
''We're willing to take our chances on a filibuster,'' Mr. Packwood said. ''We think we would have the votes of those who would filibuster on a deficit package, but would not filibuster on a debt bill.''
Concerned about precisely that situation, Democratic leaders have argued that Republicans should attach their capital gains tax cut to a long-term debt ceiling bill that will come before Congress at the end of the month.
Republicans preferred the short-term measure because they believe they have a better chance of winning the capital gains fight if they can buy some time in which to debate it. They say that waiting for the long-term bill has little appeal because they would have been able to make that effort anyway, without special negotiations.
''The Democrats think we're asking for an advantage and giving up nothing,'' Mr. Packwood said.
The fight over a capital gains tax cut has dominated the Congressional budget process since the beginning of the year, when Mr. Bush made clear that he intended to keep his election campaign pledge to try to permanently lower the rate. Capital gains, essentially the profits on the sale of stocks, bonds, real estate and other such investments, are currently taxed at the same rate as ordinary income: 15 percent, 28 percent or 33 percent.
 
Benefits for the Wealthy
Mr. Bush proposed lowering the rate to 15 percent over all, touching off protests from Democrats who argued that such a reduction primarily benefits only the wealthiest taxpayers and that it would violate the principles of the 1986 tax reform law. Under that law, preferential treatment for capital gains was eliminated so that all tax rates could be lowered.
Mr. Bush has maintained that reducing the tax on capital gains would stimulate investment and economic growth and generate additional revenue for the Treasury. Democrats agree that cutting the capital gains tax rate initially would generate new revenue as investors sell their assets to take advantage of the lower rate, but they argue that over time, the capital gains cut would be a revenue loser.
As Senators shuttled today between the offices of Mr. Dole and Mr. Mitchell to discuss the latest offers, the fate of the deficit reduction package that started all the bargaining remained uncertain. The House last week approved its version of the package, which includes a temporary reduction in the capital gains tax. Mr. Mitchell said the Senate would take up its version on Thursday with or without a deal on the capital gains tax cut and removing the extraneous tax and spending measures.
The House and Senate packages include dozens of new spending programs and tax breaks that Congressional leaders would like to see removed so that the legislation can be returned to its original deficit reduction purpose.
 
'A Fluid Discussion'
The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, who briefly attended the negotiating sessions this morning, has long favored stripping the deficit package of these extraneous measures. Republicans say the Speaker would like to avoid another separate House vote on the capital gains issue and has discussed a strategy that would repackage the temporary cut the House has already approved in the short-term debt bill.
As he left the negotiations, Mr. Foley characterized the situation as ''a fluid discussion without any agreement on any serious, major point.''
If the two sides reach a final agreement on capital gains, they will still face the major hurdle of deciding which provisions in the big House and Senate deficit packages are actually extraneous. In addition to assorted tax breaks, both bills include such things as child-care legislation, a popular provision to repeal a law prohibiting discrimination against lower-wage workers in employer-paid health benefit plans and an increase in the limit on earnings by Social Security recipients.
''Extraneous is like obscenity,'' Mr. Packwood said. ''It's in the eye of the beholder.''

HEADLINE: Bush Gets Bill on Timber Sales

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The Senate sent to President Bush today legislation that would allow sales of timber from Federal forests in the Northwest while protecting the habitat of the spotted owl.
The lumber provisions were part of an $11.2 billion spending bill for land and cultural programs to which the Senate gave final Congressional approval by a vote of 91 to 6. Mr. Bush is expected to sign the measure for the fiscal year that began last Sunday. 
Disputes over logging on Federally owned tracts in the Northwest have occurred for years. Environmentalists argue that rare spotted owls and the virgin forests they inhabit must be preserved, while timber interests and others say cutting the trees creates jobs and helps the region's economy.
The Federal Fish and Wildlife Service is considering whether to declare the spotted owl an endangered species. Such a declaration would require Federal agencies to protect the habitats of the species, which are in forests that are centuries old.
The compromise legislation reduces to 9.6 billion board feet the amount of timber from the region's Federal forests to be sold this fiscal year.
