HEADLINE: Noriega's Party Proposes Laws to Punish Dissent

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The political party controlled by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has proposed a sweeping set of 16 laws aimed at identifying and punishing Panamanians who do not actively support his military rule.
The new laws, proposed by leaders of the Revolutionary Democracy Party after a meeting on Friday, appeared to be directed primarily at eliminating dissent among the large number of Government employees.
During a coup attempt last Tuesday, workers in several Government offices were seen celebrating General Noriega's overthrow before learning that he had defeated the rebellion and was again in control. 
Party officials said other new laws in the package, whose precise provisions have not yet been made public, would also impose restrictions on national news organizations and tighten Government control over transportation, private enterprise and the registration of foreign agents working in Panama. Party members said the laws would be promulgated by executive decree.
The laws were proposed a day after General Noriega, in an angry, defiant speech to Government employees in the city of Santiago, called for a sweeping crackdown on his opponents and urged Government employees to expose traitors in their ranks.
In a message that has resonated ominously in the tense atmosphere after Tuesday's aborted coup, the military leader declared what he called in Spanish a policy of ''the three P's'' -''palos,'' or truncheons, for the undecided; ''plomo,'' or bullets, for his enemies, and ''plata'' or money, for his friends.
Speaking to reporters at the party meeting late Friday, leaders of the Revolutionary Democratic Party said they interpreted the General's words as a clear mandate to purge the Government ranks of any suspected dissidents.
The party leader and former presidential candidate, Carlos A. Duque, declared that he had ordered the immediate dismissal of any Government functionaries suspected of disloyalty to the party, and warned state workers that the Government would permit them to have no connections to other political groups or movements.
''In the ranks of the Revolutionary Democratic Party and the Dignity Batallions, there are many unemployed people who could take the place of these seditious elements, who definitely have no place in our republic,'' Mr. Duque said. The Dignity Batallions are large, loosely organized units of armed civilians that have incited street violence against opposition leaders and demonstrators, and that General Noriega has described as a weapon against a possible invasion by United States troops.
Leaders of the Panamanian political opposition made no direct comment on the new laws.
Guillermo Endara and Ricardo Arias Calderon, who won election as president and vice president, respectively, in national elections this year that were later anulled by General Noriega, remained in hiding today after a group of armed men in civilian and military dress ransacked their headquarters late Thursday.
But other political opponents of General Noriega described the new measures less as a means of augmenting the military Government's punitive powers, which are already subject to few if any restrictions, than as a psychological tool for instilling fear and promoting orthodoxy among Government workers.
After early reports that the coup attempt against General Noriega had succeeded, witnesses said, several large Government offices here took on a holiday atmosphere in celebration of the military leader's demise.
''Everybody was thrilled,'' said one man, who asked not to be identified. ''Everybody had stopped working, and started dancing with a bottle in their hand.''
But the celebration soon turned to chastened silence as rebel radio communiques were replaced by official declarations that General Noriega was still in control. And the General's strident address on Thursday is now believed to have sown deep anxiety among thousands of Government workers.

HEADLINE: Casualties Of a Truce In Angola

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAMBA CAJU, Angola

 BODY:
Just before dawn a couple of weeks ago, peasants in this languid town in Angola's central highlands were awakened by singing and chanting. Then, without warning, the shooting began.
Townspeople say 15 unarmed peasants were killed and at least 40 wounded in the fighting, which they say came during a sweep by United States-backed guerrillas fighting Government troops who control the region.
Supplied mostly by the United States and South Africa, the guerrillas of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, are fighting to overthrow Angola's Marxist Government. The Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola has governed since the nation gained independence in 1976. The Government forces are armed by Cuba and the Soviet Union. 
The fighting here on Sept. 17 came nearly three months after a cease-fire between rebel and Government forces. Since then, each side has accused the other of violating the truce and each has returned to the battlefields with a vengeance. The rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, and the Angolan President, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, have issued conflicting interpretations of the cease-fire agreement reached in Gbadolite, Zaire, on June 22.
 
Sweeps Through Remote Towns
In the war, taking place in a country without reliable transport or communications, soldiers from both sides have been accused of periodically sweeping through remote towns they consider hostile, sometimes killing and kidnapping as they rampage.
The massacre here in this town of several thousand about 180 miles east of Luanda was one of the most gruesome outbreaks of violence in the region, which has seen heavy fighting, since the civil war began 14 years ago. Twice before, in July 1985 and January 1986, rebel troops swept through the town, sacking houses and shops. The raid last month, however, was of an entirely different magnitude, townspeople say. The rebels not only assaulted unarmed civilians, but sabotaged the community's economic infrastructure.
Virtually every house and shop along the main thoroughfare now stands empty, some abandoned after rebel bombs crashed through the orange tile roofs.
A two-room medical clinic, serving 60,000 people, was completely destroyed.
 
Villages Cut Off From Food
The regional power plant was split open by a bazooka. Down the road, two old Portuguese administrative buildings and a warehouse for coffee and food were burned.
On the outskirts, the landscape is pockmarked by dozens of burned huts. Outside one of them, a woman cowered in a ragged sack with her 2-year-old son, a child with a distended belly and dull eyes. They had not eaten for several days.
A report made public in April by Africa Watch, a human-rights organization, said thousands of Angolan civilians had been killed by land mines, by indiscriminate attacks and by starvation. The report also said attacks by both sides had violated international codes of war through the 14 years of fighting.
The Africa Watch report, however, was especially critical of Unita. When short of rations, the report said, Government soldiers steal from the fields of peasants, as does Unita. But the report accused Unita of deliberately encircling and ''strangling'' villages by insuring that there is no access to food, which ''means virtual starvation for the civilians in those area.''
 
Singing, Chanting and Machetes
The scope of the Africa Watch investigation was limited, however, because representatives of Africa Watch were not allowed to interview victims of the war inside Angola. Unita officals have denied the accusations, saying most civilians killed in guerrilla areas are either caught in a cross fire or are legitimate targets killed while taking part in guerrilla military operations.
Angolan Government officials offered a tour for Western reporters to Samba Caju, site of a four-hour battle, saying it was the first time such a group had been seen the results of sustained fighting since the cease-fire began. Armed Government troops were in the area and present during the interviews, but reporters were allowed to roam the town freely and talk with any of its residents.
The townspeople spoke angrily of the damage done by Unita forces, who a Government guide said had numbered from 1,000 to 1,200.
The townspeople said the events began before dawn on Sept. 17, when groups of rebels, some singing and chanting and banging machetes against the sides of their trucks, arrived in the town.
 
'The People Started Running'
One of the townspeople is Esperanca Antonio Camoes, a 23-year-old woman who was wearing black clothes in mourning for her husband and a child.
''On the morning of the attack, we were all sleeping,'' she said. ''And we started hearing mortars and shots and shooting. And the people starting running. I had my baby on my back, and was holding my other baby in my arms.
''And I was running and running, and came to a river, and when I was running in the river, I tripped and fell, and when I fell, the baby in my arms hit his head on a rock, and he died.''
Mrs. Camoes said her husband, Antonio, was shot in the back. ''He fell on the ground,'' she said, ''and they started hitting him with machetes.''
Another townsperson, Maria Domingo Couveia, 25 years old, recalled first hearing ''laughing and chanting and singing'' and then the gunfire.
''I was very afraid, and started running, and I didn't realize that my mother wasn't able to escape.'' she said.
Her mother and brother, who was blind, were asleep when the raid began.
''My mother ran out of the house, and my brother was holding onto her, and they shot and killed them both,'' she said.

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
Rejoice! It's Independents' Day

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby

 BODY:
Alternative commercial cinema lives. Among other things, the box-office success of Steven Soderbergh's independently produced ''Sex, Lies and Videotape'' is proof that there is vibrant life outside of the Hollywood establishment.
Though ''Sex, Lies and Videotape'' is scarcely avant-garde, it is not a result of consensus movie making. It's a first film by an amazingly talented, self-assured young (26-year-old) director who came out of (in Hollywood terms) nowhere in May to win the grand prize at the Cannes Film Festival.
Variety reports that since the film's July opening in this country, ''Sex, Lies and Videotape'' has earned an estimated box-office gross of nearly $16 million. The same Variety chart reports that ''Batman'' has earned approximately $245 million. When one considers the $1.6 million production cost of ''Sex, Lies and Videotape'' against the $50 million reported for ''Batman,'' then the Soderbergh film was a better investment. 
That sort of figure juggling isn't quite fair. It doesn't take into account all of the subsidiary income that ''Batman'' has earned and the residual income that will continue to come in. However, it does emphasize the fact that idiosyncratic, independent directors, working on Poverty Row budgets, can make films that are first-rate and in touch with audiences.
These independents don't give audiences what they want. They give them what they don't yet know they want.
Possibly the most invigorating news to come out of the 27th New York Film Festival, which closes tomorrow night with Bill Forsyth's ''Breaking In,'' concerns the interest of commercial distributors in acquiring the theatrical rights to Michael Moore's ''Roger and Me,'' a feature-length documentary. A feature-length documentary? In the syntax of Mr. Moore, who sometimes sounds like a folksy cracker-barrel Marxist, with a little bit of Barnum thrown in, you heard right, son.
One might suspect that the distributors who are reported to be so keen on the film, or, at least, so keen on looking at it, are out of their minds. With a handful of exceptions, documentaries are what open in theaters on Friday and turn up on public television 10 days later.
''Roger and Me'' is not only a documentary, it's also a documentary about economic depression and emotional dislocation, which are usually gritty subjects even for public television.
Yet the audiences that saw ''Roger and Me'' first at the Telluride Film Festival, at the Toronto Film Festival and, finally, at Lincoln Center, have come out of the screenings buoyed up. The good feeling is not at the expense of the unemployed of Flint, Mich., who are the subject of the film.
It's the result of attending to the on-screen personality of Mr. Moore, a former journalist (briefly the editor of Mother Jones magazine) who shares with Mark Twain the singular gift of being able to make common sense sound pricelessly funny. Also like Twain, Mr. Moore is biased, pessimistic, not strictly fair and, in this age of submission to consensus, nearly always a tonic.
Mr. Moore comes out of the tradition of American radicalism associated with the history of the Middle West, which gave us the farmers' Granger Movement (in Minnesota) and Wisconsin's Senator Bob La Follette, the Progressive Party's Presidential candidate in the 1924 election.
At a time when we've been told that space is the last frontier, Mr. Moore is a frontiersman whose territory is Flint, the birthplace of General Motors and where he was born and bred of men who had always worked for G.M.
''Roger and Me,'' Mr. Moore's first film, is very much the sort of first-person narrative that, had it been written in the 19th century, would have been told in phonetically spelled dialect that today's readers find nearly incomprehensible. It purports to be a record of the multiple failed attempts of a plain ordinary little guy (Mr. Moore) to reach Roger Smith, the chairman of General Motors. Mr. Moore wants to take Mr. Smith on a personally escorted tour of Flint, to show him the terrible consequences that have resulted from the closing of various G.M. operations there. According to the film, the city of 150,000 has lost 40,000 jobs, many, we are told, to G.M. facilities in Mexico, where the labor is cheaper. The only Flint citizens working overtime today are postal workers executing change-of-address requests.
Wearing jeans, a down jacket and a baseball cap, with a toothpick sometimes stuck in the corner of his mouth, the hefty Mr. Moore shambles through ''Roger and Me'' as if he were a town booster manque. He interviews former G.M. workers who are at their wits' end and strikes up a palship with the man from the sheriff's office in charge of evicting people from their houses and mobilehomes. In the film's most riotous sequences, he inventories Flint's many doomed efforts to turn the city into a tourist mecca, complete with a theme park called AutoWorld, which quickly went broke. Flint will never be Orlando.
Mr. Moore is merciless, but cruelty at the expense of the rich and smug still is irresistible in our society.
He journeys onto a golf course to ask one society matron about the good life in Flint. She talks about her club, her friends and shopping. Somebody else mentions the joys of hockey and ballet. He attends a ''fun'' Great Gatsby party, which, of course, looks pretty grim, and another party, a benefit held in Flint's brand-new jail where, for their donations, guests can be handcuffed and spend the night in the lock-up. Other Flint residents, in the meantime, are selling their blood. Pat Boone, Anita Bryant and President Reagan come to the city to lift morale. Miss Bryant quotes Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher as saying, ''Cheer up, America!'' Bob Eubanks, then emcee of ''The Newlywed Game,'' appears at the 1988 state fair and, while relaxing, tells a joke that, for monumental boorishness, may not be equaled on film for another century.
From time to time, Mr. Moore makes halfhearted attempts to contact Mr. Smith, who, in the way of such things, becomes a figure of ever greater hilarity the longer he remains off-screen. The director is seen being tossed out of Mr. Smith's haunts (the Detroit Athletic Club and the Grosse Point Yacht Club) and being denied entry to the chairman's 14th-floor offices at G.M. headquarters in Detroit.
He is prevented from speaking at the annual G.M. stockholders' meeting, and, when he finally does get close to the chairman at a G.M. Christmas party, the confrontation is a bit of a fizzle. It's the only anticlimax in the movie, which, otherwise, is an effectively populist call to arms.
Behind all the humor, there is a committed social critic at work. Mr. Moore clearly believes that corporations have responsibilities to the communities in which they have prospered.
A G.M. spokesman, who seems to be a decent fellow at heart, attempts to persuade Mr. Moore that the future of Flint might well be with a company that manufactures sticky rollers, designed to rid clothes of lint. We roar with laughter as Mr. Moore allows himself only the slightest look of surprise.
Like all serious humorists, Mr. Moore knows enough not to laugh at situations of his own making. (A closing credit notes that this particular G.M. spokesman also lost his job.) With any luck, ''Roger and Me'' will soon be available, if not at a theater right next door, then at a theater worth traveling a certain distance to reach.
Alternative commercial cinema, including the wise and joyful ''High Fidelity: The Adventures of the Guarneri String Quartet,'' suddenly seems to be all around us. It has been especially evident at the current New York festival, which is turning out to be one of the best in recent years. In the past, the festival has often seen fit to program a couple of mainstream American films to soothe the philistines. This year, Mr. Forsyth's ''Breaking In,'' which stars Burt Reynolds, must fill that slot.
Instead we've had several original, sometimes blithely serious films that will soon offer commercial moviegoers the chance to see something they cannot predict, shot-for-shot, as they buy their tickets.
Chief among these: Jim Jarmusch's blissful ''Mystery Train,'' set in a Memphis, Tenn., where the portrait, if not the legend, of Elvis Presley seems to hang over every bed, and Jane Campion's ''Sweetie,'' a soberly funny Australian film about two mismatched sisters. More about them when they arrive in the theaters.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Puerto Rico's 'Watergate' Is Filmed

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH WEIS; Elisabeth Weis is a professor of film at Brooklyn College.

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R.

 BODY:
Scene one: Day, interior. The prosecutor taps his pen nervously on his files during a Senate hearing. His language may be American legalese, but his pen taps a 6/8 Latin beat.
This juxtaposition of two cultures is a distinctive component of a film shot this past summer in Puerto Rico about a political trauma often called Puerto Rico's Watergate. Tentatively entitled ''Show of Force,'' the film is a fictionalization of Anne Nelson's book, ''Murder Under Two Flags: The U.S., Puerto Rico and the Cerro Maravilla Cover-Up.'' The film stars Amy Irving as a television journalist, Robert Duvall as her boss, Lou Diamond Phillips as an undercover agent and Andy Garcia as a special investigator for the Puerto Rican Senate.
'' 'Show of Force' is the first Hollywood feature to be shot entirely in Puerto Rico and the first to focus on a Puerto Rican story,'' said Luis Ramos, the executive director of the Puerto Rico Film Institute, a Government-sponsored organization that fosters movie production on the island. The film, expected to be released early next year by Paramount Pictures, seems likely to draw attention to the island's fiery political passions, which are growing more heated as it prepares to hold a plebiscite within a year or two to gauge public opinion on Puerto Rico's future relationship to the United States. 
Cerro Maravilla is the name by which Puerto Ricans refer to the scandal triggered by the police shooting in 1978 of two young advocates of independence and the subsequent official cover-up, which is still undergoing investigation.
According to Samuel Dash, who served as the chief counsel of the Senate Watergate committee, ''Cerro Maravilla is actually one of the most outrageous violations of democratic government in Puerto Rico's history and certainly ranks with the scandal of Watergate in the United States.''
Throughout five years and two official inquiries after the shooting, the police contended that they shot in self-defense two terrorists who had intended to sabotage the television towers on a mountain named Cerro Maravilla near the city of Ponce.
Though the Government pronounced the issue closed, parallel efforts to uncover the truth were continued by the Senate president, Miguel Hernandez Agosto, and by several members of the press, notably the television journalist Carmen Jovet and two reporters for The San Juan Star, Tomas Stella and Manuel Suarez, who is also a contributor to The New York Times. In 1983 a third set of hearings was held - this time under the aegis of the Puerto Rican Senate and on live television.
The public watched mesmerized as witnesses provided graphic testimony that the shooting victims had thrown down their weapons and surrendered before they were killed. The revelations led eventually to the imprisonment of 10 police officers, the fall of the last - pro-statehood - Puerto Rican administration and the assassination of the undercover agent who led the two youths into the police ambush.
Ms. Jovet explained the importance of televising the hearings live. ''When you write, you interpret,'' she said. ''But television presented the hearings unedited - all day long. So the jury was the Puerto Rican people.''
The Senate is still investigating how high the cover-up went. Mr. Dash has been serving as special consultant to its investigation of whether the cover-up was sanctioned by officials of the Puerto Rican and United States Departments of Justice, in particular, the F.B.I. Most recently, ''officials have arrested and charged most of the top lawyers of the Puerto Rican Justice Department during that period, and they are awaiting trial,'' said Mr. Dash.
Scene Two: Night, exterior. An electric storm has temporarily blacked out the area, but the public square facing San Juan's Spanish Colonial City Hall looks brighter than ever, thanks to movie generators that power the festive lights strung around the kiosks, gazebo and fountain.
Between setups, the Brazilian director Bruno Barreto is asked what attracted him to a project so different from his best-known, sensuous fantasies, ''Gabriella'' and ''Dona Flor and Her Two Husbands.''
''The uniqueness of Anne Nelson's book is that she provides a historical context to suggest why Cerro Maravilla happened,'' he said. ''She uses the specific event as a metaphor for the way the U.S. has treated Latin America in general. You could say those two kids were killed because of a hundred years of history. I want to translate that concept into dramatic terms.''
Mr. Barreto goes on to emphasize that he wants to reach a broad audience by providing ''all the elements to attract and entertain. I want to make the audience think - not in a didactic but in an emotional way.''
Predictably, this approach has provoked mixed reactions in Puerto Rico. Although the film's director, the executive producer and several of the stars have Latin American ties, and although two-thirds of the crew and more than 40 speaking parts have been chosen from local professional talent, there is some resentment on the part of the island's press that the principal character, played by Ms. Irving, is not Puerto Rican. As an American journalist and widow of a Puerto Rican lawyer, Ms. Irving's character is a fictional composite of several journalists - primarily Puerto Rican - who refused to accept the official version of the shooting.
To feature an American or British character with whom the viewers can identify as they learn about a foreign country is, of course, the standard Hollywood choice for engaging audience sympathies in films like ''Missing,'' ''Under Fire,'' ''Cry Freedom,'' ''Salvador,'' ''The Killing Fields'' and ''Midnight Express.'' Traditionally, the character is a journalist. ''In effect, Americans perceive of Puerto Rico as a foreign country,'' said the film's producer, Fred Weintraub. ''I got lots of calls about obtaining passports to get here. And the callers thought it had a different currency from ours.''
The protagonists of the original Cerro Maravilla drama are still very public figures in Puerto Rico. There is talk about erecting a statue of the taxi driver - and his battered cab - whose testimony helped break the case. The journalist whose experiences in exposing the cover-up most closely resemble those of Ms. Irving's character is Carmen Jovet. Ms. Jovet, who was threatened with physical assault and fired from her job as a reporter in the course of the investigations, is now one of Puerto Rico's most popular television personalities.
Alejandro Gonzalez Malave, the police undercover agent killed in the aftermath of the incident, who provided the basis for Lou Diamond Phillips's character, has practically entered into island folklore. Local opinions are heated as to how their roles should be played, which has given rise to some misconceptions.
The local press brought many preconceptions to the film, said Amy Irving. ''Because Lou Diamond Phillips played such a sweet person in 'La Bamba,' they think we must be making this film into a love story. Actually his character is quite frightening.'' Ms. Irving is the first to volunteer that until she started preparing for her role, she, like most Americans, knew ''next to nothing about Puerto Rico or its status as a commonwealth.'' Ms. Irving suggested that ''though the film is primarily the story of one woman, it should also broaden viewers' notions of Puerto Ricans.'' The film features a wide cross section of Puerto Ricans; major characters include a taxi driver, a public prosecutor and the owner of a television station.
Ms. Jovet is worried about telling an unresolved story that is still ''an open wound in the heart of Puerto Ricans.'' As for their portrayal, ''I hope we don't have another 'West Side Story' ghost following us for 20 years,'' she said. ''It hurt our image; people expect Puerto Ricans to carry knives between our teeth.''
However, Jaime Montilla, a prominent actor here, does expect the film to show that ''there are different types of Puerto Ricans just as there are different types of Americans. When I auditioned for Puerto Rican parts in New York after getting my master's degree there,'' he said, ''the casting agent would ask me to be more Puerto Rican. That image is based on a single stereotype from the Bronx.''
Asked how close the film is to the real story of Cerro Maravilla, Mr. Montilla said that the scenes in which he plays a senator are true to the spirit of the actual hearings, which he watched as avidly as everyone else here. ''We have to remember that the movies have always used historical events as a background. Look at all the films that have taken place during the French or American revolutions.''
''The growing involvement of Latins on the other side of the camera,'' said Richard Pena, the program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, ''has brought an increased sensitivity towards Latin American subjects.'' Mr. Pena also cites economic incentives for the production of Latin and Chicano films ranging from Hector Babenco's ''Kiss of the Spider Woman'' to ''Stand and Deliver'' and ''The Milagro Beanfield War.''
''As Latins become a greater presence in our marketplace, film makers are hoping that they will provide a partially built-in audience. On the other hand,'' he said, ''as Latin America looms more largely in the American consciousness, owing both to recent waves of immigrants and to U.S. political involvement, that, too, makes Latin America very topical.''
As for Puerto Rico in particular, the United States Senate is currently debating the terms of the plebiscite on Puerto Rico's status. The Puerto Rican Senate expects to hold new public hearings on the Cerro Maravilla case, which is inextricably linked to the statehood issue, next summer.
''The Cerro Maravilla incident will continue to be debated for many years to come - in the courtroom, in print, and on film,'' said the book's author, Anne Nelson. ''I think that the contribution 'Show of Force' can make at the moment is to bring the issues before a broader public than ever before. There's an old saying that 'Americans will do anything about Latin America except read about it,' and that's held doubly true for Puerto Rico. If this film encourages people to educate themselves on Puerto Rico and to think harder about U.S. relations with Latin America in general, it will be a very positive development.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 8, 1989

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1, Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2663 words

HEADLINE: Is Political Humor Politic?

BYLINE: By MARK RUSSELL; the writer is host of the Mark Russell comedy specials on PBS.

 BODY:
Do we need political humor? I usually answer that question with the smart-alecky response, ''I certainly do - I have bills to pay.'' The humorist Tom Lehrer gave up his practice years ago with the proclamation that political satire died the moment Henry Kissinger received the Nobel Peace Prize, and my endeavors as a satirist are often threatened by the verbatim statements of public figures. For example, during the Irangate investigations a reporter asked President Reagan if William Casey, the director of the C.I.A., had carried on covert operations without the President knowing about it. President Reagan's exact response was, ''Not to my knowledge.'' During the pay wars in Congress last January, I quoted an unnamed Senator as saying, ''If we in the Congress must maintain a higher standard of morality without a higher salary, where is the incentive? If we must spend all day long being ethical, how can we do our jobs?'' The quote was pure invention, but inasmuch as it was completely believable no one questioned it. The quote was also deemed acceptable by my audience because Congress itself, unlike the Presidency, is one of those safe objects of ridicule in this country, along with New York City, the Postal Service, potholes and Geraldo Rivera. 
How can Larry Gelbart's play ''Mastergate,'' a satire of Washington scandals and ensuing Congressional investigations that opens Thursday at the Criterion Center, compete with reality as it parodies Congress, the Presidency and the media? Or is the play really a parody at all? Or is it reality? Or Memorex? Didn't the cartoonist Garry Trudeau take us on a journey through Ronald Reagan's brain several years ago? When we recently saw the ex-President's half-shaved head with Mrs. Reagan attempting to cover it with her hand - was that a photograph, a cartoon or deja vu?
As the mass audience revels in the Gary Hart, Dan Quayle, John Tower, Barney Frank, et al., pratfalls de jour, the measurement of political humor is in direct proportion to the number of political gaffes. This is not war-and-peace satire, but rather Punch-and-Judy slapstick.
It is in gentler times when political jokes are most accepted by the general public. But when the going gets tough, the comic does a segue. Only the brave will stay the course and enter the tempest of, say, the mayoral race in New York City. As the candidate Rudolph Giuliani once said, ''Hey, let's call Jackie Mason.'' Satire That Stays Ahead of the Curve Once, a satirist wrote an attack on a well-known political figure. A fictitious name was used, but people had no trouble figuring out the identity of the satirist's victim, whose erratic physical features and mannerisms were ridiculed with deft humor. Whereupon, a large segment of the population became outraged, and several newspapers editorialized on what right the satirist had to be so impertinent. The humorist was Charlie Chaplin, the country was the United States, and the object of ridicule was Adolf Hitler.
The year was 1940, and isolationists in America were quite bothered by Chaplin's movie ''The Great Dictator.'' Their argument was that Chaplin was stirring up pro-British emotions and foisting his left-wing opinions on an American public in no mood for war. Fifty years later we can only imagine that time when a writer attacking Hitler could be labeled a warmonger. Today we would say that Chaplin was ahead of the curve, which is where a satirist belongs. Most humorists have operated behind the curve - a much safer, risk-free zone, i.e., ridiculing Hitler, Tojo and Mussolini after Dec. 7, 1941.
Incidentally, Chaplin would later state that had he known of the ghastly results of Nazism he never would have made such a movie. Indeed, lampooning Hitler during the war reached sophomoric triviality. I recall a character in Herman Wouk's ''War and Remembrance'' who expressed disgust at such silliness as the zany bandleader Spike Jones's popular recording ''In Der Fuhrer's Face.''
 
Ayatollah Khomeini Is the One Exception
 In the 44 years since World War II ended, the targets of American humorists for the most part have been their fellow Americans. Quick - who was the villain of the Korean War? In the Vietnam conflict our official adversary was Ho Chi Minh, whose image in this country was, shall we say, ill-defined. Where were the Stalin routines? Pol Pot? Didn't their vicious acts qualify them to be suitably unpopular, therefore safe subjects for humor?
Instead, our targets have been domestic ones - Joe McCarthy, Jack Kennedy, Lyndon Johnson, Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter, Billy Carter, Ronald Reagan, Nancy Reagan, George Bush and one more time - Mr. Nixon. And in recent years supporting players such as Michael Dukakis, James Watt, Oliver North, John Tower and Dan Quayle have amused. These have all been fun people, and the humor aimed at them on American television over the years has been mostly lighthearted, lightweight and an end-of-the-day giggle before snapping off the bed lamp at 11:40 P.M. and going to sleep after the Johnny Carson monologue.
The only public figure approaching Adolf Hitler as a hate object was the Ayatollah Khomeini. But as I recall, many of us welcomed the Shah's overthrow and didn't become terribly worked up over Khomeini until he took 52 American hostages, at which point jokes about him were rendered behind the curve. (Mr. Chaplin, we needed you.) In fact, the television networks were country miles behind the curve. After the hostage-taking, NBC issued a directive forbidding all humorous references to anything pertaining to the Iranian situation. After a few weeks of this, a frustrated Mr. Carson would ask the audience to bear with him as he sidestepped this major news event that was on everyone's mind.
The network's pusillanimous edict was soon violated by George Schlatter, the producer of NBC's own show ''Real People.'' Mr. Schlatter sanctioned my standing in front of the Iranian Embassy in Washington doing Ayatollah jokes. Actually, they were reworked Stalin jokes which originated (surreptitiously) in the Soviet Union:
''They have come out with a new Joseph Stalin (Khomeini) postage stamp, but it doesn't stick. People keep spitting on the wrong side.''
 
 Little boy, who is your mother?
 My mother is Iran.
 And who is your father?
 My father is the great and glorious Khomeini.
 And what do you want to be when you grow up?
 An orphan.
 Safe, risk-free, behind the curve and no problem for NBC. But, out of fear of the public and underestimating our intelligence, the network had muzzled its creative people.
 
Major Manley Battle and Capital Lunacy
 I had best throw the curve away in an attempt to fix the position of Mr. Gelbart's ''Mastergate,'' which received glowing reviews when it was presented last spring at Harvard's American Repertory Theater. Set solely in a Congressional committee hearing room, the play touches on just about every Washington-based lunacy of the last 20 years without using any real names. However, as with Chaplin's maniac fuhrer Hinkle with the funny little mustache, we have no trouble identifying Mr. Gelbart's hospitalized and dying C.I.A. director, Wylie Slaughter, who had a detached and befuddled President under his control. Then, there is the gung-ho, spit-and-polish Marine hero, Maj. Manley Battle, whose attorney, with the aid of a pointer, indicates to the committee the many campaign ribbons on Major Battle's chest as a demure Mrs. Battle sits behind the witness busily knitting an American flag.
Had Mr. Gelbart been able to bring his play to Broadway, say, a week after Colonel North's riveting six days of testimony, would the Iran-Contra affair have played out any differently? Would CNN have run lengthy portions of ''Mastergate'' every 30 minutes? Would Ted Koppel have devoted several nights to the play in order to present to his audience another dimension of Irangate, albeit a cartoon dimension?
 
What's Real And What Isn't
 Actually, the reality of Irangate and Mr. Gelbart's satire ''Mastergate'' are two cartoons separated by a very fine line. I don't think an on-target spoof such as ''Mastergate'' would have changed anything, because the very idea of any threat to President Reagan's honorable and untarnished retirement was something most American's didn't want to think about.
One would think that, compared with Mr. Reagan, Mr. Nixon had less of a chance of survival from the onslaught of political humor. Not so. Mr. Nixon's political demise was self-inflicted with just the tiniest assistance from the humorists. We must remember that ''Saturday Night Live'' and ''Doonesbury,'' which could have turned up the temperature in Nixon's Oval Office considerably, didn't reach the heights of their popularity until after the Vietnam and Watergate sagas were over. Although Art Buchwald's columns have always had to be reckoned with in government circles, his Vietnam era play, ''Sheep on the Runway'' (1970), had short runs in New York and Washington. Nor did Barbara Garson's Off Broadway ''MacBird'' (1967) capture the country's attention; the play never attained more than cult status.
In 1968 television's No. 1 rated show, ''Laugh-In,'' had its way with the hawks of the day - the hosts Dan Rowan and Dick Martin even flaunted peace symbols on the pockets of their blazers. But by 1970, even as antiwar sentiment increased across the nation, ''Laugh In'' eased up on its dovishness.
The Smothers Brothers' upstart mocking of America's noble war effort eventually proved to be too much for CBS and that show was canceled. Dick and Tom Smothers and the folk singer Pete Seeger singing about ''the big fool Lyndon'' wading deeper into the muddy water rankled the hierarchy of this same network, which had abetted in the blacklisting of the humorist John Henry Faulk during the McCarthy period years earlier.
The civil rights struggle brought us the vantage-point observations of the black comedian Dick Gregory, who would admonish a nightclub heckler by telling him, ''Why don't you just burn your cross and get the hell out of here?'' Mr. Gregory began his career in a climate in this country that prompted a well-known ice-cream company to suddenly cancel sponsorship of the singer Petula Clark's television show because her hand had touched the hand of Harry Belafonte as they sang a duet. Dick Gregory gave little comfort to the North or the South when he said, ''In the South white people don't care how close I get as long as I don't get too big. In the North they don't care how big I get as long as I don't get too close.''
In the election of 1956, the satirist Mort Sahl told of the strong opposing civil rights stands taken by each candidate: ''Eisenhower says we should integrate moderately, but Stevenson wants to do it gradually.''
The Reagan era practically negated the old 60's establishment-bashing, exemplified by Mr. Sahl's suggestion that the American Medical Association was against faith healing and any other cure that was rapid. Mr. Reagan brought us a corporations-are-people-too sentiment, and it takes a 10-million-gallon oil spill or the revelation of a $500 million-a-year inside trader to get the public's attention to the extent that they might possibly relate to humor on these subjects. Nestled safely behind the curve of the Wall Street scandal, we can state that Drexel Burnham Lambert's inside-trading escapades were to free enterprise what mud wrestling is to the performing arts, and one wonders what Mr. Gelbart could do with Tom Wolfe's ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' or for that matter the H.U.D. revelations.
All of these events become blurred and run together to those of us ''marinading in media,'' as Russell Baker describes it. We see the mud wrestler Michael Milken defended by the attorney Arthur Lyman, whose performance for the Iran-Contra committee made him my matinee idol in the summer of 1987. In Washington we toss and turn at night wondering if Mr. Milken knows Colonel North. Did Richard Secord and Albert Hakim ever meet with Ivan Boesky at Fawn Hall's apartment? Or was it H.U.D.'s Debbie Dean? Or Donna Rice? Or Jessica Hahn, who knew Jimmy Swaggart, who converted Manuel Noriega?
As we are warned in ''Mastergate'' - ''watch your nightly news. It's only a matter of time before you're scandalized by the stars of the next, inevitable Whatever-Gate: another crowd of photo-opportunistic nobodies who grab the limelight before either being sent to jail or up to higher office.''
 
In the Mood For Some Humor
 The current glut of topical humor, good and awful, has burgeoned in the absence of a world war and national unemployment of 25 percent. When either occurs and the iconoclasts offer up their droll perceptions, the people again will not want to hear about it. Ask ''Doonesbury's'' Trudeau how those AIDS pieces went over out there in comic strip land.
Collectively, drugs, AIDS, the homeless and interest on the national debt, which has increased by millions of dollars since you started reading this sentence, all add up to Vietnam II, but in comedy clubs across the land Jim and Tammy Bakker and Leona Helmsley references dominate.
Paraphrasing Mr. Gelbart's paraphrase of Senator Howard Baker: What do Americans know and why don't they all see the humor in it? I visualize ''Mastergate'' having its premiere in Washington instead of New York. On opening night, Congressional V.I.P.'s file out of the theater, their goofy parliamentary parlance having just been thoroughly mocked. A senator bids a colleague goodnight as he climbs into his limousine and says, ''Great play, wasn't it? I'll see you bright and early tomorrow for our preliminary hearings with the sub-staff members of the permanent committee's temporary subcommittee on flag burning.''
 
THE WHOLE NINE YARDSKI
This is an excerpt from ''Mastergate'' by Larry Gelbart. The scene is the Sherman Adams Room of the John Mitchell Building in Washington, where Maj. Manley Battle is testifying before the House Select Committee to Investigate Alleged Covert Arms Assistance to Alleged Other Americas. Major Battle, under examination by Senator Bunting of the committee, stands at a map with a wooden pointer.
 
 MAJOR BATTLE: San Elvador lies just right of center here in Central America. It has a democratic form of government that has been run by its army for the past 40 years. Passionately anti-Communist, with a vigorous opposition press, a strong, vocal church and free elections that are promised regularly. But most geopolitically significant, there is San Elvador's unmistakable proximityship to its immediate neighbor to the far left, Ambigua. SENATOR BUNTING: Ambigua is totalitarily Lenin-Marxist? BATTLE: It's as red as the ace of hearts, sir. The whole nine yardski. BUNTING: And completely controlled by Moscow? BATTLE: Does the Pope ride an encyclical? (CROWD LAUGHS) BATTLE: Not that I mean to make light of the Communist menace. Or the Catholics, either.
BUNTING: Major, I'm sure that this committee, as well as the country for which we stand, would be most appreciative for you to share some of your daylight with us on that sad and benighted land.
BATTLE: Yes, sir. The Republic of Ambigua, or La Republica de Ambigua, is yet another betrayed revolution in which a legitimate set of high ideals were once more cruelly twisted and cynically Sovietized. The United States has had a long period of the most intimate relations with the Ambiguan government, the last 18 of Ambigua's presidents being West Point graduates. But a coup occurred and the reins of power changed hands three years ago when the former President of Ambigua, General Delinqua, and the country's Prime Minister, Mrs. Delinqua, were in New York on an emergency shopping trip, at which point the government was taken over by Dr. Overtega, a former podiatrist, and his band of foot soldiers.

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
A Trump Target: American Airlines

BYLINE: By WILLIAM S. NIEDERKORN

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump offered $7.5 billion for AMR, the parent of American Airlines. The company is expected to reject the $120-a-share bid. It was not clear whether Mr. Trump would pursue a hostile takeover against AMR's chairman, Robert L. Crandall, one of the most fiercely independent executives in the airline business. AMR's stock rose $20.75 following the offer, to close the week at $103.75.
 
*
 Fifty billion dollars will not be enough to bail out the savings and loan industry, L. William Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C., told the Senate Banking Committee, raising the possibility that the Administration would have to come back to Congress for a second bailout package. 
 
 * The Administration will regulate international money transfers by U.S. banks in an attempt to curb the laundering of drug profits, the Treasury said. The Government will open a financial crimes center next month to supply information on money laundering to several agencies.
 
 *
 The U.S. and Mexico signed the broadest agreement ever reached by the countries to spur trade and investment. The two governments are to decide by November on specific industrial sectors that could benefit from lower tariffs.
 
*
 The nation's unemployment rate edged up one-tenth of a percentage point to 5.2 percent in September as manufacturing payrolls shrank by more than 100,000 jobs, the Labor Department said. U.S. factory orders for manufactured goods rose 2.9 percent in August. New home sales fell 0.4 percent in August. The nation's purchasing managers reported a continued slowing in the manufacturing sector in their September report. Construction spending rose in August for Government and nonresidential building, but single-family housing sagged. Top retailers reported generally strong sales in September, but big-ticket, household durable goods lagged.
 
*
 The Dow industrials rose to 2,785.52, with a gain for the week of 92.70 points and three straight record- high closes. The dollar also rose, despite intervention, weakening indicators and the fact that interest rates were raised by West Germany and other European countries. All Treasury maturities advanced in the week, largely on the strength of the dollar and weakening economic indicators. Coffee prices plunged to a 14-year low as the International Coffee Organization struggled to make progress toward a new price-support agreement.
 
*
 Canada said it would cut more than 50 percent of its passenger train service, touching off bitter protests. The cuts, from 405 trains a week to 191 in the heavily subsidized rail network, were described as irreversible by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Conservative Government.
 
*
 A Senate panel approved a Democratic plan that would restore tax deductions for contributions to individual retirement accounts, while a Republican measure to reduce the capital gains rate lost on a tie vote. Republicans later said they might be willing to strike a deal to keep certain spending and tax measures, including their proposed reduction in the capital gains rate, out of a pending deficit reduction package.
 
*
 The European Community adopted a compromise plan of nonbinding rules that urge European television stations to devote a majority of their airtime to shows made in Europe. Subsequently, the Bush Administration warned that it might have to re- examine its support for community efforts to forge a single market by the end of 1992 if Europeans continued taking actions that discriminated against the U.S.
 
*
 Young & Rubicam was indicted, along with two of its executives and two Jamaican citizens, on charges that the agency participated in bribing Jamaican Government officials with almost $1 million to obtain the Jamaica Tourist Board's advertising account in 1981.
 
*
 Miscellanea. A House subcommittee voted unanimously to tighten automobile emission controls that would establish pollution standards as strict as California's . . . Zenith Electronics said it would sell its computer business to Groupe Bull for about $635 million . . . The Transportation Department proposed to open additional American cities to foreign airlines . . . G.M. and Chrysler plan to establish a joint venture to make manual transmissions and other components . . . USX said it planned to sell the reserves of its Texas Oil and Gas subsidiary . . . Prudential- Bache Securities was censured by the S.E.C. for numerous violations of securities laws . . . U S West will buy Financial Security Assurance, the largest insurer of corporate bonds . . . Bulova will offer watch faces with miniature copies of paintings by Leonardo, van Gogh and other masters.

PUB-DATE: October 8, 1989

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2200 words

HEADLINE: Unfinished Business With Canada

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
Nine months after the United States-Canada free-trade agreement began chipping away at tariffs and trade barriers, trade relations between the world's two busiest trading partners have slipped once again to their accustomed place on the policy makers' back burner.
In Canada, after a hard-fought and suspenseful battle for passage, the Free Trade Act, as the pact is known, has been nudged out of the trade spotlight by other issues. Attention has shifted to Europe's efforts to wipe out trade barriers in 1992 and the Geneva negotiations on freer trade rules for the nearly 100 nations subscribing to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
In the United States, where the agreement never was as hot an issue, its slide down the agenda has been even more pronounced. Washington's attention, too, has been diverted by GATT negotiations and 1992, but also by the politically charged battle to get Japan and other Asian nations to open their markets further and by the completion last week of a free-trade agreement with Mexico. 
But big things are slowly taking shape in the shadows. Low-level negotiations to flesh out the agreement continue, including efforts to accelerate the schedule for removing thousands of tariffs by 1998. Both sides are looking ahead nervously to negotiations on some of the most important topics mentioned in the pact, notably reducing industry subsidies. And thousands of businesses on both sides of the border are already scrambling to adapt to provisions of the agreement. In addition to phasing out tariffs, the treaty removed or reduced numerous hurdles to cross-border investment, government procurement, agricultural sales and movement of employees.
 
Global Competitiveness
 How all of this unfolds may well have an impact on other trade matters that policy makers find more compelling. The pact is not just an overhaul of the rules governing trade that topped $180 billion last year, but also, like Europe's plans for 1992, an ambitious effort to help domestic companies compete as business becomes more global. Its phased reduction of tariffs and other reforms should level the playing fields among Canadian and American companies so that the strongest are freer to marshal their resources while the weak are weeded out.
And the agreement's dispute settlement procedures, though yet to be tested, may serve as an example for GATT and other trade agreements. ''It's a model of open markets,'' said Robert Blair, chairman of the Nova Corporation, an Edmonton, Alberta, petrochemical producer.
Here in Canada, where most industries consist of only a few players and fears of American dominance are part of the national birthright, the risks and benefits of that drive to create a free-trade zone from the Arctic Ocean to the Rio Grande are easier to pinpoint. For every well-publicized announcement that a company, like the Canadian subsidiary of E.I. du Pont de Nemours, is sharply increasing investment in response to the pact, there are terse releases saying companies, like Inglis Ltd., the 72 percent-owned subsidiary of the Whirlpool Corporation, will close some Canadian operations and import products from the United States.
''There may not be much public debate anymore but there's tremendous sensitivity, and the employees are knowledgeable where they are facing the effects of adjustment,'' said William Blundell, the chief executive of the General Electric Company's diverse Canadian operations.
''Adjustment,'' of course, is the polite term for the layoffs, wage cuts, production shifts and losses that many companies already face from the internationalization of business. Canadian opponents of the treaty, who hope that a future Government will abrogate it, routinely blame it for most bad economic news. But the companies expanding in Canada these days, like Du Pont, and those cutting back, like Whirlpool, Gillette, and Burlington Industries, invariably stress that the agreement is not so much the reason for their actions as an additional incentive to make the changes now rather than later.
 
'One Step Ahead'
 ''The people who are claiming they lost out because of the F.T.A. are really losing out to the third world,'' said William Neil, director of international affairs for the Canadian Manufacturers Association in Ottawa, ''The U.S. is just one step ahead in pressuring them.''
The treaty's effects are magnified here because more than 70 percent of Canada's exports go to the United States, which, in turn, sends just 22 percent of its exports to its vast but more sparsely populated neighbor. But both countries gain if they become more globally competitive.
Among the treaty's other benefits to the United States are more secure supplies of energy and natural resources, and opportunities for companies to expand in banking and financial services on an equal footing with Canadian competitors. And Canadian companies are stepping up their investments in the United States.
''The American plant is our insurance policy,'' said Harvey Nudel, president of Braemer Convertibles, a subsidiary of Toronto-based Dylex Ltd. that recently opened a furniture factory in Medina, in upstate New York. He said the plant provides a low-cost base for expanding into the United States and could serve Canadian customers if the Toronto factory did not adapt to growing import pressure. ''American-made furniture could flood the Canadian market as the tariffs, which were 15 percent, disappear over the next three years.''
Such investments go beyond new production lines. Braemer has hired an American manager for Medina and an American sales manager and has opened a showroom in High Point, N.C., the furniture capital of the United States. ''We have tried to buy the American way of thinking,'' Mr. Nudel said. Economists have estimated that by 1988 the accord will increase the United States output of goods and services by the equivalent of one-half a percentage point of G.N.P. and create 750,000 jobs. Ottawa has said Canada's economy, one-tenth the size of the United States', will get a much larger gain - perhaps 2.5 percentage points of G.N.P., and 250,000 jobs.
 
Too Early to Call
 No one knows whether these projections will be borne out. Nor, despite voluminous studies by both sides before the agreement, can anyone identify winners and losers whose fates clearly stem from the pact rather than economic trends in general. ''At this point, it would be like asking who will be the winner after 6 minutes of a football game,'' said Michael Dufour, a spokesman for Dominion Textile Ltd. of Montreal, Canada's largest textile company.
Some reasons for the uncertainty are fairly obvious, starting with the wide range of details negotiators left to be filled in later. Eight groups have been appointed to harmonize health and safety standards in agriculture, including labeling rules, to ease the flow of goods. Another group is tackling that problem in the fish products industry. And architects' associations in both countries are jointly fashioning licensing standards that both Governments will accept so members can practice in either country.
This harmonization, said Charles Roh, assistant United States trade representative for North America, is ''not stuff that stirs the blood of policy people, but it can stir up a lot of trade and make money for a business.''
And the trading partners have yet to deal with what may be the thorniest problem of all - how to reduce subsidies. Under terms of the treaty, this is to be addressed in negotiations that can take up to seven years.
''The real test of the F.T.A. is not the tariff cuts,'' said Peter Morici, professor of economics and Canadian studies at the University of Maine. ''It's the negotiating agenda.''
''There's a huge chunk of unfinished business that could blow up the whole thing,'' agreed Alan M. Rugman, a management professor at University of Toronto.
Adding to the touchiness of the situation is the widespread suspicion in each country that the other has achieved an advantage, or is about to do so. ''There are three people working on this at the U.S. trade representative's office and one at Commerce, compared to 40 in Canada,'' said Teresa Taylor, a policy analyst for the Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition in Washington. ''Canada is ultimately going to gain more out of the treaty because they are paying more attention to it.''
United States trade officials deny that the agreement is being given short shrift. But they concede that other trade policy problems are taking priority. They say both sides are busy on the details, like deciding which tariff reductions may be accelerated after 550 companies and trade groups submitted petitions covering more than 5,000 items. And they say negotiations on more controversial issues, like subsidies, should be left until more data are gathered.
In Canada some policy analysts, like Mr. Rugman, say Ottawa is equally unprepared to push forward on major issues that remain. The Trade Negotiating Office led by Simon Reisman, who had direct access to Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, has been disbanded and responsibility for the treaty has been given to the Department of External Affairs. That agency, the equivalent of the State Department, is more inclined to support multilateral efforts, like GATT, Mr. Rugman said.
Tensions between the two sides could soar as new dispute settlement mechanisms get their first tests. The accord sets up binational panels to review most trade disputes. And five-member binational boards will hear appeals of cases where government agencies determine that there has been dumping or approve a countervailing duty on what they consider an unfairly subsidized import. Until now, such cases could be appealed only to the other nation's courts, where delays and expenses were formidable and chances of reversal slim.
Canadians have high hopes that the new system will provide relief from the steady stream of countervailing duties, on products ranging from pork to stretch limousines. Some say it may encourage fairer reviews and quicker disposal of frivolous claims. Skeptics point out that the accord does not allow the panels to do anything more than determine whether a country followed its own laws, making any reversals unlikely.
Meanwhile, some Canadian businessmen say, the treaty is producing more bad news than good north of the border. ''I am now having some doubts about it because of the number of plant closures in Canada by subsidiaries of U.S. companies,'' said Brian Edwards, chief executive of Weiser Inc., a Burnaby, British Columbia, lock maker and subsidiary of the Masco Corporation of Taylor, Mich. ''There is rising concern among Canadian businessmen that it seems to be a one-way street,'' said Mr. Edwards, once an F.T.A. supporter but now neutral.
It is not one-way, of course. The Canada Malting Company, for example, was able to outbid United States and overseas rivals in March for control of the Great Western Malting Company, in Vancouver, Wash., making it the world's largest supplier of malt to brewers. And the treaty played a role, according to Jonathan Bamberger, the Toronto company's vice president in charge of finance and corporate development. ''The strategic advantage of being able to look at supplying all of North America from the combined companies was enhanced by free trade,'' he said.
 
Opposition From Labor
 Canadian labor unions, which represent 40 percent of the work force compared with 17 percent in the Untied States, remain resolutely opposed to the pact, and it is not hard to see why. Even the companies that expect to prosper may be making deep cuts in their labor forces.
Glendale Spinning Mills Ltd. in Hamilton, Ont., is responding to the phasing out of the 17 percent tariff on cotton yarn imports by investing heavily in automation. ''We will be producing about three times as much yarn with about one-third the work force by the end of next year,'' said Mohamed A. Kamel, the company's president. One positive result: the company expects to expand sales into the Northeastern United States. ''It's the only way to compete,'' he said.
Labor leaders and other critics say the treaty - and free trade in general - is being used to whittle away Canada's commitment to social benefits, like unemployment insurance, which is much more generous than that in the United States. And they say it is behind such controversial changes as the 9 percent sales tax recently proposed by the Conservative Government to replace corporate taxes that currently burden Canadian business. ''One of the consequences of a unified market is that you have to have common rules,'' said Bruce Campbell, an economist for the Canadian Labor Congress. ''The pressure is on.''
Some observers like Isaiah Litvak, an economist at the University of York here, say the critics have a point. ''There is a definite push toward standardization,'' he said, ''but it is naive to attribute the problem to the treaty.''
In an era of globalization, all industrial nations are feeling the same pressure, even if those whose economies are most dependent on trade, like Canada, are hardest hit.
